name: The Smithfield Market Tavern
description:
EBG Rating:: 7.7
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Focused on keg and cask ales from the UK with Blackjack Brewery represents, with some European options on draft and bottles. Limited non-beer options.

Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️
Stripped back ale house with restrained decor of old brewery ephemera and mirrors. Chunky worn tables and relatively spacious.

Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
A bustle of ambient noise that gives away the spot as a perennial weekend drinking destination.

Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️
Board games, occasional events, snacks

Value For Money: ❤️❤️
Middling, city centre prices.

description: A solid choice carefully blending elements of traditional boozing with modern touches. Lost some of its simple charm after a refit. Plenty of amenities and a very well chosen selection of ales. Busy trade on weekends and it can get noisy. (Added 2018)

name: Trafalgar Bay
description:
EBG Rating:: 7.5
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️
Value For Money: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
description: A distinctive pub with three sided bar and cosy side rooms replete with roaring fires and board games. A cheery community place by Sam Smiths usual standards and very comfy. The beer garden also gets plenty of use. Full of locals and well off the York tourist trail despite its proximity to the city walls and train station.

name: York Tap
description:
EBG Rating:: 7.5
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️
Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️
Value For Money: ❤️❤️
description: One of Pivni's excellent station bars, this venue has been carefully restored to its original grandeur, unique fittings you will struggle to see elsewhere and a distinctive central bar. The drinks options are perhaps the standout with a full suite of traditional and modern beers. A few points lost for the poor value for money and that slightly transient custom you get at station bars. Nevertheless, an excellent option. (added 2017)

name: Golden Ball
description:
EBG Rating:: 8.3
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️
Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Value For Money: ❤️❤️❤️
description: Yorkshire's first community-owned co-operative pub, a.k.a 'the Gilded Gooley' the decisions made here are in the interest of the pub and the people that use it rather than by the edict of some top-down Pub company. With local ales and local produce on offer, and space given over to community groups, events, live performances, as well as Living Wage employers, these really are good guys trying to do things the right way. The pub layout remains the same as its 1800 origin, but each room has received its own distinct makeover. From the gigs, to bar billiards, to a pleasant garden, and display of local art you'll be immersed in a pub that feels modern, relevant while taking the best aspects of the traditional pub and its heritage along with it. Loads of amenities and events go on here and the place has a simple lived-in feel that locals seem to love. While difficult to go over the top about, it is notable precisely because of how few of these places there are now. Well off the tourist drag despite being relatively central. (added 2019)

name: The Masons Arms
description:
EBG Rating:: 7.5
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Value For Money: ❤️❤️❤️
description: A large historic building akin to a Tudor style coaching inn, with an interior that while at once recognisable as ubiquitous 1970s 'traditional English pub' design also stands out now as a dying breed. Everything is kept in fabulous condition including the cask ales. Distinctive and characterful, they could do a little more to drum up a community feel, but overall the style stands out a mile from other venues.

name: Bierblume
description:
EBG Rating:: 8.4
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Value For Money: ❤️❤️❤️
description: A charming small-time brewery operations almost singlehandedly injecting life into the comatose old town of Gorlitz, which lacks great beer pubs. Easy to start conversation and as friendly as it comes. A curved ceiling and enclosed, it feels like you're in a basement - in a good way - despite being at ground level. With a piano, meals, and community events this is a dream destination for such a town. (Added 2019)

name: Hop & Vine
description:
EBG Rating:: 7.8
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️❤️

Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️

description: Half-basement micropub with Czech/Belgian influences. Genteel with a natural social space. Cosy and friendly, and a change of speed from other Hull pub venues. Local ales and Pilsner Urquell on tap which is always in great condition. (Added 2020)

name: Gosser Bierklinik
description:
EBG Rating:: 7.6
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️
Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️
Value For Money: ❤️❤️
description: Beisl with cosy pub room for drinking, chatting and - be warned - smoking. Gosser range of beer, including the very nice Stiftsbrau Dunkel. Expensive but you can enjoy an authentic atmosphere with the sound of horses clopping past on the cobbles.

name: Zorki
description:
EBG Rating:: 7.8

Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Value For Money: ❤️❤️❤️
description: Bookish but very lively upstairs bar with a literary bent. Some interesting décor, a young crowd and seemingly for those in the know. (added 2018)

name: Black Dog Pub
description:
EBG Rating:: 8
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️
Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Value For Money: ❤️❤️❤️
description: UPDATE - Is this bar currently closed? Recent reports suggest it has.

Finding an acceptable night spot for a drink in Bosnia isn’t always easy. For a start, several cities are split evenly between Christians and Muslims, with a good slice taken out of the target market already. Then take into account the lack of money and good taste, and there isn’t often much left by way of a friendly, locals pub.
However, thankfully there are exceptions, one of those being Black Dog in Mostar, which is located a short walk over the old bridge. When the restaurants draw to a close around 10:30pm head here for your onward socialising, with a cast of regulars who speak English and will greet and talk to you. Although I imagine they meet English people fairly regularly given Mostar’s reputation and position on the tourist trail, they seemed pretty keen on making our acquaintance. The bar guy is typically steady and impassive, and the pub itselfa wooden cabin-style interior, almost in the manner of a western saloon.
Although they offer a range of beers, the beer choice appears to be yet another dividing line, so although Sarajevsko might be the best beer on offer, have a good look to check the local options. Mostar has a brewery so at the very least a first glass of their beer will be taken as polite.
Being such an informal place, I got the picture this place remains open until the last person leaves, but similarly might not even bother staying open past 9:30pm if it seems quiet. Make your presence known, ingratiate yourself with a few local characters and enjoy both the inside and the terrace area which still has a beautiful view of Mostar’s old town area.

name: Café Józef K.
description:
EBG Rating:: 8.2
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️
Value For Money: ❤️❤️❤️
description: Any trip we make to a new city involves researching local breweries and popular pubs in advance. While breweries are easy enough to find it can be difficult to filter out drab mainstream bars and Irish Pubs and drill down to find alternative pubs and bars where locals go, or where there is anything different going on.
Jozef K was one such place we probably would have walked straight past if it wasn’t for word of mouth recommendation. Granted, it is located on ‘Beer Street’ in Gdansk, but the entrance is so plain you would never get an idea what was inside unless someone told you.
The bar is situated in a modernist building with impressive and elegant narrow windows stretching from the ceiling downwards. Strangely enough I can’t remember too many bars featuring these. This allows quite a deal of light into the bar, which allows them to keep the place relatively unlit during the day.
The style is ‘abandoned scientific equipment’, which individually looks odd, but when placed together and mounted so they all align with each other does create an impressive feel. Certainly techy and geeky, but elegant with it.
The place appears to be the place to see and be seen in Gdansk, and in the evenings there are crowds of townies who appear. The seating is a little sparse which reflects how quickly the transition from sleepy afternoon place to buzzing night venue takes place.

Jozef K deservedly earns a reputation as a good all-rounder. The atmosphere and style is good, there is plenty of local life, good cheap beer and it seems to occupy an important role in the local pub scene. It comes highly recommended. (Founder Member - 2017)

name: Ye Olde Blue Bell
description:
EBG Rating:: 7.7
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️
Value For Money: ❤️❤️❤️
description: Sam Smiths pub based down an alley, a character hidden bunker with lots of old bells on display, several anterooms and dartboard. Real fire, so pretty cosy. A slice of local life that feels out of time, in a good way. (Added 2018)

name: Aachener Brauhaus
description:
EBG Rating:: 8
Choice/Quality of Drinks: Brewpub with its traditional range of pale and dark lagers some of which are regional but others Bavarian in style.
Style/Décor: Very classical city centre beer hall with wide space around a central bar, some nice niches for tables, and a schenke off the side for drop-in drinking.
Atmosphere/Character: Typical cavernous venue with the ambience and cooking smells you'd expect. The schenke room is the reverse, an intimate space cheek by jowl with locals.
Amenities/Events: Restaurant, limited outdoor seating
Value For Money: Middling to expensive for the city centre.
description: A fairly cosy bierhalle with an old fashioned Schenk, taproom with bench seats opposite the bar. A typical, but well-executed affair with good quality beer and food, and a warm ambience to the place.

EBG Rating:: 7.6

description:
EBG Rating:: 7.5

Limited beer selection, albeit better than some in the city. Reasonable selection of Eastern European liqueurs.

Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️
Typical neighbourhood fare, plus students and youngsters later on in the evening.

Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️
Board games, snacks, limited.

Value For Money: ❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️
Very affordable, even in an already affordable area.

description: A comfortable characterful drop-in pub with a mezzanine seating area overlooking a traditional wooden bar area. Popular with students and older boozers. Very low profile.

name: Cerveseria BierCaB
description:
EBG Rating:: 7.5
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Value For Money: ❤️❤️❤️
description: The exposed industrial chic + street food template for the Craft Beer pub is past its sell-by date, and so common now as to almost defeat the principles upon which many bars and breweries of that ouevre were founded.
BierCaB is another bar which has studied and aped the concept successfully, meaning if this is your sort of thing it will be right up your street regardless of my pernickety existential grumbling.
I prefer, by some distance, bars with unique character and a more natural sense of communal socialising, meaning these craft beer bars have to go some distance in other ways if they fail on these scores.
BierCaB manages to clear the bar by taking the multi-tap concept to almost unholy levels of detail and precision, boasting by a clear distance, despite much competition for this award, the best kept, most varied and well chosen selection of beers on tap of any bar I can think of visiting.
It is nice when bars select their beers carefully as often these beers define a pub. I like the fact some pubs have 2 or 3 staple beers. However, past a point, simply letting you have at it is liberating and invites you to treat the bar area as a sampling board (something which they also cater for). Not only does the place sell the usual craft ale styles but if you want a wild yeast fermented Belgian lambic, a Doppelbock from a medium sized Franconian brewery, or unfiltered, not just unpasteurised but unfiltered Pilsner Urquell, this place does it.
On top of this the staff were very friendly and seemed to bounce off my enthusiasm for the beers above.
Everything else? Well, there’s a street food fan, the décor is inoffensive, and the place feels pretty generic. The lights are too bright, and the seating fails to provide any kind of communal pub feel, leaving it feeling like a hip bar restaurant rather than pub.
It’s a shame as with a few tweaks they could still keep their beloved industrial chic and the food element but also build an atmosphere and venue you want to base your entire night around. As it is, it’s a beer mecca you’ll want to visit primarily for the tasting of delicious beers; in this regard at least, they fulfil their purpose with panache.

name: El Bosc de Les Fades
description:
EBG Rating:: 8
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Value For Money: ❤️❤️
description: Translating to The Forest of the Fairies, this bar is set down an alley entrance to a nearby Museum, but is signposted clearly enough on an arch set off La Rambla.

El Bosc is one of those bars where you can turn your head in any direction and see something new. The main area is initially quite a sight to behold, with tree trunks shooting up to the ceiling and branches crawling along to create a forested feel. Fairy lights make a rather obvious appearance. The room is largely cleared of furniture to allow people to wander around, and there are plenty of other places in the bar to wander to.

You have a snug area, rather unexpected in such a place, a completely different backroom with origami beetles in the window, a medieval style rocking bed to sit on, a table held forward by a toy soldier. Then another room, suddenly the bar turns into a lush upholstered Victorian bedroom with pretty white furniture and billowing curtains. Then a corridor with huge machine like cogs on the wall and lampshades that look like bats, and a wall covered in backlit butterflies.
I wasn’t on anything, I can assure you. Wherever you turn, something new.
The beers are the usual limited Spanish arrangement, and aren’t especially cheap (it’s La Rambla, no surprise). Probably the best option is Voll-Damm, a double pilsner with just enough flavour and just clean enough to be inoffensive.
If you ever fancied a drink in A Midsummer Night’s Dream this is your chance.

It doesn’t have the raw power of an alternative bar, indeed it’s been lavished with money and attention, but it’s so unusual and well done you can hardly leave it out, regardless of any stylistic apprehensions or beer snobbery.

name: Garage Beer Co
description:
EBG Rating:: 7.5
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Value For Money: ❤️❤️
description: Garage Bar could hardly describe itself as a particularly Spanish place, indeed when you walk in, you might see the sign “Mr Steve Huxley, you’re a ****ing legend!” on the blackboard.
This craft ale brewery got off the ground because of British interest, and it shows in nearly everything about the bar, right down to the studied checked shirts and beards of the bar staff.
These kind of places set off a deep-set annoyance in me so any that can overcome it one way or another are usually a pleasant surprise.
Garage has a core host of regulars, which becomes obvious when hanging around the bar area. They are young and noisy and enjoying both Garage’s decent craft output and the array of other options on tap. It has something to do with the sheer informality of the bar staff, who may be the other side of the bar but do their best to make you feel like you’re having a good time with them.
Decent rock music, the odd singalong, and sampling of beers all makes up for the cliched exposed industrial chic décor and uncomfortable seating.
Also, when you’re greated with free raspberry sour beer from an alembic you’re always going to have a soft spot for the place.
The prices are standard for craft beer in the city centre, topping out at 5 euros, which is pretty steep by Spanish standards but probably won’t be too offensive to British beer lovers. Are they twice as good as normal Spanish beers. Some are, some aren’t, but in this case it’s a price to pay to explore Barcelona’s beer scene. On occasion I’d rather be drinking a Moritz (especially on a warm day) for 2 euros than paying 5 euros for a generic American Pale Ale.
As per usual, craft beer pubs are places to feel ambivalent about, but in many ways Garage takes you out of that dubious façade a little bit, and returns to what the whole point of going out for a drink it, good beers, good company and a good laugh.
Perhaps I was warmer to Garage than I would have been were it in England as I dislike going to tapas bars for a drink, as the beer is such a sideshow. Barcelona needs at least a few places like this.

name: Kælderkold
description:
EBG Rating:: 7.5
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️
Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️
Value For Money: ❤️❤️
description: Kaelderkold is a great choice if you’re looking to drink beer near La Rambla that’s actually good. Ignore the ‘world beer’ bar the other side of the road that’s dubious in the extreme, and dive to your left.
You’ll find what seems to be a narrow and self contained dive bar, whitewashed with light wood and some rather kooky scandi-inspired artwork on the walls. The bar staff are your usual craft beer stereotypes, pretending to be Icelandic loggers or something, the girls with pierced noserings and dungarees. Don’t expect any grasps towards individuality in the décor, only in the beer.
There’s a really impressive selection of tapped beer, most of which is craft ale, and they’ve done a good job of providing a range of styles meaning I found it easy to pick one suiting my mood.

Also, it’s not the tiny bar it first appears – keep going past the bogs and you’ll find an American diner-meets-comic book designed cellar area. Rather strange but worth it for the space and cushioned seats.
The rest of the crowd around the bar area tilt a little bit too far towards preening and self-aware, but there is a generally friendly sense overall, as the staff are friendly and plenty of people are into hanging out and chatting rather than doing precision pouting.

The prices are nearly double than you’d pay in a tapas bar for a glass of Estrella (perhaps not a half litre though), and it’s arguable whether this price hike is justified, even when considering British wallets are used to taking that sort of hit. In Barcelona city centre they know enough big spending hipsters will be around to capitalise.
Still, you can get a pint of some really great ales and it’s a nice place to go – if a little arch-hipster. If you’ve got the readies and want a break from sipping that gassy metallic Estrella Damn take the sidestreet to Kaelderkold and drop by for a drink with the in-crowd.

name: L'Ovella Negra Ramblas
description:
EBG Rating:: 7.5
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Value For Money: ❤️❤️❤️
description: The Black Sheep is a locally famous student spot whose business plan involves big groups, adverts for pitchers, buckets of crap beer and deals for shots. Why then does it have an appearance on this list?
Well, once you’ve taken everything about the pub as a whole, there’s actually rather a lot to like. The interior itself is like stepping into a country barn, rather impressive considering you’re in Barcelona city centre. No windows, but plenty of space, with side rooms and a large central area with a raised seating area and a large area in front of the bar for standing/games etc.
Although the décor looks like it gets a hammering week in week out, the rustic furniture is sturdy and built to last, the general feel is pretty warm and welcoming. The dark wooden ceiling, vaulted beams, stone walls and huge chimney really help build a characterful interior. The side rooms themselves have some interesting features such as intricate rustic tiling. The space itself gives you a breathing space (should you require it) from the excitable and sometimes a little too in-your-face student crowd.
Further plus points for the facilities, with a pool table, dart board, jukebox, along with a few community events they have going on. The decision to place the pool table by the bar area is ridiculously stupid though, meaning the players can’t play their shots without jabbing cues into people.
The beer isn’t the best selection you’ll ever be met with, however the prices are very good and adequately compensate.
The place transforms depending on the time of day, so afternoon and early evenings may seem rather sedate (and definitely the best time for a game of pool) but the late opening hours mean it turns into one of those boisterous venues that you can leave in the early hours and find it was as busy, if not busier than when you came in.
I wouldn’t recommend it for a romantic soiree, exactly, and they could easily attract the same audience without the marketing being so garish and out of place. The beer selection is a little poor as well, so there is work to do. The fundamentals are there though, this is a genuine pub with a good atmosphere.

name: Bar Manchester
description:
EBG Rating:: 8
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️
Value For Money: ❤️❤️❤️
description: Unless you’re obsessed with Mancunian indie music you might not think of a trip to a Manchester-themed bar on your trip to Barcelona as being judicious use of your precious time. There are plenty of similar bars in England, most of which are as dirty, ragged and out of date as the musicians are themselves.
However, I always have a morbid fascination with how other countries interpret British culture and the combination of being able to do that over a beer, along with it being in a convenient location at that point in the evening, made it worth a try.
Manchester is based down the warren of narrow back streets in Barcelona’s attractive and rather atmospheric Gothic Quarter. In the past locating it might have presented a challenge but anyone with gps should find it with ease.
The sign sticks out on your entry to the tiny square, and on entry step down to the bar area and you’ll find a fairly small and lively space, decorated in the fashion a lot of bars thought was cool back in the late 90s and early 2000s, which now seems oddly quaint.
The bar largely serves cheap beer and cheap cocktails, although on our visit nearly everyone was drinking Heineken as it was on sale for 1 euro 50 cents. Being on holiday, we naturally didn’t see the need to take such drastic measures. There are some decent bottles including imported German beer and the standard Barca lagers on tap, all of which are cheap themselves.
Naturally, the music is pretty good, though don’t expect it to be all strictly Mancunian, they were playing a range of British indie, punk and psych music from the 70s all the way up to the mid 00s.
The general atmosphere is good because its inhabited by a mainly local crowd, and manages to be busy and vibrant while still having available seating.
There’s no point going over the top about it. Manchester certainly isn’t doing anything unique or brilliant, but it’s a good option for a cheap beer or cocktail and a hang out, to enjoy some music and be on your way.
A: 7/10 B: 6/10 C: 8/10 D: 7/10 E: 8/10 F: 8/10

name: Pipa Club Plaça Reial
description:
EBG Rating:: 7.5
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Value For Money: ❤️❤️❤️
description: This place was the one bar that didn’t quite live up to my expectations on my visit to Barcelona, though by no means does that make it a bad place to go.

If you read the glowing fawning praise about the place you’d be forgiven for thinking this was some unique Sherlock Holmes style nudge-and-wink secret smoker’s hideout, rather than simply another bar. Well, I’ll start in reality TV style by shattering your illusions and then build a new impression from scratch.
The pipe stuff was so low key as to be virtually non-existent. I didn’t mind that so much but was rather surprised. The description of the décor may have previously applied, but again didn’t fit my expectation.

There are a number of different rooms, as this place is set in a first floor apartment in Placa Reial. It’s an atmospheric venue as it clearly used to be a rather grand apartment. Enormous ceilings and grand doorways, while the bar makes use of its prime location with some extraordinarily good views over the square. You can dip in and out of the various features, which are, in turn, quite interesting.

There’s a fairly trad modern bar area just in front of the entrance that serves upscale cocktails and a couple of dull beers on tap, San Miguel Selecta being the best. This seems to have been renovated as the images online suggest a working man’s club type bar area was previously there. There’s a room showing some vintage cinema, and another room with a pool table of all things.

I have to mark it down for the general sense of confusion – it certainly failed to fit some of the descriptions, though there is reference to a private member’s lounge, there’s not much point referencing that unless you can access it.
Definitely pay a visit and see if you can get more from it that we did. Even if you don’t there’s a very pleasant stylish apartment bar with good cocktails and great views.

name: The Black Turtle Pub
description:
EBG Rating:: 8
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ****
Style/Décor: ****
Atmosphere/Character: ****
Amenities/Events: ****
Value For Money: ***
description: Although it’s difficult to detect much stylistically to announce The Black Turtle as Serbian, neither is it a tacky theme pub. It does have an English name, and plenty of English language stuff about (a relief in a city where all the signs are in Cyrillic) but the venue is focused on the idea of a pub itself, and there are some detailed, understated touches in the decor which help create a strongly recognisable pub atmosphere.
It’s worth stating at this point there are a number of Black Turtles around the city, five I believe, only one of which I have been to, located near Kalmegdan fortress. However, research concludes the template is more or less the same in each venue, so I feel safe in writing this in the knowledge that a great deal will apply to the whole chain.
Along with being a reliable spot for good quality beers, the other draw to visit is the very lively atmosphere. There are many backpackers who drop down here, as there are young Serbians who want something to drink that isn’t the ubiquitous and awful Jelen Piwo. I remember the experience being a loud, occasionally raucous and smokey experience which is more or less what you would want and expect from Belgrade in general.
Being far away from home, it is wise to give some places a degree of latitude in certain areas they fall short – primarily because there often aren’t superior options. So visit The Black Turtle (any of the black turtles) with your eyes open, as it is no drinking mecca akin to Prague, Krakow or Brussels’ pubs, but it is still pretty damn good.
A: 8/10 B: 7/10 C: 9/10 D: 7/10 E: 7/10 F: 8/10

name: Gostilna Pri Planincu
description:
EBG Rating:: 7.5
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Value For Money: ❤️❤️❤️
description: The offerings and special experience of the Slovenian ‘Gostilna’ have in recent years become the subject of sentimental revival, partly due to a period of national reflection, and also in acknowledgement of their slow and gradual disappearance as international restaurants took their place. They have now trademarked the ‘Gostilna Slovenija’ in their ongoing attempt to promote and rationalise what is a distinct and important offering in an otherwise dinky and Slavic-influenced country.
The Gostilna is the nearest place you can think of to an English country inn, a large but very homely venue, predominantly serving food but also offering pub elements. Originally these began through landlords inviting guests around to taste their local food and wine. In the countryside these venues offer a home away from home, roaring fires, hearty food and shelter from harsh weather.
As a small town in the foothills of the Julian Alps, Bled is well placed to offer a good Gostilna, and there are a few worthy venues in town. The greatest of all is Gostilna Pri Planincu, both a cracking country restaurant of true history and authenticity, and a characterful local pub.
The service was efficient, ruthlessly polite and cheerful, and the food as you could expect arrived in suitably mountainous portions, after a reassurringly long wait. Our whole table were in approval at the size and the flavour of the food. Dining occurs in evocative country surroundings that feel real and aged with time and use rather than occasionally kitsch and plastic. Little oddities such as the stuffed witch character hanging from the ceiling are precisely the sort of oddity you wouldn’t find in a bar created from scratch.
Slovenia’s drinks options are still limited at the time of writing but Lasko is a bearable lager for the first pint. The pub area is typically countrified and has an obsession with car registration plates that cover more of the walls and ceilings than you’d first expect.
On a trip out into the countryside it would be difficult to create a venue more desirable to visit than this excellent Gostilna. The only improvements I can think of would be longer opening hours for the bar area and a physical extension to the pub area, which would elevate this to a 10/10.

name: Bratislavský Meštiansky Pivovar
description:
EBG Rating:: 7.5
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️
Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️
Value For Money: ❤️❤️❤️
description: This modern venture offers the best beer and quite possibly the best pub food in Bratislava.
Centrally located, unashamedly upmarket and lavished with money, they compensate for the corresponding drop in atmosphere by the undeniable sheer quality of the products you can eat and drink.
Forget the fact that up the road they’re selling Bernard for a euro, or the fact the food costs more like an English pub than a Czech or Slovak pub, when you taste what they make you’ll be won round.
The interior is a strange design, with a series of stairs and metal railings making quite a busy feeling entrance, but the bar area alone is rather elegant, with a series of arches, impressive tiled floor and dark wood bar top and stools. There are inset blackboards with the beer options and specials, while the staff run a very slick operation.
I originally thought that was it, but there are further rooms with pillars, arches and an enormous curved ceiling. Despite all this grandeur, it doesn’t feel particularly traditional. Everything is new and there is a conspicuous absence of history and character to the place. However, they are consciously at the start of that journey, and the fixtures and fittings themselves are clearly built to last.
The beer then, an unfiltered 12 degrees lager is heavenly, the dark lager itself as fresh and flavourful as you could reasonably expect. You’d knock back a few no problems at all. Bar service allows for that to happen with alacrity. 2 euros for a large glass constitutes good value across Europe in general, although represents something like a 75% markup on similarly good beers you can access locally.
Even if you just wanted lunch Mestiansky won’t disappoint. There are a range of central European staples, but the ingredients are noticeably fresh, carefully cooked and have a little extra flourish that elevates the dishes.
It’s difficult to determine local life in this place. They haven’t made anywhere near enough provision for a dedicated drinking area which deserves a big mark down, but I did notice quite a few solo males who drop in for a drink or for lunch. At night I still feel the place would lean more towards dining than drinking.
It’s a shame as only a few different decisions could have helped the place feel inclusive for dedicated drinking and dining, but it’s unlikely they’ll be able to change this template without practically ripping up half the area.
Therefore, drop by for a drink and for lunch, or go to the bar on an evening to sample their fantastic beers, for the pure enjoyment, and feel a little wistful and regretful that they passed up the opportunity to make something better

name: Bernard pri Lýceu
description:
EBG Rating:: 7.9
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️
Value For Money: ❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️
description: The appeal of pure, unfettered drinking, no B.S, or pretentions is something that grows on you the longer you spend time in Czechia or Slovakia. Backing this philosophy up is absolutely excellent, world class beer kept to strict and exacting standards that is so singularly enjoyable you can find yourself in many scuzzy and otherwise unappealling dive bars still with something to literally cling on to.
This Bernard insignia pub typifies working class drinking, set with only a car park between it and the dual carriageway out of town. It’s easy to reach if you’re near the old town, 15 minutes walk, or 10 minutes if you’re based on the road up to the castle. The discount supermarket and sex shop next door certainly hammers home the location even further, yet there is a terrace area outside with some pleasant bench seating.
The real welcome is the blackboard stand by the pub, boasting of nearly the full Bernard range from the simple desitka at barely a euro for a glass up to the bock type special beers. Walk inside and find a very simple cosy room with a dinky bar area. There is a TV in the corner and some ice hockey memorabilia dotted around the place. Don’t expect anything fancy otherwise, it’s a classic sporty local drinking hole. The staff don’t speak English but neither do they utter any objection or hostility when you order a beer – they know why you are here and are pleased to serve. The other patrons inside barely even turn around to acknowledge you in their haze of cigarette smoke and drunkenness, which might give you peace of mind if you sometimes dislike feeling like an intruder.
The terrace is a bit more communal, and even if you aren’t involved in conversation there is a friendly feel to sit with the crowd. The pub crowd is an odd split between young couples who sit outside and typically grizzled old boozehounds who wander in and out, but this sort of works in its favour and I quite like places like this that throw different groups of people together.
The Bernard is excellent, disappearring down the hatch with alarming ease. On both occasions I found myself dispatching several in short order, the combination of price and quality proving irresistible. While there are many humdrum aspects to the pub you could probably find in dozens of other hospodas in the city, I couldn’t think of a better example of a comfortable, strongly-supported diverse working class venue, and the beer and value just tops it off.
When compared to the central brewery and pub Mestiansky Pivovar with its glass, chrome and corporate feel, Bernard pri Lyceu provides a stark contrast but equally, a welcome reminder of the more homely and simple values of pub going.

name: Pegas Pivnice
description:
EBG Rating:: 7.8
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Value For Money: ❤️❤️
description: We've been visiting Pegas since 2016, the last occasion being 2024.

Pegas in Brno is the best old fashioned Pivnice in the city centre, the emphasis on fashioned rather than old.

The décor is well done, aping a traditional Pivnice in every way I can think of, curved ceiling, wood paneling, bench seating, hops dangling off the beams, and, despite a ground floor level location, a real cellar type feel. This is enhanced further by the gorgeous copper mash tuns by the kitchen which give evidence of the brewing activity at the hotel. There is a nice range of beer ephemera and artwork spaced out sparsely along the walls, and there is the potential that adding more and making it a little more ramshackle would give it more character and the feel of it being an institution.

Often these efforts can end up being an afterthought and a little corporate/by-the-numbers, but Pegas have concocted a solid, high quality range of Czech beers supplemented by seasonal brews. When combined with the friendly beer hall atmosphere it justifies wandering in for a drink alone.

Food is decent - big portions of hearty winter fuel cooked with fresh ingredients, well seasoned and delicious, although increasingly quite expensive.

Service is professional and courteous, relatively tourist-friendly, although you may get ushered towards the corner of your table when a big group arrives, that is rather inevitable. There is a lunch crowd and an evening crowd, so if you don’t want to mingle your boozing in with dining try mid-afternoon, early evening or late night.

As hinted at above, Pegas is actually in its infancy, but all its moves so far have been the right ones. It would be great to return in 40-50 years.

name: 't Brugsch Bieratelier
description:
EBG Rating:: 8
Choice/Quality of Drinks: Curated selection of belgian beers on tap offered with a tasting guide, pushing people towards buying flights/planks.
Style/Décor: Typical unfussy Belgian bar with plenty of glassware hung at the bar area. Narrow entrance leads to a wider backroom. Plenty of wood but not really a 'Belgian cafe'. Bras on the ceiling in dive bar fashion.
Atmosphere/Character: Suitable for an afternoon or evening, although the tempo certainly rises later on. A mixed crowd, albeit largely tourists.
Amenities/Events: Some seasonal events, rotating drinks offers, space in the backroom for board games, etc.
Value For Money: Typical for central Bruges, ie. Not Cheap.
description: The venue has quickly acquired the sort of memorabilia, gifts and tat that accompany bars of far greater age. It took me aback a little as their website and some of the descriptions had made it seem like quite a modern, sterile (if interesting) specialist beer tasting house.
The core purpose of the bar is to serve eight small-batch tapped Belgian ales on rotation, be that seasonal or chance offerings. These are outlined in an ever changing clipbook you will no doubt be handed upon your seating at the bar.
Disappointingly, Bieratelier’s own house beer is a thin, unworthy and wholly disappointing blonde, but at the time of visiting, the other beers were all of a dark xmas ale style, with the exception of a gorgeous strong ale from Dupont Avec Bons Voeux, nevertheless brewed seasonally for the holidays.
Despite being a degustation for beer, the bar lady is teetotal and not Belgian. In spite of the fact she is very friendly, conversational and a natural in all other ways the job demands, she has little to say about the beers, indeed she has a well-rehearsed bit about being ‘perfect for the role’, so be warned if you’re making a beer pilgrimage solo, despite the beer tasting purpose, the bar chat is not going to be beer based past the bleeding obvious.
The bar area is in the front room, which has a row of 8-9 seats. There is a very decent pub area in the back room as well, but the front seats feel like the important ‘service seats’, and it was engaging to sit there with a few other couples all working their way through the enormously strong array of xmas ales.
Prices are on the high side, but similarly generosity and loyalty is rewarded. We all received Gordon Xmas Ale branded socks, St. Bernadus playing cards, a La Chouffe bauble, and a number of freebie tastings before our purchases. The pleasure of company, good conversation and the psychological effect of being handed freebies soon made the slight shock to the wallet dissipate.
It’s good that the bar has made a concerted effort to do something different without snubbing the needs of most bar goers, and it’s in a nice area of town, just enough off a side-street so as to be quiet on an afternoon. The atmosphere is decent without being electric, and there are (as usual) a few rooms for improvement. Ditch the house beer for a start, it’s poor. A bartender with background knowledge of the beers, slightly fairer pricing, and a few bits here and there to improve the character and the seating would attract more locals and all elevate the experience.
As it is, Bieratelier is a very good option to taste a new Belgian beer, a friendly and homely spot that’s more down to earth than you’d expect from the website or the concept of the bar and importantly definitely a full fledged pub and bar rather than a café. A good option in a city with lots of good options and a few genuinely great options – i.e – go if it fits in with your pub crawl or preferences, but you may not feel like you’ve missed out on a star attraction if you don’t.
A: 9/10 B: 7/10 C: 7/10 D: 7/10 E: 5/10 F: 8/10

name: Cafe Rose Red
description:
EBG Rating:: 8
Choice/Quality of Drinks: *****
Style/Décor: ****
Atmosphere/Character: *****
Amenities/Events: ***
Value For Money: **
description: Possibly the number one venue to take your loved one for a beer in Belgium, the brooding atmosphere, slow pace and comfortable seating makes this a strong choice, particularly in the winter months, to cosy up to one another by the fire getting gradually hammered on 9% ale.
The pub’s name isn’t a lie, there are red roses attached upside down to the ceiling, and a reference to the official literature explains this was all inspired by the novels of Stephen King, though there are other elements, Shakespeare, Twin Peaks that it put me in mind of. While still romantic there is a slightly foreboding gothic quality at work, in an understated fashion.
Otherwise, you have a quite typical Belgian pub, a smallish space, one room with with stocky and comfy bench seating and thick wooden tables starting from by the window to the back wall opposite the bar. The bar area gleams with the most impressively clean and varied selection of glasses hanging above the bar. It’s a miracle they manage not to smash dozens of these a week, but the slow, measured service gives an indication that nothing here is done in a rush, indeed nothing needs smashing when you’re delivering the beers with the sort of care and attention normally preserved for new born babies.
The pub aims at an affluent market, meaning the base price for a bottle is 4 euros 50 and upwards. I’m torn as to whether that is worth it, as the quality of the beer is great, as is the atmosphere of the pub, but similarly, you can find great beer virtually anywhere, and Bruges is not a city lacking in atmospheric venues to drink beer. The other consequence of the price is that it drives out locals, apart from wealthy couples, from seeking it out. It is far from the worse venue in Bruges for this, and the theme and style of the bar probably makes it more forgivable that there isn’t a clutch of men in their 70s sat at the bar clutching glasses of Jupiler and grunting.
As a couple, you need to pay a visit to Café Rose Red. As a solo traveller it is an intense sensation but perhaps inessential and fairly lonely feeling choice. As a group, it works well as a pub venue, although any sort of raucousness and raised voices doesn’t quite fit with the tone of the place. Nevertheless it comes recommended and definitely in the top ten drinking holes in Bruges.

name: The Vintage
description:
EBG Rating:: 8
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ****
Style/Décor: ****
Atmosphere/Character: ****
Amenities/Events: ***
Value For Money: ***
description: After spending your time time supping specialist boutique ales in some of Bruges’ more preened and rather feminine café bars, you might find Vintage to be a refreshing change of speed. Set just 10 minutes walk from the central square, Vintage offers a far more gritty experience, while still maintaining a few norms you could expect from a typical Belgian pub.
Vintage is a hangout for rock music fans and has attached biker clubs, along with the odd bit of football represented. Thankfully this is one pub that hasn’t been cleansed of local life, and despite being halfway between the station terminal and the centre of the old town, and looking innocuous enough from the outside it seems to keep tourists at bay. No doubt the pugnacious feel of the place has something to do with that - which isn’t to say it’s all rough and ready, as there is a roaring fire and a cosy intimate feel, but they seem determined to project the fact Bruges isn’t all twee, chocolates and lace - it has some teeth.
Drinking mainly occurs on stool seating rather than chairs, for me usually indicating a venue to be more of a late night stand up bar where they need the floor space, but it is a little bit lacking comfort for afternoon drinking. At night though, and also in the early evening for a quick drink. Vintage is a great choice to sup Belgian ale, which it does a reasonable selection of at moderate prices. It could be improved by stocking the local Fort Lapin or Damme’s beer but that is nitpicking.
The unpretensiousness was summed up for me in the beer pouring. Often drinking a Belgian ale in England is defined by this ludicrous ceremony as though they are attempting to forge jewellery from precious metals, but instead of this nonsense the bar guy will take your expensive quadrupel, slam the liquid into its component glass (somehow managing to get the head on it just right) and bin the bottle without a by or leave. If you’d rather read the label, then be prepared to let them know in advance (they won’t mind overly).
A terrific counterpoint to the great but admittedly stuffier establishments in the centre of Bruges, this is where to go if you want to hang out with a few locals, drink a great beer in a down to earth environment and listen to some decent music; what pub going is all about in many ways.

name: À la Bécasse
description:
EBG Rating:: 8
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️
Value For Money: ❤️❤️
description: Another of central Brussels impasse pubs, I must have walked past the entrance a dozen times before ever going down there, but such is the wealth of good pub going to be found down these things that I am at risk of associating back alleys as places where only good things can be found at the end of them.
A La Becasse is definitely an old fashioned pub, with wood pannelled walls, some great period features like candelabras, and a Victorian era staircase down to the toilets. However, there is also a formality to the place. The staff all wear rather old-fashioned tabards in the manner of milksops, and look particularly strange given they are both bald. The seating is all stiffly upright in the manner of a restaurant despite the place only serving bar snacks and very basic meals, and there is only table service rather than bar service.
This style sets it apart from other Belgian venues and is nearer to a Brauhaus in format. At the same time I can’t help but feel it would be even better and possibly loveable with a slight rejig of the pub seating, more communal tables and upholstered seats, losing the traditional tabards without this affecting any of what the pub does best.
The pub serves blends of Lambic from the barrel, something you will struggle to find anywhere. The standard blend Lambic doux, is a really beautiful blend of sweet and ever so slightly sour beer. Similarly, they do blends of Gueue and Kriek which are worth a try. These are served in a ceramic jug which you then dispense into small beakers. This gives the impression of drinking more than perhaps you actually have, which is good because A La Becasse isn’t the cheapest venue in Brussels.
There is a decent range of beer covering most of the usual Belgian styles from good breweries, meaning you can happily sit around and enjoy a quality beer in some impressively stately surroundings.
This is one of the few really central pubs where I felt there was an array of local regulars, mainly middle aged folk who would turn up for a jug of Lambic and a spread of cheese and pickles. The place also sees custom from adventurous couples seeking a secluded drink down the rabbit hole and away from the crowds.
It can take a while to get busy, even given the central location, but when busy A La Becasse transforms into a genuinely heartwarming lively, social and characterful venue, though you do need it to be at least three-quarters full in order to foster that great communal hubbub. Perhaps a few changes to the format, without throwing the baby out with the bathwater could ensure that

name: À la Mort Subite
description:
EBG Rating:: 7.9
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️
Value For Money: ❤️
description: There is sometimes a premium to be paid for a rare occasion, so on my near annual visit to A La Mort Subite I suck it up on occasion of the overall experience.
Distinctly French in format, this opulent faded grandeur art nouveau venue is one of Brussels most famous bars. It might count as a brown café for the bench seating up the sides of the long room, if it wasn’t for the lack of brown elsewhere and the elegant ornamental décor stacked with crenullations, and stately design. You have a venue somewhere in between a café and a salon, originally built as a place for socialites to be seen in, and still focused predominantly on beer. It is so of its time it’s difficult to think of too many other places that are alike.
Mort Subite is the draft beer, and this brewery serves fruit beers and lambic effect rather than the real McCoy. They are still rich in flavour and sweetness, and a tad sour, but lacking any sort of dryness and depth that might indicate the traditional lambic brewing process. A small serving of their kriek for example, which would be a good choice, will set you back five euros on its own. Some of the other options are fairly astronomical considering the price one can drink for elsewhere, and in excellent surroundings.
They clearly feel they are unique, and annoyingly, they are right. An afternoon drink in A La Mort Subite can feel rather like a drink in a café, albeit a particularly impressive historical one, but not so bar like. The place starts to come alive in the evening time as the crowd changes, and you can suddenly start to absorb some of the atmosphere and understand the underlying reasons for the endurance of this place. The grandeur and glamour of socialising in the pre-war era is yet to be recreated around Europe on any identifiable level, partly because of the lack of venues who have committed to investing the kind of money to pull it off well, and also because the eventual crowd it attracts tend to have little to no appreciation of their surroundings anyway. They visit for novelty factor alone.
A La Mort Subite is a preserved remnant of a particular era and a great opportunity for anyone with a real passion in the rich and diverse history of socialising, beer drinking and recreational culture to soak in something different.
Service is almost classically continental, with wide stomached balding Rene type characters smoothly dissecting the venue with assurance and steady hands under the drinks trays. They are immaculately professional and patient considering the table service and conveyor belt of foreign tourists.
Although the evening and night crowd appeals to a few nostalgic locals, it’s usually Brussels tourists who venture in, and because of the heritage of the place, often a middle-aged crowd.
Changing the venue in anyway seems to be verboten, and I wouldn’t approve either however it seems to me there is nothing to stop it rejigging the drinks choices and doing some marketing from the outside, as this venue is not designed for middle aged obese American sat in Burghaus jackets, it is designed for the young, the stylish and the vibrant. The way to really bring back the good old days isn’t just to leave the décor and service meticulously unchanged and hope for the best. The good old days were good because they were vital, vibrant and inhabited a nascent social scene.
In order for A La Mort Subite to take the next step, they need to be brave enough to recapture the zeitgeist in any way that doesn’t upset the period features, rather than settling for being a museum.

name: La Porte Noire
description:
EBG Rating:: 7.5
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️
Value For Money: ❤️❤️
description: A long standing inclusion on our guide.

Set apart from the crush in crowds in the centre of Brussels, but close enough to be nothing but a brief wander down some side streets, La Porte Noire has succeeded in maintaining a local crowd (with a peppering of backpackers) by making itself look rather intimidating.

The Black Door in this case is literal, an enormous wrought iron beast that you have to wrench open to gain access to a cellar bar downstairs, along with a thick curtain well and truly marking your exit from the outside world.

The steps down are a bit of a wasted opportunity for further décor, and the glass door to the bar area seems inconsistent as well.

Nevertheless, upon entry you will find a genuine cellar pub, with minimal décor but a vaguely gothic theme. Across the bar area there is a row of bench seats at the far end pitted in near darkness, nary a candle or a lamp to assist

Although I enjoy cellar bars, the brickwork and subterranean feel makes it more difficult for them to stand out, but this dive certainly has plenty of character to speak of.

Along with 8 or 9 pretty good tap choices there is a fridge full of various Belgian drinking options, some standouts and some reliable fallbacks most of which fall around middling in the generally quite expensive Brussels pricing.

Thankfully there is some decent music played in here, as I think it feel more like a prison cell with drinking facilities without some music. This is backed up with a live roster, usually set up in the backroom, which overall lift the venue from interesting and pointedly dingy gothic cellar to a truly enjoyable offbeat destination that’s quite a bit different from other places you can visit in the vicinity.

Bring a group so you’re adding to the atmosphere. On a quiet night, or going solo, you may find the sheer blackness and quiet just a little bit much - or absolutely love it. Your call.

name: Délirium Café
description:
EBG Rating:: 8.5
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Value For Money: ❤️❤️
description: Reviewing a really well known mainstream destination like Delerium Café is quite difficult, partly because it is about three pubs rolled into one, and also because the place is so large and caters for such a wide range of people.
You may not find it an ideal destination for a quiet drink, as even during quiet periods the music can be pumping.
To start with, the bar area on the ground floor is generally used to keep happy the patrons who want to drink green beer, cactus beer, jagerbombs, absinthe shots and the various other vile concoctions, although equally you can order Delerium on tap there. Then, if you walk around the corner you will find what looks like a perfectly normal lively Belgian pub – wooden tables, beer ephemera on the walls and some laid back seating, certainly not in any way geared up for a wild party.
The third area, the basement constantly morphs with the crowd. The atmosphere can change in fifteen minutes from a jovial hubbub in a traditional beer hall type atmosphere to party central, and half an hour snap back again. The décor down there is also traditonal and you will see barrel ends everywhere and beer ephemera stretching back through the ages.
There is the regular Delerium bar menu, but don’t go off that, ask for the beer bible. Delerium was known at one point for offering the most beers in the world for any bar, and a flick through the book would seem to confirm that. Impressively, the vast majority from the hundreds on offer are Belgian, but they have dipped their toe across the globe as well should you fancy anything from Zambia or Barbados (unlikely). Be patient for some of these as they will require staff to dive downstairs for the relevant bottle and hunt around for the glass.
As you’d expect, the pub is a mecca for Americans and tourist from the Far East, likewise English and Australian backpackers, though I have seen a tonne of Spanish and Italian people here as well. Don’t expect to brush shoulders with the Bruxelloise or indeed any Belgians other than those with slightly tired expressions acting as the chaperones of excited young women they are with.
I have had some average experiences in Delerium, not awful exactly but a bit loud, towny and unloveable, and similarly a couple of terrific nights where I’ve got talking to a group. It can transform after a few drinks and with the right people into a really good venue.
Some of the areas are getting a bit dog eared purely because of the volumes of people coming and going. It gets more wear and tear than most, so in a few years time I think they will need to give it a bit of a revamp. The decorations still look okay but the furniture, the bar area and some of the literature is due a refresh.
It almost goes without saying that a visit to Brussels will include a drink in Delerium at some point. In order to get the best out of it, think about how many people you’re with, how social you’re feeling and what time of day it is. When you’re already drunk, in a good mood and feeling like you want to chat to folk it provides an excellent opportunity to socialise and have fun.
Also, don’t race up and down the courtyard on your way in and out, hang around for a while to take in the vibrant atmosphere and look towards the far end for a particularly amusing take on the Mannekin Pis, a female version called Jeanneke.
You might also want to pop across the courtyard to Floris, Delerium’s sister bar, though this place isn’t focused on beer and there’s not quite as much of interest.

name: Au Bon Vieux Temps
description:
EBG Rating:: 7.8
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️
Value For Money: ❤️❤️
description: Another impasse pub, this one is well known above and beyond any other, indeed might be among the top 5 most famous drinking holes in Brussels, with some of the problems that generally accompany such notoriety. You can read numerous gushing reviews about this place, and it is admittedly a wonderful pub in many ways.
The impasse itself is another itch-scratching curiosity, this time well signposted with an ornate stone entrance that is difficult to miss, with a number of neon signs from classic Belgian brands and at the other end of the alley a quirky medieval style sign over the front door beckoning people inside. Yes please.
You will note the stained glass windows from the outside and once in you are greeted by a cosy pub with some unique features and gothic décor that go beyond the level of detail usually associated with humble taverns. Try and visit out of the Christmas season as their decorations are hideous and ruin the otherwise fantastic feel of the place.
Unlike the hard exposed wooden benches of most Brussels pubs you can expect comfy upholstered and cushioned seats, angled corners like an English pub, and a true feeling of security and cosiness that’s difficult to create from scratch.
One of the niggling problems that has always restrained me from taking up a short term leasehold tenancy agreement in the place is the price, which similar to A La Mort Subite is a ripoff. The selection is also quite poor by Belgian standards, although you can expect the typical trappiste offerings marked up by 25%. This poor pricing has desolated the place of nearly all locals or regulars, something a pub like this would greatly benefit from. It’s a great shame, as without locals it doesn’t extend beyond being a frozen in time museum piece hollowed out for the novelty of tourists, when it could be far far more than that.
Nonetheless, it’s impossible not to pay a visit because the pub is unique, carrying a feel unlike nearly any other Brussels pub going. Visit and like me you will take a moment to contemplate just how incredible it would be if it was run by locals for locals, to its full potential.

name: Sielanka
description:
EBG Rating:: 7.8
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️
Value For Money: ❤️❤️❤️
description: Characterful antique single-room bar set underneath traintracks. Candlelight and the sounds of trains passing above your heads, a real fire, quality Czech beer on tap and Polish craft options in bottles. Plenty of seating despite the short space. A little gem. (Added 2019)

name: Traveller's Hostel & Pub
description:
EBG Rating:: 7.6
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Value For Money: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
description: The only reason for my visit to Traveller’s Hostel in Cesky Krumlov for a drink was a reaction to the paucity of other drinking options. It’s nice to have a good spread of places to go to, even in a smaller city, as there are usually unforeseeable elements such as the pub being closed or deserted, or just unpleasant. Given the few options available it appearred essential to note down. It appeared to have an adjoining pub section, which, while not ideal on the face of it, was better than nothing.
Fortunately, this pub is quite separate from the hostel, indeed the first steps walking through the door make it seem uncertain this is actually a hostel. With a sloping wooden floor down to an old fashioned bar area, traditional Czech bench seating lined along the walls and a classic Pivnice style curved roof, there is in essence a self-contained pub in the front room.
The bar staff are also a bit more hospitable on account of the adjoining hostel, and there are a couple of the very decent Eggenberg beers brewed literally just down the road. These are served in classic Czech glasses – thick, sturdy with a wide brimmed base and a handle. Prices are under a pound a pint, so overall, some pretty glorious drinking is to be had.
The patrons are for the most part all connected to the hostel, though I saw enough people venturing in from the outside. There is a clear hostel sign above the door which no doubt puts a few people off, but I reiterate – this is a full on Czech pub, and I’m not sure what else it would need to do in order to quality.
On your trip to the toilet you will notice there are some back rooms with overspill seating which are not quite in the same Pivnice style but were also busy and the sound of conversation was feeding through to the main room, helping create a nice atmosphere.
The middle of the main room is kept clear, presumably to accommodate large groups arriving with luggage, but I think it would help if there was a central table, and it wouldn’t make entrance overly difficult. Similarly, I wouldn’t want to stop at a hostel with a pub in case my room was above/underneath and I wanted some sleep. But that’s hostel reviewing, not pub reviewing, and this is in most ways a really good old fashioned pub, with some characterful elements and that quirky sloped floor especially underlined the rather gnarled medieval feel of Cesky Krumlov’s bars and cellars.

name: Früh am Dom
description:
EBG Rating:: 7.7
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Value For Money: ❤️❤️
description: Fruh is Cologne’s quintessential Kolsch brauhaus, and it’s unlikely any beer drinker’s visit to Cologne will be without paying a visit here. The venue is vast set among three floors, and containing backrooms that will make you feel like you’re in down in a cellar even when you’re reclining thirty feet in the air.
Service in a Kolsch brauhaus starts by taking a table, and barely after sitting down a gruff Kobe will have greeted you to check whether you want anything else except a conveyor belt of Kolsch. Give a quick nod or indication it’s beer you’re after, and you’re pretty much all set until it’s time to settle up.
The Kobes who serve the Kolsch are renowned for being notoriously stuff which is amusing given they probably have the most contact with the general public of any bar/restaurant staff. The reason for this is that the Kolsch is served in 0.2l, partly for the purpose of never having to drink the ‘dregs’ from a glass. The beer is always delivered lightning quick in the hope that your speed of drinking will be likewise.
As a result, the venue demands dozens of Kobes on their feet all day rushing around with circular pods rather than trays, each with space for 20 or so glasses of Fruh. If you’re anywhere near the end of your glass a replacement will be on its way before you can even stop them – indeed the only way to do so is to pop the beer mat on your glass, whereby they will tot up the pencil marks they’ve been inscribing on there and charge you accordingly.
The serving measure is one way of making quite a lot of money, and to be honest it’s pretty easy to drop 10-15 euro in here on drinks without even paying much attention. The beer is a crystal clear ale (not strictly speaking a lager) with a well balanced pils-like balance between sweetish flavour and bitter refreshing aftertaste. It’s sometimes easy to overlook Kolsch which on a good day stands up to anything.
Fruh is the face of Kolsch worldwide and you may have drank some of their pasteurised stuff from bottles, which are generally quite poor representations of drinking Kolsch in Cologne which always seems to have a cleaner, less acrid taste than the pasteurising and bottling process seems to end up producing.
The space inside Fruh is designed to allow for dining, and to be honest this can detract from values I am hoping to judge, namely the pub-going quality. Some areas do not feel overly communal and much more restaurant-like. Another downside is they will kick you out on some days what seems rather early, and the service towards the end of the evening couldn’t be clearer that they want you to go home.
That said, the place is ideal for big groups, and does indeed have plenty of rooms for en masse socialising in true German fashion, and the offering of food still remains a net positive.
We all know you’re going to end up in this pub in Cologne so this is enough talk from me about it – get on with it!

name: Brauhaus Sünner im Walfisch
description:
EBG Rating:: 7.7
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️
Value For Money: ❤️❤️
description: Walfisch is located in an old step-gabled house relocated onto Salzgasse. When the nearby Tipsgasse was removed the house was moved brick by brick to its current spot. It was reopened as a Sünner taproom in the mid-1990s, after an expensive refurbishment. It has a tiny, standup Schanke/taproom next to the entrance and a further room with the pine tables you would expect. They've done a really good job maintaining the Brauhaus feel - better even than some of the more stories names in town.

name: Brauhaus Sion
description:
EBG Rating:: 7.6
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Value For Money: ❤️❤️❤️
description: Sion may not be the tastiest Kolsch going (though neither is it awful exactly), and from the outside with an unexciting 1970s era frontage you may find yourself approaching Sion with a little trepidation in comparison to some of the more inviting looking Kolsch hauses in Cologne.
Do persist though, as what awaits inside is a hugely atmospheric traditional beer hall venue, tarred black and stained with smoke, portraits on the walls that hark back centuries. There are enormous medieval style candelabras with tiers of lamp lights attached (better that than wax dripping on your head), and several rooms and ante-rooms all of which are consistent with the theme, some of which look like they have hosted some grand municipal occasions. That sense of importance elevates the place from the get go.
Plenty of the Sion experience relies on the food, and while there are some mixed reviews about this, dining in Germany requires careful thought, as the wrong choice can often sit poorly with you afterwards. Our own experience was impressive, with a delicious seasoned wurst presented on a wooden block virtually the size of a snooker case.
The beer service is much like all the others, a time-honoured and efficient method of making you drink far more than you had ever intended to. The 0.2l glasses disappear in a few minutes flat and very soon they are replaced with another, and so on and so on, delaying the pain on your wallet until the end.
If Fruh is the modern epicentre of Kolsch in the known universe, and Peters is the understated, plucky purveyor of the ultimate Kolsch beer itself, Sion deserves a place in this trilogy for the historical atmosphere that more than the other two brings to life the heritage of pub going in central Cologne.
It’s a little bit more of a restaurant than a pub, but nevertheless qualifies and I submit this plea for you to visit and go drinking there on that basis.

name: Peters Brauhaus
description:
EBG Rating:: 7.6
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️
Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️
Value For Money: ❤️❤️
description: Possibly the least fashionable of the central Cologne brauhauses, Peters is entirely unconcerned by such things and succeeds by offering a really atmospheric beerhall and arguably the best Kolsch going.
Whether dining or just drinking, the venue never seems like you’re there doing the wrong thing or there at the wrong time. It’s all communal, and surprisingly airy considering the traditional décor. There are some stylish windows lining the frontage and the place has an understated class about it, the piece de resistance being an impressive stained glass ceiling feature which is probably the takehome memory I have of the interior.
Service is a little less brusque than other places, probably a compliment to say they are unintrusive and get on with things without looking like the entire world is against them. Why the Kobes seem to act like English bus drivers is for a person better acquainted than I am to explain.
Don’t expect a particularly lively young crowd, as most of those people have gone to Fruh, or just not bothered with a traditional German brauhaus at all – they aren’t especially geared towards pure out and out night drinking after all, and Peters is no different, closing relatively early by the standards of a Kneipe or a club.
The Kolsch is crisp, clean, with a terrific refreshing flavour that speaks of the pure freshness. Cologne is a great example of a city where great tasting beer is available unpasteurised on site. The style may be the most uniform of all but it really does taste great. Peters beer is at standard price for the city centre and as usual served in the classic 0.2l Kolsch style glasses. Service isn’t as frenetic as Fruh as it doesn’t need to be, so you don’t feel like a Kobe is always on your shoulder, but likewise your glass will get replaced with another beer unless you put your beermat on top in quick order.
Peters Brauhaus should be an essential visit on your tour of Cologne’s Kolsch hauses, because it represents the near pinnacle of the beer style, and is a very charming and atmospheric venue. Don’t rely on it for any partying or youthful antics, but appreciate it for what it is – a stately and beer hall.

name: Red Light
description:
EBG Rating:: 7.8
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️
Value For Money: ❤️❤️❤️
description: If you’re in Gdansk and looking to hang around late in ul. Piwna and the surrounding area, rather than wandering off to any of the slightly edgier backstreet haunts, you can’t do better than Red Light Pub, (more of a bar really) that stays open until the small hours of the mornings most nights.
This is another bar whose name literally does what it says, as your entrance to the bar area will illustrate. Wall to wall red paint, this isn’t an understated theme by any means. Their idea seems to have been to fall somewhere in between groovy red-coloured bar with a dance area near the back and a more shady, boudoir type feel that is popular across Poland.
Somehow, falling squarely in-between, it works pretty well. 
The front room has a small bar area which works as a good place to meet new people. The bar is close by to a few hostels and is on one of the main drinking drags in the city. The result is a healthy mixture of locals and curious travellers.
Beer-wise, don’t expect anything spectacular on tap, though this bar had a reputation for stocking local beers when all you could get were the big macro-brewed lagers and still does Browar Amber’s along with one or two others aside of the norm.
It’s really a social joint and a decent all-rounder pub with some extra points for the late-night party facilities, which while not everyone’s thing, provides a decent excuse to hang around from the transition between early evening conversation and late night revelry - opening hours which drag seemingly every remaining partygoer in the city here after 2am. (added 2017)

name: Galgenhuis
description:
EBG Rating:: 7.7
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️
Value For Money: ❤️❤️
description: https://theeuropeanbarguide.com/2019/03/21/het-galgenhuis-ghent/
‘The Gallows House’ is Ghent’s most central and historical pub and occupies a tiny but nevertheless interesting spot the city folklore. A tiny place set on a corner by one of the canal bridges, it could never have been purpose-built as a pub due to its uneconomically modest size.
A former fish stall, then tripe house, then schandstraffen, Galgenhuis has seen its fair share of fishy doings, none lessened by its conversion into a pub in the Victorian era. The main room fits a row of bench seats on each side of the room, and just enough space in the middle to congregate if they are full. The terrace area is probably bigger than the pub itself.
Galgenhuis counts as a genuine ‘brown café’ due to the traditional furnishings and genteel down to earth feel of the main room, very much a Belgian pub, but has some additional historical features that predate the style. It also has some impressive painted tiled walls and beamed ceiling painted with some rather threatening gallows-appropriate slogans. However, the white painted frontage sticks out a mile in front of some grand stepped gable buildings by the water front, and the modern signage, not really in keeping with the tradition or the interior, makes it look a little bland.
This isn’t a concern once you’re inside however, and if you’re lucky enough to find a seat you’ll want to stay for the duration. Perhaps it’s the modest size that makes it feel like the centre of the action, being so close to the water nearby and the goings-on in the street, it really does feel like being inside a capsule. The bar area is set a half-level down from the street, but with plenty of windows outside there is a slight chalet/grotto type feel.
If you strip back the numerous eccentricities there is a fundamentally sound pub. A cosy front room, jovial atmosphere, and during the evening that classic golden glow that emerges from a well decorated friendly pub room and careful application of beer.
Speaking of beer, there is a small but decent selection of Belgian ales on tap, from the fairly rare on tap Tongerlo down to a lager Primus, which is vaguely preferable to the ghastly Jupiler and a decent regular strength fallback if the dubbels, tripels and quadrupels are getting on top of you.
The bar staff carry out their job with pride, clearly feeling they are playing their small part in the continuation of Galgenhuis, and I felt they were among the more friendly in Ghent to the places I visited.
The central location means you can shoot off from here to half a dozen other bars and pubs within minutes, making it suitable for a pub crawl, but the high demand for seating makes this place the most suitable for a full afternoon session, so turn up early afternoon with a small group, bag a table and get drinking

name: Craft Bier Bar Hannover
description:
EBG Rating:: 7.5
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️
Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️
Value For Money: ❤️❤️
description: The Craft Bier concept seems to have done well pretty much everywhere, however Germany in particular was always going to be a hard nut to crack. The Reinheitsgebot forbids beer brewed in Germany to stray beyond basic ingredients, and also to brew beer according to set standards.
This has proved both a blessing and a hindrance, because German beer has adopted immaculately high standards of brewing as a result, but similarly the styles of beer produced, with the exception of some zombified revivals like Sticke and Dampfbier haven’t beer as colourful or varied as the likes of Belgium or USA. This is changing, as in late 2015 Bavarian brewers voted in favour of a revision to allow other natural ingredients to be included in the roster, though this hasn’t resulted in any concrete revisions since.
In the meantime the limits German craft beer producers work within is much more rigid. Often these kind of restrictions can lead to inspiration and innovation, so there is a school of thought that their purity laws should be maintained for the sake of tradition. After all, the export market provides the different flavours and styles they wish to adopt in any event.
On the other hand, the parochialism and misguided sense of imperial superiority of the German beer drinker can be very annoying. Often their refusal to accept or even tolerate other beer styles makes me feel a strong dislike for them. On these occasions a trip to a craft beer venue like the wonderously inspired in-name Craft Bier Bar in Hannover is called for.
