You all know the format by now. Unvarnished wood, industrial chic décor, multi-tap keg beer and a blackboard of ever changing beers. Plenty of high quality choice and different styles.
In terms of beer quality and friendliness you couldn’t hope to visit a nice place, particularly on a sunny afternoon with a set of tables on the terrace good for lingering around and supping beer of various styles. The bar guys are very talkative and passionate about what they’re doing. There isn’t yet the blaze and rather jaded supercilious that has developed in England.
It’s nonsensical that two very meritorious sorts of beers – traditional historical styles (when brewed to a good standard) and experiemental, but almost scientifically clinical and micro-managed craft ale would be pitted in competition with each other. For me they have little overlap and there is plenty of a market for them both. They should be concentrating on joining together to wipe crap chemical-tasting macro-brewed lager off the map. Instead Craft Beer appears to be about aggressively marketing to a young audience at the expense of the traditional crowd, deliberately setting itself against and positioning itself as separate from some brilliant and traditional breweries. There is little to no value in this.
Still, try telling any Craft Beer disciple this, I have even encountered some claiming to dislike ‘cask’ ale. It takes all sorts.
As per usual, Craft Bier Bar is not the kind of place to have a relaxing, cosy homely pub experience or a sit down. Apparently young people don’t want to be doing that. There’s a stripped back bare room and they just want people to be milling about, sharing their various beers for their unusual flavours. You would think both would be possible, but again, apparently Craft Beer must be distinct and separate, for reasons unknown.
I would still venture here as there’s little else to get overly excited about beer wise in Hannover, other than a corporate central brasserie with a bland venue but decent enough beer. There are some good Kneip’s around as well but Craft Bier Bar has a really excellent location next to the river in the Altstadt and a beautiful courtyard area where the restored and completely fake (but still authentic looking) fachwerk area is. Indeed Craft Bier Bar is set inside a fachwerkhaus, something which when you consider the interior proves to be a rather pointed juxtaposition.
As per usual, Craft Bier makes me feel very ambivalent, but when it comes to the products themselves there are some excellent beers to try. I remember drinking a wheat ale with just a tinge of ginger and apple flavour that was beautiful. You won’t find stuff like that in a traditional brauhaus, but then again, in this craft beer place you won’t find different generations of people enjoying good cheer among a setting redolent of the generations past.
Visit, and similar to myself experience the melange of differing emotions that generally accompanies craft ale drinking.

name: California Club
description:
EBG Rating:: 7.5
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Value For Money: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
description: A name such as California Club doesn’t exactly scream ‘excellent bar’, but put aside your reservations in this case. Karlovy Vary is a bit of a special case, as the stretch down the river is lacking any sort of late night drinking spot. The town is one of the oldest ‘resorts’ with its thermal springs making it a mecca for Russians and elderly Germans, and has much to recommend it in general, apart from the drinking scene.
Ordinary folk in Karlovy Vary live the other side of the river, or in effectively dormitory suburbs that are quite a way out of town, too far to realistically walk there and back if you’re based in the centre.
In order to get a beer that isn’t a crummy Krusovice for double the price in a drab restaurant or generic hotel bar, head up the hill on the south East bank where there are a few enclaves of local life, the best by far being California Club.
You still won’t be enamoured when you arrive, as the tacky American sign on the building and the energy drink sign outside still isn’t sending out any great signals. You can probably almost smell my desperation at this point as I dived inside.
However, when you enter you’ll find a bar teeming with local life and plenty of facilities making it worth hanging around for a drink. Pub games, live sport, and a large curved bar area serving a range of decent lagers, most importantly some pretty damn good Pilsner Urquell, cheaper than you’ll find in the centre of Prague for sure.The bar also serves as a ‘Herna’, a weird Eastern European thing where there is a partitioned gambling area based in the pub.
The décor is a little on the dated side, that isn’t all bad, as there are some nice cushioned lounge style seats which makes a nice change from the relentless hard bench seating of Czech Pivnices, but generally it’s nothing to write home about.
Ultimately it’s a chance to escape the centre, and will highlight just how hollowed out the centre of Karlovy Vary is, once the day trippers leave and the elderly hotel residents retire to bed. Thankfully there are places like this on the fringes where locals go, and although one might get a little sniffy at some of the stylistics, the beer is high quality, dirt cheap, it’s comfortable, warm and there’s lots to do. I wouldn’t usually have considered visiting a drinking hole called ‘California Club’, least of all solo in Eastern Europe, but the call of a beer is strong; necessity is the mother of invention.

name: NIShA bar'o perspektyva
description:
EBG Rating:: 7.5
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️
Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️
Value For Money: ❤️❤️❤️
description: Despite a bar’s shortcomings and even considering the inherent limitations, I always have a soft spot for a bar geared up for absolutely nothing except one thing - drinking. For a start, the simplicity but also it sets the expectation level for the one thing it does do, pretty highly.
This is Lithuania, and even more provincially than that, Kaunas, so there’s a silly bar name. Sorry about that, but don’t let it put you off just yet. At first glance at the name you might expect just some awful mid 00’s funky house bar with plastic seats and Corona bottles behind the bar. Thankfully this isn’t it at all.
Nisha is a pretty tiny corner bar, really like an updated 21st century version of an old fashioned French/Belgian drop in smoker’s bar where the working class man would pop over for a smoke and a beer. The update is to turn it into a smart, very compact but effective venue for local beer and quite a generous side helping of craft ale.
It is so intently beer focused that despite two of the four walls of the entire venue being the bar area, the remaining walls are stocked to the gills with various beers under the sun.
Talking with the owner, bizarrely they had formed a connection with Leeds Brewery and were serving Leeds Pale on tap. I thought about it for the novelty value, but after a quick reminder how awful Leeds Pale is even in Leeds, thought against it. Nevertheless, I humoured him and it was a nice exchange of opinions about the bar scene in our respective home cities.
I eventually settled on a Sour Pale Ale, in a craft style by a Vilnius based brewery which was delicious. The price was very reasonable for a craft beer, but in Lithuania it isn’t quite as cheap as you may think, so don’t be surprised to be paying 2 euros 50 cents upwards in a lot of mainstream venues just for one of their main lagers.
There isn’t much action going on in the afternoon, which shouldn’t have been surprising to me visiting on a shiveringly bleak November weekday, but you may find more joy in the evenings, as it is on a very doable pub crawl along some of Kaunas’ local bars.
The seating is mainly bar stools and the drinking mainly over ledges, so take a while to consider where Nisha fits into your drinking plans. Be assured though that it’s a high quality representation of Lithuania’s modern beer and bar scene, with many good beers to try and a willing participant in beer and bar chat if you’re flying solo.

name: BO baras
description:
EBG Rating:: 7.5
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Value For Money: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
description: Blue Orange is undoubtedly Kaunas’ social institution for students and young folk, and seems to take the role almost as an unofficial Student Union type bar, but with a few bells and whistles that entice the post-uni crowd there as well.
By all accounts Blue Orange or BO as it is known colloquially (presumably unwittingly) has peaked, and isn’t quite as zeitgeisty as it’s heyday. It must have been some heydey though, as during my visit it was rammed full of people who all looked like they were having a great time, also with that distinct feel that it was their regular hangout spot.
BO offers a range of the usual amenities in addition to the beer, board games, beer pong, foosball, rudimentary pub food, events nights etc, and is without doubt occupying itself with gathering a community around it as best as it can.
The furnishings and the bar concept is visibly getting past its sell by date but some how it doesn’t quite seem to matter.
As far as the beers go, you can fill your glass for a very decent price, and there are 6-7 decent taps with Lithuanian beer on offer, along with a correspondingly well stocked fridge full of bottles. It is, after consideration, a very good range and for the type of bar it is, good quality. Unfortunately you might find as with a lot of small time operations that the beer comes out very lively and they can take about three pint glasses to fill one glass full of beer. This can keep you waiting but thankfully the drink at the end is worth it.
BO remains a really good place to go if you want to start a conversation, as there are so many friendly groups, and similarly if you arrive and there’s a table free it’s a great place to spend an hour or two in Kaunas, both to socialise among yourselves and sample what the Kaunasii are up to with their free time.

name: John's Pub Public House & Restaurant
description:
EBG Rating:: 7
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Value For Money: ❤️❤️❤️
description: When the cafes have closed and it’s time to do some late night drinking, there aren’t all that many options open to you in Keszthely, so stake out as many options as possible, but make sure John’s Pub is your last port of call.
It’s solid, stays open late and serves you beer, in doing so fulfilling the main purpose of having a night out in a place.
The décor isn’t all that much to write home about, a generic sort of American diner type décor, but around the other side of the bar things become more pub-like with a dedicated drinking area and a nice outside terrace (albeit a smokey one).
Yes, there are live music nights, sturdy – if derivative food and after a short time in the wilds of Hungary south west of Lake Balaton you’d be surprised how relieving it is to spend some time in such an otherwise unremarkable place.
If you ever want to know where to go for a drink in Keszthely, now you know.

name: C.K. Browar
description:
EBG Rating:: 7.6
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Value For Money: ❤️❤️❤️
description: Before the alternative bar scene in Kazimierz stole the show, Krakow’s drinking scene was more famous for its underground cellar bars, generally vast spaces or grotto like hidey holes underneath the foundations of old town houses.
CK Browar manages to be both a throwback to that era and yet also a pioneer, as while it is a very conventional and well done cellar pub, it was one of Poland’s very first microbreweries, a concept that is starting to become a norm in virtually every large town and city in the country.
CK Browar had actually arrived on the scene a whole decade before craft beer even started to be whispered about, and along with Browar Amber in Pomerania, can be counted as a true forerunner to a culture that has crept up then expanded so fast that for some of the young Polish drinkers it must be considered the norm. Despite CK Browar being young by most bars standards it already has somewhat of a heritage feel and a sentimental institution from another era. Only the 90s for crying out loud.
Not that it looks particularly impressive from the outside. It would be interesting to discover just how many people have been put off by the crappy formica sign above the door, and although it isn’t the bars fault, its commercial neighbours don’t exactly help to give off the vibe that this is the place to be.
Nevertheless, ignore all the frontage and wander downstairs where the appeal will become quickly apparent. A long main room adorned with some rather elegant old bar signs, and memorabilia, awards and ephemera from the bars early days as a mini-brewer.
The brewing happens behind the bar area, and if you take a look while walking through, the already sizeable cellar extends even further onwards to almost cavernous levels. You can buy five beers, all of which are the typical sort you can expect in central Europe, a light and dark lager, a wheat beer, a honey beer and a semi-dark style. They brew seasonable beers but usually only every 3-6 months. Most of the core range is very nice, particularly the unfiltered light lager, but the wheatbeer needs a complete revamp.
The seating is designed for large groups, and indeed for novelty value you can choose to buy beer by the 5 litre, which arrives in an enormous tube for your friends to tap-off at their leisure. It must be a pain to have to clean or something, as there is no discernible discount for choosing this option.
I’ve often found the service here a little slow, and lacking acknowledgement from the staff when you walk in. However, once the order is actually put in, beer and food arrives quickly. The food is pretty good, albeit a rather playing-it-safe array of dry meals to soak up the beer. It’s tasty enough and just as importantly won’t break the bank. Neither will the beers which are a perfectly fair price.
If you visit any time before 7-8pm it will feel more like a pivnice and restaurant but they are keen to ensure it carries out a pub venue, and have even extended a club area, which to me looks more like a greenhouse filled with disco smoke, but nevertheless some points for trying. The format is a delightfully honest attempt to create a central European beer cellar and due to some tasteful decisions and the largely successful beer offerings, I recommend a visit.

name: Omerta Pub
description:
EBG Rating:: 8.5
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️
Value For Money: ❤️❤️❤️
description: It’s funny sometimes the place a young crowd determines is ‘The Place To Be’. Often older people have a tendency to criticise younger folk for being vacuous and only interested in glitz and edifice, citing the unsocial and artificial feeling clubs and towny bars some people prefer to visit. Omerta is one of many examples proving that, while they may follow trends like moth to a flame, superficiality is not in any way intrinsic to that. Far more important and intrinsic to most people is the social element of drinking.
Omerta is about sitting down and enjoying a beer in lively social company. There’s a silly and completely unnecessary ‘Godfather’ theme to Omerta, which is so low-key as to be virtually ignorable, but after that it’s very minimalistic. Cream walls, simple chairs and tables. Gather round, sink a few beers and chat with your friends.

Chiefly, what caused Omerta’s explosive popularity was the choice of beer, as they were a pub early on the craft scene in Poland, a scene in which Krakow was a big player in the early days. It’s debatable whether Omerta would have ever been such a social hub if it served only Tyskie, Zywiec, etc. Whoever made the decision to stock craft beer was jumping on an upward curve at just the right time.

While craft beer is starting to become mainstream in Poland it hasn’t reached the ubiquity of the UK by any means, with all the mediocrity and apathy that tends to engender. Similarly, the beer is competing with a fairly uniform beer style that frankly a lot of people are sick and tired of drinking day in day out.

The main advantage of craft beer in Poland isn’t so much the beer itself. It’s great to have a range of choice brewed to a high standard, but with the exception of certain beers, they are generic and easy to find in the UK. What makes the high quality craft keg ale even better is paying little more than £2 at any one time for a pint of the stuff. It remains superb value, even if it is a big jump in price for the locals, on the evidence of any night out in Poland, they are prepared to pay it, often as they pay 15zl for a beer and a shot at the likes of Pijalnia Wodka I Pivo anyway.

Omerta offers a good range of craft beer from some breweries that are more or less local institutions already, and this is the place to come in Kazimierz for that. What’s interesting is that unlike the sheer pretentiousness of many craft ale bars, Poland’s general approach hasn’t gone that way at all, much more interested in keeping artifice to a minimum, and letting the beers speak for themselves. This must be applauded.

As with a lot of Kazimierz places, you’ll find that the locals haven’t given up on it just because some tourists have started going. Indeed it’s so busy and full of locals that I imagine a few travellers are probably put off going in at first. Time your visit well because standing around with a craft ale in this place isn’t ideal. Once you’re seated however, you’re going to want to hang around, for the raw and friendly pub atmosphere and array of nice beers to drink.

name: Au Delft
description:
EBG Rating:: 8
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ****
Style/Décor: ****
Atmosphere/Character: ****
Amenities/Events: ***
Value For Money: *****
description: Old school democratically-priced brown café with a classic look. Go before its gone.

name: Singer
description:
EBG Rating:: 8.5
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️
Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️
Value For Money: ❤️❤️❤️
description: Another fantastic bar in the Plac Nowy area of Kazimierz district, the sheer wealth of options including some of the best bars in the world may have the result of making some of the others look like stylish wallpaper in comparison.
It was therefore not until several visits to Kazimierz until we chose to visit Singer, a bar located on a street corner, with some café style furniture outside that always looked like a reasonable choice but for reasons that become obvious just by looking around, inessential.
Yet Singer can claim to be one of the first on the scene, offering the now well established style of antique furnishings, faded history and obsession with nik-naks and ephemera, building the sort of brooding candlelit atmosphere that more or less defines a night out in Kazimierz.
Singer comes alive when you walk inside, as the bar’s concept hits you from all angles. Preserved fixtures and fittings, old fashioned décor, carpeted floor, stylish furniture and each table featuring a classic Singer sewing machine with the foot operated spindle underneath.
Furthermore, the strength of the bar is in its ability to adapt from snoozy decorous café by day, to dusky evening venue and onto raucous partying by night (very late night).
The service is no more than adequate, and the beer options peak at Ksiasece, which has always been the better of the mainstream selection, very pleasant without being superb. Similarly the prices will neither delight nor offend. It’s all about the venue and atmosphere itself.
Choose your moment to visit to suit your mood, and Singer will fit in nicely to your plans. If you fail to do this you may find that you only take on a glimmer of this bar’s potential. (added 2018)

name: Domus
description:
EBG Rating:: 8
Choice/Quality of Drinks: *****
Style/Décor: ****
Atmosphere/Character: ***
Amenities/Events: ****
Value For Money: ***
description: Domus is a typical Belgian brasserie that is set up for the purposes of dining just as well as drinking. It therefore falls into that slight hinterland between restaurant and pub, never really feeling like it’s just a pub.
However, there are a few things that compensate for this. Firstly, the décor is fairly ramshackle and traditional, with some gothic/religious themes going on, as well as some pretty common pub-type features. Dark wood furniture, wrought iron, hanging beams. It does well to invoke the feel of a pub. It’s also warm and comfortable inside in the same way a large English pub doing meals would be.
Their beers are the stars of the show, with a core range all of which are above par for microbreweries, and touch a reasonable baseline standard for Belgian beer overall. The extra benefit is that they are as fresh as could be, thicker than normal Belgian ale and served in English style dimpled mugs and pint glasses. Having a beer in Domus is a pleasure, indeed it could unwittingly take over an entire afternoon.
When I visited it had begun raining outside, and after the first couple I started secretly hoping the rain would continue to give me an excuse to stay.
Food is a sideshow as far as this blog is concerned, but just to mention that my steak frites was fresh and well cooked – the quality really showed.
Have a good look around the place, as there are plenty of different feeling points to sit. There are a couple of tables by the bar area that are very strongly akin to a pub. This would be your best port of call.
It’s difficult to picture what happens here on an evening, as to whether it evolves into a drinking destination, particularly as Leuven’s Oude Markt so clearly supplies many places for that. My suspicion, and this is the main drawback really, is that Domus has forgotten one of the clearest principles of a pub – making a hangout space for people who just want to pop by and have a pint. The inevitable consequence is a one paced, albeit very nice and cosy lunch, following into afternoon pub, that doesn’t have the feel of a venue with a clutch of locals flocking to it. Given a central brewery should be the epitome of such a place, you have to say that there is still much work to do

name: De Metafoor
description:
EBG Rating:: 8
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ****
Style/Décor: ****
Atmosphere/Character: ****
Amenities/Events: ***
Value For Money: ***
description: Leuven’s call to arms in terms of nightlife is the Oude Markt, a traditional Flemish square lined almost nose to tail with bars, and claiming (as many do) that it represents the biggest number of bars per square kilometre. Being a university town in Western Europe, the obligation to fulfil drinking and partying needs obviously has something to do with that.
While there’s clearly something to be said for the atmosphere on the Markt, the bars themselves don’t really stand out, and simply churn out a fairly familiar café bar feel, presumably as they have a captive audience and a slightly transient one at that.
The best pub I could find in Leuven was just off the Markt. Metafoor seems to have carved out a careful niche attracting the snoozy one-beer an hour chin stroking sorts that frequent brown cafes (ie. me), and offering a fairly friendly, upbeat space and mood that gives it the facility to change pace when the hordes of boozers arrive.
Although the bar is a pleasant place, there is itself a little further room for improvement, as I didn’t really feel the place was exploring a sense of identity enough, and still felt rather upright. Perhaps too much light comes in from the indoors during the day, and some of the homely pub qualities it could be taking on is lost. There is no doubt the place becomes packed during the evening as the bar area has that natural footfall type space that you can see has been hewn over the years.
The beer choice is selective, but very well chosen, with some interesting stuff on tap such as Rodenbach Grand Cru (does anyone still drink the standard stuff anymore when that exists?), some other ales on rotation and a modest but again well selected bottle menu. It’s Belgium, so we’re starting at a very good point anyway.
Leuven lies somewhere between large important feeling town and provinciality, and Metafoor is like the bar equivalent of that, with plenty of likable elements, and certainly a superior option even when taking Belgium in general. It would be remiss though not to point out the opportunities that are there for it to be even better.

name: Gostilna Sokol
description:
EBG Rating:: 7.5
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️
Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Value For Money: ❤️❤️❤️
description: While Gostilna Sokol falls down the Pivnice route of ‘not really a purely for drinking pub’, it’s almost impossible not to include it as the place to go for a drink (and a meal) in Ljubljana, being the most central institution in the city for both things. I still regard an ‘inn’ as qualifying for the purposes of this website, which is something Sokol certainly is.
A country tavern, with all that involves may feel out of place in a city centre, but it’s so enormous inside, room after room of tables, and so lacking in natural light that the lamps are lit all through the day. The end result is to block out nearly everything going on outside, while everything going on really does feel like a country venue. The use of space mean you are never really staring at anything that doesn’t look like it could be a pub room in the country.
Gostilnas exist to fill your stomach with huge plates of country cooking, and Sokol doesn’t disappoint on this score, with a large menu of hearty food, leaning towards casseroles, soups and marinades to further pep up the well sourced and well cooked meat and veg.
Slovenia might give some people out-dated images of war torn Balkan states, but best to dispel that image straight away. This place is an hour or so’s drive from Italy, the country is in the Eurozone and is a prosperous dynamic country brimming with natural advantages that independence has allowed them to wield to good effect. Prices correspond to this, and even more so given the city centre location. Sokol is not the place to go for good value, but at least delivers on its end of the bargain in terms of quality – the food is delicious. As our server said, “For you this is excellent, for us this is normal.”
There is a dedicated bar area, albeit a very small one, so don’t be disheartened if you only want a drink. As usual, it’s too small, but these are the cultural quirks you will find around Europe.
Sokol serves Union and Lasko, both pretty disappointing lagers (particularly Union, Ljubljana’s anonymous and pitiful contribution to brewing), and they do a house beer (read: brewed elsewhere with a label slapped on it), which must surely be worth a try given the paucity of options. Sadly Slovenia isn’t exactly brilliant for beer right now, and despite the proximity to Austria, and heritage in the old Austrian empire, doesn’t offer much to get excited about, even considering imports.
For this reason, the good food and hearty homely feel of an inn is crucial to a successful experience, and it is these elements, along with the history of the place that propel Sokol up the charts to being an essential Inn to stop off at for a meal and a drink.

name: Pivovar Svatý Florián
description:
EBG Rating:: 8
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ****
Style/Décor: ***
Atmosphere/Character: ****
Amenities/Events: ****
Value For Money: ****
description: The great thing about central Europe’s tradition of town brewing is that almost every visit to a new town allows you to try new beers. Capitalism and communism combined to crush these during the second half of the twentieth century, but now personal freedom and economic freedom has returned, it’s burgeoning again, with all sort of breweries. Minibreweries in hotels and restaurants, more serious concerns exporting their beers and competing in regional competitions. In Czechia they weren’t hit as hard as most, indeed their medium sized breweries have proved extraordinarily resilient considering the existential threats they faced. It’s clear both in Czechia and elsewhere that brewing is back, big time.
Sometimes a town brewery can help elevate an otherwise prosaic place in some subtle ways you wouldn’t think of. In Czechia many successful breweries are often located in rather anonymous towns you wouldn’t pay a visit to, but some, like Pivovar Svaty Florian, a microbrewery, just add the cherry on top of what is an already impressive place.
Loket is a hill town based on a sweeping peninusula, a large river surrounded by steep forested banks. The road down into town provides you with a spectacular scene, a dainty central European town capped off by a medieval castle perched on a rocky promontory.
The whole town is an ideal day trip from Karlovy Vary and although small, there’s plenty of enjoyment to be had with a castle visit, pacing the streets, the town ‘square’, and wandering around the perimeter.
Stop off for lunch at Pivovar Svaty Florian which offers a nice range of beers, made using some small batch equipment you will see at the far end of the cellar. It’s a serious concern rather than an afterthought, but I don’t know whether there is anyone on site itself doing the maintenance or the brewing, or whether they contract that aspect and sort the day-to-day stuff out themselves. The best of the brews by far is their delicious special beer, similar to a bock style, strong with fantastic blend of sweet and bitter. There was nothing wrong at all with the others, mind you.
The pub area is based on the spot of the malt house for Loket’s previous brewery, closed in the 1950s and is attached to a hotel. As you’d expect for a tourist spot, there is largely passing trade, and this pleasant enough cellar bar/restaurant provides a typical but not out of the ordinary spot for lunch or dinner, although if you stay in Loket for the night, please let me know where you went for a beer.
So, in response to the question ‘alright, so where do we go for a beer’ in your day trip to Loket, Svaty Florian supplies a decent cellar pivnice and pretty tasty beer. While nothing about it is mind-blowing, that doesn’t matter when you’re already in a place like Loket.

name: Św. Michał pub
description:
EBG Rating:: 7.6
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Value For Money: ❤️❤️❤️
description: On one of those cold Polish nights the draw to a warm, dark cosy pub is irresistible. Lublin’s old town provides a pocket-sized but decent array of options, varying from Czech-themed pubs, computer game pubs (a new idea), a Pivnice style cellar brewery, craft ale hideouts and the most pub like of all, Sw. Michal.
Being based on ul. Grodska ensures some steady passing trade, but Sw. Michal makes the slight error of marketing itself as a restaurant, when actually the venue most suits a pub, a meeting place where yes, food is consumed, but the general point should be to dive in from the cold, huddle around the fire and drink.
This will be apparent on your couple of steps up and swing through the door, being greeted by dark wood, portraits lining most available space on the wall, the roaring fire at the side of the room and the pub like bar area at the back. Take a glance up at the ceiling for a fabulous inset design and some vaulted beams.
Despite the efforts at traditionality, the place has clearly been recently fitted out, and there are some slightly tacky/modern concessions, but if they stick with it, the venue should age well. The dusky ambience inside, as well as the crackling fireplace gives it only one tempo. Slow and comfortable.
Sw. Michal offers a quirky take on pizza using Lublin’s own bread cebularz, which works well as a high-end take on deep pan pizza, and is pretty cheap. There are an array of other options and staff are pleasant and eager to please.
Sw. Michal does a couple of its ‘own’ beers, the best of which is a delicious semi-dark ale, and there are some reasonable other options, most of which are out of the standard Polish beer playbook.
Both food and drink are reasonably priced, both in terms of Poland in general versus the UK, and in comparison to its local competitors.
There are quite a few options to explore in Lublin’s old town and university area, so you may find time to go here only the once, but to me this place could become a classic local haunt if they stripped back some of the townier elements and make a few tweaks. There are some great raw materials here and it’s a very enjoyable place to go for a pub meal and a pint.
A: 7/10 B: 8/10 C: 7/10 D: 7/10 E: 8/10 F: 8/10

name: Bierwerk - charakterbierbar
description:
EBG Rating:: 8
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Value For Money: ❤️❤️❤️
description: Whatever you think of craft ale, good or bad, the evidence of visiting Bierwerk is that it’s extremely popular. Given the venue itself doesn’t offer anything in terms of décor or atmosphere beyond any other clean-lined generic bar, it’s interesting to have a dig in and explore why that is.
After all, Germany has some terrific traditional beers, and is in fact parochial and patrician about that fact. The reinheitsgebot even prevents them from making the kinds of beer craft ale thrives on (additional ingredients).
Could its popularity be simply down to sheeplike trend following? I went to Bierwerk in Nuremberg with this question in mind.
Although craft ale bars rely heavily on the quality of their output, I have been to quite a few that have extraordinarily dull choices and overrated drinks masquerading as trendy, luxury products. It’s just no-one of significance has called them out on it yet. Undoubtedly though, when they get the choice right and keep the beers well, they only require an inoffensive bar area and a reasonable atmosphere to make their bar worth a visit. They may never become as loveable as a trusted pub but they’re certainly eligible for a quality beer on a pub crawl.
Bierwerk fits this aspiration comfortably, as the beer choice is a sensible mixture of local and regional beer, craft ale from German breweries, and a few Belgian, Czech beer, English and US beers. It speaks of a holistic and meritorious approach rather than a slavish obsession with US craft brewing. It was also fortunate as for my visit I drank the most delicious dunkelweizen I’ve had for a long time, which made me extremely happy.
Certainly for the wealth of choice and quality of beer available, Bierwerk will not disappoint. As mentioned, it’s thronged with locals, especially in the evenings. There’s even decent (ie. non-contemporary chart) music. However, when you look around, you won’t find anything notable about the décor or the format, nor is it especially comfortable which is a great shame as it inherently limits how highly I can rate the place. When you have gone to the trouble of putting so much great product together why build such a generic and featureless place to drink it in? Look at the name of the place!
There is a stunted ambition borne from trying to mistakenly copy elements of craft beer bars that aren’t why people visit. No-one goes to a craft ale bar for the exposed industrial chic unless it is in such a dramatic or tasteful setting as to make it actually stand out. People are here for the beer. The beer is excellent – meaning you have absolute freedom to make the bar in any shape or form you desire, so as to elevate the venue even further. They haven’t managed that, which is a real shame, but the beer is excellent, really, really excellent.

name: Hausbrauerei Altstadthof
description:
EBG Rating:: 7.9
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️
Value For Money: ❤️❤️❤️
description: A German city without a centrally located brewery would be a sad thing indeed. Nuremberg’s centre is divided up between north and south of the river. The North side is the historical and cultural centre, while the south side, still pretty and smart, is mainly taken up with the everyday shopping streets. Bar Fuesser is situated here and provides the traditional German Bierkeller experience, as well as brewing its own stuff on tap.
Until recently the historical centre on the North side had no operating brewery, until Altstadthof came along. The brewery have taken up residence in a mini-complex, bigger than it first appears but certainly compact, on the street leading up to Albrecht Durer’s house and what seems to be the natural focal point of the city. There is a certain strategic advantage to this, picking up touristic footfall as the hordes make the pilgrimage past the attractive fachwerk houses and up the hill to the castle. The question is, have they made a pub or bar that locals actually go to?
Altstadthof isn’t exactly in prime location if you’re a local, but the general answer is yes. You’ll find a core crowd congregating around the bar and the shelf lining the wall, while the bench seats seem to be a mixture of business groups, romantic couples and the odd group of youngsters.
The biggest surprise is that the pub is so small, as for a brewery in a city the size of Nuremberg, you would expect at least an upstairs area, but no, it’s just the main room which for now appears to be doing its duty.
They have made an intelligent choice to kit the place out in traditional fashion with sturdy bench seats, studded leather upholstery, wooden beams and some tasteful decoration. It still has that ‘new’ feel, but has character and it will develop further character over time.
As for the beer, well, that’s another reason the pub is included, as their range is all very decent. You can enjoy bock and rotbier on tap, something not commonly available everywhere, and both are delicious. Their core range starts at good and peaks at really good. There’s nothing to worry about drinks wise here other than the overly lively tapping, whereby the by-now jaded bar staff scoop the mounds of foam off the beers, usually taking 2 or 3 glasses just to fill a 0.4l serving. This inevitably takes time, making your wait beyond Guinness level to the point that where your drink eventually arrives, you’re gagging for it.
There’s a really friendly and surprisingly low-key feel to an evening in here. It feels communal, it is literally a pub, rather than a brasserie or brewery tap, and they’ve succeeded in making a vital addition to pubgoing in Nuremberg.

name: Kater Murr
description:
EBG Rating:: 7.5
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Value For Money: ❤️❤️❤️
description: Once you subtract the traditional beer halls and craft beer bars it’s interesting to wonder where the alternative spaces are in Nuremberg. I was put onto this place by a guy from Maine called Luke who was running the craft ale bar Mr Kennedy’s and given the quality of the stout I had just drunk, he seemed like a decent enough judge.
Kater Murr is a backstreet kind of place that you’d never know about if you didn’t live here, as there’s not enough of a presence when doing research online for it to ever stand out. With my map and gps on I slowly arced left around an unlit backstreet wondering where the hell it was taking me, until Kater Murr’s doorway appeared.
The venue is relatively bright for an evening visit, as it doubles as a quiet studenty café and reading spot by day. When you walk in there is a large rectangular space with light wooden seating lining the walls and large windows with books and games stacked on the ledges. It’s busy but not so bad that you can’t find a table or a bar stool, and large enough that no-one will stare at you for walking in alone, or even in a group.
The drinks selection is pretty good for a so-called café (it’s a bar) with typical Franconian beers and some more unusual bottles including craft ale representation. Even better is the price, bargain basement for German standards, and I picked up a 500ml bock beer for 2 euros 50 cents.
You can’t bottle the sort of vitality imbued in a place when it’s clearly at the peak of its lifespan, which Kater Murr clearly is. Often a place can start to look a little tired and passe once its glory years have passed but Kater Murr doesn’t have to worry about that just yet. There are plenty of amenities, food, games, books, live music and community events which all count in its favour and maintain its reason for being.
I really liked the space and the atmosphere and couldn’t really suggest too many improvements, other than perhaps a few more decorations on the walls, and a more pubby feeling bar area. Find some time to squeeze in Kater Murr during your visit to Nuremberg.

name: Pivovarský šenk Na Parkánu
description:
EBG Rating:: 8
Choice/Quality of Drinks: *****
Style/Décor: ****
Atmosphere/Character: ***
Amenities/Events: ****
Value For Money: ****
description: Drink unfiltered unpasteurised Pilsner Urquell delivered in barrels via horse and cart from Plzensky Prazdroj brewery up the road.
It doesn’t get much better than that for beer drinking, and despite the relative expense (cost being £1.50 rather than £1 which is the usual price for a beer in Czechia) it still represents extraordinary good value by any Western measure for supping the nicest beer going.
The horse and cart service also goes around 8 other Pilsner Urquell pubs in Plzen, but Na Parkanu is really the cultural epicentre, also including an adjoining brewing museum which is brief, poorly marked and a tad disappointing, although naturally comes with a pint thrown in.
Na Parkanu itself is a fairly modern Pivnice, with some nice traditional features and a few little quirky concessions, along with reliable, absolutely conventional Czech food. You can sit down and just have a beer anywhere, much in the way you can at a chain pub in England, but there is a dedicated bar area too with the predictable footy and hockey memorabilia and sport on TV.
In the main, Na Parkanu is a fairly by-the-by venue and in local terms a tad expensive by virtue of self-awareness of its own importance.
Why the fuss then?
It serves a special beer that is vanishingly difficult to obtain in unfiltered form, and there is always a tinge of excitement at the prospect of drinking at the ‘place to be’. That’s enough in itself on this occasion, as the venue doesn’t really have any weak points other than failing to fulfil my desire for it to be wonderfully old historic and traditional, which is hardly its fault. Basically, a trip to Plzen that doesn’t include a pint of unfiltered PU at Na Parkanu would feel strangely hollow and lacking.This is something that I and the Google reviewers seem to agree on.
If you want to step out of the sameyness, try some of the intimidating looking ‘food to go with beer’ options on the menu, and wash it down with the gorgeous beer - you’ll soon be transported into a fatty, gristly, and delicious world of true Czech pub going – halitosis central but very satisfying at the time.

name: Proletaryat
description:
EBG Rating:: 8
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ****
Style/Décor: ****
Atmosphere/Character: ****
Amenities/Events: ***
Value For Money: ****
description: https://theeuropeanbarguide.com/2018/10/28/proletaryat-poznan/

Soviet-themed bars have quickly become a staple part of the Eastern European bar scene. It must be due to the tonnes of old communist bric-a-brac that has been purloined from flea markets over the years. It’s remarkable how quickly this ephemera has been regurgitated, often in an apolitical way. Now, shorn of the memory of state repression, paranoia and hardship much of the era’s junk has been re-purposed and exhibited, capturing people’s nostalgic fondness for the idealism, optimism as well as the iconography of the era. Ideal for adorning a moody Polish bar so as this one in Poznań.

Proletaryat isn’t exactly lined with volumes of Das Kapital; instead you’ll note a large bust of Lenin staring at you out on the street. Enter to find a display of fairly impressive social realist paintings, disproportionately large portraits of Lenin and Marx, hung in front of rich crimson paint, with emblems and military insignia thrown in. The central bar area also expands further into an interesting looking terrace-style back room where the cool kids hang out, that seems a little separated from the central premise.

There may be a vague leftist feel to the crowd here (perhaps its just the students) but in the main it does seem to be led by decoration rather than a hotbed of any political grouping.


That said, the decoration is impressive nonetheless, it’s a very stylish place to go for a drink, without being particularly pretentious. The crimson and lamplight works well for a shady atmospheric slow sup, while at night it gets more raucous and one of those truly buzzing city centre bars where the lack of space and abundance of booze creates its own head of steam. This is a great example of decoration that allows a venue to work well in different ways at different times.

The location down one of the main city centre streets means it feels in the middle of the action – which in Poznan is pretty bloody active. You can expect to witness the type of revelry usually preserved for English city centres on an evening. It was quite an eye-opener, but I had previously been warned about it by some Poznanites (Poznanians?) during a separate trip to Wroclaw (another excellent city). The levity doesn’t emerge from English stag parties or boys-on-tour either – in Poznan it’s mainly locals doing their homespun thing. Wodka i piwo can be a dangerous combo.

Aside of the tongue-in-cheek atmosphere, Proletaryat offers its ‘own’ beer as well (from what I can gathered, this is brewed elsewhere at Browar Czarnków and labelled accordingly), which is cheap even by Polish standards nowadays. The jasne (light) and ciemne (dark) beers are both fresh and well balanced. Not the finest ever brewed but tasty certainly and designed to knock back in volume. Apparently the vodka is served with a pickle here if you are interested in going native.

Any pub crawl around Poznań would be improved by a stop off at Proletaryat, as despite the increasingly familiar concept of the Soviet-themed bar, a good concept doesn’t stop being good just on account of its familiarity. Besides, they do a decent job of and it feels like its own thing rather than a cookie-cutter version or a clone-bar. If you haven’t been to one of these type of places before, then go at least once for the novelty value. If you already have and enjoyed it, then this bar is not to be missed!

name: U Slovanské Lípy
description:
EBG Rating:: 7.5
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️
Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️
Value For Money: ❤️❤️❤️
description: Zizkov is an area of Prague usually associated with grungy alternative bars, perhaps unfairly, as it is so large and brimming with drinking holes it should just be associated for ‘pubs and bars generally’.

U Slovanske Lipy is proof enough that there is more to it than that, a beer hall with a surprisingly delicate and genteel edge, appropriate for summer drinking (despite being entirely indoors) as well as roaring fires on a winter evening.

The bohemian script on the sign outside with the very common green background is a reasonable indicator of the traditional interior, and you can rest assured before your visit that all involved in the making of this pub have a command and mastery of what they’re doing. As you often find, there is a tapster area but unlike some pubs this is only usually used during busy periods, and the tapster is otherwise obliged to (shock-horror) actually engage with the general public.

You’ll find around 8-12 beers on tap, usually a choice mature selection of regional Czech ales, one or two short term German or Polish kegs and a desitka lager should anyone simply want to get down to business. The beer is excellent, offering genuine competition to the usual big beers, but look out for some rarer microbrews from across the country including their connection at Kostenec nad Cernymi Lesy.

It all sounds great so far, but sadly the restaurant aspect of the pub and the choice of furnishings does somewhat detract from the pub feel, and it never really strikes a comfortable balance, teetering between dedicated lunch and evening meal spot and drinking hole. They ideally want you to eat a full meal then hang around downing a series of glasses, but in reality there’s too much going on in Zizkov, let alone Prague in general for that to be a judicious use of time. This is a frequent problem with Czech pubgoing, the blurring between dining and boozing.

It depends which night you come and which crowds are in. Sometimes it is full of dedicated drinkers (the best time to come) other times you might feel slightly, just slightly out on a limb sitting there with only a pint.

There is a beauty to the simple stylings of the place as well as the beer selections which invite further inspection. The food is purportedly pretty good by any local standards. It stands to reason that this is a venue to merit serious consideration as you plan your choices of pub crawl/lunch from the many hundreds (yes, hundreds) of viable options around Prague. (Added 2017)

name: U Vejvodů
description:
EBG Rating:: 7.6
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️
Value For Money: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
description: Any serious beer drinker’s first trip to Prague will almost certainly involve a pub crawl of the old town area, where the majority of the best venues are traditional Czech beer halls selling the holy grail: unpasteurised Pilsner Urquell poured direct from the tank, with a formidable wall of head occupying a third of the glass, obstructing your path to the beautiful beer below but keeping the beer fresh and adding aroma and texture.

U Vejvodu has a lot of the characteristics that captured my imagination on my first visit.

In addition to what seems to be a nicely sized pub area in the front room, and a number of alcoves to sit and plot over a pint, venture even further down the stairs to discover an enormous - cavernous even - historical cellar, with a giant curved roof and a skylight. When you’ve stood outside the place and inspected the tiny pub entrance, and the oblique surrounding buildings it appears at first impossible to conceive such a space would be downstairs.

It’s also a restaurant and there is a dining area, but this place at least couldn’t be clearer of its core purpose – it’s an enormous beer hall.

Be Warned: If you decide to eat this pub is notorious for sharp practise such as 'couvert charges', with bread and condiments added to your bill even if you ask for it without, and attempts by staff to cleave tips which is not practise in Prague.

We recommend sticking to beer, which is very reasonably priced for the city centre, and you won't be expected to tip for a round or two.

The raw materials of this pub speak for themselves. If you like your impressive beer hall surroundings, a great pub atmosphere and quality Czech lager, there's a very good chance you'll enjoy yourself at U Vejvodu.

It’s a classic Prague beer hall. (Added 2017)

name: U Medvídků
description:
EBG Rating:: 7.5
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️
Value For Money: ❤️❤️❤️
description: The old town in Prague may be saturated with tourists, but regardless of that, certain traditions remain. The Pivnice is a format that tourism can’t change, and U Medvidku is another venue that delivers on that promised format, adding a little something extra in the process.
Yes, there’s cream walls, curved ceilings, wooden bench seatings and that sense of institutionalised grandeur even in the mere size of the building itself. If you’re seeking out that Prague pub atmosphere, you won’t go wrong coming here.
The tap beer in Medvidku, surprisingly, is a Budvar rather than Pilsner Urquell, a reasonably rare sight around the city. It’s pristine, as you’d expect, but look further around the place, have a wander. There’s more than meets the eye.
There’s a pub within a pub serving their own brewed beer Old Gott, a special beer (similar to a German bock) of hefty strength but masses of flavour. Depending on the season they will usually be brewing one or two others, so don’t miss the chance to try a glass of something else as well as the Bud.
Make sure to explore the premises and take your seat in the place that most fits your needs, be that a quick dive in through the front for a pint, or a meal in the pivnice or a secret glass of the good stuff upstairs in the ante room. There’s plenty to U Medvidku and I must confess even I don’t feel like I’ve truly explored it.
U Medvidku has okay reviews, partly on account of some ridiculous expectations of absolute dweebs that come to Prague but comes highly recommended from the beer drinking and pub going fraternity and for good reason, none other than Pivni Filosof Max Bahnson has included it in his list of Prague Pub Crawls and I echo that. (Founder Member 2017)

name: Pivnice U Rudolfina
description:
EBG Rating:: 7.5
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️
Value For Money: ❤️❤️❤️
description: If you were to draw a Czech Pivnice from a blank piece of paper (and had the requisite knowledge and talent), it would in nearly every way look like U Rudolfina. The layout, the fixtures, the fittings, the beer, the style of service, all correspond to an archetype of traditional Czech pub going.
I think U Rudolfina knows this quite well, and fortunately for all concerned, has no intentions of changing.
Walking through the door brings you to the pub area, designed purely for stop-off drinking, a kind of glass and be-on-your-way kind of thing. This smallish area attracts a host of locals and tends to put off tourists who prefer to dive straight down to the cellar.True, the bar part of the pub gives you only a sliver of the experience but it’s a really good one.
This is another of the Pilsner Urquell tankovna pubs and they take a real care and pride at keeping it at pristine quality. There’s something you can sense just from observing the glacial smoothness of the foam on a head of a jar of Pilsner Urquell that sends off all the right signals that you’re about to enjoy a very good pint.
By the limited parameters of Czech customer service, it’s actually fairly friendly in here. Eye contact, a mutual acknowledgement of each other’s humanity, and on occasion I’ve found almost a sense of satisfaction at delivering the good stuff to the table, in that stodgy matter of fact manner, yes, but you take every victory you can get. Prices are just a little inflated but that extra 20 pence a jar won’t hurt British wallets.
As for the Pivnice, you couldn’t say fairer than the fare offered here. Straight down the line Czech dishes, a roll call of the 6-8 dishes you could probably find at every Czech restaurant in the country, made to a very enjoyable if not absolutely distinctive standard, something underlined by the reviews online even those by hardened idiots.
If you’re alone, stick to the bar area and hang out with the locals. If you’re in a group dive downstairs and get drinking and dining post-haste in a cellar area brimming with all the history and good cheer you would expect from a Czech pivnice. This is core Czech pub territory.

name: Runcis
description:
EBG Rating:: 7.5
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Value For Money: ❤️❤️❤️
description: Runcis makes a refreshing change from the usual Riga old town scene. With a name translating to ‘Tomcat’, you’d be forgiven for interpreting the wrong kind of signals, but don’t worry, it’s no dodgy gentleman’s club, nor a stag-party venue, this unassuming bar is hidden away in a courtyard minding its own business.
Runcis is happy being a very low key meeting place, with an atmosphere similar to a pub. The plain decor and simple functional furniture couldn’t indicate clearer your reason to be here. Whether it’s to read a book, play board games or discuss issues over a pint or two, Runcis shows a truer side to contemporary Latvia.
However, like a lot of true Latvian pubs it’s also open late, until 2am most nights, making Runcis a great option to have in your back pocket for a late drink if the seedier bars don’t appeal. There are also a few bench seats in the courtyard which is a really pleasant place for a drink in spring/summer.
This isn’t to say the atmosphere is non-existent by any means. There is a pleasant feel to hanging out here, and some good music too. It does become lively when it is busy, but it is the hubbub of conversation, rather than thumping bass or laddishness that provides the soundtrack.
There are 4 or 5 tapped beer options, mostly of a local slant which are of varying quality and compared to most old town venues they are sold at a snip, so cheap in fact that you feel a bit of a skinflint complaining over the incompetently uneven heads on the beers poured.
Runcis isn’t going to take your breath away, but it’s a vital inclusion both in its style and situation, and comes highly recommend to anyone not in Riga to thunderdown steins of Aldaris with large groups of lads while thinking of hilarious forfeits.

name: Sarajevo Brewery & Pub
description:
EBG Rating:: 7.8
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️
Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Value For Money: ❤️❤️❤️
description: The best traditional brewery in the Balkans, so a visit to Sarajevo’s central brewery is essential, almost regardless of the externalities.
Sarajevsko lager would be anonymous were it sold in England or Germany but it just shows the paucity of real options in the former Yugoslav states that such a beer manages to stand out. There’s no point being too sniffy about it though, it’s not a bad beer by any means, especially if you can drink the tank stuff which gets sent across the city, or if you visit the brewery itself, where the best tasting Sarajevsko can be found.
The brewery is located close to the centre, so can be joined on to any pub crawl near the old town fairly easily. The building sticks out like a sore thumb, as it was a concern of the Austro-Hungarian empire, so you won’t have any trouble finding it, but even if you do, the enormous backlit sign will guide you there.
Over time the locals have grown an attachment to it, having gradually appreciated it to be an asset and a source of jobs rather than grumbling about it being some imperial vestige (astonishingly some people still have a problem despite the Empire ceasing to exist over a century ago)
Once you arrive, keep heading through the doors in order to find another shock, as the pivnica inside is a grand beer hall with a theatrical shape, a central area surrounded by balcony levels. This isn’t some modest pale imitation of another country, it would be impressive were it in Munich or Vienna. Opulent would be the word. Take a seat and before long one of the ambling rotund servers will approach. ‘Pivo molim’ if you’re on your own, ‘piva molim’ if you’re in a group.
The beers are served in sturdy dimpled mugs and are fresh as you’re ever likely to get. The ‘tamno’ dark larger is much more generic, and probably best avoided out of winter unless you’re trying to increase your count on Untappd. Sources reveal they are bringing out an unfiltered larger which is something I’d encourage anyone to try straight away.
As it’s such a large venue, it does require the patronage of large groups to build the atmosphere. It has a sense that it isn’t ever busier than ‘ticking over’, but neither does it feel particularly abandoned. There’s a pleasant atmosphere as the disparate conversations bounce across the room. Take a moment to explore the bar area and the upstairs, as it really is a grand place.
The beer won’t set you back more a few Bosnian marks, so there’s no impediment to staying here for the duration and getting sloshed.
Keep an eye out for the museum and lunch deal, if you’re coming during the day, which at 12 euros 50 represents pretty good value.
It’s always interesting seeing attempts to transplant one culture into another, and this Pivnica allows you to experience this AND go to the pub. A slight improvement to the beer and the atmosphere aside, it’s fascinating, brilliant and comes highly recommend.

name: Valhalla Pub
description:
EBG Rating:: 7.5
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️
Value For Money: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
description: Drinking small town style isn’t so bad in Western Europe – there is nearly always somewhere to go. Despite the reputation for hard drinking, many Eastern spots can be frustratingly sleepy and eager to shut early. Sigulda in Latvia reduced late night drinking options substantially to the point where we were having to visit hotel bars in the early evening, and even considering visiting a Casino on the edge of town.
Thankfully, the Kaku Maja complex (now upgraded to Valhalla) saved us from what would otherwise have been some very drab nights out. Part hotel, part apartments, part restaurant, part buffet, part everything, it’s like someone trying to create a global conglomerate entirely within their back garden.
Rebranded Valhalla, this place offers an updated offering from the homely hangout that preceded it. There are plenty of facilities in the complex and nearby which mean it deserves props for trying 
The beer choices aren’t terrible, with the usual Aldaris, Piebalgus being a weird outlier, and the schwarzbier Mezpils which has quite stylish branding and is a reasonably tasty dark ale. Prices are pretty cheap though nowhere near the kind of prices some Westerners think it is like in Latvia. The euro is in and those times have gone. Nevertheless, paying between a few euros for a beer isn’t going to hurt.
The place stays open til 11-12 at night which isn’t ideal, and once that has happened it’s either a trip to the casino, or bed/drinking at home after that.
It’s an essential drinking base if staying in Sigulda, particularly if you aren’t driving, so make yourself at home, have a few games of pool and sit back and relax, which is generally the point of being in Sigulda to start with. (Added 2017)

name: Tommis Pub
description:
EBG Rating:: 7.5
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Value For Money: ❤️❤️❤️
description: Not all drinking in Germany takes place in enormous beer halls, in fact many who favour a simple drink avoid them as the restaurant dining and open plan format don’t serve the purpose as well. Similarly, you don’t get the flavour of local life in quite the same way, for all the great things about them.
To find out what’s going on locally find a Kneipe, where the average German heads in the evening for a beer and a chat. These are very close in style to an English pub, usually beamed, traditionally styled and cosy, though they also tend to be distinctly more working class in feel and far less concerned about décor or fripperies.
Tommis Pub is a classic example. Wernigerode is the centre of operations for any holiday in the Harz region and as with most German towns it has its own brauhaus. There’s nothing wrong with the brauhaus per se. The service is good, beer is reasonably good and there’s been plenty of money spent. It just fails almost altogether to conjure up any character or local life.
In order to experience that, get down to Tommis, a busy dark wood beamed pub with that typical country town atmosphere, lively and chatty, and rather smokey still. It could hardly be less pretentious – the beers are sturdy Harz offerings (the best of which is a delicious schwarzbier) for reasonable prices, there’s sport on telly in the corner, the crowd around the place are gregarious, and the low ceilings, lack of windows and narrow shape give that nice reassurringly cosy feel that invites you to stay for another one.
It’s also right next to Wernigerode’s dramatic town square which makes it ideal for a bleary-eyed wander when you stumble out of the pub at kicking out time. A true kneipe.

name: Pivnica-Medvedgrad
description:
EBG Rating:: 8
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ***
Style/Décor: ****
Atmosphere/Character: ****
Amenities/Events: ***
Value For Money: ***
description: http://theeuropeanbarguide.com/2018/06/04/pivnica-mali-medo-zagreb/

The ‘Little Bear’ is located in the centre of Zagreb’s old town and offers by far the best example of a pub around these environs. Otherwise, your options are identikit café terraces or the odd raucous rakija bar. To be honest, a night out spent solely Zagreb’s old town would be pretty bland unless you dedicated yourself to drinking shots, or visited this place.

Mali Medo acts as brewery tap for Pivovara Medvedgrad (translates as Beartown), named after an old fortress in the hills North of the city which has undergone a rather appalling renovation, but is worth seeking out for the view over the city.

The brewery, operating since 1994 precedes the craft beer craze and concocts a range of different beers – including their own attempt at Kriek – highly peculiar by Croatian standards where anything outside Euro Lager seems to be regarded as otherworldly. Their beers aren’t unpleasant but they’re some way short of the wider standard these days and a bit ‘last generation’. Nevertheless, a couple of the more traditional styles are competent enough to put away a few of, and the extra flavour and freshness will come as a relief after drinking the likes of Karlovacko everywhere else.

They operate a number of pubs, but the best of the lot is, in my opinion Mali Medo in the centre of town.

The pub itself has a typical pivnica look, dropping down off the main cobbled street to a large half-basement area with a curved ceiling, and some partitioned niches with bench seating (one of my favourite pub features) along with the typical long tables you’d expect of a central European cellar pub. Mostly, the décor is in-keeping with inn-keeping, wooden framed artwork on the wall, and traditional furniture, a step above bland. It’s suitably cavernous in order to cram in the many hundreds of people who flock to it daily – worth a reminder at this stage that it is the number one venue slap bang in the centre of town.


As there is a beer terrace out front with much coming and going the atmosphere is very noisy and lively, sometimes pierced by live music performances. The upstairs area serves as a stage, with performers opening the windows to serenade people on the street. Very unusual and atmospheric. You get the picture that this is one of the cultural hubs of the city. Be warned, if you’re after peace and quiet, this isn’t the place for you.

As with most pivnicas there is food available. Sometimes this can turn a place too much like a restaurant, but here it blends in with people turning up for a drink of beer better than some others, and as the evening progresses you can tell this is chiefly a drinking spot – good.

Considering the hustle and bustle, service is actually not too bad until it comes to the point of paying, where you almost have to grab the staff by the lapels and shove the money into their pockets. As per usual, table service slows up the whole arrangement. This is a very inefficient method when you compare it to those mega-brauhauses in Germany and Austria where a tapster and a token system means hundreds can be catered for by just a few people, or simply an English pub with a big bar where you can walk up to the bar staff and order – sort yourself out rather than relying on others to carry a glass for you. Unfortunately in Eastern Europe there appears to be an unwritten rule that one must never ever approach the person pouring the beer, or expect them to be able to operate a till.

Any place, city, town or village automatically feels enhanced by a centrally located brewery and/or its taproom, and this is certainly the effect Mali Medo has had on Zagreb old town. There is some work to do on the beers themselves, and it would be nice to see a few more pub touches, just slightly, to add character. It wouldn’t be an 8/10 unless there was some constructive criticism to encourage improvements. Aside of this, it still remains an essential, indeed desperately vital place to go for a beer in Zagreb.

name: The Red Lion Inn
description:
EBG Rating:: 7.5
