Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️
Value For Money: ❤️❤️❤️
description: Alternative, if slightly twee Russian themed café bar, with a pub style open-bar top. A friendly neighbourly feel with kind service. Vodka and vermouth are its specialities but it does some decent beer too. Think of it as a local and it all makes sense.

name: Retro Pivnice
description:
EBG Rating:: 8
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Value For Money: ❤️❤️❤️
description: Interesting retro interior set in a basement series of room. 10 high quality beer taps with rotating guest options. Younger crowd than at a traditional hospoda. Feels relevant still. (Added 2017)

name: Metafora
description:
EBG Rating:: 8
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️
Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️
Value For Money: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
description: A strong all-rounder. Great views of the square and framed artwork of the city add some atmosphere. The layout retains a city tavern type feel, and it is suitable for only drinking, though food is available. (Added 2019)

name: Kirkstall Brewery Taproom
description:
EBG Rating:: 7.8
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️
Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Value For Money: ❤️❤️
description: An odd, yet effective clash of breweriana, old wooden fittings and chandeliers, with exposed concrete ceilings, metal stanchions and pipes. It just kind of works. Most of Kirkstall Brewery's best stuff is available on tap from the source. A little expensive given all the beer is made rate here, but it is an effective venue and practical meeting point, which helps stitch the city centre and Burley area pubs together. (Added 2021)

name: Rundes Eck Raucherkneipe
description:
EBG Rating:: 8.1
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️
Value For Money: ❤️❤️❤️
description: An absolutely fab traditional kneipe with individual touches. Low ceiling, wooden cabinets, curtains, lamplight. Smokey. Local Life. Beer options may be limited but it truly compensates. Smoking permitted. (Added 2019)

name: Zum Batzewert
description:
EBG Rating:: 7.8
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Value For Money: ❤️❤️❤️
description: A strong all-rounder, this place is the oldest pub in the city. The seating plan does a lot with very little, and allows space for both drinking and to a small extent dining. The bar taps have a distinctive 'bell jar' style decoration and there are some impressively large works of art around the place, interspersed with retro signage. In summary: a really good town kneipe. (Added 2019)

name: Weißer Holunder
description:
EBG Rating:: 8.2
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Value For Money: ❤️❤️❤️
description: A neighbourhood boozer with a strong 1960s aesthetic among trad wooden fixtures and fittings. Atmospheric with patient service and a mixed crowd. Jukebox, pool table and simple pub food complete a reasonable range of amenities. Worth the walk from the old town.

name: Poslední Leč
description:
EBG Rating:: 8.6
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️
Limited but good Czech lagers on tap. Basic array of mixers, wines and liqueurs on offer also.

Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Faded grandeur with wooden fixtures, dusty and cobwebby radiator grills, deathtrap spiral staircase to the toilets, and bizarre upside down relief carving attached to the ceiling. Chess boards on the tables. Mezzanine back room. Stained glass frontage with pub accessible by the theatre door.

Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️
Brooding and inert when quiet, raucous and verging on edgy at the peak of the evening. Convivial and engaging space in between then.

Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️
Very late opening hours by Czech standards.

Value For Money: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Fair

description: Initially tricky to find the front door, but when in it's a traditional, rickety pub really close to the centre. Interesting decor like stained glass from the outside and an upside down relief of the town centre make it distinctive as well as atmospheric. We upgraded it to 9/10. (Added 2018)

name: U zlatého tygra
description:
EBG Rating:: 8.7
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Pilsner Urquell on tap and nothing else except a small range of wines and Eastern European liqueurs.

Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Czech Pivnice with curved ceiling, bench seating and simple wooden tables in communal layout. Small backrooms. Tiger ephemera and tributes to former patron Bohumil Hrabal.

Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️
Superb from opening time to closing. Sociable, chatty, communal, democratic.

Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️
Food, table reservations

Value For Money: ❤️❤️❤️
Reasonable for the area and given the fame of the establishment.

description: Anyone with a mild interest in the European bar scene or the city of Prague will no doubt have heard about the institution U Zlateho Tygra, a traditional preserved Czech pub slap-bang in the old town, famous for welcoming political dignitaries, scholars and celebrities over the years.
Reading about the pub’s stories and seeing Bill Clinton and the like tucking into goulash and dumplings may generate a degree of excitement. Not to dampen the fires too much, but I think it would be best if I was realistic about the good – and the bad – aspects of U Zlateho Tygra.
The good stuff first – the design and layout is an archetypal Czech pub with wooden tables and panels along the wall, curved cream-coloured walls and the odd framed photograph touching on most of the key themes of the pub – tigers, literary figures and Pilsner Urquell. You’ll find a tapster working the taps almost non-stop. At some quieter places the tapster can be at a loose end but this is one of those places that is so busy it looks like extremely hard work.
The beer itself is a standard, non-mickey taking price when you consider the old town mean average and arrives without your say so, as does a second and a third (unless you make a point of putting the mat over your drink). If you turn up thirsty you could easily find yourself processing several Pilsners in short order.
There’s a gregarious excitable atmosphere inside, and it really does feel like the place to be.
Now the bad stuff. You may or may not be aware that Czech pubs allow reservations, meaning turning up at some places on spec can result in disappointment. At U Zlateho Tygra you may as well forget even trying to turn up in the evening unless you have reserved your spot in advance. When you get in it will feel like a private member’s club where you need to stay all evening to get full value for the exclusivety. Don’t despair though, as there is a way in. Turn up at 2.50pm, join the queue, and if you’re in the front 30 or so you should be assured of a seat unless you’re in a large group. If you see people pushing in at the front then choose whatever retribution you see fit.
This may not be a concern for you, but I feel a duty to point out that U Zlateho Tygra’s main appeal is that of a minimalist down-to-earth Czech pub. That down-to-earth feel is detracted from when you queue up to get in then upon entering find yourself boozing among multinationals. And for those expecting anything spectacular in terms of décor, they may be even further disappointed, as even though there is some nice stained glass and a sturdy venerable feel, it’s hardly La Sagrada Familia.
In order to have the best time at U Zlateho Tygra, work out when you’d prefer to go, and if that’s after 3.15pm book a table in advance. Come for a flavour of Czech drinking at its best, and try not to focus too much on the externalities. You’re here for a good time, and everyone else is. Don’t expect much from the server other than a conveyor belt of Pilsner Urquell and a food order.
It’s not somewhere I would choose to go every week and there are places to go for a similar experience without the hype and tourism, but there’s no doubt it has a certain sprinkling of magic, and unlike me you may be lucky enough to try it on different dates and times of day to work out when to absorb the most local flavour. As hackneyed as it is to say, you can’t really miss out this pub.

name: Robins and Keller #Currently Closed#
description:
EBG Rating:: 8.5
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Cask ales from limited arrange of quantity over quality breweries and their own occasionally successful mini-brewery. Keg options recently introduced. Small range of spirits and mixers.

Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️
Cluttered and characterful. Candlelight, tarred beams, horse brasses, framed photos and every available space used. A one off. An old gunsmith's workshop.

Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Brooding, yet reasonably lively with the immediate street facing frontage inviting incomers and outgoers. 

Amenities/Events: ❤️
Minimal. Snacks.

Value For Money: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Good

description: Low ceiling and clutter with a vague olde worlde theme, based on the fact the venue was an old gunsmiths. Small conversation filled bar area and candlelit at night. Very atmospheric. Be warned that the owners are Covid conspiracists and some remnants of their agenda pushing can still be spotted inside. (Added August 2023)

name: Domkeller
description:
EBG Rating:: 9
Choice/Quality of Drinks: Range of tapped German beers covering several bases well. Bottled Belgian beers available which is a rarity for Germany. Typical back bar selection of mixers, spirits, whiskies covered.
Style/Décor: Kneipe with stools and bench seats by the bar and chunkier furniture in the niche opposite. Different feel upstairs and in the small performance area to the right of the bar. Lantern lighting and bunker like.
Atmosphere/Character: Local life and a passing trade mixing well together. Lively and friendly
Amenities/Events: Live music, courtyard seating, possible to bring food in to eat with drinks.
Value For Money: Mediocre
description: Cosy kneipe with plenty of seating. You can bring food in, and there's a friendly local atmosphere. Several Belgian beers available in addition to a handsome range of trad German styles on tap. Easy to make friends, and comfortable enough that it doesn't matter if you don't. A true pub in that sense. An upstairs plays host to live music.

name: Élesztő
description:
EBG Rating:: 8.2
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Multitap Hungarian craft beer offerings. Limited back bar selection but covering the important bases.

Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Central courtyard with tall plants, bench seating and screens with darker industrial chic rooms 

Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Modern, slightly hipster, casual, relaxed, sometimes lively when music is on later in the day.

Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Street food, Djs, TV screens, outdoor seating

Value For Money: ❤️❤️
Mediocre

description: Eleszto is the best possible combination of the ruin-pub and craft beer scene, offering an open plan, relaxed atrium and garden area in semi-industrial surroundings, while focusing drinks options on vastly improved Hungarian small-batch brewing which has vaulted the not exactly difficult task of being effortlessly better than macro-brewed Hungarian lager. They even claim to be the first bar offering cask ale in Europe, which is patently rubbish, but nevertheless is a welcome acknowledgement of the quality of cask brewing, sometimes overlooked by keg obsessed craft brewers.
As with many ruin pubs the place has a great number of amenities and is so open plan and relaxed you can make more or less anything socially you want out of it. Lunch spot? Yes. Relax with a book. Yes. Beer tastings at the bar? Yes. Live sports? Yes. Club. Yes.
There are certain places that try and combine these things horrendously unsuccessfully, so I hope I can allay your fears in this respect. Each utility has its own place, and its unlikely you will ever feel any aspect of the place oppressive.
The painted black industrial feel works well combined with the greenery, and although it is nowhere near as unique and quirky as many ruin pubs, on a hot day you can nosey around the various interesting hidey holes and side-rooms well into the evening.
The crowd in Eleszto is a combination of hardcore beer geeks and hostel-based backpackers, a young and largely friendly crowd. Eleszto is not in the core ruin pub area either so it does require a very short tram or metro ride. The area is also up and coming for bars and pubs so it isn’t out on a limb by any means.
Much like Poland, Hungary is among the countries where you can obtain very full flavoured craft ale on the cheap, and Eleszto goes quite some way towards flaunting Hungary’s current wares. There is a way to go but it’s just encouraging to know they’ve finally had enough of Borsodi and Dreher and doing something about it.
The good thing about Eleszto is, you can fit it in with your own plans, safe in the knowledge that there’s no particular time to go, it’s always a good time to go. If it wasn’t in Budapest it would be nearly every other city’s number one or two bar.

name: Pivnice U Poutníka
description:
EBG Rating:: 8.5
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Very limited to Poutnika beer on tap and a modest offering of mixers, wines and Eastern European liqueurs.

Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Pivnice style with curved ceilings and communal seating indoors. Lived-in, slightly ragged with a bit of a rock-pub slant (though not totally)

Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Buzzy, chatty, sometimes difficult to get a seat. Popular with an unpretentious younger crowd. Very atmospheric when busy.

Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️
Courtyard space, some board games, snacks

Value For Money: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Good value.

description: Czechia excels in very unpretentious pubs devoted to swilling high quality beers of its own making. These pubs are down to earth, welcoming all comers so long as they wish to adhere to this mission. U Poutnika is Brno’s best example of this, with several features belonging to those rare standout pubs that tie in everything together.
The house beer Poutnik is excellent and served via the tapster, a silent dignified gentleman attending only to the pouring of beer. The main bar area is a little unusual with full length glass windows overlooking an arcade – a trifle too modern and hasn’t done well with their attempt to give it character - but the backroom is an absolutely classic example of a Czech pub, with a curved pivnice type ceiling, plenty of communal tables and the sense of history reverberating through the echoes of friendly conversation.
The server is fairly efficient considering the space in the pub, meaning you can expect swift refills at all but the busiest times, and being in Brno, the beer itself is dirt cheap, and will barely bust 30 koruna.
It’s the kind of pub you would make your local minutes after moving into town. (added 2017)

name: Neonside
description:
EBG Rating:: 8.2
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️
Standard range of mixers and corporate drinks covering most basis.

Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️
Dozens of refurbished and rehomed neon signs light up an otherwise grey industrial alleyway. Deckchairs, stools and simple seating outside.

Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Buzzing, cool, a hint of an underground scene while in practise not being at all that way. Visit at night for obvious reasons.

Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️
Outdoor space, art exhibits

Value For Money: ❤️❤️❤️
Standard

description: Bars have to offer something spectacularly different if they aren’t living long in the memory for other reasons, and thankfully Neon Side does just that.
Transforming the courtyard of ul. Ruska into a display of retro neon signs salvaged from across the city, a walk here is almost obligatory. The problem is, with the expense of maintaining the signs and keeping them switched on, how they can persuade anyone into the bar itself and spend some money.
They have tried to combat that with displays inside, although these are a little less impressive than the enormous industrial scale signs in the yard. The bar also offer a range of decent Polish craft ale, and it is a reasonably decent sort of venue, with a New York loft type feel, lots of unused signage stocked by the walls and a lo-fi sort of feel.
It wasn’t apparent whether there were any more signs to look at, so I asked at the bar to some bemused expressions, and the question ‘this is it, are the signs outside not enough?’ A fair point, but you can’t help but ask.
Because of the industrial nature of the venue, and the main idea being simply to loiter around outside with a beer the place attracts some teens trying to get drunk on the sly, and a slightly closed off cliquey crowd. Nonetheless, I managed to join a crowd from Poznan out partying for the night who seems pretty impressed by it too, and it proved the jumping off point for, of all things, a club.
With a tasty beer and some extraordinary visuals, this is Wroclaw’s most extraordinary spectacle.

name: U Alberta
description:
EBG Rating:: 8.1
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Czech regional beers with a craft ale focus. Small selection of wines and Eastern European liqueurs.

Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️
Homely ad-hoc, DIY feel in parkside building. Part hut, part homely feel. Wooden furniture. Some 'craft' aesthetic in places.

Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Calm and pleasant retreat during the day, cosy, convivial, sociable and popular in the evenings.

Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️
Some freshly prepared sandwiches, minimal outdoor seating, occasional events.

Value For Money: ❤️❤️❤️
Fair but higher prices due to the quality of drinks offering

description: It is difficult for a brand new pub to compete with the decades of character attained by historical pubs. Even when they adopt a certain style, their wood has not yet aged or warped, their furniture still smells newly crafted and varnished and the walls and beams are still clear of the accumulation of odds and ends inherited over the years. It’s difficult to get a local crowd kick started when everything feels clean and sterilised.
Often the reaction to this is to change the style – go modern – and in doing so create a place that works from the word go. However, there is the riskier niche, to simply build a cheap DIY venue and pray that people turn up.
U Alberta is an example of the latter, and is hugely popular. The pub is in an odd place, which itself may help it stand out, being in what looks like a hut on the footpath up to Spilberk Castle. There are not too many obvious signs of its whereabouts leaving you to chance your arm.
When I arrived most tables were full, leaving only a space at the bar. The bar area itself was very rudimentary, and the barman was struggling between servicing sandwich orders and tapping off various ales.
U Alberta prizes itself on the quality and locality of the beer, and has a part in Brno’s growing craft ale scene. This is one area of Czech Republic where the larger breweries don’t hold as much sway, and the locals, including the university crowd have happily got into drinking beer from craft and regional brewers. This means more variety of styles and sometimes higher quality of beers.
The place had a terrific atmosphere, being largely twenty-somethings in diverse groups, sitting around in friendly bunches, with a fire going around the side of the room. The main quality I could describe this as is very unpretentious, which given you’re talking about students and the young is quite a commendation.
I got talking to a local member of Pivni (similar to CAMRA) about the scene in Brno and had a very friendly evening here. I would like to think over time they would make a few changes here and there to make it feel a tad more homely and less like it was half-finished, but other than that, I can’t fault it and would strongly urge anyone in Brno to pay a visit. (Added 2017)

name: La Fleur en Papier Doré / Het Goudblommeke in Paper
description:
EBG Rating:: 9.3
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Revamped beers from Verschueren and Brasserie De La Senne. Back bar is reasonably stocked for mixers, shots, and non-beer alternatives.

Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️
Medieval / Arty, with wrought iron window guards, chunky furniture and faded artwork and nik naks on the wall. Lots of browns, golds and blacks. 

Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️
Very characterful and distinctive venue, as the net curtains block the outside and make the place feel clandestine and bunker like. The pantry-style backroom adds a further aspect. Bar area also unusual. Hugely atmospheric whether quiet or busy.

Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️
Small selection of cold food, snacks, deli options, etc.

Value For Money: ❤️❤️
Slightly higher prices for the area.

description: Brussels centre is so heaving with tourists that it can be difficult to find the little nooks and crannies locals know about and still flock to. There is always a lively internationalism about Brussels nevertheless, but it is still vital the city expresses its own traditions at the same time, otherwise why invite people there? You don’t have to venture too far out of the old town until a few of these pubs and bars start to appear.

La Fleur en Papier Dore combines several crucial constituents that make a great pub. The style and décor goes for a vintage aesthetic, the wall covered in antiquey framed artwork, leaning towards medievalism and floral romanticism overall. Not always comfortable bed fellows and yet it is all tied together cohesively, and it feels permanent rather than thrown together on a whim over a weekend.

The place is one man's labour of love, Gérard van Bruaene who curated a pub so magnificent it was the meeting place for Magritte and the surrealist set. After his death the place slowly became threadless and eventually ended in bankruptcy in 2006.

After a few attempts to revive the pub, Covid struck and there were serious concerns it would ever reopen. Mercifully, the guys that run Brasserie Verschueren stepped in and revived the place!

Plonk yourself down on one of the bench seats, get warm and cosy and enjoy the atmospheric surroundings. The pub is at once decorous and fussy while at the same time really down-to-earth. If you look at anything below hip height, it’s simple tables, an old tiled floor and plenty of wood. It has a very homely living room area, precisely the sort that always scores highly with me. Once the front door closes the place is contained, the front windows frosted and stained glass so while it lets plenty of light in, you feel detached from the world outside. If you weren’t on holiday and simply needed a place to slowly recline and dissolve into, you could hardly make a better choice than this pub.

As referenced above, this is not as touristy a place, although it does receive a few keen travellers such as myself, and there appears to be a couple of hostels nearby so the crowd is a healthy mixture of both locals and people enjoying it for their first time.

Due to the new association with Verschueren, the beers have been revamped, a genuinely excellent selection at perfectly reasonable prices, elevating the place to a near mythical level.

name: TEA Time
description:
EBG Rating:: 8
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
English Ales cask-conditioned and served by gravity hand-pulled via angram pumps from a basement brewery. These have been erratic but there are signs of improvement. Small range of alternatives.

Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️
Simple wooden decor with some English nods which isn't over the top. Craft beer signage starting to creep in.

Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️
A calm welcoming venue with an immediately familiar feel. Better when busy.

Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Food, board games, pub quizzes, occasional events.

Value For Money: ❤️❤️❤️
Standard for the area and fair considering the unusual wares.

description: This pub has eschewed new Polish breweries typical approach, of making hundreds of identikit American Pale Ales and copies of beers that already exist thousands of times over to a very competent standard, and decided to pursue something genuinely novel for Poland, and perhaps mainland Europe.
Drink thick gravity pulled English style cask bitter brewed on site.
The owners must have developed a liking for English bitter during their time in England, as you can buy a range, usually 3-4 home brewed beers served in pint measures in classic English pint pubs. And they aren’t half bad. There’s a bit of a way to go still but they are the most authentic beers of the style you are likely to find in the whole of Poland. I can’t think of any other countries where this has been attempted either.
But this isn’t your stereotypical theme pub. There aren’t any tacky cheap St. George’s flags, and there isn’t a fruit machine. There’s no tacky Wetherspoons type details carpet or upholstered seats. Yes, they serve fish and chips and they have a pub quiz, but both of those are arguably good things by themselves. They have chosen to recreate a stripped back and elegant corner bar akin to a coastal corner pub in south of England. The pub area is very friendly and comfortable, and while it is a little bright and airy to be a true English pub (they need to be either more rustic in decore or darker toned), the end effect is pleasant.
Yes, the name is awful (T.E.A is an acronym for The English Ale), and perhaps you may find it odd being in a different country drinking English bitter, perhaps even counter-intuitive to your visit. But my priorities are to visit places that are good in their own right, and if possible novel or different which T.E.A Time clearly is.
There are a huge number of bars in Krakow to grab your attention, but I would ask you to try and fit in a visit to T.E.A Time if at all possible. It’s terrific.

name: Eszeweria
description:
EBG Rating:: 9.1
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️
Standard corporate Polish beer offerings. Limited keg and cask. More extensive cafe alternatives with herbal teas, vodkas, and mixers.

Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️
Brooding antiquey olde-world decor with faded furniture, candle-light, local artwork, recovered nik-naks, and walls that are literally stained with history.

Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️
Calm dusky hideout during the day, the place is the ultimate slow burner, getting going in the late evening.

Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️
Beer garden, small selection of snacks.

Value For Money: ❤️❤️❤️
Standard for the area.

description: Being a standout bar in Kazimierz is going some, but Eszeweria (Esh-evver-eee-aah) goes even further, by nailing the district’s established style – antiquey furnishings and crumbling edifices - as well.
Throw in a summer garden (albeit a very busy one), and there’s enough here to make you fall in love with Kazimierz all on its own.
Eszeweria opens very late as well. If it’s dark they will seemingly keep on serving. I couldn’t imagine visiting the bar any other time than very late in the evening, as walking in past the rows of couples dripping sweet nothings by murky candle light, and groups of young folk plotting in the nooks and crannies of the bar is never better than at some unholy late time of night. Every visit seems to end with the bar being at least as busy as when you entered, it seems like it will never really close.
Unfortunately the pub only offers slightly last-gen beer offerings, with the Zywiec range on tap, at a locally uncompetitive price, but that weakness aside, there’s very little else to mark the bar down for. The range of rooms and seating allow groups to have the kind of evening they want. There are intimate tables for two, communal pub type seating, sofas and of course the garden space.
Every city needs a go-to place for a late drink and this is definitely one of the greatest at that task. (Added 2017)

name: Spiż
description:
EBG Rating:: 8.5
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Brewpub serving several, largely European style lagers. A perfunctory selection of alternatives available.

Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Basement celler/beer hall with exposed brewing equipment and memorabilia. TVs in the corners and communal  wooden seating. Dining area to the rear. Large terrace seating at the front on the square.

Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Buzzing hubbub whether inside out out. On summer days the terrace doesn't get much better. In winter evenings it is warm, gregarious and cosy downstairs among the crowd.

Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Outdoor terrace, food, self-contained brewery, outdoor kiosk

Value For Money: ❤️❤️
Higher than normal for the area.

description: The history of the ‘Ratskeller’ in central Europe is rich and fascinating, not least because the concept of the main social meeting place being in the epicentre of the town has become lost, even in regions famed for such traditions, not least Germany.
Wroclaw has a great deal of crossover culture with Germany, being known as ‘Breslau’ commonly, and along with that, the drinking culture centred on the extremely large and impressive Rynek. Today, the Ratskeller ‘Spiz’ delivers to modern Poland an authentic enough representation of the style, and acts as an anchor in the city’s social scene.
Importantly too, Spiz has its own brewery, competing with two other breweries based on the square itself. All their brewers are unfiltered and unpasteurised giving them a hard-to-match freshness, and the whole range from the light lagers, yeast beer and honey mead are somewhere between good and very good. They are geared towards either hearty winter drinking or refreshing high volume session drinking and hit the mark exactly.
Along with the Germanic, gothic and stately subterranean beer hall with its impressive mash tuns, giant barrels, cloistered ceiling and interesting display cabinets, there is a huge seating area outside, which on a sunny day becomes the ultimate drinking spot, as one can recline and enjoy the sights and sounds of a buzzing and vibrant Rynek. To your left, the clock tower of the Ratusz, straight ahead the magnificently restored burgher houses, and to your right the join onto the Maly Rynek.
A passion for preserved historical features isn’t just borne of an interest and preference in historical architecture, but a yearning for the atmosphere and simplicity of the time. Sat outside spectating on the various forms of life passing by does on a temporal level transport you to a previous era. The Rynek is terrific and Spiz has the number one location for enjoying it.
If there wasn’t anything to do in Wroclaw it would be enjoyable in itself to spend your entire time at Spiz. As can be seen by the various reviews, the positive experiences are well founded.
Yes, it’s entirely obvious as a destination and not ‘alternative’ in the slightest. The service may not be all that, and it can be very busy. Similarly, the TV screens downstairs in the beer hall garishly advertising info about its horrendous looking disco nights detract from the experience. It needs to be very very good to overcome these – and it is. (Added 2017)

name: Papa Joe's Biersalon
description:
EBG Rating:: 9.1
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️
Kolsch, Lager, Wheatbeer and a suite of alternatives to beer including Krautlikor.

Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️
Jazz ephemera and old-time decor to conjure up the roaring 20s or pretty much any of the good old days. Outdoor terrace, balcony area, performance area in the corner. Mechanical marionette that is coin operated, cobbled floor.

Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️
When the music is playing the place comes to life, like a fairground attraction sparking into life. Outside of this there is plenty to enjoy still, with the decor and churn of people providing great ambience.

Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Live music, food, outdoor seating, amusements

Value For Money: ❤️❤️
Higher prices than normal for the area.

description: Some forms of pub going occur entirely outside of the confines of English culture, and one of these is to be found in Cologne, where Papa Joe’s Biersalon has become a local institution.
The traditional of socialising with strangers and even group singing is much more common in Germany, and Papa Joe’s is really a proto-form of kareoke, except instead of one person singing, everyone joins in.
To make matters weirder, the songs are ‘performed’ by a mechanical marionette by the bar, the range of tunes being a remorseless cast list of traditional German favourites with the typical organ, harpsichord and accordion ensemble.
Sitting among the locals, even if you aren’t joining in the singing (there is no obligation to) is a heady experience of local life, even national expression if you want to take it further. The venue itself is traditional in style, and theatrical in shape with raised seating around the perimeter of the ‘pit’ area in front of the bar.
Drinks are best procured from the bar area as table service and can be a little slow at peak times. The local beer Gaffel Kolsch is on tap and delicious, at a standard price for the city centre.
The traditional seating and cosy interior is about the only aspect of the experience I can think of that was akin to English pub going. Everything else was rather quaint, quirky and shameless in its kitsch quality. Expect to see a huddle of young folk bombastically belting out the standards, while the middle aged folk sit further back, rocking their heads and crooning along.
It’s an essential place to drop by in Cologne, particularly as some of the brahaus beer halls melt into one, it offers something utterly different, strange, and yet pitted in the local tradition. Throw down a far jars of Gaffel Kolsch, gawp at the spectacle in front of you, then head around the corner to a kebab shop for a Turkisch pizza (making care to consume it before the alcohol wears off

name: Oldsmobil Pub
description:
EBG Rating:: 8
Choice/Quality of Drinks: Some less typical mid-range Polish beer options on tap. Well stocked back bar for alternatives including vodkas.
Style/Décor: Part Irish bar, part roadside saloon stylings with red bench seating and lamp light in the side room that is a distinctive look. More wooden and familiar in the main rooms
Atmosphere/Character: A very brooding late night hangout. Depending when you go there can be tourists or locals, increasingly the former.
Amenities/Events: TV, small range of food options. 
Value For Money: Standard for the area.
description: Called Oldsmobil now, but there’s a sign outside with The Dog In The Fog logo and that is a far better name, I feel like keeping that spirit alive.
This pub is one of Krakow’s very many dusky, atmospheric venues that appeal by virtue of their style and character above all else. The benefit of these places is even on quiet days with not many people around, the décor in the room closes in even further to swaddle you in crimson and lamp light.
The entrance leads directly to the bar area, which doesn’t quite give off that impression at all, indeed it feels more like the ticket office for an old cinema. There are a range of decent beer options leaning towards regional medium sized breweries rather than craft ale. Once served, take a right turn into the seating area, which looks somewhat preserved in aspic.
It advertises itself as a ‘Restobar’ which is slightly confused, but when you’re there you can kind of understand it. The seating layout is diner style, but all the décor is very much more of a shady bar. It’s not very often you can visit a venue as evocative as that which you read of in stories, but The Dog In The Fog belongs in that category.
The overwhelming choice of bar in Krakow makes it difficult for me to insist on a visit, but nevertheless, you may find yourself dropping by.

name: Lórien
description:
EBG Rating:: 8.6
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️
Mallorcan and Spanish craft beer focused, with other European craft beers featuring. It's an alehouse. A small stock of alternatives.

Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Their Lord of the Rings theme is a light touch not a heavy touch, mercifully. A single room with wooden furniture and small tables, with a more craft beer bar like bar area with black frontage. Tasteful.

Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Sociable neighbourhood hangout spot which is unpretentious despite the craft connection. Popular with locals.

Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️
Small range of food (it is Spain after all), board games and occasional events.

Value For Money: ❤️❤️❤️
Higher than normal for the area but to be expected for the quality of drinks available.

description: In a city geared up for café culture, wine drinking, tapas and pintxos, beer and cosy pub going plays a definite bit part role. Going for a night out in Palma generally revolves around tapas bars, often lively and buzzing but lacking any really loveable venues. Indeed, the noise, constant eating and paucity of good beer becomes a drawback after a time.
Thankfully Lorien has stepped into the breach, a superb genuine beer pub with a thankfully loose Lord of The Rings theme (think tastefully framed artwork rather than costumes). The pub tailors for an audience starved of choice and quality, with a range of Spanish and Mallorcan craft ales on tap. This will come as a refreshing change of speed from the relentlessly uniform options of Estrella or Mahou everywhere else in the city.

There is a corresponding uptick in price which is hardly surprising given the sheer lack of competition, but given the alternative option is standing around food-munching Mallorcans in corporate tapas bars, or drinking wine in inappropriately intimate cellar bars, it’s worth it.
Furthermore, Lorien succeeds by being a real pub. There is bench seating and a square communally facing main room, and unsurprisingly a rather different crowd of young people dressed informally in a cosy and informal setting.
The bar staff are almost textbook beer monsters, bald, big beards and big beer guts, and are more than happy to chew over your drinking options. Thankfully Lorien strikes the balance right between the studious beer contemplation and a friendly communal feel.
Anyone dying for a good beer and a communal pub in Palma should come here. (Added 2017)

name: De Garre
description:
EBG Rating:: 9
Choice/Quality of Drinks: Rotating range of Belgian beers capped off by its flagship 13% Tripel 'De Garre'. A healthy range of bottled beer alternatives covering most lowlander styles. Very limited alternatives. 
Style/Décor: Genteel alehouse located down an alleyway with tablecloths, fireplace, chunky furniture. Multi-floored tavern. The best rooms are undoubtedly the ground floor and first floor, whereas the loft feels more like an overflow area.
Atmosphere/Character: Popular venue and the worst kept secret 'hidden bar' in the country. A good range of ages visit which gives the place a sociable democratic feel. Service is decent given the tourist churn. A place one could find themselves drinking in all afternoon.
Amenities/Events: Small selection of food, tasting trays, multiple floors.
Value For Money: Higher than normal for the area.
description: Reading old blogs, you’d think the destination of this bar was a mystery, or that the existence of side alleys was. However difficult to find people seem to think De Garre is, that doesn’t seem to stop it being full half an hour after opening and all day until closing.
Its popularity is based on the charm of the place. The side alley location certainly lends it a bit of character, with crumbling whitewashed brickwork draped with ivy branches and an uneven, typically Bruges set of cobblestones underfoot. The property is extremely old, and the staircase and floorboards are wonky and uneven, which may seem almost kitsch but Bruges is old and crooked enough a city to make it congruous.
The pub is set on 3 storeys, and each sort of feel like their own internal habitat. I like the idea of pubs set on several floors but sometimes you can end up on the least desirable one. The higher up you go, the more uneven steps you must take, so if you turn up worse for wear, have a quick think how sensible that is.
One of the pubs little specialities is its own house beer, a formidable Tripel called De Garre, weighing in at nearly barley wine strength and served with a side-plate of gouda to wash it down with. The De Garre is brewed by Van Steenberge off-site but it’s still nice to see a house beer that’s actually interesting and unique rather than a rebadged lager or pale ale.
The genteel nature of the pub means it attracts elderly custom, who don’t appear to consider the uneven angles, steps and low hanging beams a threat to their existence. During the day the place has much more of a café feel as a consequence, so you might want to consider whether that’s your sort of thing. However, finding a nice table and position somewhere, chatting along in your own little world is often just as enjoyable, and it does get more pub-like and atmospheric in the evening.
It’s a very popular place so time your visit wisely, and if that doesn’t work, persist, it’s located in the centre and easy to pop back for another try.

name: Le Coq
description:
EBG Rating:: 8.5
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️
Several Belgian beers on tap with some rotating offerings. Decent sized selection of beer bottles covering most based. Small selection of alternatives.

Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Stained glass frontage with Stella Artois signage. Typical Belgian brown café with wooden bench seating and simple tables. Long one-room format with more space than it may appear. Central location means it can be very popular.

Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
No matter how busy or quiet it is, the natural ambience of Le Coq provides a great deal of character. The best time is the swell from afternoon into early evening.

Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️
Limited selection of snacks. 

Value For Money: ❤️❤️
Standard for the area.

description: The art and tradition of the brown café is not upheld in any more authentic fashion in Brussels than Le Coq, located just metres away from Bourse in the city centre.
The venue itself stands out a little among the stylish eateries and fashion shops, largely as it still sports the name ‘Le Coq’ in Stella Artois insignia in the manner of a lot of down to earth boozers. There’s the impression Le Coq sits on some prime real estate but stubbornly refuses to be pushed out onto the fringes.
At the time of writing the pub remains almost off-grid in terms of its online presence, even in terms of user-generated content which is very odd given the hundreds of patrons that pile through its doors every day in search of moody refreshment. Therefore it is difficult to provide much visually, and I wished I had taken the opportunity in my last visit.
The brown café involves a mixture of seductive atmospheric drinking and something more solid, a plain matter-of-factness stripping away some of the ephemera and fripperies other pubs go in for. On the one hand, there is an element of the humdrum and workaday about a brown café – the typical working class drinks offerings on tap, Stella, Hoegaarden and Leffe, the sound of simple bar stools and pub furniture scraping across tiled floors, the head-space offered by the tracks of time inbetween music playing. On the one hand the browns, the crimsons and the lighting slowly create a comforting woozy feeling as the alcohol takes hold and the pub conversation coalesces into a pleasant background murmur. This is especially strong during the transition from afternoon to evening, a fascinating collective shift in mood. Le Coq is a classic example of this, treading a tightrope between the prosaic and the profound.
Beer fans will be pleased to learn there are other offerings than the AB InBev triptych, as their bottle menu is pretty decent. Price wise, it’s relatively expensive as it’s central Brussels, though you can sip safe in the knowledge you’re still drinking beer that would cost a third more exported to the UK.
The staff were charismatic and a little rough around the edges, which seems to suit the pub just right.
Le Coq is the place to go if you want to experience Brussels’ brown cafés’.

name: Strefa Piwa Pub
description:
EBG Rating:: 7.8
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️
Rotating selection of Polish and Czech tap offerings and more high-end bottles on offer. It is an ale house. Very limited selection of alternatives.

Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️
Curved ceiling in Czech pivnice style decorated with beer styles and their connections. Mirrors give the appearance of space but it is a small venue. The backroom pantry has slightly more atmosphere than it ought to have.

Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️
The people make the atmosphere here. If there aren't any, there isn't any.

Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️
Small selection of board games, snacks and Czech tapas 

Value For Money: ❤️❤️❤️
Good, a range to suit most wallets.

description: Any new bar venture in Kazimierz is likely to take a while to wrench people away from the dozen brilliant venues. My first visit to Strefa Piwa a couple of years ago was enjoyable, but the venue was yet to take off.
The pub is a fairly small narrow room with a curved ceiling in the style of a Pivnice decorated with a rather striking flow chart linking a hundred beer styles with their parent families. This gives a clue to their raison d’etre. I quite liked the fact it was a nice cross between a hospoda type drinking den but with some of the architectural features of a beer hall.
Two years ago a visit to Strefa Piwa would have been largely one to seek out a beer, with the atmosphere still a little ‘new’ and quiet, however that has all changed in the meantime. I’m pleased to say since that visit Strefa Piwa now has a core audience of locals who share space with clutches of travellers and backpackers. It’s a friendly, hustle and bustle type place that isn’t overly bothered about competing with the faded antiquey style bars down the road.
Because the décor is simple, it is the kind of place that needs a throng of people to lend it vitality, but now it has that, a great combination of incredibly high quality beer and a fun vibrant venue, that is still just about down-to-earth enough to not fall down the pretentious multi-tap beard-stroking craft venues.
To compliment the nod towards Czech pubs, there are a few high quality Czech ales along with craft Polish beer, and the range is wide enough that you can find something great in a range of styles. As per usual, the pricing while expensive by Polish standards is among the cheapest for craft ale you are likely to find around Europe.
Strefa Piwa succeeds by offering something different to the majority of Kazimierz bars, the pointedly different style seems to appeal to a crowd who are more interesting in drinking and socialising than ‘being seen’. It has a great location so works well as a stop off in between Plac Nowy and the old town in Krakow, similarly as an adjoinder to a night out in Kazimierz, or just for a casual evening out. (Founder Member)

name: Poechenellekelder
description:
EBG Rating:: 8.6
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️
Large selection of draft and bottled Belgian beers covering most traditional bases and a few new trends. Limited range of alternatives.

Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️
Multi-floored cafe with stairs to a large mezzanine floor. Marionettes and puppets everywhere along with framed artwork and photos. Very distinctive. Wooden flooring, typical rickety wooden furniture.

Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Constantly lively due to central situation. Cosy in the winter evenings and fairly airy during the summer. A good all-rounder.

Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️
Small Estaminet-style cooked food offerings, outdoor terrace

Value For Money: ❤️❤️❤️
Reasonable considering the area

description: Due to the touristy situation directly opposite Mannekin Pis and the fact it always looked so crowded, it was years until we tried grabbing a beer at the indulgently lengthy-named Poechenellekelder. It had always looked somewhat interesting, taking up three floors in an old fashioned stepped gable Flemish house, and the odd peer through the windows made me wonder what I was missing out on.
I should be annoyed at myself in hindsight, as this is a wonderful place, but I’m glad to have eventually found it. Although the place can look packed from the outside, this is a little deceptive as there are several areas within the building and people are spread out. Also, quite a lot of these ‘people’ were silhouettes of mannequins and marionettes, which is the theme of the bar.
While I enjoy the simplicity of a brown café or Czech hospoda I’ve always been a fan of bars cluttered with collected items as they give your eyes something to do while drinking, as well as adding a little charm to a place.
Walk up a couple of sets of stairs to the bar area and try to find a seat, as this is the epicentre of activity and the most ‘pub like’ the place gets – it also has the most to look at.
There is a medium sized and well chosen range of beers, most of which are top class Belgian ales, some of which are small scale and harder to come by. The price is surprisingly fair considering the immensely touristy location. The pub food offered is middle of the road but likewise inoffensive, really serving to provide a stodgy base for the beer consumption. They also offer free bar snacks which seems like a petty thing to worry about either way, but always adds a little something. Considering the number of people in the place, the service is skilled and efficient.
As with several Belgian places there is a slight blurring of what the place actually is – is this pub, or a café, or a simple restaurant. It’s all three to some extent, and you might find that doesn’t suit your own needs. Nevertheless it’s an atmospheric, friendly and very quirky venue serving high quality beer, and certainly one I would blaze a trail to over and over.

name: A Baiuca - fado vadio
description:
EBG Rating:: 9
Choice/Quality of Drinks: Wine, ginjinha cherry liqueur, limited range of other liqueurs and alternatives.
Style/Décor: Kitchenette/Tavern with tiling and genteel homely decor. Communal space.
Atmosphere/Character: Both a tavern and a performance area. Very intimate and occasionally intense. 
Amenities/Events: Live Fado performances, food
Value For Money: Set price agreed on the door, normally reasonable for a one-off authentic experience.
description: Although you may see reviews of this place as a restaurant, the homely open-kitchen style and the late night atmosphere make this place definitely worth of the name pub – indeed the doors themselves describe the place as a ‘Taberna’.
That said, there is an entrance fee which covers the flow of wine and shots and the musical main event, fado, dramatically mournful Portuguese folk music. At the time of the visit this fee was 10 euros which at the time seemed very reasonable considering the wine and music were both very good.
This may seem a bit off-piste so far considering the beer halls and pubs covered on the blog, but be aware I have offered a degree of latitude to this venue on account of the authenticity and character.
Lisbon’s traditional working class neighbourhood the Alfama is the perfect setting for the place, and it can be difficult to track down while wandering up and down the maze of winding streets on the hillside. I remember we ended up locating it by deduction alone, and peering through a metal garage door. The front door itself was shut, but after a couple of knocks the owner met us at the door and arranged our seating after payment was made.
We gathered on a communal table in a small room, with most places taken, and were made to feel welcome with a couple of glasses of wine. There is no stage, and the musicians simply perform in the corner of the room. Each song is dramatic and passionate and the performers looked extremely well practised at the style. An overkill of maudlin music doesn’t seem like the basis for a night out, but the songs are short, melodic and received enthusiastically.
There are a great many corporate joints in the city centre offering fado performances with the meal, and while there is always a place for that, this is where to go for the real McCoy, stripped back, homely and raw in an unbroken folk tradition.
After considering the experience overall, I think aside of the entrance fee, it occupied a very similar social space as going to a pub, both in terms of the homely working class surroundings and manner of drinking.
Our visit extended long into the early hours of the morning leading to a very uncomfortable wakeup call the following morning to the airport!
There are a few other traditional fado venues in the Alfama, which I am sure warrant exploration, but I can strongly advocate visiting here if you like your experiences real and rustic. Finding this place on our final night in Lisbon more or less made the trip.

name: Pub „Graciarnia u Plastyków”
description:
EBG Rating:: 8.4
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️
Typical Polish range of beers, vodka and Eastern European liqueurs.

Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️
Multi-room and multi-floor venue which is eclectic, bunker-like and alternative.

Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Due to the unusual venue there is an excitable feel with each group finding the space they want to hang out in. 

Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️
Outdoor seating, live music, board games, musical instruments

Value For Money: ❤️❤️❤️
Fair for the area.

description: Dark, very atmospheric bunker type pub with plenty of décor, a little worn and faded, well reviewed and down to earth. The pub has since moved location to a less exciting, bunker-like venue but is still one of the strong choices in the city. (Added 2018)

name: L’Imaige Nostre-Dame
description:
EBG Rating:: 9
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Compact tap offerings covering the traditional Belgian beer basics with a few interesting ones poking out.

Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Wooden tavern with beams, tiles and chunky seats. Impasse location which leads out across to another pub out the back door. 

Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Particularly characterful in winter, small but charming, despite the tourist churn. Historic feel retained.

Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️
Deli offerings have been on/off over the years so may be unavailable. Live music performances in the back room.

Value For Money: ❤️❤️
Mediocre/poor

description: I love any pubs found down the end of alleyways and tunnels, largely as in my experience they tend to be pretty good. I live in Leeds which has its fair share of arcades and side alleys, with several pubs of note to be found. Brussels is another city which hides many of its good pubs down little passageways, referred to as ‘impasses’. Down the end of one of these, only a few minutes walk from Grand Platz is A L’Imaige Nostre Dame.
The fun rabbit hole feel is enhanced on the inside as the window at the other side of the pub looks out over another impasse and another pub. This labyrinthine medieval feel adds so much character in itself the pub would have to be truly appalling to not be worth visiting.
It’s a cosy pub with a small bar area, sturdy furniture and the by now familiar tiled flooring. Despite the central location I’ve never found it to be overly busy, always ticking along nicely. The pub mainly serves clutches ofyoung tourists rather than locals, though there are on occasion groups of locals here, especially when there’s music in the back room.
The beer focuses on Trappist ale, presumably with the tourists in mind, and they push La Trappe which are tasty beers but not the premier Trappist brewers (indeed it was in dispute for a time whether their brewing really was in accordance with Trappist standards). There is a modest selection of other beers which are all pretty good, though admiteddly could be even better. They used to do bar snacks and degustations but appear to have stopped this at the moment. That’s a shame and they should bring it back if possible.
Because of its location I enjoy combining paying a visit to A L’Imaige Nostre Dame as part of a crawl. There is too much in the vicinity to spend all day in here, very nice though it is. You will get the most out of it by staying for an hour or so to enjoy the fun hidden away cavernly nature, and especially if there are some friendly travellers who are looking for conversation. I have a great fondness for the place and if I lived anywhere near central Brussels I would always drop by here on a night out.

name: Bodega Bellver
description:
EBG Rating:: 8.5
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️
Wines and sherries with chest freezer full of bottled beers.

Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Spanish bodega with upturned barrels, candlewax growing everywhere like mould, simple and unpretentious with tiny kitchen area.

Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️
Historic venue which has retained its character. Lively and intimate feel with a sense of homeliness.

Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️
Food, small tv screens, seating (this isn't a joke, sometimes bodegas have no real seating)

Value For Money: ❤️❤️❤️
Middling for the area.

description: Just around the corner from Lorien, which is central Palma’s best native beer pub (ie. excluding the German beer pubs in S’Arenal) is a classic bodega, with a down to earth pub atmosphere and informal feel that is a good distance away from the mainstream tapas Bars in Palma.
The drinking (and eating if you so wish) takes place in informal settings surrounded by crusty old barrels, some of which are upturned to prop your drink up. Wine or beer play a similar role here, and although there aren’t any tapped beers, Paulaner and Estrella Galicia are adequate for the setting.
There is an ad hoc kitchen about the size of a portaloo hidden behind a metal screen, and every few minutes you will receive wafts of great smells as the latest seafood on the production line is fried and grilled.
The owner is a kindly enough old man who takes things at a steady pace and appropriately enough looks like the human embodiment of his surroundings – one of those tiny details that can all join up to make an enjoyable venue.
The atmosphere inside Bodega Bellver is akin to conversational pub going, so in spite of the distracting pintxos smells and wine/sherry dominated drinking options, the reason you are here is much like any other pub, and it fits I think very well with the purpose of the European Bar Guide. The surroundings are rustic and authentic feeling with candle wax strewn about the place and the floor and barrels blackened and thick with age and wear.
Tack a visit to Bellver onto your trip to Lorien for a really enjoyable mini-pub crawl. (Added 2017)

name: Caffe bar SECRET GARDEN
description:
EBG Rating:: 9
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️
Whatever is handed to you by the association who gather here.

Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️
Bicycles, umbrellas, recovered furniture and nik-naks line the courtyard.

Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️
Beautiful courtyard atmosphere which evokes ruin pubs.

Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️
Merchandise of the local cycle association

Value For Money: Not applicable
description: The anticipation of visiting somewhere with a good reputation can be exciting but also loaded with expectations, sets of pitfalls that can make the eventual experience not live up to them. This is no reason to not get excited, it’s just a fact of life.
What you can’t bottle are surprises, events and chance discoveries outside of any planning or research that fit the bill and transform your evening.
Discovering Garden Henry in the picturesque town of Varazdin in Northern Croatia was one of those moments. Earlier in the evening we had been wandering around an open air folk festival ‘Spancirfest’, which again we had known little about in advance. The centre was buzzing with stalls, street theatre and music, which alone gave a pleasant lift to our stay there. After doing the circuit of the town and around the castle we double backed onto ourselves hoping to find a bar in the vicinity to drop into. Most of these were busy but we stayed for a couple. On our way home I noticed a courtyard on our left and feeling curious ventured further in and found Garden Henry.
This venue is mainly open air, a terrace for cycling enthusiasts to congregate and drink a coffee. Varazdin was also hosting a protest against city plans to ban cyclists from the pedestrianised old town, which on balance seems completely unnecessary, but typical of the vagaries and petty feuds associated with town management.
This place was essentially their plotting spot, and they were selling tshirts and other merchandist in support of their cause. It was not apparent whether there was a bar or anywhere to get drinks, but we were approached by a gentleman who seemed to be co-ordinating some of the get together, and had a couple of cans thrust in our general direction.
The atmosphere was terrific as you could probably expect, a combination of the local buzz from the evening and really stylish design, upturned umbrellas, old cycles pinned to the walls and antique furniture in the courtyard. It’s the kind of place you would want to hang out in the summer pretty much anywhere.

name: Café de Wetering
description:
EBG Rating:: 8.9
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️
Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️
Value For Money: ❤️❤️
description: Lively and bustling venue with a characterful layout, small balcony area overlooking the bar and cosy ricketing backroom with large fireplace. Popular with a young crowd, and very atmospheric. One of Amsterdam's finest.

name: Jazz Kocsma
description:
EBG Rating:: 8.6
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️
Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Value For Money: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
description: One of the pleasures of travelling is the inevitability after a while of unearthing a gem, and even more rewarding when it involves some level of adventure. That was certainly the case when discovering Jazz Kocsma in Szeged.
There are a number of bars in Szeged city centre, although fairly few for a city of its size. The central pub scene seems to divide itself between student drinking and old man drinking, without too many crossover places which were tacky and corporate in any event.
Jazz Kocsma is set on an unlit back street 20 minutes out of the centre, in an area that is spookily quiet to the point of abandoned. When we approached the bar, its old wooden doors were shut and it seemed impossible to think the place had been open for years.
Desparate to find somewhere before heading back to our awful hotel, we tried the doors nevertheless and to our amazement found light downstairs, the place alive and accepting guests. There was a short break of silence as we walked in, our entrance most likely unexpected, and surveying the scene discovered a very ramshackle, ancient jazz club, with a corner bar area on the right and small stage on the left.
The beer options are perfunctory Hungarian stuff, unspectacular, but the primary quality of the pub was its atmosphere. Being very late at night things were slowing in pace, with groups huddling quietly around their tables in the candlelight. The mood lighting and gentle murmur of the crowd
Yes, the Jazz part of the title does actually mean something, and although there was no music playing at our late time of arrival, their calendar shows their live music events remain in full swing. It was easy to see from the interior how a Jazz band would elevate the experience even further.
This venue is a historical slice of local life that seems determined never to redecorate or change. Impossible to tell whether it was always this ad hoc, old and crusty or it has been happy to become so dilapidated. Regardless, the end effect is a powerful and distinct experience that will elevate your trip to Szeged.

name: Za Kulisami
description:
EBG Rating:: 9
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ***
Style/Décor: *****
Atmosphere/Character: ****
Amenities/Events: ***
Value For Money: ****
description: Poznan really delivers as a city for a good night out, with a breadth of choice and high bar for quality. Furthermore, the locals are spending their time socialising with a determination and energy you could find in the UK in the early 00s.
Za Kulisami is a place that fits in nicely with informal post-uni drinking. The style is somewhere between ramshackle and psychedlic, with large bookcases, old tattered sofas and yet also a backroom with neon lights, and some rather moody and trippy decorations.
The crowd are lively, friendly and hang around by the bar. You will occasionally need to lean over shoulders to order but don’t be afraid to, there isn’t the same conservative personal space issue as there is in England.
The beers are a variety of regional medium sized brewers like Fortuna, Miroslaw and Brackie which makes an interesting middle ground between the Euro Lager giants and craft ale. They are decent enough quality and superbly cheap, weighing in barely above 1 pound a pint, which is alone noteworthy.
Quite a lot of the locals are into beer + vodka orders, and many places in Poland offer the combo at a slightly reduced rate, making it barely more expensive than ordering a craft beer, but far more effective at getting you drunk. We stuck to the beer, and found each visit to be relaxing and enjoyable. The place has a club-type character, and I got the impression a great many of the regulars knew each other well. A few visits to the place would soon ingratiate yourself, and as with a lot of other Polish cities, there are a surfeit of young people who speak great English without much opportunity to use it.
Za Kulisami is a great pub that seems to naturally filter out unsuitable types, and is so close to the Rynek as to be tempting almost every time you walk past. It feels much more like a friendly backstreet pub, word of mouth based with a regular cast. There aren’t many large cities where such a venue would be so central. It would hover around the top 3 choices for a pint in Poznan.

name: Känguruh-Pub
description:
EBG Rating:: 8.9
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️
Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️
Value For Money: ❤️❤️❤️
description: It’s a slightly off-kilter situation for Vienna’s best bar to specialise in Belgian beer, but at a loss of any compelling alternatives, it does seem to be the truth.
Kanguruh offers a large menu of bottled Belgian beer which they have to dive into their cellars to retrieve for you. They are nearly all 4 euros 50, which in certain cases is extraordinarily good value, meaning you can try rare small batch beers, quadrupel strength beers, lambic etc for less than you would pay in Brussels city centre. As you can expect, the quality is terrific. The bar also have 6 taps on rotation, largely German and Czech beer if you require lighter high-volume refreshment.
Aside from the beers being exceptionally good, the venue itself is cracking. Although the pub is street-facing, they have made a conscious choice to cut off the outside world (there isn’t much of a view anyway), so it is one of those places where the transition from outside to inside and vice versa is quite dramatic.
There is a rounded bar area and the main room is largely stool seating, however the room in the back offers a little more lounge comfort. The atmosphere is shady, candlelit and dramatic, the crowd a mixture of ruminating solo drinkers (referred to as “einslers” in German),couples and friendly youngsters enjoying the close feel and the gloom.
Such a place is very appropriate for knocking back Belgian ale, and before long all the outlines of your sight will start to become a little fuzzy. There is a reasonable turnover of patrons so if you don’t strike up a conversation at first, hang around and see what happens.
Kanguruh is a well-known about local legend, not likely to change in any way any time soon, and essential visiting while in Vienna.

name: The Bath Hotel
description:
EBG Rating:: 9
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ****
Style/Décor: ****
Atmosphere/Character: *****
Amenities/Events: ****

description: Preserved fittings, plenty of handpulled ales and local life. Popular with football fans on match days but not really that type of pub. Focus is on beer and quality thereof.

description:
EBG Rating:: 8.5

Unfortunately a tied pub and as such its future always seems to be distantly hanging in the balance thanks to the awful PubCo who have overarching control. (Added 2017)

name: Sheaf View
description:
EBG Rating:: 8.3

description:
EBG Rating:: 8.5

name: Robin Hood Inn
description:
EBG Rating:: 8.5
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️
Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Value For Money: ❤️❤️❤️
description: Simply magnificent cosy, ungentrified freehold pub based halfway up the longest single uphill stretch of road in England. Popular with cyclists and featured on the Tour De France Grand Depart when they visited Yorkshire. Their fleeting fame is commemorated on the walls. Inside you'll find a simple ungentrified little bar with some decent cask and keg options, to the left up a step a more dining-focused area but still without any bland refurbishment applied, with worn in rugs and cosy, homely surroundings. Unmissable if in the area. (Added 2017)

name: Headrow House
description:
EBG Rating:: 8.1
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️
Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️
Value For Money: ❤️❤️
description: An ambitious and well-financed large venue, Headrow House comes ready-made to meet a whole host of needs, whether it’s the adjoining restaurant, events room on the first floor, cocktail lounge above or two rooftop terraces.
Pubgoers however will be more keen to learn whether there is anything good to drink. One of the very few bars outside London to service tank Pilsner Urquell on tap, no matter how great the rest of the bar may be, the temptation is always to order several pints of the good stuff stuff. You may have tried Pilsner Urquell on tap elsewhere, or in bottles, pasteurised and filtered, and struggled to work out what the fuss was about. As Headrow House are blessed to be able to serve the stuff unpasteurised and fresh from the tank, it comes with a natural shelf life meaning they have to get rid of it in 10-14 days after it’s opened, and they usually manage far sooner than that. Not going through the pasteurisation process where the beer is heated up, PU retains a great deal of its intended character. Always quite a volatile beer, here at least you can rest assured of a pint of it in good condition.

You might find the staff a little ignorant and sniffy, although on other days they can be perfectly fine. This comes with the territory, Leeds bar staff are often very far short from what you’d ideally want. If the place did enough volume they could justify a tapster, Czech style, simply delivering the beers themselves in pristine fashion, while the staff come around to deliver the beers. Unfortunately the variety of beer options and English custom dictate otherwise.
The music venue space is decent enough, and certainly one of the few venues anywhere where you can get such a great lager to enjoy with a gig. The cocktail area is a little mediocre in comparison to the rest of the venue, so keep on going up until you reach the terrace. If there’s even a hint of sun in Leeds you need to be here, soaking up the limited rays and enjoying the rooftop level view of Leeds’ Victorian domes and crenulations.
The décor follows a more mature ‘industrial chic’ look than most, with grass green upholstered bench seating in the main pub area and standard craft style benches running down the middle. It’s comfortable enough but there is an element of homeliness missing, and requires big groups to foster the sort of convivial atmosphere that inspires loyalty. That slightly corporate feel runs all the way through sadly, and you’ll find the price, service, décor, atmosphere all consistent with that.
Nevertheless on a busy evening or a summer’s day this is still the place to be in Leeds.

name: The Fat Cat
description:
EBG Rating:: 8.5

description: Superb iconic Kelham Island venue, a quintessential multi-room traditional pub with simple comfortable seating, a well curated outside yard and basic food all at fair prices. (Added 2017)

name: Fagans
description:
EBG Rating:: 8.5
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️
Value For Money: ❤️❤️
description: Tom & Barbara finally retired, but a group of people who loved the pub have stepped into save it.

The huge meals, lived-in family feel and sense of survivor charm has gone.

In comes merchandising, an unsuitable Irish theme focus (as Tom used to repeat, it has never been an Irish pub) and a considerable increase to drinks prices. 

The interior remains unspoilt, largely, folk nights continue and the range of drinks has expanded (one of the few weaknesses under the old regime). Plus the pub's future is at least secure. So, we'll have to give it a deduction, but it still remains one of Sheffield's finest. 

(Added 2017, updated August 2023)

name: Shakespeare's
description:
EBG Rating:: 8.5
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Value For Money: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
description: A fantastic preserved pub with a lot going for it. Many drinks options, unique bar features, events, side rooms and snugs, and a large yard is a plain list of them, but the truth is it always seems close to being the answer to 'where next' in Sheffield. Resurrected after a period of closure, there is a ramshackle informality and a blend of traditional with a modern sensibility that is attractive to young and old. (Added 2018)

name: Whitelock's Ale House
description:
EBG Rating:: 8.8
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Updated modern range of cask and keg ales. Lacking superior lagers but most bases well covered. Theakston Old Peculier rarely better found than here.

Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️
Alleyway pub with stained glass, brass table tops and intricate tiled bar. A long narrow room with low ceilings and old wooden partitions, mirrors and etched glass. A blend of Georgia to Victorian interior that is a heritage location.

Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
The interior creates its own atmosphere quiet or busy. The intimate space fills up quickly, particularly as there is dining space taken up. This is in itself interesting to spectate on. Styled as 'The Heart of Leeds', it really feels like that.

Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️
Meals, snacks, outdoor seating, occasional beer festivals.

Value For Money: ❤️❤️
City centre prices

description: Amid a shower of mediocrity, Whitelock’s is a beacon for the values of preservation and tradition in creating a characterful pub.
Whether Leeds is serving up mediocrity in the form of cut-and-paste template industrial chic craft ale venues or boring chain pubs, you only have to look at Whitelock’s to tell the difference between a here today gone tomorrow fad, a vacuous meaningless container of nothing except Greene King IPA and sports screen and the timeless values that have helped a venue endure.
Whitelock’s itself was first founded in 1715, although you’ll find the current state more akin to late Victorian in style, with mirrored panelling, stained glass and tarred black wood. The pub was a ‘Luncheon Bar’, and during the day has much the same feel as it would have had back in the day, with a bustling busy atmosphere with food service and drinking intermingling. There is a stolid feeling of grandeur and it always feel like you are partaking in the upkeep of a fine tradition.
Situated down of one of Leeds many arcades, the pub used to stretch along the length of the arcade, a narrow snaking venue with effectively two bars (one of which is now a modernised cocktail bar called The Turk’s Head). The pub can be approached from either entrance, although I recommend the entrance nearest Trinity centre which provides the most rabbit hole like escape from the modern world and really makes you feel like you’ve been transported back in time. There are benches outside which can be nice on a humid day but are not the reason for venturing down here. Head inside and chance your arm at finding a seat – not an easy task sometimes.
The crowd at Whitelock’s rises and falls in swells. In the space of half an hour the scene at bar can change from a breathless tangle vying for space to calm and sedate, with a regular slowly enjoying a sup of cask ale perched by the brass serving area.
The bar area itself is a little unusual and old-fashioned, as despite the bar having a low ceiling, the staff seem raised above the level of the pub and after serving your pint, will deliver it down to you. The toilets are also odd, with a tiny staircase at the end of the bar which is almost like being on a ship rather than in a pub.
You’ll find some of the best classic real ales, along with some interesting local options. They have some forays into craft styles on keg with a modernised range, but could use much better lagers.
For a change, I would like to enthuse about the food. They have put a lot of thought into how to bring the idea of Luncheon menu into the 21st century, and have managed it, with most dishes having an English pub heritage, and using very fresh ingredients. You pay for it, but it’s pretty good. It isn’t just a generic pub grub place.
Once you’re inside and sat down, with only the dappled light coming through the frosted glass, you can really soak up your extraordinary environment and with it being a typically cosy old pub, it won’t feel like there’s any reason to move. Whole afternoons and evenings can come and go here supping quality pints of ales swaddled by comfortable surroundings.
By far the best pub in Leeds and due to its very particular features it could stake a fair claim to being one of the very best in the United Kingdom. (Added 2017)

name: Nightjar
description:
EBG Rating:: 8.5
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️❤️

description:
EBG Rating:: 9.1
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️
