Beer, beer and more beer, unsurprisingly. 8+ taps, fridge of cans and bottles from across Europe.

Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️
Scuzzy Berlin-style interior with black paint, chains and metal. Upstairs find further seating and an amusingly obstructive archway.

Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️
Very lively in the evening and largely an international flavour. Way too hot in summer though.

Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️Hmm.. beer?
Value For Money: ❤️❤️
Nearer the top of the range in the district which reflects the audience it is made for.

description: You can't say fairer than the energy drummed up here in tandem with the quality of the drinks. Both obscure some of the more irritating aspects to the extent that this small beer bar does the job well enough to be a clear recommendation. (Added June 2022)

name: Púder Bárszínház
description:
EBG Rating:: 7.7
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️
A competent although not especially ambitious café bar range.

Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️
The strong suit of the bar with a really colourful mix taking in steampunk and ruin bar aesthetic. The place itself is a wide pub with a high ceiling.

Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️
A hint of pretense to the venue, with unnecessary table service and definitely pitching to a more upmarket audience, although despite that, you'll find the amazing decor and the huge windows on the front that provide a view onto the street give the place the energy it needs, even during the daytime to compensate.

Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️
Outdoor seating, meals, snacks

Value For Money: ❤️❤️
More expensive, though in line with the type of audience it is trying to attract

description: A bar with a 'theatre bar' moniker but little evidence of that inside. Instead you'll encounter a vivid, flamboyantly designed bar taking cues from steampunk and ruin bars, mixed up with the function of a café bar. A different feel during the day to nighttime and table service during the day makes it feel unnecessarily staid, but the raw materials of the concept helps it shine through nonetheless. (Added June 2022)

name: The Pub
description:
EBG Rating:: 7.6
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
6 handpulled ales and 2 kegs along with cider and a compact back bar. Very good for the tiny size.

Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️
Compact 1 room micropub adorned with old pump clips and rustic furniture, some ad hoc DIY in places.

Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️
Characterful and local with cast of regulars and good for socialising and ice-breaking with strangers.

Amenities/Events: ❤️
Err.. Toilets?

Value For Money: ❤️❤️❤️
High for the area but in line with the quality of goods on offer.

description: A charming micropub that is local while being friendly and welcoming. The room promotes socialising and conversation with both staff and strangers, bringing back some of the lost elements of older pubgoing. Great beer choices on cask and keg are the highlight, with a nice homely interior to, rounding off a deserved inclusion. (added June 2022)2023 UPDATE - MAY HAVE MOVED LOCATION - check online for details

name: Stratford Haven
description:
EBG Rating:: 7.8
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️
A very impressive range covering cask, keg and interesting bottled beers covering craft and European bases too, with cider and perry options. A well stocked back bar.

Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️
Expanded alehouse with simple rustic appearance and brick tiled floor, basic but homely. The bar is plastered with TV's promoting the beer options which somewhat reduces the rustic appearance. Atrium area further in the pub with beer garden. There's a decent capacity and it's a lot bigger than it seems from the front.

Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
The venue works if it's calm and quiet or if there's a crowd in (often from the cricket or football grounds nearby), with enough space and enough personalised cosy corners to feel at home almost whatever's going on.

Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Meals, snacks, outdoor seating, community events, pub quiz, jukebox, fruit machines, books etc

Value For Money: ❤️❤️❤️
Standard, but very short on any bargains.

description: This Castle Rock pub could easily have adopted the attitude of only serving the brewery's beers, instead they've made the choice of turning it into a destination alehouse with a dozen cask and keg options each and large bottle selection besides. The venue has a simple neighbourhood alehouse feel in warm rustic tones, with an expanded rear and beer garden. Versatile, with evening community events and capacity to accommodate crowds from the nearby stadiums without ever feeling alienating, this comes warmly recommended. (Added June 2022)

name: The Gentlemen's Beer Shop
description:
EBG Rating:: 7.5
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️
Rotating tap beer offering of high quality Czech and Slovakian brews from less corporate sized breweries. Several fridges and shelves with craft options and alternatives.

Style/Décor: ❤️❤️
Modern café type surroundings with a patio out from before an L shaped space around the bar, basic tables backing onto fridges and shelves with more beer. Clean, white, some greenery.

Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️
A more sterile appearance means this relies on local life, and thankfully there is a fair offering here day and night.

Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️
Outdoor seating, snacks, takeaway drinks

Value For Money: ❤️❤️❤️
More expensive for the area but in line with the goods on offer.

description: A clean bar with great beer and local life is always a relieving sight in provincial central Europe and this performs the function well enough to deserve an inclusion. The selection of bottles and cans is fairly impressive but when here it's difficult to look past the tap options which are served immaculately. Clean, modern lines supplemented with some greenery and a patio make this a bar with a distinctly craft-aesthetic which can be sterile, but is saved by its genteel local life that has more in common with a roadside pivnica in the Balkans than some Scandi city bar. (Added June 2022)

name: Borozó
description:
EBG Rating:: 7.7
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️
A Borozo suggests a focus of wine, but there's really an even mix here of wine, beer, spirits. Basic selection befitting the fact this is a simple working class pub first and foremost.

Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️
Unusual (for the area) timber frame exterior with rickety, lived-in appearance inside. It's all well worn-in and has the feel of a long-standing venue.

Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
The epicentre of the town's social scene, so busy, buzzy and up-tempo with a younger crowd.

Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️
Live music, outdoor seating, snacks

Value For Money: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Good value for money considering they have a captive audience, cheap for Slovakia.

description: The epicentre of Komarno's nightlife, a market town pub in the main square with a busy, buzzy younger crowd. A wholly unpretentious establishment with simple offerings in a lived-in rickety building. Great value for basic offerings and good company. If that sounds like your thing you'll enjoy the place, and we certainly did. (Added June 2022)

name: Hostinec U Čierneho Psa
description:
EBG Rating:: 8
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️
Simple tap beer offerings despite the potentially promising frontage, but a well stocked back bar for wines and spirits.

Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Musical themed with some nice jazz and old time ephemera including instruments fixed to the wall. More distinctive than most Czech/Slovak pubs. One room leads deep into a building with a large seating area past the bar.

Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️
Sleepy and a little sad when quiet, but the place seems to come to life later on in the day, and then you can really capture its essence.

Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️
Live music, limited outdoor seating, limited meals. Darts.

Value For Money: ❤️❤️❤️
Decent enough value for money, largely not notable on this front either way.

description: Music themed pub with jazz and old-timer ephemera, a personalised space with some character. Limited beer options but a well-stocked back bar and famous for pork knee even if it seems to do virtually nothing else! Visit later on as crowds swell to get the best out of it. (Added June 2022)

name: Kollarko
description:
EBG Rating:: 7.7
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
A decent wide range of beer including various styles, focusing on smaller brewers from Czechia and Slovakia. Well stocked back bar which reflects the more diverse audience.

Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️
Intriguing location with rotunda exterior and windows looking over the main road up a small garden. The bar area is small and conservatory like with a round table on the patio with a degree of cover from the elements.

Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
This does have a feeling of a 'place to be' for locals with some tourists mixing in. Not overly pretentious but some characters taking a see and be seen approach, others turning up casually.

Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️
Outdoor seating, meals, snacks

Value For Money: ❤️❤️❤️
Slightly more expensive for the area.

description: A popular venue with a youngish crowd of twenty and thirty somethings which is houses in an interesting building. A conservatory type space in the bar itself with hatched windows leads to a round social space out front, well used and in demand during summer, but partly covered from the elements. Drinks are great with a wide range of beers from smaller breweries and a well stocked back bar accommodating the needs of a more diverse clientele than the male focused Pivaren you can find. Comes recommended. (Added June 2022)

name: Za rohom by Bombovar
description:
EBG Rating:: 7.6
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
6 taps and a fridge all selling the best of beer from smaller Slovakian breweries, a more tempting choice as the years go by.

Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️
Old time one-room streetside hospoda with a mezzanine level and bottom floor by the taps. Small and traditional in appearance with a minimalist feel. 

Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️
Locals with some craft beer fans from abroad, social and casual.

Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️
Snacks, limited outdoor seating. 

Value For Money: ❤️❤️
A little more expensive for the area even factoring in the improved drinks options.

description: One of those venues we walked past and thought, "Oh, that looks good." With no research whatsoever this turned out to be a solid choice and a good recommendation. A small interior that fits well as a little Knajpa or Pivaren rebooted for the 21st century. Old time decor, new time beers with craft on tap and in the fridge covering the best of Slovakian beers (which thankfully has improved substantially and gets better by the year). A local vibe and only really known more widely in craft beer circles, so you can expect a nice social neighbourly vibe. (Added June 2022)

name: Café DeRat
description:
EBG Rating:: 9
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️
High quality tap and bottle selection with local beers, craft beer from different corners of Europe and Belgian/Dutch classics. Well stocked back bar too.

Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Corner bar on a quiet street, some attractive brown café features. Ornate bar area with classical hanging lamps, large windows and old staircase with plenty of ephemera from times past, including the old Rat signage. 

Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Neighbourly, local but relevant. Cosmopolitan and international but unpretentious and friendly with that classic appealing Dutch mix.

Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Pub snacks, limited outdoor seating, community events, chess, board games.

Value For Money: ❤️❤️❤️
Fair considering the going rate.

description: One of the Netherlands classic café bars, a corner pub that makes everything that other bars make look difficult feel so simple. Typical trad corner neighbourhood location with some preserved interior features with wooden cabinets and a cellar accessed underneath one of the very pub tables. Characterful and quirky without being offputting in any way. Friendly service and customers that are both cosmopolitan, international and relaxed, unpretentious and welcoming. The beers are superb covering local breweries, contemporary craft and classic Belgian/Dutch favourites. There's plenty to do whether you're stroking the cat, chatting to the bar staff or playing board games. It's simply a brilliant social pub that should be on the corner of every street. (Added June 2022)

name: Cafe Scharrebier
description:
EBG Rating:: 8.1
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
The usual brown café classics on tap supplemented with Belgian bottles. A decent selection with a similarly classic selection of Jenevers, Brandywijn and Korenwijn at the back.

Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️
A simple one room café with a strong brown/gold appearance. Classic motifs from the detailed lettering on the glass windows to the ancient cupboards and bars. All achieving the 'gezellig' effect.

Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Atmospheric, cosy and homely while enjoying a touch of that historic elan and class from the faded grandeur aesthetic. A more local crowd despite a relatively central location and it's clear this is a regular haunt for some of the locals.

Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Pub snacks, toasties, board games, outdoor seating.

Value For Money: ❤️❤️❤️
Food is reasonable value, drinks are standard for the area (ie. expensive)

description: It seems almost contradictory to spend paragraphs praising something that is in its essence necessarily understated, but here we are. Scharrebier is happy being a relatively off-grid Amsterdam brown café popular with locals and with a neighbourhood vibe. Inside there's a classic and fairly intact ensemble constituting the classic brown café appearance. Warm, gold, brown hazy hues. Friendly service and decent value food are a bonus alongside typical tap and bottle options. The board game cupboard and chit-chat emphasises this is a true social hangout. That is all for the better. (Added June 2022)

name: Cafe de Druif
description:
EBG Rating:: 9.1
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
A classic Amsterdam range, decent beer selection supplemented with Jenever, Brandywijn and Korenwijn and classic lowlander bottles.

Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️
Extremely old rickety brown café interior with layer upon layer of history lining the walls. A very small bar facing the entrance with tiny seating area up a few steps to the left. Cafe furniture on the street corner.

Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️
Layers of character from the history of the place, over 100 years old and looks every inch of it. A local institution that has seen good times and bad.

Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️
Outdoor seating, basic pub snacks.

Value For Money: ❤️❤️
Around normal for the area, perhaps a tad more expensive.

description: One of Amsterdam's core bruine kroege/brown cafés, this centuries old tasting house stands on a corner by the canal leading to the docs, and has seen many good times and bad come and go. A real survivor and institution with brandy barrels behind the bar, ageing proprietors and cut, quirky, distinctive and unique appearance. A must visit in the city. (Added June 2022)

name: Café Langereis
description:
EBG Rating:: 8.2
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
A decent range of beers on tap with similarly versatile back bar. There's going to be something here for most.

Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Corner bar on a busy junction, a long room with some people handing out on the window ledges. Warm and welcoming inside with a personalised feel. Not tacky, not a work of art either. Something quite nice.

Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
A late bar at a busy junction, this area of the city is its own neighbourhood in a sense, and this occupies a central point. Popular and busy until the late hours, but the atmosphere always seems to stay the right side of buzzy and friendly versus chaotic and edgy.

Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️
Board games, snacks, limited outdoor seating, occasional live events.

Value For Money: ❤️❤️
Not the best but standard for the area.

description: The centrepoint hangout spot at a busy junction, the steps of the evening from craft beer bar to late bar to takeaway are only metres away forming a constant churn of traffic to and fro. That should in theory make the bar unpleasant but in fact it robustly maintains its cheerful, buzzy feel with a friendly welcome and versatile space as adept at late night revelry as it is for quiet afternoon supping. Mark down as a must visit for a late drink as its hours are very accommodating. (Added June 2022)

name: 't Aepjen
description:
EBG Rating:: 8.5
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
An ur-typical Amsterdam range with Gulpener beers, typical supplements from Belgian and Dutch classics and various spirits from Jenever to Korenwijn

Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️
One of the pubs strong points, with impressive large oil paintings, exposed beams, taxidermy and fairylights. A one-room pub facing a pedestrian street.

Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️
The decor whips up such an atmosphere that the place can be deathly quiet or full to bursting and still be extremely atmospheric. The place is inevitably very touristy and among the most in the city, not without good reason, but clearly changes the overall feel, not all negatively.

Amenities/Events: ❤️
Limited snacks

Value For Money: ❤️❤️
Inevitably pretty expensive.

description: A pub that has become a city institution, if largely for tourists rather than locals. That has not hindered its appeal overly however, with the fabulous oil paintings, taxidermy and ape theme combining to great effect with the typical high ceilinged brown café skeleton adding plenty of character with it. Service is typically friendly and the venue always seems to have the buzz behind it of people having a great time. Something about it seems to keep a lid on excess, which is extra impressive given the place is at the heart of the action. An essential visit. (Added June 2022)

name: Cafe Slijterij Oosterling
description:
EBG Rating:: 8.6
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️
A very typical selection of spirits and tapped beer here, none of which will particularly surprise or frustrate you.

Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Superb preserved decor with barrels everywhere you look. Barrels hoisted above the tables, barrels as tables, barrels behind the bar. Retro old-time signage which perfectly fits the rickety worn saloon style. Junction-side corner bar facing a park.

Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Characterful, as confirmed above, with a local crowd. 

Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️
Bar snacks, outdoor seating.

Value For Money: ❤️❤️
Typical Amsterdam prices.

description: One of the more characterful brown café interiors and a venue that is still enjoyed mainly by locals. A city institution well thought of and for good reason. Both stylish in its own worn way and casual in terms of friendly service and lack of pretension. A classic. (Added June 2022)

name: Cafe Gollem Raamsteeg
description:
EBG Rating:: 9
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️
Big selection of tapped beers of different styles, most of Dutch/lowlands origin. Even bigger bottle selection touching classic styles.

Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Simple worn-in, rickety old streetside bar with seating around the bar area by the entrance and mezzanine area up a few stairs overlooking the scene. Boards with the bottle options take up much of the wall.

Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️
Busy and buzzy, as could be expected from a famous Amsterdam boozer. Fairly touristy but not at a loss of atmosphere. Popular with beer monsters.

Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️
Pub snacks, cheese/sausage platters, board games

Value For Money: ❤️❤️❤️
Fairly standard for the area, nothing different to the norm.

description: Famous Amsterdam venue that has spawned offshoots but is still the original rickety place to be. A typical setup with bar area facing the front window and mezzanine with further seating. Small and cosy, the place stays open late, provides large cheese platters and a huge range of tap and bottled beer most of which is of a very high standard. A must visit. (Added June 2022)

name: Café "De Eland"
description:
EBG Rating:: 8.5
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️
A compact, competent range of typical Amsterdam options from the Dutch and Belgian staples, with Jenever and other spirits to back that up. 

Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Dark brown wood panelled interior with raised level further back overlooking the street. Candlelit with rickety furniture and old timer, faintly twee decor. A large central table lit like a pool table.

Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️
Brooding, candlelit and highly atmospheric cosy venue. This is the core reason to visit. Perfect to meet as a couple. A mixture of tourists and locals.

Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️
Limited outdoor seating, pub snacks.

Value For Money: ❤️❤️❤️
Normal for the area.

description: A wonderfully atmospheric bar that is so dark brown that even large windows facing the street don't really seem to let the light in. In the brooding murk of wood and candlelight enjoy a beer over a twee table and the atmosphere of intimate, though friendly pubgoing. A different speed here, but just as good as anything else going in the city. (Added June 2022)

name: Café Anno 1890
description:
EBG Rating:: 9
Choice/Quality of Drinks: Fairly corporate tap selection with some Belgian highlights and better bottled options.
Style/Décor: Large expanded venue with a cosy bar in the front room where locals congregate leading to two large rooms and a conservatory area, fit for hundreds of people. Each inch of it is personalised and very pubby in a way that may have gone completely out of fashion, but is nevertheless very well done.
Atmosphere/Character: Characterful interior with plenty of space to either congregate or find a quieter place to ponder. Wherever you sit there's something to look at. Nearby sports venues mean there can be a steady supply of passing trade supplementing the locals playing cards by the bar. 
Amenities/Events: Meals, games, outdoor seating.
Value For Money: Still relatively expensive even outside of central Amsterdam, relentless.
description: A true pub, which is like an expanded version of a brown café. Adorned with nik-naks and characterful lived-in personality - including some risque urinals - Dutch character on show here with a distinctly British/Irish influence. Almost like a roadside diner on the other hand with space for meals and set up to deal with a high volume of people. It is an excellent all-rounder and a must visit in the area. (added June 2022)

name: Proeflokaal Arendsnest
description:
EBG Rating:: 8
Choice/Quality of Drinks: The superb reviews are on account of the 50+ taps offering beers of different styles from Dutch breweries. Almost crowded out are the decent selection of Dutch spirits including some expensive rarities. It's a place for epicurists.
Style/Décor: Step up off the street to a small narrow bar with an impressive - and fairly shiny bar lined with stools. Limited seating elsewhere. Somewhere between a brown café and a more glitzy taproom.
Atmosphere/Character: Well-known and popular with tourists and beer-lovers on the Amsterdam beer trail. Service is friendly and the atmosphere is pretty good, if just a tiny wee bit staid.
Amenities/Events: Pub snacks, limited outdoor seating. Occasional beer events.
Value For Money: Slightly more expensive than the norm.
description: An epicurist's paradise with over 50 taps of Dutch beer and rare Jenever on offer, the place also fulfils its social function reasonably well too. It feels more natural to sit at the bar here, with the narrow space lending itself naturally to doing so. Colours are warm and the place is a halfway house between old, classic and modern. There is too much here to ignore and it should be firmly on a list of places to visit. (Added June 2022)

name: Onder de Ooievaar
description:
EBG Rating:: 8.2
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
A decent selection hovering around the typical central Amsterdam fare but with a few flourishes of difference.

Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Much more pubby than brown café in appearance with communal tables and exposed beams, familiar feel with homely decoration on the walls. A little bigger than some which explains the change in feel.

Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
A sense of stolid reliable bolthole with its corner location capturing passing trade and the interior atmosphere offering a good consistent experience.

Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️
Games, events, snacks, pub fodder.

Value For Money: ❤️❤️❤️
Standard for the area.

description: It's telling for Amsterdam that this excellent pub is merely a makeweight among the 20-30 best venues in the city rather than, as it would be nearly everywhere else, in the top 2 or 3. A classic pub on the corner of a junction capturing passing trade while being a reliable bolthole for regulars. Plenty of amenities, this has more of a community feel than some of the central pubs and deserves recognition, along with your custom. (added June 2022)

name: Café de Laurierboom
description:
EBG Rating:: 8.1
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️
A competent but not overly ambitious choice touching the familiar Amsterdam beers with one or two extras. Decent back bar.

Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
A one room corner affair with simple, homely, lived, and rather alternative but tidy and sensible feel.

Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
A chess pub, you'll find at least one game going on in the early evenings but that's not to say these games are played in hushed silence. Act just how you would anywhere else and enjoy a mellow but bohemian atmosphere alongside locals who are the main customers of this Jordaan pub.

Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️
Chess, pub snacks, occasional events.

Value For Money: ❤️❤️❤️
Fine for the area.

description: Chess and pubs, a decent combo, but it isn't all about chin stroking and quiet strategy,, it's a welcoming, friendly café bar with a mellow but quietly subversive, bohemian vibe. Well worth a look for local life in a relatively central part of Amsterdam. (added June 2022)

name: Café De Nieuwe Lelie
description:
EBG Rating:: 7.9
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Amsterdam classics with a few contemporary beers mixed in when it comes to both tap and bottles. A classic stock of back bar options.

Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Corner (yet again) bar with a mezzanine/balcony overlooking the bar and basement pool room. Old and creaky in the classic brown café mould.

Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
A versatile hangout spot that accommodates beer tasting, romantic get togethers, games of pool, and it's pretty small, all told, so that's very impressive.

Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️
Pool, pub snacks, limited outdoor seating (if any).

Value For Money: ❤️❤️❤️
Standard for the city.

description: Another, yet another corner bar, so what to say to drum up excitement for this one? Well, it's a brown café for sure, with classic appearance inside and out, rickety wooden mezzanine that slopes (mind your beer), a pool room in a half-step basement almost New York City style, and decent array of non-standard beer options. With fairylights and cosy corners for intimate chats around the bar, the place is surprisingly versatile, hence the fantastic reviews. (added June 2022)

name: Café Van Daele
description:
EBG Rating:: 8
Choice/Quality of Drinks: A decent selection of Dutch beers supplemented with Belgian classics. OK tap options overall and standard back bar with some Dutch jenevers.
Style/Décor: A little different, this has a strange shape and not the typical brown café design. Angular, not exactly elegant but certainly stylish with hanging lamps from a tall ceiling, tiny front seating area and a mezzanine overlooking the bar upstairs. 
Atmosphere/Character: A little 'towny' at times, which is its main drawback, the late opening too may contribute to the slight feeling of transient trade. It lacks a cast of regulars and focal point. That said, with all the negativity there's plenty happening and a buzz that may appeal to you.
Amenities/Events: Bar snacks, outdoor seating.
Value For Money: A bit more expensive than the average.
description: A change is as good as a rest, they say. Well, here is a bar that doesn't follow the brown café style, but instead picks inspiration from the interwar era with a striking hanging lamp and balcony overlooking an angular bar. Trade is busy, sometimes touristy and transient, but certainly active, and with plenty of beer to choose from, there is certainly reason to drop by and chance your arm. Just sneaks on our guide as a recommendation. (added June 2022)

name: Boar & Fable
description:
EBG Rating:: 7.6
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
A compact but varied selection of cask and craft keg with some European presence. Beer focused with some gin and cider options.

Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️
Reasonably homely one-room ale house with familiar appearance, falling somewhere between cafe and bar.

Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Friendly and relatively come-one-come-all atmosphere that is appealing, as such a place could without care be a little discriminating, but instead you'll get a warm welcome. Relaxing surroundings that have a degree of personalisation.

Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
TV, snacks, games, books.

Value For Money: ❤️❤️❤️
Nothing out of the ordinary for what's on offer, cask perhaps a little more expensive than average.

description: Based on a street with a congregation of little bars, Boar & Fable stands out in so much as it covers off various angles well to the point you can't really see any glaring weak spots. This reasonably cosy personalised ale house has a compact but well-ranged selection of beers and gins, a little TV, with books and board games tempting people to hang around. It's well worth a look. (added July 2022)

name: The Sair Inn
description:
EBG Rating:: 9.1
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️
10+ cask ales from the brewpub Linfit Ales, some unusual traditional strong ales among them. A standard range of lager and alternatives with some ciders.

Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️
Unspoilt village pub on a hilltop with flagstone floor, exposed beams and bench seating. Several side rooms off a main entrance and bar room including a snug. Large fireplace, heritage artwork and signage. Views over the valley. Musical instruments including a piano.

Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️
Atmospheric even when quiet, an 'if these walls could talk' pub that's all about the old school social values of pubgoing. Local life to be found along with the odd hiker and day tripper. 

Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️
Live music, pizza, dog friendly, outdoor seating, jukebox, games + books

Value For Money: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Good value for the local ales.

description: Rub your eyes and then rub them again, these pubs still do exist. A superb unspoilt social local Yorkshire pub that's all part of a brewpub operation. You'll find a large range of local ales, a step-back-in-time stone Inn with flagstone floor, old fireplace and low-slung exposed beams across several cosy rooms with bench seating. Good when quiet, exceptionally good when busy, with plenty on offer to keep it that way. Along with the local ales you'll find musical instruments and music nights, a pizza oven later in the week, community events, and outdoor seating. It's good value too for the ales. The sort of pub you dream about finding. The owners feel it is a bit of a love-or-hate place, but that sells it extremely short. Learn to love it because you'll be sorry when it's gone. One of the best pubs in Yorkshire. (Added July 2022)

name: Retsins Lucifernum
description:
EBG Rating:: 10
Choice/Quality of Drinks: Excellent cocktails prepared by the lady of the house, modest alternatives with a couple of bottled beers and back bar of spirits.
Style/Décor: A difficult venue to describe. An art gallery in an opulent art nouveau mansion with many rooms leading to a drinking area in the kitchen and verdant courtyard. Gothic art and affected lighting in the art space.
Atmosphere/Character: You won't have been anywhere like it, from the deliberately 'Dracula's butler' type introduction at the door, to the maze of art accompanied by Edgar Allen Poe excerpts, conservatory roofs, comic erotica, babies heads, plastic food, circus props, and jungle of a garden. A private, intimate yet fun, social experience that is macabre, totally unpredictable but once in a lifetime.
Amenities/Events: Occasional food/dancing events, outdoor seating.
Value For Money: May seem expensive for entry, but you are really paying 5 euros for an art gallery and 10 euros for a cocktail, which is not bad at all. Every drink after that is a regular price.
description: One of Europe's best bars, a labour of love, something totally macabre, off-the-wall and out-there in concept, a life experience as well as a place for a drink. The 'butler' with his Brylcreemed hair invites you to explore a mansion of gothic art, antiques and ephemera which eventually leads to a downstairs bar and garden courtyard. That isn't even the half of it. Mad antics and superb cocktails along with social conversation with the other guests in a private setting limited to only 20 people at any one time. Limited opening hours also, so plan in advance! Simply unmissable. (Added July 2022)

name: Cafe Kulminator
description:
EBG Rating:: 10
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️
Unique collection of privately aged Belgian ales going back decades, with a full roster of Belgian classics and some around Europe too.

Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️
Cluttered lived-in sitting room with books, board-games, plants and every other thing that makes a home a home. The bar area becomes gradually more cluttered as years go by. A small backyard area for outdoor seating.

Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️
A wonderful, private, safe and calm atmosphere aided by a soundtrack of classical music and the calm, friendly comings and goings of Leen, one half of Café Kulminator. The erratic other half Dirk potters around, sometimes half-stupefied tolerating rather than aiding what's going on.

Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Food (check the beer bible, it exists), books, board games, outdoor seating.

Value For Money: ❤️❤️❤️
Fair given what's on offer.

description: One of the best beer venues in Europe, and also notable for its special qualities aside of that. Dirk & Leen run the place, now an elderly couple, and have decades of experience cellaring Belgian ale of all kinds. These stay in the cellar for years maturing and taking on different qualities. This is the core appeal from a drinking perspective. From a pub going perspective it hardly gets homelier with surroundings that put you at ease, like being in someone's living room rather than a pub. Cluttered and personalised with books, games, comfy seating and made welcome by Leen's kindly service. Dirk is a bit more of a loose cannon, sometimes grumpy, sometimes in a stupor, tolerating what's happening but no more than that. This culminates (get it!) into a really special, intimate and lovely experience. Those who don't care for clutter or idiosyncratic service are advised to seer clear. Check opening times carefully which reduce as the years go by, and on entering do confirm that you are there to 'taste' rather than drink a nice beer. (Added July 2022)

name: Oud Arsenaal
description:
EBG Rating:: 8.7
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Antwerpen classics like Bolleke along with a really traditional selection of well known Belgian/Trappist offerings in tap and bottle. Check out the Gueuze/Sour menu in the corner for some special beers. A competent back bar offering some Duch Jenever too.

Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️
A preserved Jewel with original wood fittings, beautiful lights and tiled flooring. A very small space with wooden bench seating facing a dinky bar, with further seats adjacent to it. Decorated with breweriana and some old timer Belgian stuff (think cycling and other sport). 

Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Characterful all of its own, a pub you could sit happily in on your own. However, due to the central location and its qualities, you will nearly never find yourself alone in this pub. Still jealously guarded by locals, this tourist has a real mix, a bit like some of the best venues in Prague, meaning you're as likely to find an inebriated following holding court at the bar in dirty overalls as you are a romantic couple in the corner having a chat. Democracy is alive here.

Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️
Limited snacks, newspapers, outdoor seating, pub cats

Value For Money: ❤️❤️❤️
Nothing out of the ordinary for the area, not notably good value either.

description: One of Antwerp's jewels, a preserved little brown café with all the cosy/gezellig qualities you'd hope to find from such a venue. The patina of character only grows with the years, and the location of the bar is so out of keeping it looks like it has beamed down from space. Hugely popular with a wide range of people across classes and backgrounds, with locals jealously guarding it, while never making you feel unwelcome. Beer selection is good with a little range of sours and gueuzes for specialist drinkers, and as the sense of institution pervades almost everything about the place, ordering a Bolleke of De Koninck feels appropriate, where it is often said to be among the freshest and best poured in the city. (added July 2022)

name: Den Engel
description:
EBG Rating:: 9
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️
Antwerp classics, on a compact but effectively normal everyday menu, supplemented with some bottle choices. It's Belgium so a gueuze may be casually placed in there.

Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️
One of the bar's strongest features is its characterful historic interior with almost scorched ceiling from years of smoke and heat, something almost playfully referenced by helmets from the fire brigate and police department. Retro signage, breweriana, long bench seating and stools at the bar. Really a classic setup.

Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Local life abounding even in the centre of the Grote Markt, this is pretty much the epicentre of Antwerp's social scene, and it knows it. But what makes that special is the democracy - there are no class barriers in here.

Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️
Limited snacks, outdoor seating, fire

Value For Money: ❤️❤️❤️
Surprisingly reasonabl given prime location on the central square. Fair prices kept that way to keep loyal customers and presumably due to an equally honest operation.

description: One of Antwerp's and therefore Belgium's finest bars, characterful local life of all classes gather here in what feels like the epicentre of Antwerp's social activity and rumour mill. Even when it isn't jam-packed the place still feels like where you'd go to pick up on the latest events or find a friend having a quiet drink. That says a great deal. This is before you get to the wonderfully characterful venue with its scorched ceiling, steam heater, array of fire and police hats and tiled floor. Much to see and enjoy - at fair prices too, an honest operation and a great bar. (Added July 2022)

name: De Kroon Van Hopland
description:
EBG Rating:: 8.5
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️
Compact selection of beers, aperitivo, wine, spirits etc. Stripped back which helps in a way, but don't be expecting any vast beer menu here.

Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️
Quirky yet traditional. Another venue which is a brown café but saying that hardly sums it up at all. Distinctive with greenery, a mannequin sat by the entrance, some colonial influences in the decoration, mirrors, tiled floor and a smart bar area facing a small one-room corner pub with a terrace.

Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️
This is a popular, well reviewed spot with a core crowd of locals and proximity to a major metro stop. They invite locals to make use of a restaurant over the road and bring their food over to eat, which is always a nice co-operative thing to do. Brooding interior with an atmosphere all of its own, fun with an eclectic sound track. At ease with itself, meaning you're likely to find elderly regulars stewing away alongside hipsters.

Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️
Outdoor seating, limited snacks, books.

Value For Money: ❤️❤️❤️
Standard for the area, perhaps 10/20 cents higher in some regards, nothing offensive.

description: A core Antwerp venue that takes a brown café concept, expanding on it with funky, quirky, if not slightly macabre decor. There's a mannequin sat in a wicker chair by the entrance, vague colonial stylings and oozing neon light in the evening alongside eclectic music selection. The adjacent restaurant offers food delivery you can eat in the pub, there's a social terrace out front and a smart little bar churning out a stripped back selection. The locals don't seem to mind at all, as reviews attest. Due to its location it is a venue never far from your thoughts as you traverse the city for the next watering hole. (Added July 2022)

name: The Golden Fish
description:
EBG Rating:: 8
Choice/Quality of Drinks: A decent enough beer range with a wider mix on account of the more versatile venue pointing in several directions.
Style/Décor: Beautiful nouveau exterior leading to a tasteful cafe interior with tiled floor, vases, classic film posters and mirrors. A verdant terrace area overlooks the river. All very stylish without being austere or unwelcoming.
Atmosphere/Character: Understated class complimented by a friendly mixed crowd and good service, adept enough to accommodate romantic couples, groups of students, older folks without any contingent pulling the feel of the place overly in either direction.
Amenities/Events: Food, community events, outdoor seating
Value For Money: Fair for the area and the style of the place.
description: This elegant cafe backs out onto the Dijle river making its terrace one of the most popular summer choices. However, there is much to admire about the interior from its art nouveau frontage, large mirrors and tasteful film posters, this establishes a convincing ensemble with a heady, atmospheric effect. It isn't overbearing either, allowing for an unusual versatility, different groups rubbing shoulders with one another with ease. Always difficult to achieve and a reason to give this place considerable merit, nearly worth of a 9/10. (Added July 2022)

name: Folklore
description:
EBG Rating:: 8
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️
Classic lagers with a few additional taps of Belgian traditionals. As a neighbourhood brown café serving locals, this is normal.

Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️
Wonderful cosy, gezellig interior with brewery signage, exposed brick and comfortable rickety furniture. A one room setup with the bar at the back. Small terrace out front.

Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️
This is a social atmosphere where conversation turns inwards. A locals joint but not an unwelcoming one. The owners and their son come back and forth and welcome business along with newcomers.

Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️
Books, games, snacks, outdoor seating.

Value For Money: ❤️❤️❤️
Fair for the area.

description: "One of the last remaining true brown cafes" - good reviews and a real traditional pub look. A very typical Ghent snack to try is Kroakemandels: these are heavily salted peas which are deep-fried in oil. Locals savour this not so healthy snack during the Ghent Festivities. However out of festival season, you can try this at the quirky Cafe Folklore which is located in the Patersoll neighborhood. Folklore is one of Ghent’s last real brown cafés. Owner Jacques is a real character with lots of stories to tell. The cafe serves a nice range of beers and obviously the house speciality, the Kroakemandels. Brewery signage along with a warm welcome adds to the sense of cosiness in this small, local pub. One of these places that will one day suddenly vanish and never re-open. Make plans to visit. (Added July 2022)

name: Quinten Matsijs
description:
EBG Rating:: 8.5
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️
A solid range of Belgian classics with a few less common tap options, nothing too obscure or modern though. A compact but competent range of alternatives including wines and Jenevers.

Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️
Beautiful old pub covered in ivy on the exterior, tinted leaded glass windows and a wooden interior with bench seats, large tables and candelabras almost in the style of a German wirthaus, but older still. Old paintings on the wall.

Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
A preserved historic venue in a city centre, with all that entails. Transient custom but a sense of institution too. Above all else, it is comfortable, pleasant and cosy inside.

Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️
Food, outdoor seating, snacks

Value For Money: ❤️❤️❤️
City prices, but not extortionate.

description: It argues to be Antwerp's oldest pub. Whether that's true or not is up for debate, but more importantly than its age is how effective it is. A truly beautiful venue with climbing ivy running rampant up the exterior walls and tinted leaded glass in the windows that create an almost holy calm in the cosy wooden interior with its large table, bench seating and candelabras. Reminiscent of Café Vlissinghe in Bruges along with the oil paintings, but just not quite as quirky or outstanding. That is not exactly a criticism, as the venue still remains one of Antwerp's finest. Take a moment to enjoy the transition from medieval to 1970s as you pay a visit to the bathrooms! (Added July 2022)

name: Gaarkeuken 110
description:
EBG Rating:: 8
Choice/Quality of Drinks: Simple tap options targeted at nearby workers, so De Koninck and basic lagers, with a perfunctory selection of classic bottles for pickier customers.
Style/Décor: A huge black hut with the name printed in large letters makes quite an impression as you emerge from the retail park. Shipping containers and a more modern hipster courtyard do not give much of a clue to the interior. Head inside to find a large long Eetcafé with high ceilings and preserved decor, from the cream walls, to the grooved worn away bench seating to the tiled floor. A bar opposite is busy with kitchen orders and bills.
Atmosphere/Character: A busy, bustling atmosphere inside as the kitchen delivers multiple food orders with lightning speed. Service is occasionally hurried but still scrupulously pleasant and polite. A democratic place with a range of people from mucky dockworkers in their overalls to young families. 
Amenities/Events: Outdoor seating, meals
Value For Money: Good value versus the city centre, especially for the food portions which are enormous.
description: One of the last surviving dockworker's kitchen Eetcafés. Closed at weekends and closes at 8pm on weekdays. Loyal, committed ownership and following. Hearty food, democratic prices and cheap good beer. It's an adventure to find, with a tram and a walk through an industrial estate, you emerge by wind turbines and a busy through road to find this large black hut, containing the preserved century old interior and all the warmth and welcome you are praying awaits you inside. Meals are hearty and enormous, service is busy but unfailingly polite and pleasant, the atmosphere is matter of fact, that is to say unpretentious and without artifice or conceit, while not being especially cliquey, arch or off-putting. A genuine achievement. With a new cult following supplementing the local workers, its future looks secure. Really, really worth the trip out. (Added July 2022)

name: Cafe De Kat
description:
EBG Rating:: 8
Choice/Quality of Drinks: Simple Antwerp fare at this deliberately stripped back brown café. A few taps with a bottle selection of Belgian classics. Stock, if perfunctory alternatives. 
Style/Décor: An ur-typical brown café, one room corner setup with worn wooden furniture and preserved bar area, tiled floor. Decorated with posters advertising the latest concerts.
Atmosphere/Character: Popular with a range of ages, there is a stolidity that attracts both old and new, central location not hurting either. A throwback venue for atmosphere, which is both dusty, social and lively depending on custom and time of day. 
Amenities/Events: Limited outdoor seating, snacks, board games.
Value For Money: Fair for the centre
description: If you were to show someone an example of a brown café, De Kat would not be far away from the most typical of the genre. One room corner café with worn light wood fittings, a patina of age and some splendidly aged elegant features at the bar and across the floor in the shape of classic Antwerpse tiling. The custom is mixed from a core crowd of older regulars to a similarly loyal younger crowd who use it as a fashionable hangout, signs of which are evident by the film posters on the wall. You could do better in Antwerp, a little bit here and there, but you could also do miles, miles worse. One of the best pubs in the city. (Added July 2022)

name: Beers Yesterday's World
description:
EBG Rating:: 8
Choice/Quality of Drinks: A decent selection of Belgian classics on tap and in bottle. While not offering the most refined or up-to-date selection, there is plenty to dig into from the conventional range after all. Competent back bar which is not the focus but is adequately stocked.
Style/Décor: As the name suggests, you'll find antiques stretching from flowery ornaments to film memorabilia. A one room setup with a terrace out the back and corridor with further cabinets, this is intended to be both a work of art and contemplative.
Atmosphere/Character: As with most cluttersome antiquey bars, you can visit and always have something to look at, making it suitable for quiet and busier times. The duo at the bar are polite enough although you get the impression the place is intended for tourists rather than locals overall.
Amenities/Events: Outdoor seating, snacks, music on tv
Value For Money: Nothing out of the ordinary, albeit maybe 10 or 20 cents more in places.
description: Although the sidestreet doesn't receive the most footfall of Bruges' medieval alleys, this venue is intended to capture passing trade from tourists. The antiquey nature of this is perfect to snaring visitors seeking a slice of something out of the ordinary. Yesterday's World seems both irrelevant yet grandiose as a name, but in fact neither are accurate to describe it. The venue is indeed relevant and does good trade from word of mouth, but grandiose it is not. A small one room setup with a cabinet lined corridor and shelf filled with antiques and film memorabilia, much of which is for sale. A leafy courtyard out the back provides an alternative. Service is reasonably efficient if not warm and there is always plenty to look at, indeed you may find yourself sat in the cinema stalls facing the front window! Characterful, a degree of charm and worth a look. (Added July 2022)

name: De Blauwe Kater
description:
EBG Rating:: 8
Choice/Quality of Drinks: A decent enough tap range of Belgian classics with some rotation, with a much better extensive bottle menu, albeit still focused on traditional options rather than specialist or craft-leaning ones.
Style/Décor: The whitewashed frontage with awning projects a rather upright café type venue, but once inside, rickety furniture and exposed beams including into a snug and mezzanine level around a curved frame are quite rustic. Decorated with many old jazz concert posters.
Atmosphere/Character: Characterful and it feels like in winter the place will come alive. In summer terrace drinking on the square takes precedence and you may find it rather sleepy inside. Service is busy but friendly when given opportunity.
Amenities/Events: Live music, outdoor seating, snacks, books and board games
Value For Money: Given the suburban location and outside the capital you may expect a little more value on show than is present here, however the prices are not offensively more than normal.
description: Popular and well reviewed music-focused pub with a rather upright appearance with its whitewashed exterior, awning and patio furniture, before you dive in to find a characterful and quirky rickety pub with snug and mezzanine level, with part-rotunda type framing. This is complimented by regular live Jazz performances and posters from old gigs, along with decent tap options and extensive bottle options along the lines of the Belgian classics. A must visit in Leuven which despite the 'longest bar in Europe' one the Oude Markt is not furnished with the finest bars in Belgium, putting it mildly. (added July 2022)

name: Elfde Gebod
description:
EBG Rating:: 8.2
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️
House beers with a decent range on tap and extensive menu. This is a tourist led palace of beers with a large selection of classic Belgian ales dominating.

Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️
The theme of the bar is its religious iconography, statuettes and collection of figurines. There are over 200, some of which are several feet tall in side. Alongside the classic Belgian surroundings of exposed beams and creaky staircases it creates a heady effect.

Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
There is no doubt the theme provokes a degree of gawking, and the tourist element is made worse by the constant queuing at the door for a table and table service format. Once seated, matters improve. Service is relatively swift and civil, and the tables allow for a degree of socialising rather than simply private groups. General excitement abounds as it feels almost like being part of an ancient ritual for the first time.

Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️
Meals, outdoor seating, snacks

Value For Money: ❤️❤️
More expensive than normal, though not egregiously so.

description: The theme of the bar is its religious iconography, statuettes and collection of figurines. There are over 200, some of which are several feet tall in side. Alongside the classic Belgian surroundings of exposed beams and creaky staircases it creates a heady effect. There is no doubt the theme provokes a degree of gawking, and the tourist element is made worse by the constant queuing at the door for a table and table service format. Once seated, matters improve. Service is relatively swift and civil, and the tables allow for a degree of socialising rather than simply private groups. General excitement abounds as it feels almost like being part of an ancient ritual for the first time. With its extensive beer menu and meals, you'll be well catered for. It's a shame to some degree that the place has inevitably become a bit gimmicky and over-touristy, but that hasn't totally spoiled it and there is plenty of enjoyment to be found. (Added July 2022)

name: Dulle Griet
description:
EBG Rating:: 8
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️
Extensive beer selection with house beers and traditional classics extending to a few specialist options.

Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Based on a market square with a patio on the front, there is a large bar room with a long bar along the side. Dark wood with brewery signage the style firmly focused on age and character. There is a backroom too. Mind the staircase which can be dangerous after a few drinks.

Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Clearly a city institution with a mixture of visitors and locals. Heaving on winter evenings, festivals and weekends, it pays to visit later on. That said, with attractive plants at the entrance, quirky signage and a pile of beers to aim at, a quiet drink is still possible, and enjoyable. 

Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️
A shoe based challenge where you donate one of your shoes which they string up until you have drunk the famous MAX, a yard of strong ale. Food, snacks, outdoor seating.

Value For Money: ❤️❤️
A little more expensive than most, although there are budget options.

description: Ghent's foremost brown café, pub and city institution, this is the epicentre of most of the beer-based nightlife. A long bar set up to mass cater for hordes that descend at certain times of year, there are nice touches that still make it cosy when it's quiet. The place has a sense of knackeredness as you'd expect from hosting so many late night piss-ups, which is partly characterful, partly genuinely knackered. For now we are happy to recommend it, and think a few more visits might help ingratiate this bar to us even more. (Added July 2022)

name: Pelikaan
description:
EBG Rating:: 8
Choice/Quality of Drinks: A classic Antwerp range, compact which is in keeping with the pub itself.
Style/Décor: Tiny venue with some opulent early 20th century designs and neons, along with more familiar characteristics - long wooden bench seating, rickety furniture, mirrors and panels. 
Atmosphere/Character: Almost a split personality with a café/locals pub atmosphere during the day turning out into the street in the evening, overflowing with customers. The place is so small that you feel it is a shared experience, somewhat. A city institution too, with all that entails.
Amenities/Events: Outdoor seating, snacks
Value For Money: Not unreasonable for the area.
description: The tiny dinky Pelikaan has a bright opulent design that is distinctive, perhaps not to everyone's tastes but nevertheless memorable. It is twinned with characterful preserved decor from the bar to the elderly bench seating. During the day it feels pokey and almost uncomfortably intimate at times, as locals come and go, cheek by jowl. At night the action overflows into the streets, the bar itself shining like a beacon. An interesting venue and definitely one you could love. (Added July 2022)

name: Paters Vaetje
description:
EBG Rating:: 8
Choice/Quality of Drinks: A decent beer selection on tap a step above the normal Antwerp selection without being dramatic. Decent range of bottles and competent back bar.
Style/Décor: Unprepossessing exterior with a terrace leads to a cute little bar with limited seating dominated by an almost church like panel of gothic arches above an old wooden bar, with a steam heater splitting the bench seats. Limited additional room upstairs. Vatje means 'little barrel', you can certainly see why.
Atmosphere/Character: One of Antwerp's core central pubs with a constantly stream of visitors. Not totally taken up with tourists but largely serving out-of-towners. The interior is cosy and characterful, promoting social interaction, all for the better.
Amenities/Events: Outdoor seating, basic food & snacks
Value For Money: A little more expensive than average.
description: One of the central Antwerp tour pubs, mere minutes away from half a dozen others, with transient custom to match. The interior is quirky and characterful though with its tiny bar, church window like panels, steam heater and rickety mezzanine level. It's tiny, cosy and promotes social interaction while serving very good Belgian beer. Sounds good to us, and it is. (Added July 2022)

name: The Old Bridge Inn Ripponden
description:
EBG Rating:: 7.8
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️
Surprisingly diverse beer range, beginning with the more familiar sight of the full Timothy Taylor's cask range, before guest ales, craft keg and Belgian ales catch the eye, competent if less exciting back bar.

Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️
A cottage dating back to the 1300s with a beautiful exterior complimented by cobbled streets, riverside setting, packhorse bridge, church and willow trees. Somewhat idyllic. Inside the place is crooked with off centre beams and rickety fittings, but opened out to an extent, with exposed beams and rafters. The social space is slightly lacking a communal area.

Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️
As above, the main drawback to the pub is a lack of bench seating, now all tables set for dinner, leaving only the bar area and front of the pub for socialising. This does appear to be a bit of a shame and the only real drawback to the place. It can feel pokey when busy.

Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️
Food, community events, outdoor seating

Value For Money: ❤️❤️❤️
Drinks are a little expensive but food is good quality and fairly priced.

description: A gem of a country inn that has retained its historic character rather than becoming a shell with a blue plaque on it. Complimented by a great selection of local cask ale and bottled beers from Belgian, stunning setting with historic ensemble of cobbles, packhorse bridge and church by a willow-lined river. Hearty Sunday meals and a situation within easy reach gives plenty of reason to return. (Added July 2022)

name: 't Licht der Dokken
description:
EBG Rating:: 8
Choice/Quality of Drinks: Standard Antwerpse fair with basic Belgian lagers complimented by classic traditional bottles.
Style/Décor: An attractive genteel brown café with nicely aged, worn wood, net curtains. Based on the corner of the dock, there are pleasant views inside and out. A smallish place that would fill up very quickly in winter. One of the closest Antwerp venues to Amsterdam's brown cafés in style.
Atmosphere/Character: Local life here from regulars to occasional throngs of cyclists. People know about the place and it's a handy bolthole for those living in the area. Well thought of with a nice rhythm that can be enjoyed as you sit and spectate on proceedings. 
Amenities/Events: Outdoor seating, snacks, sweet tray!
Value For Money: Fair 
description: One of Antwerp's brown cafés, worn wood and genteel furnishings with net curtain, that is so close to the water, it feels almost like you could be in Rotterdam or Amsterdam. While it may look like a relic, it remains relevant to locals and provides a handy bolthole for the occasional cyclist group or community event, with a rhythm that very much suggests a presence that projects past a few mouldy old regulars. Easily worth the walk over for views of the dock and a friendly little slice of local life. Drinks are basic, but as this is Belgium, that still means there are some exquisite beers to enjoy. (Added July 2022)

name: Dansing Chocola
description:
EBG Rating:: 8
Choice/Quality of Drinks: A different balance here with wine, aperitivo, beers and spirits given an even spread. Choice is not vast for any, but it is compact and easy to choose. You may find one or two more craft-angled beers here.
Style/Décor: A very strong suit for the venue is its decor, lush and verdant with plants decked around what is a large opened out corner townhouse with a high ceiling and mezzanine level overlooking the bar. Funky, cool, with a hint of the macabre at times to the eclectic decor.
Atmosphere/Character: Loungey during the day and lively at night, this is a versatile space aiming at a more specific target market than the average brown café. Not at all bland, this is the type of venue you'd expect somewhere like Budapest over Belgium.
Amenities/Events: Outdoor seating, food, occasional events
Value For Money: A little higher than average, but not outrageously so.
description: When brown cafés become monotonous, Dansing Chocola is a strong option for a little visual variety - and how. The high-ceilinged venue resembles the sort of space you'd find in one of Budapest's Austrian-era mansions rather than a Belgian backstreet, and it is decorated with plants, funky bits and pieces and eclectic, going on macabre recovered items. The drinks selection is varied and the offering more unisex than the average old man boozer, certainly. While loungey during the day, this is an interesting and cool place to lounge in, and becomes steadily more so as the evening picks up. Take note. (Added July 2022)

name: De Muze
description:
EBG Rating:: 8
Choice/Quality of Drinks: Decent fare with a good range of both beers and cocktails. The bar is versatile and set up to cater for most needs, but doesn't do so perfunctorily, some thought has gone into it.
Style/Décor: A multi-storey venue, a strange choice for a music venue with no obvious gathering point and plenty of obstructions for the view of the stage, but they have somehow turned that into a bit of a quirk. Exposed beams and large decorations suspended from the ceiling set the scene, with plenty of niches to do pretty much whatever in.
Atmosphere/Character: A large collegiate venue tends to attract the corresponding custom. Younger, yes, but not exclusively so. Live jazz pulls in a good range of people, while others are there for the vastness of space and odd but present counterbalance balance of intimacy.
Amenities/Events: Live music, snacks, outdoor seating, occasional community events
Value For Money: Fine considering the social epicentre of an Antwerp evening is basically here.
description: In the very centre of Antwerp, this live music venue is not only at the hub but is the hub of the city's social scene. A characterful 3 storey bar without an obvious focal point for viewing the music, but instead a sprawling venue of niches, overlooks, columns and exposed beams. Fairylights and odd fixed decorations complete the set. Drinks are varied and most people are well catered for here at a fair going rate for the area, and being here feels like you are part of something, something that has been around a while too. This deserves credit, even if it is occasionally let down by people with headphones on on their laptops in a corner. (Added July 2022)

name: Boer van Tienen
description:
EBG Rating:: 8
Choice/Quality of Drinks: You've heard this already by now right? A staple of Antwerp classics on tap with only a little rotation now and then, backed up by traditional Belgian classics.
Style/Décor: Three layers here, firstly the terrace, then a covered terrace, then finally the bar itself, which is merely a dinky little brown café with tiled floor, ancient beams and lots of very satisfactory pleasant aged wood.
Atmosphere/Character: A little more everyday, so that means more music, more telly and more back bar griping and so forth. Not that this spoils it exactly, but anyone hoping for a puritanic worship of wood and beer in the calm may find that sanctity is shattered by surrounding events. It's social, it's relevant and it has an identity. Service is to the point, but quick.
Amenities/Events: Outdoor seating, light meals and snacks, TV, jukebox, occasional events
Value For Money: Nothing to cause even the flicker of an eye in either direction.
description: While there are some gripes about service, those are context specific and can be disregarded. If you are coming for a drink and sit in the pub itself, there's much to enjoy, from the tiled floor, beautifully aged wood and personalised interior, to the selection of classic Antwerp beers and local life and rhythm to be found. While it won't hit the heights of others, it will link together a bar crawl well, while providing visual interest and a certain consistency. (Added July 2022)

name: De Windmolen
description:
EBG Rating:: 8
Choice/Quality of Drinks: Brugse Zot on tap, which has become a standard all over the city, with a small but careful selection of alternatives, backed up with a decent bottle selection. They aren't know for their specialist drinks but based are covered adequately without compromises.
Style/Décor: Lovely brick townhouse on a corner by the canal and historic windmills. The lane following to the centre is cobbled, long and picturesque. Tables are set out on the corner in warmer weather. Inside plants, exposed beams and brickwork and complimented by breweriana and local heritage, in the manner you'd hoped and expect from such a pub.
Atmosphere/Character: A pleasant environment which is still largely run by and for locals rather than tourists, something notable in a city like Bruges. This isn't to say it's cliquey. Be patient for service, as when it comes, you will be treated as politely as any other guest.
Amenities/Events: Meals, board games, outdoor seating, snacks
Value For Money: Entirely ordinary, however don't expect any cheap discounts for locals, This is pitched as high as you'll find in the centre.
description: Definitely a pub rather than a café or restaurant, something defined as much by the social life surrounding it than anything else. It's also away from the tourist hustle in the centre, meaning locals find some breathing space while happily accepting the custom of any visitors who drop by. This creates a pleasing balance. The venue itself has tables on a corner by the old windmills (hence the name), while inside a very sympathetic blend of house plants and exposed wood and brick, decorated with breweriana and local heritage create what is an all-round nice place to be. We recommend visiting in the colder months due to the fly and wasp issues in summer.  (added July 2022)

name: Billie's
description:
EBG Rating:: 8
Choice/Quality of Drinks: Craft beer styles on tap and bottles covering most bases of that ouvre well, almost pointed focus away from what is generally available elsewhere. Sadly despite the Pilsner Urquell side pour tap and sign outside, that has long gone.
Style/Décor: Tiled floor and iconic bulldog mural on the side of the building make this memorable. A two storey interior which is a little bit obstructed.
Atmosphere/Character: The interior is a little obstructed to really be considered social or cosy, reinforced by high chairs which does not work with the Estaminet idea of food and beer. Nevertheless, with decent decor and human life, something just about wins out amongst that.
Amenities/Events: Food, snacks, outdoor seating, limited games
Value For Money: More expensive as befits the craft beer operation.
description: Billie's is certainly a distinctive venue and one to bookmark for Antwerp, It's difficult to muster quite the same level of excitement as other reviews. If you prize craft beer above all else, you will want to visit here, with its tap options more relevant and contemporary, as well as more varied. However, some of the original concept has fallen by the wayside. A side pour PU tap goes unused along with a few other gimmicks. In its stead, you will be presented with the familiar craft focus on pales, stouts and sours, which makes a change from some of the traditional Antwerp bars - but, let's face it, they aren't exactly bad! A large dog mural outside is iconic as is the tiled floor, yet another venue to preserver that well. In a small two-storey bar atmosphere is huddled but without the exact social element you're looking for, making this a missed opportunity for something great rather than a great bar itself. Constant kitchen smell also interferes with the idea of it as a drinking hole, however it is positioned as an Estaminet and needs to be treated as such, despite the high chairs. (Added July 2022)

name: De Duifkens
description:
EBG Rating:: 8
Choice/Quality of Drinks: Standard Antwerp fare.
Style/Décor: Striking neon signage outside in an old townhouse that sticks out on the small square. Large terrace leads to a bunker like wooden interior. Look up to find a baby doll breaking through the ceiling - just another day in Belgium.
Atmosphere/Character: A local's bunker, if you head to the bar you'll find a different rhythm less catered for tourists even than their own patio. Quite cosy and bunker like inside, but one that would work much better in the colder, wetter months (of which Belgium has many)
Amenities/Events: Snacks, games, outdoor seating
Value For Money: Fair, but nothing notable.
description: A well-reviewed local brown café still patronised by Antwerp folk rather than tourists, with all the rhythm and local patter than entails. Striking exterior with blue neons and terrace on the square leads to a bunker of dark wood with movie posters, beer signage and a baby breaking through the ceiling - just another day in Belgium. Drinks are standard fare for the city, which means at any one time several fantastic bottles are available with freshly tapped De Koninck, allowing you to drink like a local. Be polite and bring a sense of humour with you. (Added July 2022)

name: Au Laboureur
description:
EBG Rating:: 8
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
A traditional macro-brew selection on tap with occasional specials. Beer bottle selection is fairly good with one or two less usual Belgian options. Otherwise stock back bar for alternatives.

Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Corner brown café with wood fittings and pubby feel in all seasons. Some nice old elements such as a gueuze bottle opener and old savings bank on the wall. Nothing dramatic, yet a quiet undemonstrative class to it. Artwork of the former long-standing owner on the wall.

Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️
Local life clings on at this popular stop-off. Come armed with some necessary French phrases and don't expect tourist style service.

Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️
Outdoor seating, bar snacks, games

Value For Money: ❤️❤️❤️
Fair for the area.

description: It has taken several visits before finally winning us over. By Brussels standards this 'ordinary pub' may not have the quirks or ornate decor of others, but the overall ensemble with preserved features, complimented by local life and rhythm is distinctive in a way all of its own, an almost ur-typical traditional corner café mourning its long-standing owner is kept alive and relevant by a core of locals as well as visitors passing up and down Rue de Flandres. Bar options tilt towards classics rather than modern, though this is in keeping with the surroundings. An understated but effective choice.  (Added July 2022)

name: De Vagant
description:
EBG Rating:: 8
Choice/Quality of Drinks: A stripped back selection in tune with what is essentially a minimalist operation. Some slightly more craft-leaning options.
Style/Décor: An arch minimalist brown café, decluttered leaving simple wooden furniture, tiled floor and attractive bar area at the end. A certain stately elegance.
Atmosphere/Character: The stripped-back nature almost removes some of the cosy charm of this brown café but there is still some to be found. Aiming at a more modern, contemporary crowd with a hint to the past, attracting the kind of audience you'd expect. Chess and board games are played alongside glasses of beer, non-mainstream soundtrack. You get the idea.
Amenities/Events: Board games, snacks.
Value For Money: Perhaps a few cents more expensive than the norm.
description: De Vagant is a minimalist bar breaking down a brown café into its essential components so mercilessly that it almost throws the baby out with the bathwater. This is an attempt to bring the format into the present day, aiming at a younger modern crowd. There is still ever present café social life to enjoy from the beer to the board games to the rickety furniture. Definitely a venue to have up your sleeve, but unlikely to be the one place in Antwerp you rush home to tell people about. Nevertheless, anything in the top 30 in Antwerp is pretty good, which this is. (Added July 2022)

name: Moeder Lambic Original
description:
EBG Rating:: 7.5
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️
The best and most relevant Belgian beers available on tap and bottle with an extensive sharing bottle range. 

Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️
Parquet floor and exposed brick, lighting is modern as is some of the decor leaning towards craft beer. Overall a little bit of a compromise, fairly pleasant and sympathetic with the raw materials of the building without being outstanding.

Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Locals from fashionable St Gilles mixing with craft beer pilgrims looking to taste beer from the original Moeder Lambic. Overall, the neighbourhood setting lends it a calmer atmosphere, if lacking the buzz of the twin.

Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️
Snacks, outdoor seating

Value For Money: ❤️❤️
A little higher than normal for the district on account of the superior wares.

description: The original Moeder Lambic is less accessible and less well known these days than its spinoff on Place Fontainas, but nonetheless worth seeking out both for its tap offerings of high quality Belgian beers from small brewers, and to trace what has become an institution of the city. The venue itself is nothing overly outstanding however bricks and chequered flooring are pleasant and the decoration is sympathetic. Service is prompt and friendly, and the mix of beer geeks and locals is too. (added August 2022)

name: Brasserie Verschueren
description:
EBG Rating:: 8.5
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
A compact range of tap beers including own label house options balanced by a democratic selection of wines, spirits and cocktails covering several bases. 

Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️
A classic historic bar which enjoyed an Art Deco refit which has remained for decades. At once elegant and striking, the use of varnished wood adds to the faded glamour. It isn't all angular stylishness though, with an old football table still mounted on the wall, showing the former working class background of the establishment.

Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
A neighbourhood institution, sat on a square overlooking the hill up to St Gilles, it is as prominent as any church or police station. The name projects outwards with a large extruding frontage. Patio tables project its power further before entering to find the sort of slickly run institution you would expect from such grandiosity. A diverse cast are quickly through the motions of orders and service while you can sit yourself on the old benches and take in the sounds, the rhythm and the social scene of what is a clearly important pub.

Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️
Light meals, snacks, outdoor seating, community events

Value For Money: ❤️❤️❤️
A little higher in places than most, but nothing offensive.

description: Every bit as important a landmark for St Gilles as a church or monument, this bar with its Deco frontage hits you squarely as you walk up the hill into the neighbourhood, spreading out further onto a large patio. Deco continues inside with sweeping clean lines, faded grandeur and neat elegant flourishes. This is both throwback and day-to-day pub of relevance, with a diverse cast of staff and customers, the bolthole of all boltholes if you're living around here. Spacious with many options for food and drink, while being interesting enough to spectate on and melt into the scenery. One of Brussels' best. (added August 2022)

name: Beer Central Antwerp
description:
EBG Rating:: 8
Choice/Quality of Drinks: A vast bottle selection focused on traditional Belgian ale but by no means exclusively. A veritable Bible with many specialist offerings. The tap options are comparatively prosaic with a few exceptions. It is Beer Central, so that is its focus.
Style/Décor: While this is a corporate impression of a Belgian pub, the choices are nevertheless sympathetic with colourful signage amidst browns and yellows. 
Atmosphere/Character: Located on the main drag into the centre, this place attracts backpackers and lazier tourists which isn't all to its credit, but there is a pleasant buzz in the evening, low stress and low risk all-round.
Amenities/Events: Food, outdoor seating
Value For Money: A little bit higher than average overall, with some better deals hidden amongst the beer bible.
description: Beer Central is Antwerp's well financed corporate beer mecca. These things are sometimes cause for hesitancy but they have made an effective and sympathetic job of it. The decoration does a good simulacra of a Belgian pub with more beer options than you can shake a stick at. Only a slight sense of churn and tourist focus drags it down a tad, along with a few cents added onto the pricing, but overall we're pleasantly surprised how effective it is as a venue.  (Added August 2022)

name: Café Belge
description:
EBG Rating:: 8
Choice/Quality of Drinks: Some rotation choices on tap with a large bottle selection, one of the venue's best suits.
Style/Décor: A one room pub with a terrace on the Oude Markt, inside is some typical beer signage, hints of heritage here and there. Lived in and a bit battered as you'd expect from a central market square pub that stays open late most evenings.
