A knockabout bar with Belgium and Celtic influences merging. Long bar starts at the entrance ending halfway down to open up a pubby space with communal tables. Side room with pinball and darts, backroom for live events.
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
The afternoon has a 'den of iniquity' feel around the bar, with the hardcore drinkers on show (although these are a mixture of rockers, craft beer fans and a few grizzled old sorts), but by early evening it is alive and buzzing with a good range of people. Casual and friendly with a real energy to the place, somewhere to make new friends and have fun.
Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Snacks, outdoor seating, pinball, darts, live events, books, happy hour
Value For Money: ❤️❤️❤️
Standard pricing for the city in line with the quality of produce, with some gems to be had during happy hour.
description: It feels like every small city upwards in France has at least one down to earth tavern which leans heavily on Belgian beers, rock music and possibly some celtic influences - this is Reims' clearest example. A long and impressive list of taps provides a selection that can compete with anywhere in the city, with a European bias but not beyond craft selections either. These are averagely priced but there are some real standouts during happy hour to pay attention to. An unpretentious knockabout sort of place where you can turn around and find a new person to talk to. Pinball and darts in the side room, event space in the back, and a cosy set of communal tables down a long narrow central bar make this an exciteable, popular and versatile social venue that nails most of the qualities of bars aside pretense and artifice. It might not be a place to take a first date (although, being Reims, you can still purchase Champagne by the glass), but it is a place to hang out in, relax and have fun, all the better for offering very nice drinks. (Added November 2024)

name: L'Illustration
description:
EBG Rating:: 8.4
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️
A compact but well curated tap selection featuring some of Belgium's best beers. The same applies to the bottle selection. A more than decent wine list too, the equal of the beer selection with a focus on BIO/Natural wines.
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
A beautiful, compact artsy café belonging to the Nouveau era. Brown café stylings lightened with local artwork. A rickety staircase (mind your head) leads to a second level.
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️
Superb prime brown café atmosphere bolstered further by how vibrant the local life is. Space is at a premium but the scene is  so tangibly alive and well, it gladdens the heart. Run by a laid back, bucolic owner who evidently takes just as much pleasure from hosting.
Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Food, snacks, limited outdoor seating, occasional events, happy hour
Value For Money: ❤️❤️❤️
Fair value considering the quality of produce.
description: Old Lille, a patchwork quilt of tall brick buildings will bring to mind the likes of Brussels or Antwerp, not to mention the beautiful brown cafés you can visit in those cities. Lille however, lost those to the 'Estaminet', owned by a company who insist all customers dine there, therefore disqualifying them from being seen as pubs. Thank heavens for L'illustration, that keeps the Nouveau elegant cosy café alive and well. It is no surprise to see this is the work of a bucolic eccentric, whose character is as much a part of the café as its rickety fixtures and fittings - no joke, mind your head on the staircase. With space at a premium, sashaying between chairs clutching goblets of delicious beer from the likes of De Ranke, or glasses of curated bio/natural wines is par for the course when visiting here. It will not escape your attention this is a popular place where real estate is guarded carefully by locals, but as a newcomer you will receive a genial welcome nevertheless. Take care to explore the upstairs also, and dream of a life where you get to visit this café regularly, your local home from home. If you use Lille Europe while travelling by Eurostar, then make a beeline for this place, despite the extra 5-10 minutes walk it will take you. (Added November 2024)

description:
EBG Rating:: 8.1

description: Do not confuse this with the same named pub a few hundred metres away. (Added October 2024)

description:

Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️

Value For Money: ❤️❤️❤️
description:

name: Kurnik Sopa Hospoda
description:
EBG Rating:: 8
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️
8+ taps focusing on guest lagers and ales from smaller independent brewers, with some occasional exceptions. Typical back bar with some higher end spirits available too.

Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Personalised basement venue in a panelaky style concrete precinct. Distinctive inside with a bunker like appears, bar at the far end of the entrance. Two rooms, though it won't feel like that initially, there is space if you explore.
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Natural sense of identity and character from the appearance of the place, added to by an entirely local and less pretentious crowd, this is not a cutting edge chin-strokey place, more a hangout that happens to have excellent beers. 
Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️
Limited food, snacks, outdoor seating, TV
Value For Money: ❤️❤️❤️
Ok value but not notably cheap for the region.
description: A cult venue on the fringes of Poruba district in Ostrava's sprawling conurbation, this place has to fight off plenty of local competition, being one of three pubs in the same building complex alone. Their USP though has always been a beer specialists, with 8+ taps focusing on guest lagers and ales from smaller independent brewers, with some occasional exceptions. Their sister pub in the centre is now arguably as well known, and unless you catch this place on a busy evening, it is also arguably the better of the two. However, with plenty of reason to explore Poruba, you'll need a few pubs to visit and this is its best. A basement venue that has become highly personalised, it is bunker-like and entirely local - don't suddenly expect a bunch of American craft beer nerds to start stinking the place out. This helps keep the place feeling unpretentious, of its area and region, and less generic as a result. (Added November 2024)

name: Zenke Výčep
description:
EBG Rating:: 7.7
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️
5 lines from a small independent craft brewery south west of Ostrava. Simple alternatives.
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️
An old retail unit, one -room with a bit of an outbuilding feel. It's super simple on the inside, but the minimalism is in attitude rather than style, as the furnishings are functional rather than any sort of craft styling. Either way it is certainly unpretentious, and not a key feature of the pub.
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Lively social atmosphere popular with a slightly younger crowd than average, though not exclusively. A clear fanbase and regular custom gives it a sense of acquired importance. Service is decent.
Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️
Snacks, limited outdoor seating, TV
Value For Money: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Fair value for money in line with the quality of produce.
description: Established some time in 2023, Zenke, a rural brewery south west of Ostrava have an outpost in the region's capital. Set off one of the main thoroughfares in typical panelaky / hi-rise projects environment, the contrast between the surroundings and the more forward looking operation is stark. Easily reachable via Trebovice tram line, but once you're here you will feel a long way way from the old town (and in more than one sense, you are).

A brewery with a high reputation in the region, they focus evenly between traditional Czech styles and modern ales, with around 4/5 on tap here at any one time. 

The interior is simple, but warm and cosy, a social setup where the emphasis is on socialising far more than it is about sampling. The interior could use a bit more personalising and identity, but at least they haven't fallen for the same stereotypical craft bar look. Meanwhile, the social scene here ensures a good atmosphere if you arrive at the right time. Although it does slant towards a younger audience there is no particular reason why older generations shouldn't give this place a try, as it combines a number of timeless virtues. Oh, and the prices are rather fair too. (Added November 2024)

name: Pivnice U Dudáka
description:
EBG Rating:: 7.6
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️
Ostravar, PU, Mustang, and the most standard back bar of central European alternatives.
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
A large beer hall with a high ceiling and globe lighting. Yes, this is no Medieval hangout. Instead, there are some funky decorations such as the pillars and wall paintings that catch the eye and add a retro disco element which is much unexpected, but not uncomplimentary either
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
The location and space, including TVs, ensures there is a decent range of customers from the stalwart grizzled men to younger couples. There is an unusually, a half-accidental appealing retro quality which they only appear to have half realised or begun to exploit. 
Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Food, snacks, TV, pool table, newspapers
Value For Money: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Fair value in accordance with the quality of food and drink.
description: "The Piper" has been an institution in Poruba for over 50 years. Part of a new build socialist projects expanding Ostrava into a sprawling conurbation, there is an integrity to Poruba which may not be to everyone's tastes, but splendidly places you back in time to the optimism of its creation. Every new build area needs somewhere that anchors you to your roots, and Pivnice U Dudaka provides that.

You'll spot the piper emblem on its logo, underneath a large city building. Inside there's a large beer hall with a high ceiling and globe lighting. Yes, this is no Medieval hangout. Instead, there are some funky decorations such as the pillars and wall paintings that catch the eye and add a retro disco element which is much unexpected, but not uncomplimentary either. 

Cementing the retro nature, the pubs beer is Ostravar, a not all that great creation which nevertheless has the city's name attached. It works in a setting such as this. 

The location and space, including TVs, ensures there is a decent range of customers from the stalwart grizzled men to younger couples. 

There is a kitchen and although not right at the cheaper end, there are some occasional daily deals to be found. 

For a slice of social history, a peculiar funky, fashionable quality that by rights it shouldn't inhabit, and fully local life seperated from any tourism, this is an institution of Poruba worth sampling. (Added November 2024)

name: Vagón cafe bar
description:
EBG Rating:: 7.8
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Broad range of drinks, particularly spirits, PU and Radegast beer is acceptable, but perhaps beer is the slightly weaker string to its bow.
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️
Repurposed mail wagon with interesting interior, carefully curated with space at a premium. Nice niches and lighting really set the place off well. Doesn't look to have been redone since it was first kitted out.
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
The venue and novelty factor provide a certain character and atmosphere at any time of day or week, but late opening on weekends and barbecue events add to the appeal further.
Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Barbecues, snacks, outdoor seating, playground, private hire
Value For Money: ❤️❤️❤️
Fair, though not especially notable.
description: A local curio. Set in a park, an old mail wagon has been restored and refurbished after 6 years of service on the tracks in the 20th century. The bar opened in 2000 and is still going.

Homely inside with careful thought as to the spacing and layout. There is a natural ambience any time of day or year.

This isn't a place you would simply stumble over, as it is around 20 minutes walk from the main station in an area otherwise not much served by pubs.  

A local institution nevertheless, if a highly provincial one. 

There are a broad range of drinks, particularly spirits that you can choose from, and if the atmospheric twinkle and gloom of the interior doesn't fit your needs, a spacious garden area probably will. Daily barbecues in warmer months provide a further reason to drop by.

A distinctive venue with good drinks and a versatile friendly operation, that's obscure enough that we're probably the only people outside CZ to ever mention it.

(Added October 2024)

name: Beskydský pivovárek
description:
EBG Rating:: 7.7
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️
Superb lagers and ales brewed on site, from the classic Beskydsky Lezak to creative ales and seasonal specials. Standard back bar complimented by some homemade liqueurs with distillation including fruit from their own orchards.
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
A modern looking and modern branded brewery, industrial operation upon entry via the car park. Outdoor seating adjacent to the outbuildings. Inside, country comfort awaits with a traditional Gaststatte style setup. The taproom has the most character but it is pleasant too in the dining hall. 
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
An occasionally jarring union of tradition and modernity, with the transient custom you'd expect from a village in a hiking area. Nevertheless, friendly service, a sense of being 'away from it all' and the warmth and comfort of a good hostelry create the feeling of a hikers pub even though it's a brewery.
Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️
Food, snacks, rental space, shop (homemade cheeses), outdoor seating, merchandise, farm.
Value For Money: ❤️❤️❤️
Considering the beer is being bought direct from the site, not exactly eye-catching pricing.
description: For years we've been enjoying Beskydy brewery's wares, usually in Brno, Olomouc or Ostrava, but never at the taproom. In 2024 we finally made it - an easy train ride away from Frydek-Mistek into a semi-rural area surrounded by hills, a typically Czech landscape but bordering on Slovakia.

Established in 2012-2013, part of a new wave of independent breweries that sprung up across the country, there has since its inception been an interplay between a need to respect tradition and their rural surroundings, while indulging their creative urges and modern tastes. That is very much on display at the brewery, as you round a corner to be confronted by a large yellow grain silo, modern branding and a fairly sleek looking operation. Inside however, country comforts away, with a traditionally decorated Gaststatte type dining hall and taproom. Acres of trees gone into the wood fittings, with quirky elements like the tiled stove adding to the atmosphere. 

The taproom is clearly the place to be, but unfortunately they allow reservations rather than using that limited space as a casual social space, and the dining area for reservations and food. That is room for improvement. 

Pricing is ambitious for a rural Czech brewery, clocking in at only OK considering you are purchasing the beer direct from the site, and the food menu likewise. It is a good job both food and beer are high quality.

Their lagers certainly compete with some of the best in the region, with an equal, if not greater focus on ales. This gives reason to stay and explore the range.

I can recommend using this place for a middle or end stop after a hike in the surrounding hills, to Lysa Hora for example. The atmosphere inside has that feel of wandering hikers, a slightly heady feel of everyone having travelled here to get away from it all. 

As it's only 30-40 minutes from Ostrava with a straight forward train journey, this should give plenty of pause for thought. We can recommend the place.

(Added October 2024)

name: Valašská hospoda U Janíka - restaurace Frenštát
description:
EBG Rating:: 7.5
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Pilsner Urquell, Bernard, an above average range of fruit brandies.
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Hilltop cabin with rustic exterior and genteel exterior set around a sizeable bar. Wooden furniture all-round.
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
A slightly twee fairytale feel to the cabin in the woods, but the big budget/professional operation snaps you out of that a touch. Service is warm and friendly and although it is largely built for food, this is not a rule in any sense.
Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Food, snacks, shop, playground, outdoor seating
Value For Money: ❤️❤️❤️
Not the best priced pub in Moravia for sure, but the quality is good.
description: The first private pub in Frenstat following the fall of the socialist regime in 1990, the pub operation dating back a long way prior, from 1873. It began life as a hilltop rest stop for travellers and hikers, gaining a reputation gradually over time. 

These days, you'll find the location very pleasing, a gentle woodland climb from the town centre with grand views over the valley once you reach the top. 

Inside, they have purposefully retained a twee, genteel cabin feel, although it does also feel largely newly fitted and furnished.

The operation largely survives around food these days, but a large bar and pleasing homely surroundings make it feel worthy of Inn/pub status.

With such a good reputation for cooking, prices are pitched accordingly, with a limited menu of homespun classics, including Bryndzove Halusky, a dish normally synonymous with Slovakia, which shows you where you are in the country.

Pilsner and Bernard beers are very decent and the service is kind and attentive too. While we would of course prefer if it developed some casual social space (perhaps in the corner of the room next to the bar), the operation is positive enough across the board to warrant an inclusion. 

(Added October 2024)

name: Schlattauerova kavárna (Gobelínka)
description:
EBG Rating:: 8.5
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Two beer lines, one basic and the other quasi-craft, with a good, if predictable back-bar offering.
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️
Walk around the tapestry complex to find the cafe entrance at the rear of the building through a courtyard. Inside a small bar room with large lounge, stage and backroom, with further space leading to a play area and the gallery/museum. High ceilings decorated with the tapestries from the centre. Unique.
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️
Catch it on the right evening and you'll be looking up local house prices. Vibrant cultural space without some of the crap and pretence that sometimes orbits those activities, this place is about good people doing good. And hey, when there's nothing on, it's an atmospheric old venue in its own right, warm and cosy with plenty of niches to slip into a chair with a book and a pint to enjoy.
Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️
Food, snacks, outdoor seating, live cultural events, museum, gallery and books...yes, there's plenty to keep you occupied here.
Value For Money: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Entirely fair value for what's on offer.
description: One of the genuinely unique venues out there in Europe, not many pubs can claim to be not only attached but part of a tapestry weavers. Gobelinka has been going since the 1960s producing and restoring tapestries, opening a museum and gallery, exhibiting the making and heritage of original works. That gallery spills over into this pub, café, culture centre with a garden out front and large, but cosy space inside. Live music, quiet corners for reading, social meeting space, they do it here at this distinctive, versatile venue. It's a shame the town is such a pain to get to, but then sometimes that's also what helps make such experiences special. Catch the venue on a busy evening and you'll be googling local real estate prices the morning after. (Added November 2024)

name: Přístav
description:
EBG Rating:: 8.2
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Good beer from Bernard, PU, Kamenice and guest options with an extensive, if familiar back bar of alternatives.
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️
Excellent personalised decoration leaning on its dock theme without over-doing it. A large main bar is kept homely and cosy feeling with its low lighting, steam heating and wood wood wood everywhere you look. Niches in a side room are also cosy. 
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
A local feel, unsurprisingly given this is hardly the epicentre of all things cosmopolitan, but the versatility means there are a range of people up the age and class groups. Local clubs and music groups add to this further. The inside is cosy and homely, low lit and somewhere you could easily become attached to.
Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Food, snacks, outdoor seating, live music
Value For Money: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Fair value for what's on offer.
description: A town with strong competition in its breweries, cultural centre and throwback pubs is burnished further by this excellent riverside hospoda.

Pristav means dock/anchor and the reason will be obvious as you approach the entrance facng the Dolni Becva river. Inside you'll find a pub with a considerable amount more decor than the average minimalist Czech hospoda. Personalised, cosy and homely, with options to sit by the heater, or in cosy niches in an adjacent room. Hosting music nights and other local clubs, there is a sense of community to the place that is difficult to come by in larger settlements. 

As for the beer, Bernard, Pilsner Urquell and two or three other rotating options provides choice that is at least on par with most pubs that aren't lucky enough to have their own brewery inside them.

An essential stop when visiting the town. (Added November 2024)

name: Kloine Zoigl Stub'n - For Stich'n
description:
EBG Rating:: 7.8
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️

Value For Money: ❤️❤️❤️❤️

EBG Rating:: 8.5
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️
Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Value For Money: ❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️

description:
EBG Rating:: 8.5
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️
Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Value For Money: ❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️

name: Schafferhof Zoigl
description:
EBG Rating:: 8.5
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️
Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Value For Money: ❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️
description:

name: Hostinec Malý Růžek
description:
EBG Rating:: 7.8
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️
8 taps from smaller independent brewers, regular beers from Rampusak
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️
A small corner local with two rooms and limited outdoor seating. Decorated with drawings of famous Czechs past and present.
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
A relatively friendly welcome by Czech standards, truly mixed crowd in age and background and local life, with just the right element of cosmopolitan creeping in.
Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Food, snacks, takeaway, limited outdoor seating
Value For Money: ❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️
Fair value across the board with some very impressively priced excellent beers.
description: In a land where big brewers still rule the roost in terms of pub supply, it is always nice to find a corner local with a strong selection by corner brewers. 

Malý Růžek isn't only a connoisseurs choice, but a regular pub with a nice range of people old and young. 

With at least 8 taps and prices that range from decent to really very impressive for what's available, there is plenty to get stuck into here.

The welcome is friendly too, none of that initial narrowing of eyes and scrutinising. It is a nice reminder this is a university city and has some cosmopolitan attitudes.

The pub itself has limited outdoor seating and a small space indoors too, with a small bar room and smaller backroom, which is out of the sight of the rest of the pub and qualifies as an overflow area - ideally head for a table near the taps. 

Decorated with notables from Czech history past and present, which helps it past the plain/bland stage, which sadly is where a lot of places like these decide to pitch their tents.

For strong local life and fabulous beers, this comes highly recommended. (Added October 2024)

name: Na Hradě
description:
EBG Rating:: 8.5
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
The drinks don't stray from the typical PU/Radegast combination, although they do stock their Volba Sladku (brewer's choice) monthly variations on tap. Typical central European alternatives/back bar.

Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
A two room pub, the larger of which is the bar room, with kitchen to the right and bar straight ahead. A personalised room that has eschewed the minimalist approach to create something homely, something that feels like it has been around for a good while. A stalwart, if you like.

Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️
Being provincial, the atmosphere is more casual and this pub feels like it has true regulars, the ones that come in every day rather than once or twice a week.

Socialising, rather than dining is the focus. Homely during the day and lively on weekend evenings right until closing.

Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️
Food, snacks, TV, newspapers
Value For Money: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Very reasonable value for what's on offer given the location.
description: When you visit any Czech town or city for the first time and seek a beer, you're craving a central pub with a Czech character. Something worn-in, a bit of an institution, a place everyone knows well, site of many trysts and falling outs, maybe with a redoubtable tapster and server combination. 

Sadly, those can be difficult to come by, even in some larger towns, but Hradec Králové has this covered in the shape of this place.

A short lollop from the utterly beautiful central square down a cobbled lane to this pub. The exterior has unfortunately received the generic Pilsner Urquell signage, but things improve immediately on entering.

A two room pub, the larger of which is the bar room, with kitchen to the right and bar straight ahead. A personalised room that has eschewed the minimalist approach to create something homely, something that feels like it has been around for a good while. A stalwart, if you like.

Being provincial, the atmosphere is more casual and this pub feels like it has true regulars, the ones that come in every day rather than once or twice a week.

Socialising, rather than dining is the focus, but they offer a good range of food too. The drinks don't stray from the typical PU/Radegast combination, although they do stock their Volba Sladku (brewer's choice) monthly variations on tap, which is a plus. A further plus is how good value it is. This is about as central and institutiony as you'll find in the city, but the drinks clock in at an entirely fair rate.

If you were critical, perhaps the opening hours are a little inflexible (an extra hour on the weekend wouldn't hurt), but to leave you wanting more at the end of the night is one strategy to ensure your return. 

With plenty of character, a cast of regulars, a homely interior, good beer and good grub, this is a standout venue in Czechia and you can hardly skip this place. (Added October 2024)

name: Jeep Bar
description:
EBG Rating:: 8.6
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️
Basic beer, wine and central European liqueurs very much straight down the line in terms of familiarity.
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️
The reason to be here. A collection of Army and Farming machinery from the US in the garden, with an interior, bunker-like decorated with memorabilia, nik-naks and mementos, antiques and anything else that can be found. Guns? Yep. Toy trains? Also yep.
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️
The character you'd expect from a labour of love and a unique creation. Atmospheric in the evenings especially, but also worth considering for a warm Spring/Summer afternoon in the garden.
Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Food, snacks, museum/memorabilia, outdoor seating.
Value For Money: ❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️
Among the cheapest places for a beer in Prague.
description: Established in 1993, a personal labour of love, a collector and enthusiast of US machinery from farming and the armed forces, who has turned a house on an otherwise very sleepy area of the city into a curio - museum/bar/garden, a bit of all three. Drop into his little bar to find a carefully and lovingly curated ensemble - you know the kind by now - every inch of wall space taken up with memorabilia and nik-naks. The place is appropriately lit and staffed by one man and one man only.

It's something really quite incredible, and a kind of pub you can count fewer than 10 in the whole country (unless there are some we haven't discovered yet).

Rather unlikely, but the bar also serves basic food - General Patton's ration of goulash, anyone? This is to help wash down the beer - a basic Gambrinus 10 sold at basement level prices.

For a true curio, somewhere off the beaten path, and unlike almost anywhere you'll visit again, this is worth the trip out.

The easiest way is to get the Tram from Klamovka stop and walk up the hill from there. 

(Added October 2024)

name: V Koutku
description:
EBG Rating:: 8
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️
Smichov 10 plus the most basic of central European back bars.
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Well decorated. Enter up steps to a small bar room with locals, the lounge to the left. Yellow walls from the decades of smoking, skis and sledges pinned to the walls giving it a distinctive character.
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️
Highly atmospheric, a man's drinking den with a mist of smoke, loud informal chat, and a throwback feel to the place, the 1990s and further. This is something you can't easily access elsewhere in the city. 
Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️
TV, snacks, club membership
Value For Money: ❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️
Really among the cheapest places in the city centre.
description: Recommended purely for local life and among the city centre's very cheapest half litres of beer, this is a social document, somewhere you can soak up the atmosphere like a sponge.

It's also difficult, possibly very intimidating a prospect to enter for non-Czech speakers.

V Koutku belongs to the strange phenomenon of 'private members pubs', opened as a reaction to the Czech smoking ban. By turning pub into club, smoking can continue, but not all is as it was. The clientele are very much the hardcore heavy drinking, heavy smoking remnants of the 1990s scene. Women and young adults are not to be seen as you pass the bar into the lounge.

As this is a private members bar it is entirely at the discretion of the owner if they let you drink or not. Asking politely always helps - Nejsem členem, je možné si dát pivo?

It worked for us here (although in other private members bars it simply signalled we were to be refused). This is a pretty laid back operation - they just want to keep their pub the same way it has been generally - by locals for locals. They won't mind a few well behaved newcomers that mind their business though.

The interior is decorated with skis and sledges, the yellow walls typical of the chain smoking old pubs of the past. Grizzled old guys chat, play cards, watch TV and hang out. 

A way of life that used to be the norm, but is fast vanishing from the city can still be sampled here. 

It must be said, this is a really superb pajzl. 

(Added October 2024)

name: Pivní přístav
description:
EBG Rating:: 7.8
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️
9 beer taps + fridges, an excellent selection concentrating on beers from smaller or independent brewers.
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️
A small pub. The interior is recognisably Czech, with a light-touch dockside/nautical theme and artwork, small rooms furnishes with chunky communal tables.
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
The crowd is varied - a popular place with locals but with international/cosmopolitan character too, in a way that doesn't spoil it. It feels like the place to be, almost like a family welcoming you into their house, which is really quite unusual for Prague - and this part of Prague especially.

Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Food, snacks, shop, takeaway
Value For Money: ❤️❤️❤️
description: As you walk  past, spotting the tell tale green and gold Pilsner Urquell signage, for a moment you'll double-take. Is this the multi-tap pub I'd heard about? Well, yes it is! Keep on going, head inside.

A compact pub where it pays to be ruthless in terms of grabbing a table (or a bar stool), after which you are in good hands.

A family-run business with dedicated tapsters and servers, specialising in beers from smaller breweries, while of course offering a couple of more recognisable names.

The interior is recognisably Czech, with a light-touch dockside/nautical theme and artwork, small rooms furnishes with chunky communal tables.

The beer is excellent, the welcome is good even when busy, and the crowd is varied - a popular place with locals but with international/cosmopolitan character too, in a way that doesn't spoil it. 

We can only recommend it. (Added October 2024)

name: Scottish club "Sedy Pes"
description:
EBG Rating:: 7.8
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️
Pardubice beer, Irish stout and a large back bar of Scottish whiskies, some of which are unusual and can only be found in a handful of Prague bars.
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Sedy Pes", Grey Dog is a basement bar with a cosy bar and personalised rear room which has enough going on in it to not feel detached from the action.

Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
The space is such a natural place for a bar to be that they have inherited some of that genius loci.

It's a lively place where you can make friends quickly, and an informal one too - social focus.

Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Food, Scottish food, TV, snacks, live events
Value For Money: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Fair value for most of what's available.
description: The idea of a Scottish club in Prague immediately conjures bad vibes - stag-do's, terrible music, wall to wall vomiting. Perhaps that's why we gave this one a swerve all these years. Despite that, information and good reviews continued to trickle in. In October 2024 we gave it a try.

Firstly, this is no tourist trap - positioned safely far enough away from anything anyone but the most intrepid traveller (or Scot) would seek out. Does this mean it is all local? Of course not, this is still Prague we're talking about, but the balance is healthy. 

"Sedy Pes", Grey Dog is a basement bar with a cosy bar and personalised rear room which has enough going on in it to not feel detached from the action.

On the food menu, the usual Czech staples complimented with haggis and black pudding.

Pardubice (the brewery is now gone, only the brand remains) beers are supported by Irish stout and a wall of whisky options, most of which are reasonably priced by Czech whisky standards.

It's a lively place where you can make friends quickly, and an informal one too - social focus.

The space is such a natural place for a bar to be that they have inherited some of that genius loci.

Park any reservations you may have about the theme pub, this is a good marriage of Czech surroundings and beer with a twist that's for locals rather than tourists. 

(Added October 2024)

name: Restaurace U voraře
description:
EBG Rating:: 7.8
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Svijany beers lock out the taps, offering dark, light, non-alco and even their own specially brewed Trumpetska beer. These are kept and poured to certificate standard (if that sort of thing impresses you). A good back bar for alternatives awaits also.

Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Jazz and blues bar-restaurant fitted with musical instruments in precarious locations. A double bass looms above you at the bar, a skeleton plays piano on the ceiling in the front room. Yes, welcome to the tacky, but wholesome fun.

The rooms themselves are warmly lit and personalised.

Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Naturally atmospheric either on the ground floor or the basement hangout, which is in itself a kind of bunker of its own.

Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Food, live music, outdoor seating, snacks
Value For Money: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Surprisingly decent value given the operation, location, surroundings, etc.
description: In 2024 U voraře celebrated 20 years of opening. We paid our 1st visit the same year. 

This is a venue that doesn't fit a mould.

A self-styled 'legendary' jazz and blues bar, (reputation acquired in advance, of course) fitted with musical instruments in precarious locations. A double bass looms above you at the bar, a skeleton plays piano on the ceiling in the front room. Yes, welcome to the tacky, but wholesome fun.

The rooms themselves are warmly lit, naturally atmospheric either on the ground floor or the basement hangout, which is in itself a kind of bunker of its own.

Svijany beer is very common outside Prague, but has only really made modest in-roads into the Gambrinus/Kozel/Pilsner roadshow. Here, they lock out the taps, offering dark, light, non-alco and even their own specially brewed Trumpetska beer. These are kept and poured to certificate standard (if that sort of thing impresses you).

Live music is, of course, a must, but they offer a full compliment with a kitchen pumping out meals as well.

The atmosphere is therefore a little offkey, like an experimental jazz record, slipping from romantic couples wining and dining to musos and dancers, to basement boozing, shifting sands which never resolve, but are in and of themselves engaging, making you want to try and get under its skin. 

Worth a look for sure. (Added October 2024)

name: Hospoda U Benyho
description:
EBG Rating:: 7.8
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Pilsner Urquell, Radegast 10, and a familiar central European bar bar.
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
A neighbourhood corner pub with a high ceiling, but quite compact and intimate space across two rooms. The decoration takes inspiration from First Republic/post-Austria pubs with thick curtains and nice detailing along with, of course, plenty of wood panelling.

Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
The furniture is laid out in such a way as to accommodate people who want a casual drink on the stand or to sit and while away time in good company. The casual nature of it stands out - while they serve food, this pub has a social focus. This is also seen by its dog-friendly nature (noted also in its logo). Sometimes it can be overrun but normally it's manageable.

Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Food, snacks, TV, outdoor seating
Value For Money: ❤️❤️
Not very good value or fair value overall, so must be marked down. Pilsner Urquell for 20-25% more than you can easily find elsewhere and anywhere in Prague.
description: "At Beny's" is a Pilsner Urquell pub, but more akin to Brno's corner pubs like U Vodicku, U Vaclava and U Blahovky than the places you may be familiar with in Prague's old town. A neighbourhood corner pub with a high ceiling, but quite compact and intimate space, the furniture is laid out in such a way as to accommodate people who want a casual drink on the stand or to sit and while away time in good company. The casual nature of it stands out - while they serve food, this pub has a social focus. This is also seen by its dog-friendly nature (noted also in its logo). Sometimes it can be overrun but normally it's manageable.

The decoration takes inspiration from First Republic/post-Austria pubs with thick curtains and nice detailing along with, of course, plenty of wood panelling. 

Are there things to criticise? Yes. The Pilsner Urquell is 20% more expensive than you can find easily elsewhere in the city. The dogs can get a bit much at times, and the service can sometimes come across a little too pleased with itself - if you've been to a city centre craft beer bar you'll probably know what I mean.

But outside of that it's a lovely, friendly, warm and welcoming pub, the beer is good and its a grand choice to hang out at.

(Added October 2024)

name: Vinárna U Vávrů
description:
EBG Rating:: 7.7
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
7/8 wines by the glass, plus good beer from Malesov and the basic lager from Platan. A typical central European back bar.
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️
Basement venue that is caught somewhere between its humble origins as a working class Vinarna and a cleaner look with art on the walls. It is neither unpleasant, nor is it bland, but the space itself could be put to more distinctive use.
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Very pleasant, homely and cosy venue with friendly service and nice surroundings, a venue with a better balance of men/women than you often find in Czech pubs too.
Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️
Food, snacks
Value For Money: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Entirely fair value given the location and for the product.
description: Among Prague's cast of slowly vanishing working class Vinárnas, a culture alien to Northern Europe where wine is synonymous with social climbing and status. Things are changing in central Europe too, and this is also wiping out the family-run, basic and simple wine bar as we know it.

Vinohrady is a fashionable place and knowledgeable enough to have a nostalgia for certain thing. Whether by performance, novelty, chance, or a combination of those and other things, U Vavru survives and thrives with a canny combination of offerings that draw in a typical Vinohrady audience, at a fair price.

A basement venue with simple and quite familiar surroundings, offering half a dozen wines by the glass and a good lager from Malesov, in a rather pubby environment. Here, cooked meals rather emphasis the nature of it as a pub and social meeting spot rather than any kind of pretentious wine bar. 

Please do your best to support these business so we can maintain the diversity of bars and respect a distinctive culture that deserves to see the next generation. 

(Added October 2024)

name: Bar Decentní Dýně
description:
EBG Rating:: 7.5
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️
Rum specialists with 100+ varieties plus JungBerg beer, which has replaced Unetice in recent years. Homemade Lemonades.
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
A long, thin bar with a backroom, decorated in warm pumpkiny hues. Black and + white photography. It's an interesting, vaguely gothic combination that brings to mind the 90s

Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Versatile venue that can switch from a lunch spot, to a café, to evening venue seamlessly. Cast of loyal locals, but it has past the point where it was the in vogue place to be, partly to its benefit, in all honesty.
Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Food, snacks, TV, limited outdoor seating
Value For Money: ❤️❤️❤️
Nothing out of the ordinary.
description: Dating from 2002, this bar has experienced the trajectory of being the hottest in-thing to the spat-out blazé option and back again, content now to be a stalwart and a survivor.

Rum specialists, this is a notable place to try something you may never have heard of, though JungBerg beers are always there if you want to stick to pivo.

A long, thin bar with a backroom, decorated in warm pumpkiny hues (the name of the bar means Decent Pumpkin) and black and + white photography. It's an interesting, vaguely gothic touch that brings to mind the 90s rather than the 00s in all honesty. 

For those seeking a break from hospoda after hospoda, this change of format offers a good balance of social atmosphere with the ability to up the tempo when required.

These days they even do food during the day, boasting about its versatility. 

It is well worth having up your sleeve, particularly if travelling in and around Vinohrady and the main station. 

(Added October 2024)

name: Formanská hospůdka
description:
EBG Rating:: 7.5
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️
Gambrinus, Pilsner Urquell and a basic, typical back bar for favoured central European spirits.
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Stables theme in a roadside pub. Cabin-like, the bar to the left and a lounge to the right. Locals table is nearest the bar. Simple, homely and rather out-of-time in style.
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
There are a cast of regulars but this is a sleepy spot outside of its very few peak times, with some transient custom due to its roadside situation.
Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Food, snacks, TV, outdoor seating.
Value For Money: ❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️
Among the best value venues in the entirety of Prague.
description: Not only at the end of the tram line, but 10 minutes walk up a dirt track - that would have a certain allure if the pub wasn't next to Karlovarska which at Bila Hora tram stop turns into one of the main roads into Prague.

It is therefore an easy pub to reach. Don't worry about how far away it looks on the map. 

A somewhat frozen in time saloon awaits, with a traditional interior, wood-cabin type effect with a stables theme. The bar room is to your left as you enter, with the lounge to the right. You may find the bar area where the locals, the stamgasty, hangout.

The pub offers simple, hearty cooking and cheap beer - we're not meaning to undersell that, this is one of the cheapest pints in the city. 

On our visit in October 2024 it was selling Pilsner Urquell for 45 crowns, virtually unheard of. 

The old time aesthetic, cheap and cheerful function and sense of out-on-a-limb (even though it isn't really) is enough of an ensemble to recommend it.

Locals may be initially surprised to see you, but this is roadside and near Bila Hora, a major tourist attraction, so they are used to infrequent visitors. It's a safe place to go. Arrived armed with a few Czech pleasantries though.

(Added October 2024)

name: U Prince Miroslava
description:
EBG Rating:: 7.5
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️
13 taps concentrating on beers  from smaller/independent brewers, a fabulous selection. Typical back bar 
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️
Basement bar with two large rooms. A kind of social club type space, built to accommodate the numbers who visit gigs.
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Something of a stalwart presence on Prague's bar scene, with loyal regulars which helps give it a bit of an atmosphere even when quiet. On gig nights it unsurprisingly transforms.
Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️
Meals, snacks, TV, wifi, outdoor seating, dog friendly
Value For Money: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Entirely fair value for what's on offer.
description: In 2024 U Prince Miroslava featured in Czech TV series 'Drunk Prague' owing to its history as a down-to-earth punky music venue from the 1990s, and hopefully its inclusion will help provide some fresh impetus for the place.

Located far enough outside central Andel and Smichov station to be a local's spot, this is not a pub you will find a tonne of tourists. Enter through a yard with outdoor seating downstairs into a large half-basement with two rooms that resemble social clubs in their unusually vast space. It is easy to feel the history of the place and the many many gigs that have come and gone over the decades, new partnerships, new break-ups, arguments and fights, laughter and fun. That memory which hangs in their air is more noticeable than anything visible or tangible. 

But it isn't all about history and live music, this pub offers a crackingly good selection of beers, with 13 taps concentrating on smaller, independent breweries. It was also offering a better range long before that turned into a passé business model of the kind copied and pasted across the river in Karlin district. For that, it deserves credit as a trailblazer.

There are usually a cast of regulars in here, but to see the place at its best try a gig night or a busy Friday or Saturday evening, and the point of the pub is suddenly brought into sharper focus.

(Added October 2024)

name: Hospůdka U Köhlera
description:
EBG Rating:: 7.7
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️
Radegast, Pilsner Urquell, volba sladku, typical central European back bar offerings.
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Cosy compact pub up some steps. A bar room with one side room. Traditional decorated with sporting insignia and local heritage.
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
A sense of city trade with a feel of locals/regulars too. Relatively approachable despite that, with friendly service who aren't unused to newcomers. Calm, warm and cosy.
Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Food, snacks, TV
Value For Money: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Very good value for money for the lunch menu and the regular beer prices too.
description: Central Ostrava offers a true variety of venues, but not that many of them fall into this category. It took a couple of visits to really get it. At first glance it's a Radegast pub that's a convenient bolthole for a quick pint. Returning, you can also pick up on some of its rhythms and service better and we appreciated the surroundings more too.

A relatively small pub up some stairs after the entrance. The bar room and small side-room is about all you get. Personalised with insignia from local sporting teams and city heritage, it isn't a plain venue either.

It is clearly a locals place, and lunch service offers a canteen like rush of people in and out in the space of 30-40 minutes, around which the locals slowly sup their beer and watch the TV.

Service is friendly and although you may be given a second glance as a newcomer, you won't be mistreated.

The lunch menu and beer prices are very good for central Ostrava, and worth noting for anyone on a budget.

The main beer here is Radegast. The 12, if treated correctly is a pleasant light lager and it has become something of an emblem for this part of the country, Moravia-Silesia.

Many of Ostrava's better venues don't open up until mid-afternoon at the earliest, so the presence of this place offers a practical choice for those seeking a lunchtime pint. 

(Added November 2024)

name: Bo-Bi Bar
description:
EBG Rating:: 9.2
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Drinks are basic - and in bottles, though there are some independently brewed options outside the usual Carslberg/Tuborg stranglehold. A reasonable, but compact back bar for alternatives.
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️
Small one-room candle-lit bar with rich reds, lamps and old wood. A café feel, but worn and sleazy enough it could double as a dive bar.
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️
Supremely atmospheric and characterful on another level, you will feel almost like an extra in a film. Sleepy, deeply relaxing afternoons with slow jazz, smoke trails and rustling newspapers gives way to a vibrant evening atmosphere and younger crowd.
Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️
Snacks, smoking permitted newspapers.
Value For Money: ❤️❤️❤️
description: Dating from 1917, the bar claims to still be fit with original decor from that era. You'd struggle to argue otherwise as you enter a space of rich reds, lamplights, old paintings and old wood, with its faded splendour lending the place an atmosphere that falls somewhere in between prim literary café and sleazy dive without ever really being either.

Bo-Bi Bar is located opposite Gyldendal's publishing house with its impressive angular facade comprising the view out on to the street. It is almost part of the bar itself. As a consequence, Bo-bi has traditionally been visited by writers and famous/evocative enough to be used as the location for Christian Braad Thomsen's 1998 film The Blue Monk. 

An environment that belongs to the sound of slow jazz, the mood is so horizontal during the afternoon that sometimes minutes pass between thoughts as you are lulled into a slumber, with the gentle ambience noise of rustling newspapers, adjusting of seats and glasses lifted and replaced.

This is only half the story, as Bo-bi ups the tempo in the evening, and the crowd graduates to a younger one.

Although classed as a Danish 'brown pub', Bo-bi feels more distinctive, less of an out and out boozer than most that fall into that category. It is a lost in time café bar with a close to matchless atmosphere. 

Drinks are basic and in bottles, though there are some independently brewed options outside the usual Carslberg/Tuborg stranglehold. For snacks, a boiled egg may be brought forth. 

Smoking is permitted, they greatly prefer cash payment and use of mobile phones for anything beyond reading is frowned upon. 

Like Au Daringman in Brussels, the bar is staffed by a willing middle aged woman with such care and in such a way it feels like the bar and they are connected.

A clear standout destination that cannot be missed in Copenhagen. (Added December 2024)

name: Cafe InTime
description:
EBG Rating:: 9.1
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️
A well stocked back bar serves for cocktails and mixers, and the usual Carlsberg / Tuborg taps and bottles do the rest.
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️
Bulb lighting out front suggests a camp showbar, as does the velvet curtain on entrance, but the interior remains a typical brown café - which is to say red walls, lamp lighting, candles, simple furniture. An L-shaped room with bar in the corner and grand piano by the entrance. Round tables with simple seating. Stained glass windows at the front, roses and baubles pinned to the beams.
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️
Supremely atmospheric, casual, with louche waiting staff, smokey surroundings and a sense of unpredictability and spontaneity affixed to a pub with otherwise very solid, familiar charms.
Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️
Live events, music, snacks, piano, smoking permitted
Value For Money: ❤️❤️
Not one of the cheapest venues in Copenhagen, but we are assured that the community who own and underwrite the operation look only to cover costs rather than profiteer.
description: A 'roaring twenties' jazz bar, now a centenarian known locally as "The Establishment", age has only added a further rheumy patina of sleaze, memories and character that make nights out at Intime today every bit as colourful.

A renowned gay bar, these days the crowd is mixed, usually but not exclusively young, and liberal. Waiters are notoriously gratuitous in their welcome and banter, and a bit of wise-cracking works both ways, you'll be glad to know.

Aside of table service (though you can go to the bar), the place is the height of informality.

Sunday jazz performances take place on a grand piano which takes an almost comical amount of floor space considering the available room. Inhaling from the cloud of cigarette smoke hanging across the room is unavoidable, but this bar is about tonight, not the day after.

This is hardly the only performance here - nights can seem to spontaneously give way to singalongs or events that appear to have no fanfare or trailer. Professional singers appear to emerge from within crowds of friends, and amateurs are often welcome to accompany them. It is this sense of dynamism that sets apart an already hugely atmospheric place to another level.

And drinks - well, they exist but can anyone really recall what they were drinking here? A well stocked back bar serves for cocktails and mixers, and the usual Carlsberg / Tuborg taps and bottles do the rest.

Don't look at InTime on a map and think it looks to far from central Copenhagen. It's a doddle to reach.

If you think you are perhaps a little reserved, inhibited, there may be other places to consider, but if you want to make new friends, or have a laugh with existing ones, this is one of the destinations in Copenhagen, Denmark, Europe.

(Added December 2024)

name: Jernbanecafeen
description:
EBG Rating:: 8.7
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
A reasonable selection of beers, albeit unneeded overlap of pale lagers. Nevertheless, you will find an array of options of different styles in the fridge. A modest selection of independent Danish beers. Competent back bar.
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️
A railway theme which goes almost beyond pub décor to becoming a city curio and tourist attraction in itself. Small street-facing bar with a few tables on the patio and twee, green painted exterior. Inside, a heavily decorated bunker to all things railway, with a red and white (how Danish!) colour scheme. The bar is on the left of the main lounge which, towards the back features a working model railway.
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️
Eccentric, highly unusual and distinctive, it is a pub with identity and a novelty factor, but it is also one with a crowd of loyal repeating customers. This has not become a venue where locals have fled, instead you will be among them. Social and excitable, there is an energy in here at any time of day.
Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️
Snacks, outdoor seating, train set, merchandise, loyalty card
Value For Money: ❤️
Undeniably a problem. Prices twice as high as some already pretty monstrous ones in central Copenhagen, and you'll need to skirt towards the basement options even to find anything that approaches acceptable.
description: One of Europe's famous drinking destinations, the Railway Cafe, located around the rear entrance of the main station is nothing less than a city institution and one of Europe's finest station, or station-adjacent pubs. The Railway theme bursts forth - this is no shrine to minimalism. Cute, twee, but cosy and very social, as an introduction to the Danish pub it represents one of the most vivid as well as a high watermark in general. Your eyes will dance across the room at the displays, from the wall of nik-naks to an operating train set, nothing is left to chance. Rich loungey reds decorate the room, each seating space designed to maximise room for customers. There is a cheerful verve to the place at any time of day with customers enjoying the novelty. The beer selection is broad, rather than excellent, which leads on to the bar's achilles heel - high pricing. Even a modest option like a bottle of Tuborg classic weighs in nearly double the price of nearby bars, and that continues across the board. As a cover charge to what is - almost - a sort of museum, there is an argument this is justified, but I would prefer to pay an upfront fee and enjoy fair prices than be squeezed in this way. It leaves an unnecessarily sour taste to what is otherwise a joyous experience. (Added December 2024)

name: Charlie's Bar
description:
EBG Rating:: 8.8
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️
An utterly superb selection. Several cask ales pulled and kept immaculately, a true rarity for Denmark, along with independently brewed Danish and other European beers, all of which are high quality. A very decent whisky selection to compliment that.
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️
Small and intimate, enter a room which is more of a knajpa - small with bench seating to the front and a bar up some steps, which has been decorated with beer ephemera and heritage without being suckered into the usual theme bar tacky tropes. 
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️
An intimate environment where cross-table conversation comes easy, as does chat at the bar. Denmark is not a problem as a foreigner but you will not find your nationality an issue here either, with a continental and cosmopolitan friendliness assured.
Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️
Snacks, occasional events
Value For Money: ❤️❤️
High quality beer in central Copenhagen - it is in line with the competition, but that still means expense.
description: An incredible bar that will make you rethink the role of the 'theme pub' in city centres. Normally the prospect of a British pub abroad would be a signal to steer clear, or at least leave the locals to try and enjoy such a tacky old thing.

Charlie's rips up the corporate template, offering both high quality independent brewed beer - including several cask lines which are immaculate - with an intimate, social, pubby environment that comfortably clears the low bar set by the average theme pub, while setting the marker very high in general.

Charlie's was a precursor to the craft scene, but has survived and thrived intact, without making needless concessions to its identity.

In all of Copenhagen there are very few bars that can compete either with its drinks offerings, or the venue as a whole.

An absolute must-visit. (Added December 2024)

name: Hviids Vinstue
description:
EBG Rating:: 8.3
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️
The Tuborg/Carlsberg lock-out with alternatives also from their corporate umbrella. Homemade gløgg (mulled wine) and a decent back bar of alternatives.
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
A characterful bar area that still has a tangible sense of history, with comfortable, tasteful lounges in cramped surroundings that would not have been built for such an operation if they were designed today.
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️
A patrician sense of its own importance, burnished by its prime location and waiters that puff their chests out a little, particularly by Danish standards. Bustling and sometimes impossible during the morning sandwich rush, but there are plenty of accessible occasions during the day where you can enjoy it as the good pub it is, and will continue to be.
Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Food, snacks, outdoor seating, newspapers, merchandise, shop
Value For Money: ❤️❤️
One of the more expensive city centre pubs, and as Copenhagen is expensive anyway, you can probably imagine... However, not entirely untethered from the mean average.
description: To be a standout institution in a city sprinkled with them is a noteworthy achievement. Prime location assists, as does its smorrebrød mornings, as the pub heaves with people seeking these open-faced sandwiches, beer and homemade gløgg (mulled wine). This spills out onto the street After this, the pub settles down. 

Founded in 1723, dating back to when Nyhavn was a working port, it is fair to say the most notable thing about the pub is that it has survived. Fires, wars, modernisation. It is still here.

Step in off the street into a series of compact, cosy rooms. The bar on your entrance is particularly characterful and worth spending some time to assess. Then you have a choice of lounges to position yourself, in among a classic ensemble of wood fittings, heritage framed photos, browns and greens. The clientele and service is a dead giveaway of its fame - middle-aged, middle-class groups, served by patrician no-nonsense servers (although these are Danes, not Czechs so for some people they may still seem relatively pleasant).

Protecting businesses of this kind is still a concept in its infancy around Europe, but Hviids has been a beneficiary of initial efforts by the city council, providing an assurance of sorts the business will survive for a long time to come.

Watch out on Sundays, as they close up at 8pm unlike the late opening hours of other days.

A venue that has that sprinkle of stardust.

(Added December 2024)

name: Eiffel bar
description:
EBG Rating:: 8.2
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️
The drinks selection is basic, a little above perfunctory, but some back bar concoctions can be rustled up. Their own label beer brewed by Hancock is a minor novelty. 
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
A one-room bar with tinted glass at the front, bar area to the right, and booths/café style tables to the left. Worn in to the point of worn out.
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️
During the afternoon there is a sleepy, deeply atmospheric inertia as light is filtered through tinted glass to dimly illuminate old wood fittings.

In the evenings it can become bustling, raucous and vibrant.
Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️
Snacks, late opening, food on special occasions, smoking permitted, late opening
Value For Money: ❤️❤️❤️
Given the location, reasonable value on par with the standard of offerings.
description: Although records show the building operating as a bar since the 1700s, this operation, Eiffel dates back to the 1970s. Throughout, there vague (but probably correct) assurances that this was a sailor's hangout in Christianshavn.

There were efforts to rebrand it to become a high society Parisien style café. The customers did not arrive, so it reverted back to its roots, yet with the French decor and signage intact.

These days it is a dive bar. Let's not try and second-guess, this is a god damn low-down smokey boozer with cheap prices and an excellent, bordering on sordid atmosphere.There's a sense that all involved from staff to customers are aware, adding a transgressive quality.  

Even though the pub is 'known', and part of a tourist circuit, you'll still find many locals here. Late opening 7 days a week ensures custom is spread out over the opening hours and rhythms of the day.

During the afternoon there is a sleepy, deeply atmospheric inertia as light is filtered through tinted glass to dimly illuminate old wood fittings. 

In the evenings it can become bustling, raucous and vibrant.

Both are, in their own ways excellent moods to capture. 

The drinks selection is basic, a little above perfunctory, but some back bar concoctions can be rustled up. Their own label beer brewed by Hancock is a minor novelty. 

An essential stop off for anyone remotely interested in sampling, perhaps even understanding Danish pub culture. 

(Added December 2024)

name: Tjili Pop
description:
EBG Rating:: 8.1
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Above average selection of tap and bottled beers as well as a diverse café bar menu for alternatives.
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Retro living room decor which is very effective, spread across a series of rooms. Furniture is crammed in fairly tight, which relates to the small space and need for seating on music nights particularly.
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
A funky and pleasant place to sit in even when empty, while the place obviously comes to live during its live events.
Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Food, snacks, live events, music, open mic, instruments, books, games
Value For Money: ❤️❤️
More expensive than average.
description: A funky, multi-room bar pitched pleasantly between alternative and bohemian, with the corresponding audience. Tjili Pop offers live acts as well as open mic, becoming a cultural mainstay so close to central Copenhagen. Their selection of drinks is above average too, while the smoke (which surely you will have got used to by now) is absent in the main area. Adding variety to the city's scene as well as an often missing feminine touch, there is much to recommend. (Added December 2024)

name: Floss Bar
description:
EBG Rating:: 8
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️
Basic beers but a large back bar offers a wealth of alternatives.
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Upstairs/downstairs. Upstairs you'll find a café bar that seems like it has crackled a little over time, while downstairs down a spiral staircase turns into a Berlin style punk hangout with graffiti strewn walls, pool & football tables.
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️
Very atmospheric up or down, as Floss' late openings mean it is often the last port of call for those drinking in the city centre. A younger audience and smokey surroundings. Service is gruff, tolerant at best to newcomers.
Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Snacks, happy hour, pool, table football
Value For Money: ❤️❤️❤️
City centre prices but some reasonable happy hour deals and nothing too offensive.
description: Part charmingly faded café, part punk-rock basement hangout, Floss is not shrinking violet as a glance at the frontage will confirm. Often 'the last call before home', late opening means happy hour here is 10pm rather than 5 in the afternoon like other pubs. With gruff service in front of a wall of old liqueurs and cocktail stock, basis beers and battered old furniture, this is a city stalwart and the memories linger around you, as will the fug of cigarette smoke. Downstairs it's even more deconstructed with furniture that skips would reject for being in too poor condition and games for the clientele. It's an essential stop off for the alternative scene in the centre that can't be missed, but turn up after 11 to see it at its best. (Added December 2024)

name: Woodstock Christiania Copenhagen
description:
EBG Rating:: 8
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️
Basic wares, but different bases are covered here.
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
A large sturdy wooden house with porch area for outdoor seating. Colourfully decorated with drop-out/hippy/druggy adornments, but not over the top.
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️
Summer evenings are a must, sat on the porch hearing and smelling Christiania as it drifts on the wind, enjoying drinks with friends. There is also a certain charm to clutching a cold beer and enjoying the smokey interior in winter.
Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Live events, snacks, outdoor seating
Value For Money: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Given the location, this bar has a fair attitude to pricing.
description: A stalwart of Copenhagen's hippy commune, Christiania, an area undoubtedly scarred by tourism but still offers a distinct visual and cultural counterpoint to the rest of the city. Pavements and roads give way to dirt tracks as you wander along art-lined passageways and old streets long passed into the commune's hands. Despite a friendly feel there remains a bit of an edge here and there, for reasons to obvious to bore you with in a bar review.

Woodstock is the social drinking epicentre of Christiania and maintains reasonable pricing -  admittedly for basic drinks. A large, sturdy wooden construction with an interior bar that is decorated in an almost stereotypical dropout/druggy way, the toilets vividly riffing on that further.

On summer evenings the terrace, colourfully lit is an absolute must, as the sounds and smells drift across from other buildings, and the complex feels like part of a coherent whole.

Be careful to tread lightly on Christiania though, and treat it as though you are a guest rather than a customer.

(Added December 2024)

name: Vinstue 90
description:
EBG Rating:: 7.9
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️
Slow Beer, one of the few to still pour Carlsberg over 15 minutes, something of a gimmick. The bottle selection offering regional independent beers is a little more interesting. Standard back bar of Danish brown liquor.
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
A 1920s interior, red paint, chunky furnishings and lamp light. An open room as you enter, with bar to the back, while there is another lounge, albeit narrow to the rear of the pub. 
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️
Superbly characterful owing to the genuine mixture of people who frequent it. Social, friendly, sometimes lively, never dull. Characterful busy or quiet due to the nostalgic surroundings.
Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️
Snacks, books, games, limited outdoor seating in warmer months
Value For Money: ❤️❤️❤️
Nothing out of the ordinary for Copenhagen, fair enough prices for bottles.
description: One of the few bars still advertising 'slow beer', but the bar's appeal surpasses that novelty.

Before we move on to the bar, let's deal with the Slow Beer thing. It's Carlsberg, poured slowly over 15 minutes while the foam settles to produce a thick bitter head and a smooth finish. They recommend buying a bottled beer while you wait, handily selling two beers while making it look like they're doing you a favour.

Let's move on to the positives though - a brown café with a truly mixed crowd - literary/journalistic appeal, the usual brown pub regulars, and youngster and cool kids - all in thrall to the appeal of this very atmospheric boozer. 

Red walls, lamp lights, bookshelves, smoky surroundings and chunky furniture, you'll be reminded of the best Dutch brown cafés and English taverns. 

The situation, on a busy Frederiksberg street is more like an ale house or tavern though.

Vinstue refers to wine, but you won't find that the focus here - the name harks back to alcohol licensing machinations of centuries past, as calling your bar a Vinstue was a way around the changes made to beer licensing.

Over 100 years old, there's a strong 'if these walls could talk' atmosphere whether busy or quiet. Service is friendly and willing even to tourists who venture our of the centre to come here. 

This pub is a great example of how little positives gradually build to a satisfying whole, when at a broad glance it would not seem overly remarkable.

An essential stop off in Copenhagen. (Added December 2024)

name: Diligencen
description:
EBG Rating:: 7.9
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️
Typical Carlsberg/Tuborg beer selection with Danish liqueurs.
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Western saloon bar exterior leads to a slightly different interior - bunker like with pool rooms and a main bar. Dark wood, retro kitsch on the walls relating to farming and fishing, lamplit.
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️
The place oozes character, and even if you don't enjoy the smoke that is difficult to deny. The mixed crowd in the early evening assists with this, making it not a scary old man pub, or a sterile bar with everyone on their phones, but a casual social environment.
Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Snacks, pool, cards, smoking permitted
Value For Money: ❤️❤️❤️
One of the more fairly priced venues close to the city centre.
description: On the face of it, a Western saloon type pub doesn't exactly scream 'come and visit me', but you'll notice this is one of the higher rated brown pubs in the city - for good reason, as we discovered. Set in an area without many neighbouring pubs, this appears to be to its benefit as there is a mixed clientele of old and young, overseen by the kindly bar manager Lene. The interior is dark, smoke filled but warm and welcoming too, a bunker that isn't just for old farts to chain smoke and chug back bottles, but for youngsters to play games and socialise too - a true pub, in effect. Prices are fair here given it's only a hop step and jump from the city centre and there's no doubt it would be on the rounds if we lived in the city. (Added November 2024)

name: Kompasset Beer Bar
description:
EBG Rating:: 7.8
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️
Beer specialists, at least 10 taps of high quality Danish and pan-European beers with a good can/bottle selection. Competent back bar of alternatives makes this more of an all-rounder than other craft bars in the city. 
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Light-brown ale house furnishings with more of an all-rounder café bar feel than the arch-hipster craft bar format normally applied. Similar to a suburban or small town English ale house with one main difference - the Hungarian owner has decorated it with clippings and ephemera from Hungary.
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Candlelit which is always pleasant, a warm and enjoyable environment even when quiet, chatty and convivial when full.
Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️
Snacks, board games, events
Value For Money: ❤️❤️
Not cheap by any means but perhaps slightly, slightly more amenable than some of the most high end craft beer bars. 
description: With the craft beer scene focusing on famous names like Fermentoren, Warpigs, and Soernes, this bar somehow drops off the discussion. Out in Osterbro, but perfectly easy to reach, set on a busy junction, this beer specialists is more interested in a low key ale house/café bar scenario than anything arch-hipster or cookie-cutter. Anyone who has visited a suburban or small town ale house in England will immediately recognise the similarities here. Candlelit interior furnished with light brown wooden tables and decorated rather distinctively with ephemera relating to the bars Hungarian owner - something we had to ask about given the absence of clues. Due to the nature of the pub this appeals to a wider audience than the typical craft beer bar such as those listed above, which is to its credit, and is considerably less pretentious or convinced of their own greatness as a result. The beer selection is strong with 10 taps concentrating on Danish craft but with some well-chosen pan-European options. Well worth considering above the famous ones you'll read mentioned. (Added November)

name: Søernes Ølbar
description:
EBG Rating:: 7.8
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️
Beer specialists. 24+ taps with an emphasis on local beer from independent breweries, but a wealth of choice.
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Exposed brick basement bar, candlelit with some retro signage, Front room with strange downstairs portal.
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Characterful in winter inside, or on the terrace in summer, but more tourists and fewer locals than some of the city's bars.
Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️
TV, snacks, outdoor seating
Value For Money: ❤️
While there are high quality beers available for the price it is nevertheless pitches right at the top end of an already expensive city.
description: Situated lakeside by the Sortedams Sø, one of 3 artificial stretches of water which operate an uncanny valley between river, lake and harbour. The bar is situated in a basement but in summer it makes good use of their situation and becomes an al fresco drinking spot. In the winter, the basement surroundings are of bare brick, candle-lit and sparingly decorated with retro signage, some similar to the kind of thing you see in brown pubs, but overall aiming for a more chic effect than that. This is a pub where you'll find more tourists than many, a known fixture on Copenhagen's craft beer circuit. The taplist is impressive, among the best in the city, and you will not want for variety of beer here. You may wish to say a few hail marys after reviewing the pricing, which is also correspondingly up there near the top. However, the main point is, this is a stylish, atmospheric and distinctive bar with a lot of choice of options, a combination that Copenhagen doesn't have that many competitors for. (Added November 2024)

name: Fermentoren
description:
EBG Rating:: 7.8
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️
Among the finest range of specialist beers in Denmark with a small cider selection. Specials available with guests from Dry & Bitter. 
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Leafy terrace off a main road, leading to a small candlelit basement bar with corner bar area. Mixture of leaning posts and low slung battered old lounge furniture that can safely be described as shabby chic.
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Candlelight works well in the indoors in winter, as does the nice terrace in spring and summer, but this is a bar needing customers to create atmosphere unlike many which work well whether busy or quiet.
Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️
Snacks, games, outdoor seating, occasional events.
Value For Money: ❤️
Given small pours are 0.2l this is at the top end of craft beer pricing in the city. 
description: An already famed Meatpacking District craft bar with pleasant beer garden and candlelit poky interior, Fermentoren makes no concessions in its offering of very high quality craft beer. That you'll be paying an arm and a leg for it is already accepted, so bear this in mind. There's no point spending your time here overthinking the money being deducted from your account, simply enjoy the fact it has supreme offerings in a pleasant environment. Spring lounging on the terrace is a must, as is joining the throng on a busy winter evenings. In between those peaks it can feel a little cold inside in winter months seemingly with only the candles for warmth. A clear mark better than the many corporate craft bars with their very bland template, this is a bar with its own identity regardless of its superior drinks offerings, so something worth pointing out to you, and something worth your attention. (Added November 2024)

name: Bodega 48
description:
EBG Rating:: 7.7
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️
The typical Bodega range - Tuborg/Carslberg, Danish schnapps and basic corporate back bar of alternatives.
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
A Brunt Vaertshus/Brown pub on the corner of the street. Small with the typical ensemble of old wood, fruit machines, twee artistry, lamplight and cigarette smoke.
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️
Some places have 'it' and some don't - this one does. Cosy, venerable, and atmospheric. Feels intimate during the day but comes alive at night too. 
Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️
Snacks, fruit machines, smoking permitted, TV
Value For Money: ❤️❤️❤️
Fair value for the basic goods on offer.
description: A good example of what the phrase 'beauty is in the eye of the beholder' means. Bodega 48 may look to some like the most routine corner local, and on many dimensions it is. A Brunt Vaertshus/Brown pub with the typical ensemble of old wood, lamplight and cigarette smoke.
