However, it is the execution of those and other qualities which sets it apart, making it not only the average neighbourhood living room, but a genuinely atmospheric and endearing hangout. A small pub, Bodega 48 still feels cosy and intimate when it's quiet, the kind of pub that doesn't just make you feel welcome but comfortably swaddled among its out of time decor and close atmosphere, the sort of relaxation that inspired the creation of the pub. Wholly unpretentious, the dual fruit machines, ashtrays and cast of regulars on stools at the bar seem part of a dreamy ensemble here rather than just some cranky, scuzzy old hole. Some places have 'it' and some don't - this one does. (Added November 2024)

name: Alléenberg
description:
EBG Rating:: 7.7
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️
Basic Tuborg/Carlsberg options with Danish schnapps and a couple of other different - but unexciting options.
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
A larger venue than the typical brown pub. Large front law leading to conservatory area (ignore that) and pub inside, with a lounge and slim bar at the back. Reds and browns, very worn in, and almost worn out.
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️
Oozing character and memory, a 100 year old pub that speaks to you even when only a few people are present. Later on it becomes the scene of merriment as a communal piano is the centre of early morning singalongs.
Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️
Live music, snacks, outdoor seating, smoking permitted
Value For Money: ❤️❤️❤️
Reasonable value overall, not unusual, and some fair options to be found.
description: Nicknamed 'The Psychopath', Alléenberg's reputation as a sleazy late night dive may not be immediately apparent as you pass through a quaint gate through a large garden, the sort you don't normally see around Copenhagen, but which line Pile Allé in the town (don't say district) of Frederiksberg. Everything looks reasonably restrained, with a small outdoor bar and conservatory area leading to a lounge café. This is so typical of the many faces of Copenhagen nightlife. As the evening develops, the place becomes ever rowdier, culminating in late music performances. An interior which matches the Brunt Vaertshus (Brown Pub) aesthetic - browns and reds with brewery signage and old nik-naks is the appropriate setting for that sort of debauchery. That plus the permitted smoking tends to hustle customers quickly into the love/hate camps, as its online reviews confirm, but there is no doubt that an evening here, in a 100 year old bar is an educational, and often fun exposure to Danish nightlife. (Added November 2024)

name: Børges Bodega
description:
EBG Rating:: 7.7
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️
The typical Carlsberg/Tuborg roster, Dutch schnapps and corporate back bar.
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️
Splendid one-room boozer, low lit, with bar in front of the entrance. Personalised with musical instruments, local heritage and brewery signage.
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
An atmospheric hidey-hole when quiet, and a lovely living room when busier.
Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️
Snacks, occasional live music, bar games
Value For Money: ❤️❤️❤️
Fair prices.
description: A curiosity, not set in a very pubby part of town, but  easy to reach on public transport. Børges opens only 3-8pm daily, hours not traditionally known for hordes of customers, indeed it was quiet on our visit. Unlike the typical bodega there is no smoking permitted inside the pub here, giving it a fresher atmosphere. However, it is no less cosy, really a beautiful pub, dimly lit with jazz instruments attached to walls and ceilings. The instruments are an indicator of live music which happens occasionally, while the soundtrack also spins through jazz and blues. The owner is clearly doing this out of love, making the place more endearing as well. Fair prices are assured, albeit for a fairly unexciting roster of drinks. This is certainly worth carving some time in your diary to visit. (Added November 2024)

name: Cafe Haraldsborg
description:
EBG Rating:: 7.6
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️
Basic wares - Tuborg/Carlsberg variants with the classic Danish back bar of brown bitter schnapps and corporate spirits selection.
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Facing the water, a step up off the street. Green old-fashioned frontage which doesn't give much away about the interior. Inside a 1 room pub, low-lit with moody browns and greens, retro beer signage and the occasional plume of cigarette smoke. Bar directly opposite the entrance and regulars table to the left - as this is almost always occupied you won't need to worry about committing the faux pas of sitting there.
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
With a husband-and-wife team, and friendly regulars there is a more personal feel.  There is a sense of calm and cosiness in the afternoon, but don't be fooled this is only a middle aged hangout. Like many of these places it can spark to life in the evenings. Both a throwback experience and a vibrant nightspot in one. 
Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️
Bar games, smoking permitted, outdoor seating in summer, snacks
Value For Money: ❤️❤️❤️
A fairly priced bar with budget options, very welcome so close to the centre.
description: With a husband-and-wife team, and friendly regulars there is a more personal feel on afternoons here than some of the other bodegas around Copenhagen. This is not to say the others are unfriendly, only that this adds a certain something. A brown pub/brunt vaertshus facing the Slydhavnen which reaches out into the sea, this is a vividly Danish experience. With smoking permitted and a homely interior, you can be assured of a throwback experience. The pub itself is well curated with the typical retro beer signage, low-lit lamps and booths. There is a sense of calm and cosiness in the afternoon, but don't be fooled this is only a middle aged hangout. Like many of these places it can spark to life in the evenings - some will be surprised to see it stays open until 2am most nights - this is not even unusual for the city. As well as all the above, the basic wares of the bar are fairly priced meaning this is one Danish pub that isn't going to be plundering your wallet. (Added November 2024)

name: Lord Nelson Bar
description:
EBG Rating:: 7.5
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
A strong selection of beers covering a range of styles, some Danish, some foreign, normally 8 on tap with a small fridge of bottles.
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Half-step basement with low ceiling cream walls and decorated in a nautical theme befitting Nelson and Copenhagen. Small sideroom near the toilets.
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
The low ceiling makes this a fairly compact-feeling space, and it doesn't take many guests to become lively feeling. At quieter times its a pleasant place to hang out.
Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️
Snacks, games machine, board games
Value For Money: ❤️
Fairly expensive for the product, even for the area, made worse as there is only one serving size.
description: Lord Nelson sounds like it may be a potentially horrific theme pub, but here you'll find a craft beer bar with a relatively muted and restrained decoration of ships and seafaring nik naks which don't steer the pub anywhere near that territory. Superior beers are on offer, albeit for a high rate, but the environment is warm and cosy feeling, pleasant even with its low basement ceiling making it a little more cramped than ideal. It is undeniably a more distinctive craft beer bar than many of the corporate chains in the city. (Added November 2024)

name: Toga Vinstue
description:
EBG Rating:: 7.5
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️
A very typical, patrician range of Tuborg, Carlsberg and Danish brown liqueur with some basic corporate alternatives.
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Basic green signage outside and step up to the interior. A basic layout shorn of the kind of tourist tat that may send the wrong signals. A small bar room with a nice niche, then a larger pub room decorated with old photographs and lamp light - there's not much else to it than that.
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Lively bar life and politician's gossip, occasional tourists, a prevailing sense of institution.
Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️
Snacks, events, stall at the annual carnival, newspapers. Has formerly served lunches.
Value For Money: ❤️❤️
Not the cheapest even in the city centre.
description: Nothing less than an institution. A 100+ year history, with more recent connections too. Newly elected politicians have a rite of passage acting as bartender at Toga, while the pub is commonly used for off-the-record gossip and trading of favours over a drink. Naturally this has resulted in attention being drawn to it, yet it still retains a Danish audience rather than a touristic one. A basic layout helps with that, shorn of the kind of tourist tat that may send the wrong signals. A small bar room with a nice niche, then a larger pub room decorated with old photographs and lamp light - there's not much else to it than that. The atmosphere at the bar is usually emblematic of its audience and purpose. (Added November 2024)

name: Funchs Vinstue
description:
EBG Rating:: 7.5
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️
Basic Tuborg and Carslberg products with Danish liqueur and back bar.
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Green frontage and a 1950s style interior of wood fittings. One room with bar straight ahead, and booths in an L-shape around it. A very well designed interior means that nearly all the seats contain some pleasing angle or aspect. It is an unapologetic boozer for simple drinking and hanging out. Its windows facing out onto the busy street, modern life passing by seem to almost cocking a snook at contemporary developments.
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Calm local life during the afternoons, mainly older folk, but this is one place that can be relied upon to up the tempo later on, a mixture of old and young adding vibrancy to a tradition.
Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️
Newspapers, snacks, talk of a smorrebrod/sandwich platter early on that is "on til' it's gone".
Value For Money: ❤️❤️❤️
Inexpensive but not among the truly lowest price options.
description: Occupying low-key cult status, Funchs has long been an afternoon hangout for older folk as well as the last place at night people go for a late beer before home. This duality creates a fun atmosphere as two worlds overlap for a few hours, then depart. An old-fashioned bodega with an attractive brown/green patina of wood fittings and upholstery, a sense of institution to it that is clear from the figures you'll see on entering.  Online reviews may seem mixed rather than universally complimentary but that is due to the smoking, hardly unusual here, and the love/hate nature of such places. If you enjoy an old pub and want to experience Danish culture, this is a prime central example of where to do it. One of the few venues this side of the Dronning bridge to retain entirely fair prices for its wares too. (Added November 2024)

name: Cafe Viking
description:
EBG Rating:: 7.5
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
A superior selection than the usual brown café with 4 different beers on tap to the norm still from local brewers, and European bottles. Formerly award winners for their selection though that has become a little superseded. Typical Danish back bar selection.
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️
Twee upholstery but a nice corner pub layout. Bar room in the entrance with lounge/billiards room to the left. Lamp light.
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
A pleasant calmness to the afternoon, while it takes on another character in the evening, a livelier neighbourly feel.
Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Bar games, pool, skittles, books, snacks
Value For Money: ❤️❤️❤️
A range of pricing but there are some reasonable options if you dig into it.
description: Nørrebro's everyday feel is enhanced by its corner pubs, three examples of which are on the same street, this being among them.

Inside is a rather twee affair if you stop to inspect it, but the layout is pleasingly pubby, and its no old-timers place fading away. There's a sense of relevance to it with a modern beer selection, young staff and a feeling even on a calm afternoon it will burst into life soon enough. 

Formerly award winning for its beer selection, although that has become a little superseded. Nevertheless, this is among Copenhagen's better 'bodegas' , as reviews attest, and an easy bus ride out from the centre to get to. 

(Added November 2024)

name: Dead Soldier Speakeasy
description:
EBG Rating:: 8.2
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️
Signature cocktails and a high quality back bar, you can also order "off-menu" if you have particular favourites.
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Doorway entrance next to a hotel - ring for service who will come and collect you. Push a false bookcase and descend into a basement with a lamplit bar and rooms/niches around from it, decorated individually, but with a boudoir/bohemian style.
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Dynamic at the bar with busy work and friendly patter, it is a well-staffed establishment. Each area of the bar has its own appeal - clandestine niches, the boudoir lounge or the hubbub of sitting at the bar itself, each of which are very pleasant. Despite clearly aping a big city bar, the nature of the city, the staff lends this a provincial quality - which sounds like a criticism, but really isn't, making it feel more approachable, more fun.
Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️
Table reservations, events, snacks
Value For Money: ❤️❤️❤️
The prices correspond to the quality without a doubt. Not one of Romania's cheapest cocktail bars but not unfair in any way and certainly good value in comparison to equivalents.
description: The highlight of Iasi's bar scene, Dead Soldier Speakeasy takes the concept seriously, requiring you to call ahead and be given a password for entry. On arrival you are ushered to a false bookcase and asked to figure it out (it isn't difficult). Descend into a suitably shady basement lair with the bar by the steps and lounge rooms and niches either side. Everything is clandestine, intimate, and the bar is well staffed too. Sat at the bar, the rhythms, rituals and patter of the mixologists help keep the vibe dynamic and friendly, while the lounges are boudoir like and distinctive, without the venue feeling like it was pasted from a template. Their signature cocktails are inventive while you can freely order "off menu" if there's another cocktail you desire. Prices remain reasonable - these would easily command a higher price in a Western city - without being cheap. It is a bar where you will get out of it as much as you put in - the crowd was a predictable mixture of locals, visitors, and some characters splashing the cash. Such bars provide a city like Iasi with a sense of the cosmopolitan, while in return Iasi's provincial feel really adds to the atmosphere, making it less pretentious and more personal. I'm sure they would hate to be described as provincial but it just shows you there are more elements that make up a good bar than copying others and expecting the same result. An essential venue when visiting Iasi. (Added November 2024)

name: Café Retro
description:
EBG Rating:: 7.8
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
A broad selection with a surprising emphasis on cocktails, but fridge which includes several local craft beers from AltGust, an independent brewery. All café bar bases covered too.
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
An ivy strewn old house with pleasant, funkily decorated garden. The Bohemian feel continues inside with antique furnishings, original fittings, ceramic heater, and warren of rooms. 
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Although a little twee and cafe-like in the day, overall the effect is strong, with shady corners and different spaces. A younger crowd, as can be expected, but post-grads too. It feels warm, homely and cosy, somewhere you would make a home from home.
Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️
Food, snacks, events, instruments, books, board games
Value For Money: ❤️❤️❤️
Fair value overall
description: Most cities in Romania seem to have a bar like this one - bohemian, ramshackle café full of antiques and old world charm. Here is Iasi's, set just off the university campus, therefore popular with students as well as post-grads. A beautiful old building plastered in climbing ivy with a funky courtyard and a few cats roaming around, as you step inside the usual tropes are there - the music instruments, books and board games, the old wood floor, the shady corners and lamps - it's a place you could turn into a home from home. Warm, cosy and friendly. In the daytime it perhaps errs a little more towards cafe and bar, but a wide cocktail menu, local craft beers and evening schedule shows it is versatile and adaptable. For all the city displays in terms of variety, there is nothing else like it in Iasi, and should be up near the top of your bars to visit in the city. (Added November 2024)

name: Vipard
description:
EBG Rating:: 7.7
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️
Absolute bargain basement fodder - Suceava lager and its equivalents, huge bottles of low grade liquor.
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️
Covered seating outside with a bunker like interior. One small room with wood panels surrounded by radiators keeping everything warm. Bar to the left with a plastic screen.
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
An absolute love-or-hate venue. Utterly absent of any form of pretension or artifice, the charm here is in its steadfast refusal to change with the times, and thus offers a window into a previous time and culture in the country. Popular with youngsters who occupy the terrace areas, as well as the grizzled regulars who are camped inside. Everything from the service, the clientele and the surroundings is local culture in situ. We can't promise you'll enjoy it, only that it is truthful, authentic and you can learn more about Romania in 5 minutes here than in a whole weekend at some of the central theme bars.
Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Snacks, TV, Outdoor seating
Value For Money: ❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️
By far the cheapest bar in the city, around half the price of even the cheapest alternatives (which are certainly not twice as good)
description: Nothing less than a cult classic, Vipard is popular not for its cutting edge product or see and be seen crowd, but because of its commitment to being the antithesis of modern movements. This is surely a love-hate format. Not everyone is going to enjoy diving into a local only bunker, approaching a bar with a plastic screen as grizzled patrons watch on. However, there is much fun to be had, and you can learn more about Romania spending 5 minutes in this bar than you can at the well-financed ventures further into the city centre. 
With prices pitched at not only dirt cheap but easily half the prices of even the nearest competitors, Vipard ensures the holy union of all down and dirty boozers - students and youngsters out to get wasted on a budget, and grizzled regulars who add their usual eccentric and unpredictable flavour. This is of course an intimidating environment initially for a newcomer, particularly any shrinking violet, but if I were to tell you the owner shook my hand as I left, you can build a picture of its underlying honesty, authenticity and gentility. Worthy of serious consideration for anyone who is more interested in experiencing local life and culture in situ than hopping from one empty sterile bar to another ticking off beers. And if you don't believe us, the reviews online should speak for themselves. Who knows how much longer this bar will be around? (Added November 2024)

name: Berăria Veche
description:
EBG Rating:: 7.5
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
A house beer, and very decent list of bottles covering some Belgian classics and Romanian pseudo-craft beer (craft styles brewed by Macros), nothing to bowl over aficionados but given where we are in the world, all in all a much more impressive list than expect. Well stocked back bar for alternatives.
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Split between a dining area and a pub area, the casual pub is to the left of the entrance and the interior is a suitably pub-like fit of chunky tables, wood panelling, casual, slightly quirky decor. The overall effect is not unlike an English pub, Czech hospoda or German Gaststatte.
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️
Local life, families, couples at lunch hours, dining but doing so in a casual way.
Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Food, snacks, TV, outdoor seating
Value For Money: ❤️❤️❤️
Ok, unremarkable prices.
description: "The Old Brewery" - it seems unlikely this building was ever the site of a brewery, and their house beer is a contract brewed lager, but the selection here will cause a few eyebrows to flicker up. A good selection of Belgian classics, Romanian pseudo-craft (craft brewed by macros not independents) provides a selection that is comfortably superior for the city. That is not the only surprise however. Listed as a restaurant, expectations were simply that it would be a traditional tavern, but on arrival it was clear the operation was split between formal and casual, with a fully fledged pub to the left of the building. Decorated in a familiar style like an upright English pub, Czech hospoda or German Gaststatte, with some adornments making it feel more casual and relaxed. The atmosphere is of families and couples coming for lunch and to relax, making it food focused but absolutely casual enough to qualify as a hangout spot too. Unexpected, but we find ourselves justifying it as an inclusion on our guide. (Added November 2024)

name: Kaze Taproom
description:
EBG Rating:: 7.5
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️
Beer specialists. At least 10 taps of beers from independent Romanian breweries including one brewed in the city. The styles focus on IPA but there are other alternatives as well as a fridge of cans and bottles. Limited non-beer alternatives.
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
 A central craft beer bar with colourful murals, an L-shaped bar of right angles and flat surfaces, but with seating that encourages cross-chat.
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️
Reasonably low-key for a central bar, less corporate feeling than those next to the mall. The dub/reggae soundtrack becomes the echoey medium through which beer is enjoyed. Seating encourages cross chat. Needs to grow into its surroundings and gain a fanbase.
Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️
Snacks, outdoor seating in summer, occasional events.
Value For Money: ❤️❤️❤️
Despite the quality of offerings, prices are not that much higher than only mid-range corporate beers in the average bar around the city, making it a reasonable option for most. 
description: As of 2024, a recent opening adding a missing piece to Iasi's bar landscape. A central craft beer bar with colourful murals, an L-shaped bar of right angles and flat surfaces, but with seating that encourages cross-chat. Kaze provides at least 10 taps of beers from independent Romanian breweries including one brewed in the city. The styles focus on IPA but there are other alternatives as well as a fridge of cans and bottles. The bar maintains a dub/reggae soundtrack, relatively unusual for both the city and this bar format, addition a distinctive identity that perhaps wouldn't quite be there just from the decor alone. Despite the quality of offerings, prices are not that much higher than only mid-range corporate beers in the average bar around the city, making it a reasonable option for most. Perhaps the venue needs time to grow into its own space, become more personalised and so on, but the seeds are there to allow this. It should certainly be a bookmarked venue on your visit. (Added November 2024)

name: La Bază
description:
EBG Rating:: 7.5
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️
Mainstream beer selection, but at least covering a range of styles. A similar approach to the back bar for mixers, shots, cocktails etc.
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Basement bar, darkly lit but with garish green painted walls decorated with musical ephemera. Considerably larger than pictures suggest with a big approach to the bar at the rear and two sizeable rooms either side of it.
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️
At the hear of the "Spirala" complex, the sense of institution pervades - it has hosted many nights and is a comfortable old pair of shoes that students, youngsters, as well as some post-grads and alternatives hang out at. Large enough that you can turn around to see people dancing, while across the room couples can be in comfortable conversation.
Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️
Live events, DJ, snacks
Value For Money: ❤️❤️❤️
Despite being a studenty venue this isn't as cheap as you might anticipate, but there is nothing above/below the norm.
description: La Bază is a constituent part of Spirala, a semi-abandoned mall whose basement has been converted into a half dozen bars and clubs. Therefore visiting here is to also visit what feels more of a collective space. There is a grimy charm to the basement by the spiral itself - somewhere genuinely alternative feeling rather than some corporate invention. This means mind your head, mind the puddle, mind the drunks and join the crowd. Some venues specialise in certain music genres or lifestyles but La Bază is more of a genuine all-rounder. The interior has clearly seen many nights and has that feel of slipping on a pair of old shoes. It's a larger place than you may imagine, but it makes sense when you see it getting busy.  The space allows for anything like dancing, cards, even quiet conversation in the shadier corners without those impeding on each other Despite a mainstream audience and mainstream drinks, the  atmosphere doesn't really feel like that, nor does it feel cliquey - it manages to be a reasonable all-rounder that pulls in a corresponding range of people. For the Spirala experience and late night fun, this is your best bet. (Added November 2024)

name: Laurieston Bar
description:
EBG Rating:: 9.5
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️
Fyne Ales on cask with a couple of guest lines, along with old-school ‘heavies’ like McEwans and typical Scotch selection.
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️
A bulldog of an exterior, new-build circa 1960s down to the facade and signage, which continues inside with a horseshoe bar, formica tables set across corners of the pub. Split between bar (left door) and lounge (right door) as you enter.
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️
Perhaps aided by an unprepossessing interior, the change once you enter is both a relief and an uplifting sight. Friendly, social and cosy as they come. A true mixture of people across age and class too.
Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Pies, snacks, jukebox, community meet ups, seasonal specials
(Warning: CASH ONLY)
Value For Money: ❤️❤️❤️
Fairly standard for the area.
description: The legend of the Laurieston has grown over the years to the extent it can be considered a genuine destination pub. Certainly its exterior and interior are time warps, worth a look as curios alone. The harsh 1960s flat roof exterior and the ‘murder pub’ connotations those have earned over the decades makes you double take in its bracing hideousness. Perhaps the fact it’s Glasgow, with a reputation for tough boozers (admittedly much outdated) adds an extra sense of threat. This could not be dispelled anymore firmly by walking inside.

Warm, cosy, social and friendly, every spot in the pub looks worth sitting in, from the upholstered corners in the bar, to the cushioned lounge, to the bar stools around a stylish horseshoe shaped bar, that can be viewed through at either side.

Formica tables screwed into the floor, matching curtains, reinforced glass and a pie heater add further to the sense of throwback, but the customers – those you can see, hear and sense around you lend it a vibrancy and relevance to match and beat any of the most cutting edge destinations in Scotland – this is no museum but a living, breathing democratic social space.

Majestic. (Added December 2024)

name: Doublet Bar
description:
EBG Rating:: 8.1
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Decent range of drinks on show from the typical old fashioned 'heavies' to ales from independent Scottish brewers.

The back bar menu refers to soft drinks as 'Minerals', another 60's reference. Back bar options are stripped back - don't expect a treasure trove of single malts.
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
A large exterior leads in to a pub with more cramped space than you'd expect. It's a deliberately preserved space. They aren't preserving ornate craftsmanship or listed fittings, but a space that has served the public well since the 1960s. A long ground floor space leads to a 2nd bar room, while upstairs there's a lounge.
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️
A terrific social scene - warm and friendly, shared space and communal socialising with genuinely mixed crowd.
Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️
Function room, live music upstairs, beer garden, snacks 
Value For Money: ❤️❤️❤️
Not cheap but neither is it remarkably expensive.
description: Opened in 1962, there's no surprise then the Doublet's nostalgic bar/lounge split and social scene is more than a little reminiscent of  the slightly more famous Southside boozer The Laurieston. It was kept in the same ownership for decades until a sale in 2015, but that has not resulted in major changes to the relief of a loyal audience.

At first glance it may not seem all that. There's an old fashioned neon sign outside, and mock tudor interior - two bar rooms (and bars) downstairs with an upstairs lounge. But give yourself time to survey the surroundings, the atmosphere and the environment. What is mainly apparent is a warmth and sense of welcome welcome, conviviality, bonhomie, all of that.

Head to the bar and you'll find a decent range of drinks on show from the typical old fashioned 'heavies' to ales from independent Scottish  brewers.

The back bar menu refers to soft drinks as 'Minerals', another 60's reference. 

The Doublet is up there with the best Glasgow pubs to try if you're keen to explore somewhere that hasn't been gutted for a soulless refit, and offers the most authentic, least pretentious kind of experience without the rough and ready aspects that could in the past be accompanied by that. 

(Added January 2025)

name: Scotia Bar
description:
EBG Rating:: 7.9
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️
A familiar city centre range of beers, one or two interesting ones from West and on keg, but not a specialists.
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
A low-slung ceiling and bunker-like interior with a long bar to the front, and partitioned space alongside. More snug room either side of the bar. Old-fashioned interior with brasses, low-beams with banknotes from around the world pinned to them. Vernished wood panelling alongside the walls emphasizes a bunker/ship like nature to the place.
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️
With regular live acts there is usually a lively atmosphere on evenings, although it can be worth a look during weekday afternoons for a quieter, but nonetheless characterful experience. A well-known locally famous city pub with the sense of institution which accompanies that.
Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Live music, food, snacks, jukebox, fireplace, merchandise, rehearsal space
Value For Money: ❤️❤️❤️
The going rate in the city centre, nothing out of the ordinary. 
description: Belhaven Brewery run this famous pub harking back to 1792, with sailing and seafaring connections, but these days better known for live music and similarly lively atmosphere. Acts perform 4 days a week and when nothing else is going on you can ask to perform yourself.  There are also poetry meetups and due to its cultural connections it can boast an impressive cast list of customers. This of course lends it a sense of institution, bolstered still by the low-beams, varnished wood, scattering of bank notes across the ceiling, crackling fireplaces, and local history on the walls all pointing to the fact that this is not just another pub.

On the drinks front, the selection is competent rather than spectacular, though most bases are ably covered, it could perhaps be modernised. 

Leaving that opportunity to one side though, it is a clearly superior venue for the city. (Added January 2025)

name: The Pot Still
description:
EBG Rating:: 7.8
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️
A selection of whiskies which competes with anywhere in the world. 4 cask ales from Scottish and Northern English brewers. 
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️
Some inherited Victorian fittings including detailed ceiling, in a compact 1 room pub with raised seating area to the back, booths opposite the bar, and leaning posts in the middle of the room. 
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Busy, bustling trade on evenings and weekends, not a place for a relaxing contemplative dram, but somewhere you can make new friends and enjoy a busy city tavern atmosphere. Whether the two activities naturally blend is up for debate, but it's a friendly spot.
Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️
Food, snacks, TV
Value For Money: ❤️❤️
Relatively high on account of its city centre location.
description: A Victorian pub dating from 1861, but not adopting the name Pot Still until 1981, previously McCall's. The name change coincided with a unique selling point - the introduction of a vast array of whiskies. Initially 300, expanded these days to a minimum of 600. These line the shelves behind the bar as you enter what is a compact space with booths opposite the bar, leaning posts, and a raised seating area to the rear. Along with whiskies there are 3-4 cask ales from Scotland and Northern England, and an offering of pies. None of this comes particularly cheap these days which is unsurprising given its central location. What it can provide though is specialist high quality wares. Busy, bustling trade on evenings and weekends only really subsides on midweek afternoons, but even then there is still a sense of briskness orbiting the pub. This makes it a place you can quickly get into conversations with strangers, but if you are seeking a quiet contemplative dram by a fireplace, you may wish to choose a different venue. The superb selection pushes it above simply a superior city tavern to a guide entry. Don't be afraid to ask the servers for recommendations. (Added January 2025)

name: The State Bar
description:
EBG Rating:: 7.7
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
A superior selection of cask ales for Glasgow from Scotland and the wider UK, decent keg selection by the standards of the city in general. A good selection of whisky bottles, usually 50+ options.
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Dating from 1902 with a typical city tavern appearance. Wet gloss patterned ceiling, island bar, high ceiling, mirrors and ornate wood fittings with old sayings gilded onto them. Horseshoe shaped bar upstairs.
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
An odd sensation - The State is the very picture of a central tavern, but as there isn't anything else quite like it around the city and even the nearest tend to have a greater 'city bustle', it doesn't quite occupy the epitome of the Glasgow pub you feel it should. This is very high level discernment however - the atmosphere remains a feeling of solidity, reliability, institution and like the sum of all the parts that go into it.
Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Live music, food, snacks, TV
Value For Money: ❤️❤️❤️
Typical city centre prices.
description: Boasting the best steak pie in Scotland, this quirky piece of homespun hospitality seems unusual in what is an institution city tavern with all the typical features of its 1902 inception - high ceilings with a patterned gloss finish, lavish bar area and ornate wood fittings, a sense of grandeur and space that is effective: reassuring and cradling. One of Glasgow's beer specialists with a good range of cask, keg and bottles covering bases. It must be said that those who live in other UK cities may not find the range especially impressive but this is still something Glasgow is catching up with. Live music nights provide further points of difference, while the large tellies speak of the need to gather together a relatively diverse crowd, making it a fairly versatile venue too. The large mirrors give a sense of space that is disarming, but on an evening accentuate the opulent surroundings. Something about The State as a whole is intriguing - intimate and sensual in some ways yet also a pub operated at scale. (Added January 2025)

name: Koelschip Yard
description:
EBG Rating:: 7.5
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️
Very high quality keg and fridge selection of specialist beers covering a wide range of styles. Compact cask ale range and basic back bar.
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️
Looks like a traditional pub that has been slightly refit - there's a vaguely ramshackle pubby nature as opposed to the modern/clean lines of a craft beer bar.
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️
The type of venue that requires people to generate atmosphere and feel like the place to be.
Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Takeaway, snacks, cards, board games, books, occasional events
Value For Money: ❤️❤️❤️
The going rate in line with higher quality products.
description: Taking over the premises of a former pub, Koelschip Yard, for the attentive among us references its beer-geek credentials in the titlle, a Koelschip being a vessel where beer was stored to cool.

The bare bones of the original pub are in evidence, while the interior has been given an informal knockabout type refit - this is no craft beer bar of sleek lines, but a punkier affair. This feel is complimented by ledges containing battered old books, board games and cards etc.

The product is top of the line with its kegs frequently boasting some of the UK's finest keg beer available anywhere - itself worth commending, but when you consider the unpretentious social space, and Glasgow's relatively modest record for modern beers, it's altogether a strong choice.

(Added January 2025)

name: Horseshoe Bar Glasgow
description:
EBG Rating:: 7.5
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️
4 cask ales along the left hand side of the bar and decent whisky selection, with other options familiar and mainstream.
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️
The longest bar in Scotland in a horseshoe shape along a grand room with ornately decorated glazed tiles on the surrounding walls. A statement venue for its decor that is listed as a building of National Historic Importance.
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
The surroundings add a considerable degree of character, but the city trade is fairly mainstream and enjoying it will depends on luck and taste. Busy and bustling, you can get chatting to people easily, but such surroundings perhaps could benefit from a little more discernment in places.
Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Food, snacks, TV, newspapers
Value For Money: ❤️❤️❤️
City centre prices, but not unfamiliar.
description: A busy, bustling city tavern with a unique horseshoe shaped bar - the longest in Scotland. As you enter most of the trade appears to be at the bar itself, leaning and chatting. However, more space emerges towards the rear of the bar with seating in remarkably opulent surroundings, glazed tiling depicting roman scenes. A listed building of national historic importance, there is enough on show to justify a visit even if other aspects - relatively middling mainstream trade, big screens and clatter of dinner plates let it down. If you don't see cask ales at first don't despair, wander down the left side of the horse shoe and you'll find a tidy selection. The rest, on keg, is more mainstream. The upstairs lounge is largely overflow territory.

Overall, while there is room for improvement, it contains good enough drinks, outstanding interior decor and a wide range of amenities to cover a good range of bases here, so we can recommend dropping by. (Added January 2025)

name: Tan Hill Inn
description:
EBG Rating:: 7.7
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
50+ single malt whiskies, 4 own label/contract brewed cask ales and 2/3 regulars from well known Yorkshire brands. Decent back bar.
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Enlarged and refurbished stone cottage in isolated location. Interior sympathetically refurbished retaining low beams, real fireplace adjacent to the bar, with dining rooms either side of the bar.
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
A novel feel emphasised by its remote location and sense of haven. To be here is to feel detached from the world, in a relaxing sense.
Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Live events, food, snacks, outdoor seating, fireplace
Value For Money: ❤️❤️❤️
Considering the location, excusable, although hardly cheap.
description: One of England's famous pubs, not only for being the highest Inn in the country but the remoteness. A drive to it, miles from any nearby village, let alone town, is to enter the heart of the Pennines. Indeed, Tan Hill intercepts the Pennine Way hiking route. A storied history tracing back to the old days of drovers and metres worth of snow, these days a conveyor belt of hikers and day-trippers serves the place. Although there are some of the trappings of its fame in the pub, not least in some quite generic signage and bits of the interior design, there is still a sprinkling of stardust about it. A true Inn in the sense you can stay in its rooms, which people do on the off-chance they too can have an anecdote about being snowed in. Hosting dark sky stargazing due to its distance from artificial light pollution, and a yearly calendar full of one-offs that add something extra special. A stone fireplace by the bar is always a prime spot to warm up and enjoy one or more of their 50+ single malt whiskies, while they have their own label beers contract brewed for them available on cask. Dinners are hearty pub grub - not cheap but decent and filling. Something of a pilgrimage spot, that most people in the North should pay a visit to once in their lives. (Added December 2024)

name: Lismore
description:
EBG Rating:: 7.9
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
An impressive whisky selection and superior - if still compact - selection of cask ales mark Lismore out as notable in Glasgow.
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
A restored corner pub on a row of tenement houses, fitted in a Baronial style with fireplace, stone fittings and stained glass with scenes of the highland clearances. A long narrow ground floor bar room with upstairs lounge. The fittings date from the 1996 refurbishment so in the present day retain an uncanny valley of the era they are aping and telltale signs of the era when it was constructed, a similar feeling you get while watching old sci-fi shows.
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
A popular spot near Kelvinhall station and on a prominent site by the square, meaning plenty of footfall. The interior atmosphere is close, relatively intimate but with a bustling rather than sleepy feel on weekends and evenings.
Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️
Snacks, fireplace, books
Value For Money: ❤️❤️❤️
Standard fare for the city.
description: A visit to the Lismore at first provides a hard-to-place sensation. Its 1996 refit is impressive and remains in great condition, built in a singular vision of baronial fireplaces and wooden shelves with stone walls and stained glass. It doesn't look like a traditional pub that would have existed, but nevertheless is rather curious. Situated by a square on a busy high street, trade is brisk on evenings and weekends, and space can be at a premium along a narrow ground floor bar room. A superior selection of whiskies and real ales sharpens the point of visiting further still. Cosy, curious and markedly Glaswegian, it should be on your list to visit. (Added January 2025)

name: Valhalla York
description:
EBG Rating:: 7.8
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️
Value For Money: ❤️❤️❤️
description:

name: Café littéraire Le Bovary
description:
EBG Rating:: 7.5
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️
A competent café bar selection covering a broad base, with some excellent wines, while beers are a weaker suit.
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️
Eye-catching interior with a deliberately homely feel, if a home featured more tables than usual and far more books. Even each step of the stairs has its own book. Two floors with two rooms on the ground floor and a basement performance room with a small stage. Plenty to look at and explore.
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
A neighbourhood café trade during the week, but the audience diversifies during events nights. 
Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Food, snacks, books, musical instruments, live events
Value For Money: ❤️❤️❤️
Luxembourg prices, but not particularly outside the norm.
description: Le Bovary, referencing the eponymous Madame, is situated on the outskirts of Luxembourg but easily reachable either by a 25 stroll from the lower town or one of several buses that pass by. The concept is of a neighbourhood café bar with a homely feel, decorated in the style of a traditional lounge but with hundreds of books lining the shelves and even stairs. With music instruments and a stage downstairs, this is the venue for performances including poetry readings in keeping with its mission. You can order meals and come for a drink - reasonably priced during the week. The place is characterful even on quiet dozy mid-week afternoons but adds another dimension on busy evenings, vibrant with life. Really one of Luxembourg's standouts. (Added January 2025)

name: Café Interview
description:
EBG Rating:: 7.9
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️
A café bar range of dependable, but mainstream options.
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️
Beautiful café with wood panelling and high ceilings, decorated with retro magazine covers and pale green. Each table is lamp lit and there are some bench seats on the periphery which are the most comfortable. A 70s era mosaic floor is another artistic standout.
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
The preserved fittings and prevailing sense of institution give it a natural character quiet or busy, in any weather or time of year.
Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️
Upstairs restaurant food can be taken town to eat, newspapers, snacks, outdoor seating.
Value For Money: ❤️❤️
Typical city centre prices.
description: Interview remains while the appearance of the city centre changes around it. The terrace now affords a rather drab view of a shopping centre, but inside, you can step back into a space belonging to decades past. Classical wood panels, high ceiling and lamp light hints at a typical Viennese style cafe, but this is matched by a more 1970s aesthetic of retro magazine covers, lime green paint job, and stylish mosaic floor. The end effect, while unusual gives the place the sense of history, fixture and institution. Service is friendly, you can bring down boxes of Persian food from the upstairs restaurant, and enjoy the social scene around you. If it ever closes it will be a hammer blow to the city's cultural legacy. (Added January 2025)

name: Café-bar vis-à-vis
description:
EBG Rating:: 7.6
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
A decent range of beers and back bar - not a specialists by any mean but above the local norm.
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
An L shaped seating area with carefully curated bench niches by the windows decorated with retro signage and a rich patina of yellows and reds offers that kind of environment effectively
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Day or night, the atmosphere is social and vibrant, the sense of fixture and institution pervades and being part of that, even for a wee while elevates the experience of being in Luxembourg City's upper town.
Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️
Food, snacks, magazines, limited outdoor seating in good weather.
Value For Money: ❤️❤️❤️
Typically high city centre prices, though not out of the ordinary. 
description: When in France, Belgium or the hinterland of Germania, the prospect of a characterful corner café to set down and enjoy a decent beer in surroundings that tell a bit of history is at the forefront of our mind. Many towns and cities still have these, and this is certainly Luxembourg's closest example. An L shaped seating area with carefully curated bench niches by the windows decorated with retro signage and a rich patina of yellows and reds offers that kind of environment effectively. A decent range of beers and back bar, with bistro fare for food represents a versatility - it isn't simply a boozer. However, nor does it slide into mediocrity. The atmosphere is social and vibrant, the sense of fixture and institution pervades and being part of that, even for a wee while elevates the experience of being in Luxembourg City's upper town. (Added January 2025)

name: Konrad Café & Bar
description:
EBG Rating:: 7.5
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
A broad range of drinks including local wine and beers, the tap selection superior to most nearby. 
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Shabby chic/vintage is the mode here, and while some of it is a little familiar/twee, the range of rooms provide a variety. A ground floor cafe gives way to a warren of ground floor rooms some with original vaulted ceilings. Overall there's plenty of variety which itself provides a distinct identity that's perhaps not the case purely from the upstairs bar.
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
A popular venue with a younger crowd, you can be assured of friendly service and a balance of male and female clientele. Characterful in the basement rooms, more so on event nights.
Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Live music each week, food, snacks
Value For Money: ❤️❤️
Typical city centre prices for Luxembourg, possibly leaning towards the high side.
description: Viewing pictures online may make it difficult to get a true picture of Konrad, an eclectic space where each room is different. Shabby chic and vintage is the order of the day, and there is an element to it which veers towards the Instagram narcissism we should try and avoid, but at the same time the variety and interesting cellar space is notable and distinctive. Local beer and wines, friendly service and a weekly roster of live events add a further lacquer of appeal to coming here. There's no doubt if you are sticking to the upper town then the likes of Konrad, Interview, Tube and Vis-a-Vis will be your better choices. (Added January 2025)

name: La Jehanne
description:
EBG Rating:: 8
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Availability can vary but at its best a good range of cocktails and decent beer selection for a French tavern.
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Tasteful entirely coherent middle ages theme which blends well with the building and its natural charm. A step up from a corner into a wood beamed ground floor bar with raised area to the rear. Below a live performance space in the basement.
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
A fixture on Metz's cultural schedule, both for its basement parties and summer lounging, but a versatility means that you can just as easily find young friends and middle aged couples in the same space.
Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Live music/events, snacks, outdoor seating
Value For Money: ❤️❤️
Typical city centre prices
description: One of Metz's most distinctive bars, La Jehanne blends a historic building and interior with an appropriately Medieval theme. This is tasteful however - don't think Medieval Times - it just gives the bar a distinctive identity. With a high ceiling, step up to the entrance, and a raised area to the bar, the ground floor feels more spacious than it is. Underground there's a basement venue used for parties etc, and in spring and summer La Jehanne has possibly the best leafy courtyard for drinking in all of Metz. Drinks are variable but when they're all available expect a decent blend of cocktails and beers. An essential stop. (Added February 2025)

name: Aux Paraiges
description:
EBG Rating:: 8.3
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️
Specialising in the kind of unfashionable, but still superb beers that have dropped off the map in recent years in favour of haze and stouts. Think Belgian tripels, Weizenbock and other continental European styles from great breweries. The selection is excellent (if not perhaps absolutely top tier) and enough to keep most thoroughly well occupied. 
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
The bar itself combines the faux-Trappiste abbey décor with the ancient interior well. As you enter the knobbly uneven ceiling of what were presumably former cellars are apparent above the bar. This expands to several rooms around to the back, it is bigger than it initially looks. 
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
On Place Sant Louis, this is a busy, lively bar in the evening with a tempo partly inherited from its surroundings, but drummed up to in its warm rickety interior.
Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️
Limited outdoor seating, snacks
Value For Money: ❤️❤️❤️
Fair value for the offerings.
description: Place Sant Louis has a claim to being one of France's great nightlife spots. A row of ancient townhouses with porticos and walkways along play host to a series of bars, with seating spilling out of the bars under the arches. An atmospheric experience that needs to be witnessed if you want to understand Metz. Aux Paraiges is the best of these bars, specialising in the kind of unfashionable, but still superb beers that have dropped off the map in recent years in favour of haze and stouts. Think Belgian tripels, Weizenbock and other continental European styles from great breweries. The selection is excellent and enough to keep most occupied. The bar itself combines the faux-Trappiste abbey décor with the ancient interior well. As you enter the knobbly uneven ceiling of what were presumably former cellars are apparent above the bar. This expands to several rooms around to the back, it is bigger than it initially looks. With a casual atmosphere, it is easy to imagine most dropping by here at different points of the evening. It won't take long if you're there until you start to become a familiar face. Be aware that the bar is part of three adjoining concepts including a cocktail bar. (Added February 2025)

name: Le Troubadour
description:
EBG Rating:: 7.7
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
A fairly strong range of Belgian and French ales including some from smaller independent breweries. While beer focused, the back bar is reasonably stocked for alternatives. 
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️
Ramshackle place, a small ground floor bar decorated with a mural, and downstairs stage area. All informal verging on DIY. 
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
A friendly alternative hangout with the emphasis on unpretentious. A largely younger audience but not exclusively. 
Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Live music, community events, outdoor seating, snacks 
Value For Money: ❤️❤️❤️
Typical city centre prices with some happy hour deals. 
description: La Troubadour represents the kind of unshowy but vibrant knockabout tavern you hope to find in Northern France. A good beer selection on tap provides a superior selection to most, while a downstairs stage hosts cultural events, adding a dimension that may not be immediately apparent. A venue that doesn't quite look like pictures online, you have to really be here to see for yourself. Set on the Ile Chambiere rather than Metz city centre, it feels a little more neighbourly as a result, which also doesn't hurt. (Added February 2025)

name: Comédie Café
description:
EBG Rating:: 7.8
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️
A broad rather than deep selection covering most bases. A few interesting liqueurs and a few Belgian beers on tap the standouts.
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Beautifully fit old bar with Nouveau styling carved into the wood fittings and frames. Retro posters, mirrors and fairylights. 
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Ambience from the fairylights, interior and views of the church over the river, very pleasant indeed. A casual hangout with just a touch of style to avoid it veering completely into dive bar territory, but still pretty informal.
Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Darts, pinball, games, books, snacks
Value For Money: ❤️❤️❤️
Typical city centre prices with a good Happy Hour offering.
description: An atmospheric evening  café bar on Metz riverside with attractive views of the stunning Ile and church opposite. The bar benefits from preserved Art Nouveau wood fittings and big glass frontages to enjoy the view. Inside, you'll find that elegance tempered by what is a more fun-loving, informal operations. Here you can play darts and pinball, enjoy social events and relax - the format is down to earth rather than high society, for sure. Given the central location it feels surprisingly neighbourly and lacking the sort of patrician feel central bars can develop - all in its favour. Drinks selection is decent rather than spectacular, but happy hour prices are very handy - be careful to not knock back your 8% abv pint of Belgian beer too quickly. A versatile, likeable spot that brings to mind fun with friends as well as drifty daydreaming and people watching. (Added February 2025)

name: Henry Tudor Inn
description:
EBG Rating:: 7.7
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Joule's Brewery beers, a good reputation for being well kept. Going over a range of styles on cask and keg. A typical back bar.
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Showpiece refurbishment with a lavish, going on whimsical effort in Mock Tudor, mock being the operative word. The building itself is genuine however, and is striking on the street and side alley, genuinely like stepping back in time. Inside, its modern but inspired by Tudor with niches, bookshelves, candelabras, taxidermy all pleasant amidst wood and warm lighting. Dining area upstairs.
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
A sense of modernity to the refit is slightly jarring given the building's undoubted history, but wood and warm lighting amidst the niches make this a pleasant environment for a drink.
Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️
Food, snacks, function room, real fire
Value For Money: ❤️❤️❤️
Steady pricing given the central location, nothing out of the ordinary.
description: The only pub in Shrewsbury's in a Grade I listed building, the exterior is extraordinary and one of the landmark timber frame buildings in the city. The alleyway entrance suggests a coaching inn, but the truth is that there is little evidence this operated as a pub until the mid-Victorian era, although it did operate as a brewhouse at one point. The pub function ceased again before a large expansive 90s restoration, since added to by Joule's Brewery. The interior therefore is very much Mock Tudor, a creative simulacra of themes, verging towards whimsical but using the natural structure of the building in a complimentary way. Plenty of niches and a nice bar area under those chunky beams presents a nice place to go for a drink. 

The building's main claim to fame is that Henry Tudor stated here en route to Bosworth field.

(Added February 2025)

name: The Admiral Benbow
description:
EBG Rating:: 8.3
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️
A clearly superior range of drinks for the town. 5 farmhouse ciders and good keg beers including some from independent breweries, a strong (for England) selection of Belgian beers in the fridge. Several real ales.
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
A pleasant loungey interior, open plan with bar opposite the entrance. Local's corner to the left and candlelit bench seating to the right. Further room and patio to the rear. Carpeted and cosy with candlelit tables. Beer ephemera on the walls alongside more traditional pub features.
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Welcoming, cosy and convivial, a good impression from the outset. Somewhere with its regulars while still feeling open to occasional visitors. 
Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
TV, snacks, outdoor seating, live music, occasional events, pub games, real life.
Value For Money: ❤️❤️❤️
Although not cheap, it's decent value for the quality of options.
description: A terrific backstreet pub set in a tall building with grand frontage, named after a famous seafarer, whose name adorns a far more well-known Penzance pub. Here, the appeal of this Benbow is more subtle, a combination of wise choices that combine to an impressive whole. With excellent drinks options as a starting point, you can be enjoying traditional ales and farmhouse ciders, UK craft from the likes of Burning Sky or the fridge full of Belgian beers, this would turn many heads all of itself. However, the attention paid to the environment inside and the sense of welcome and comfort plays an equally important role. Candlelit tables, fireplace and carpet gives it a cosy feel, somewhere you'd want to stay for a long time (not easy on Sunday when it closes at 7pm). Pub games, occasional live music and events and patio in summer make this an all-rounder you can keep on coming back to any time of year. For us, it's central Shrewsbury's finest pub. (Added February 2025)

name: The Cross Foxes
description:
EBG Rating:: 7.6
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Bass in prime condition and the regional classic Three Tuns are the cask highlights, which do qualify as genuine highlights anywhere. Otherwise unexciting mainstream keg beer and back bar options. The throwback M&B mild is available on keg, a Midlands staple.
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Compact pub with L-shaped room, fireplace opposite the bar. Warmly lit with crimson painted fittings. Sports trophies and fox themed nik naks.
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️
Homely, warm and cosy, but a slight feeling of intrusion on our visit suggested a certain cliqueyness, while the unsolicited opinions of the guy at the bar regarding government control, wanting to monitor our habits (while staring directly at his CCTV camera) and stuffing cash into mattresses was a little cranky too. If you can navigate that, not impossible, it's a very pleasant place to sit for a drink.
Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️
Darts, games machine, fireplace, snacks
Value For Money: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Decent value overall.
description: Family-run freehouse set in Coleham, on the periphery of the city centre, but with a very local feel. Not a pub where the tourist crowd in Wyle Cop would naturally gravitate too. The pub is a bit of a throwback, in a good way, with a drinking and social focus, warm and comfortable interior, décor taking more than a dollop of inspiration from the pub name. A fireplace in the centre of the room adds to the feeling of homely comfort. Bass on cask, and among the finest we've tasted in years, alongside regional classics like Three Tuns makes this a very appealing option. The only drawback on our view was staff who, while friendly, held world views veering towards cranky (government control, keep cash stuffed in mattresses etc), meaning you may have some conversational obstacles to navigate. You were warned. (Added February 2025)

name: Loggerheads
description:
EBG Rating:: 7.5
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️
Marston's drink range which means traditional real ales, but of a mainstream nature. Limited back bar options.
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
A multi-room pub with tiny bar, snug with high backed settles and fireplace, rear room and lounge, each of which has its own particular feel.
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Peak time to visit is on the locally famous live music evenings. At other times a local 'market town tavern' type feel with local gossip and banter. The bar area can feel like somewhat of an intrusion at times.
Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Live music, outdoor seating, snacks, TV
Value For Money: ❤️❤️
Typical city centre prices + the usual Marston's pubco percentage on top.
description: Loggerheads' peculiar name refers to the arms of Shrewsbury's crest and dates back an impressively long way, to the 18th century, a boom period in the city's history. A multi-room pub with tiny bar, snug with high backed settles and fireplace, rear room and lounge, each of which has its own particular feel. The bar room is very local, and there may be a slight sense of intrusion at busier times. The décor has not faithfully kept to the sense of history, only present in bits and pieces, so rather than being a showstopper Loggerheads is more of a curio. Part of the issue here is the Marston's ownership, a drag factor on a pub that's still good, but has considerable potential. To experience the pub at peak time visit on live music nights where the atmosphere is worth savouring. (Added February 2025)

name: The Nag’s Head
description:
EBG Rating:: 7.6
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
4-5 cask ales from regional and national breweries and decent back bar. 
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
A characterful bar area with a social layout, compact while not feeling cramped. Traditional furnishings while the decoration is an eclectic mixture of different things. Spacious beer garden with standout lean-to set within 14th century timber remains of an old hall. It's surprising a naked flame is allowed anywhere near them, but there you go.
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Market town type trade during the day, busy and chatty, while peak times can verge on over-touristy, particularly if the Ghost trail crew are in town.
Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️
Snacks, TV, outdoor seating
Value For Money: ❤️❤️❤️
Typical prices for the city centre.
description: The Henry Tudor Inn over the road can claim to have hosted its eponymous monarch en route to Bosworth field, but the Nag's Head is not far behind with its own historical boast. The timbers from a 14th century house remain standing by the main building as you enter via the beer garden. This was left behind when the building was destroyed in the 1950s. It has been used for the filming of works such as Great Expectations. Inside, the pub also boasts a cursed painting in a private room off-limits to the public, said to be of the devil, a room where three people have committed suicide-  making the pub a popular destination for ghost hunters. Despite all the extraneous rubbish, the pub still boasts a lovely bar area, dog friendly with a social layout, where you can enjoy one or more of the several real ales they offer on cask. the beer garden is also very spacious for a city centre pub and feels almost like an oasis. There's room for improvement (let's face it, there usually is), but this is a clear guide entrant in its current state. (Added February 2025)

name: The Craven Arms
description:
EBG Rating:: 8
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Black Country Ales on cask with some guests. Modern craft keg ales available too and some ciders. Decent but more ordinary back bar offering.
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Frontage of blue glazed tiles is a standout, even when approaching on a grey winters day. Grade II listed, a pub with Victorian heritage that has received a tasteful, suitable decoration inside. A small pub with floral patterned wallpaper, a fireplace to the rear and row of bench seats, there's an immediately positive impression as you enter.
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Cosy and social. While a small pub there remains a sense of space and privacy in some corners and an overall coherent whole. 
Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️
Snacks, TV, occasional events
Value For Money: ❤️❤️❤️
Fairly priced, not cheap but in line with the typical pricing for this part of the city. 
description: A successful 2022 restoration by Black Country Ales has brought this corner boozer back to life. Formerly a Holden's pub, the frontage of blue glazed tiles is a standout, even when approaching on a grey winters day. Grade II listed, a pub with Victorian heritage that has received a tasteful, suitable decoration inside. A small pub with floral patterned wallpaper, a fireplace to the rear and row of bench seats, there's an immediately positive impression as you enter. Black Country Ales on cask are supplemented with a pretty good selection of modern keg ales and some decent cider. Typical for this brewery, you can buy cobs, rolls, and pies til they're gone. A pub that manages to draw in a varied crowd without any activity dominating or spoiling it. It is certainly among Birmingham's best. (Added February 2025)

name: The Bull
description:
EBG Rating:: 8.5
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
High quality regular ales with ever changing guests. Cider options are ok while the back bar and keg options are less impressive but adequate.
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️
A showstopper, beautifully curated and maintained comfortably backstreet boozer with upholstered bench seats across two cosy rooms, decorated with hundreds of earthenware mugs and other trinkets like thimbles in large cabinets. 
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️
As such a comfortable and pleasant place to spend time, it can be so quiet it's just you, staff and the cat and still be richly enjoyable. Comes into its own when busier.
Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Food (Apart from Monday + Sunday), snacks, outdoor seating, newspapers, community events
Value For Money: ❤️❤️❤️
Normal prices for this part of Birmingham and for the products on offer.
description: Comfortably one of Birmingham's finest pubs, and the emphasis is on comfort here. The kind of warmly lit backstreet loungey boozer you'd expect to find out in the Black Country, instead situated in Birmingham's old Gun Quarter. These days there's a motorway flyover and high rise towering above it. The light from the pub glows with welcome as you approach in the evening time. The interior decoration is impressive - a neat, but busy assortment of earthenware mugs on the ceiling, cabinets of thimbles on the walls. The personal feel extends to the service and the pub's cat. Both lounge and bar area are comfortably appointed with furniture that's reassuringly sturdy and chunky. The kind you can sink in to for a whole evening. Drinks are traditional but high quality with real ales from the region, decent cider and keg. Although on the periphery of the city centre, given the paucity of good options for pubs of this kind, it's an essential walk. (Added February 2025)

name: The Blackman Bar
description:
EBG Rating:: 8.2
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️
A very familiar feel to the Irish stouts, macro lagers and back bar offerings.
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Multi-room roadside pub with plenty of space, but appointed in such a way to emphasise cosiness, with cushioned booth seating, warm lighting and traditional decorations.
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️
Somewhat of a waypoint between city and countryside, and the atmosphere feels like that, in touch with the gossip from both. The cosy, warm interior is seductive enough that it's a true wrench to leave.
Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Food, snacks, outdoor seating, fireplace, TV
Value For Money: ❤️❤️❤️
Reasonable value for money in line with the location and offerings.
description: Family-run for 50 years, the news in 2024 that the property was going up for sale caused whatever the Cork equivalent of shockwaves to ripple through local media. A fringe of town roadside pub of a kind you infrequently see these days. The focus remains very much on its social and community bonds, a place to unwind, not simply a dining destination. A comfortable, cosy warm interior across a series of rooms provides an environment that is a wrench to leave. Everything is well appointed, not shabby, but still largely in a traditional, homely style. Although it may look a way out from a glance at a map, bus connections to the North of town up to Dublin Pike are reliable and frequent enough, taking only 10 minutes or so to reach a nearby stop. Even bearing in mind the dozen plus great pubs in central Cork, there's no excuse not to give it a try. Apart from if it closes, of course.  (Added February 2025)

name: Bierhaus
description:
EBG Rating:: 7.6
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️
The strongest beer selection in the region, even with good competition from Abbot's nearby.  30 taps, sometimes a cask line, (virtually impossible to find in Ireland most of the time) covering local beers to cutting edge craft to classics. A very decent whisky selection at the back bar too.
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️
A very late 00s type US-craft influenced decor. Grey paint, a long bar and brewery signage, which at least brightens it a little. Ungrey the damn thing, please. 
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
A beer specialist bar, but one that can see a more mainstream crowd. Beer specialists tend to pop up on lists of where to go, so the next batch of people on the plane often find themselves here, giving it an international flavour.
Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️
Snacks, Merchandise, Live Events
Value For Money: ❤️❤️❤️
Honestly, pretty good for what's on offer and a tad better value than the local competition. Less good value for the merchandise.
description: Set up in 2006, this particular US-inspired beer specialists looks every inch of its era. A long bar with grey walls festooned with brewery signage (hey, at least the signage adds some colour and identity). While the interior could be improved upon, the selection of drinks is phenomenal for Ireland, and would stand out in most European cities too. Local beers from smaller independent breweries compete for tap space alongside latest craft brands and European classics. The bottle selection is mighty too. A head turning selection of whiskies is enough to make you second guess your selection. Adding much needed depth and variety, Bierhaus has become a firm fixture on Cork's circuit. We can recommend going, but we can also recommend a sympathetic refit of warm colours and nicer furnishings - the potential is there for an even better environment. (Added February 2025)

name: Maureen's
description:
EBG Rating:: 8.6
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
5 keg lines from 9 White Deer brewery and visibly no Guinness, Murphy's or Beamish. A compact selection of wines and gins advertised.
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
A former working class boozer turned into a plush, but still distinctly pubby one-room bar. Cushioned bench seating around the three walls with curved bar to the right of the entrance with interesting panelling and effect. Stools at the bar. Bell for entry.
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
A close, personal touch here, with greeting on entry and a clandestine feel from that gatekeeping. Once inside, the warmth and twinkle of lights make it cosy and atmospheric, with a friendly, unthreatening feel that will appeal to a broader audience than the typical pub men.
Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Books, snacks, live music, community and cultural events. Private hire available on closed dates.
Value For Money: ❤️❤️❤️
Typical city centre prices without standing out either way.
description: Formerly Pat Buckley's place, known locally 'Ms. Pat's', a fairly dramatic change has taken place at this venue, changing it from a rough and ready working class pub to a bar with a personal feel and a distinctly feminine touch. There's no doubt this has alienated many of its former patrons, and we aren't here to discuss which one was better or worse, but to tell you about the merits of the current operation known as Maureen's. With a bell for entry, this is a place that wants to keep big groups and loud drunks out. As you enter, you're in an old pub lovingly refit with its cushioned bench seats around the walls and a small curved bar to the right. Service is careful, welcoming and personal, all about providing an intimate, special feel. Maureen's doesn't hold back in its willingness to divert from the norm, as you'll find no Guinness, Murphy's or Beamish here. Instead, the beers of 9 White Deer, a local brewery are available on tap, alongside wines and gins offered. Among the comfortable seating, twinkle of fairy lights and murmur of conversation, this is a truly atmospheric place and a little hideaway for anyone who wants to lower the tempo and volume a tad. They've executed it so well it really deserves to be mentioned alongside Cork's best. (Added February 2025)

name: The Abbot's Ale House
description:
EBG Rating:: 8.7
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️
Well respected for its enormous bottle selection, with ten rotating taps including beers from smaller and/or independent craft beer breweries in Ireland. If you're looking to shop local, here's the place to do it.
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️
Interior of nik-naks and antiques. Bar straight in front as you enter with cushioned seats opposite. Enter a long room with chunky tables towards the end. 
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️
Tremendously characterful and lively during the evenings, often accentuated by live music and friendly get togethers from different social scenes, so basically not your average chin-strokey craft beer bar.
Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Live music, board games, occasional antique fayres, shop, snacks
Value For Money: ❤️❤️
On the higher side even adjusting for the specialist beers available. 
description: Aiming to be both a beer specialists and bonafide traditional pub. Though established in 2008, careful curation of antiques and nik-naks along with choice of furnishings gives the place a hard to place feel in time. Well respected for its enormous bottle selection, with ten rotating taps including beers from smaller and/or independent craft beer breweries in Ireland. If you're looking to shop local, here's the place to do it. Service can be occasionally gruff by Irish standards but it's functional, while the pub itself plays host to occasional antiques fayres, more frequent music nights, and board game get togethers, making it feel as important a social hub as any other pub in the city, which is to its great credit. Other than some steep pricing and occasional need for heating at times on colder days, everything else about the bar is pretty damn fantastic. (Added February 2025)

name: Sin é
description:
EBG Rating:: 8.8
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
The typical Irish stout standards, plus a range improved by Rising Sons beers on tap (usually 5). A compact but serviceable backbar of whiskies and gins.
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️
A ground floor decorated with its memories and history in a deliberately dense, cluttered way. On entry there are two small niches in the corners and a small alley leading to a backroom, with more niches. All pretty small at this point. Upstairs leads to a room not previously part of the pub which is decorated with a lighter touch, airier although still with plenty of interest to absorb.
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️
No doubt this is a tremendously characterful place, one you can while away hours on quiet afternoons or get stuck in to on mesmeric noisy folk evenings. A place with its regulars, its characters and people who have a sense of possession to it. Keep a due respect to dealings and everything will go fine.
Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️
You can take cold food into eat. Live music, snacks
Value For Money: ❤️❤️
To be diplomatic, city centre prices. A Beamish 10 minutes walk up the road can be obtained for 1 euro 50 less, put it that way. 
description: Meaning "That's it", in reference to next door's funeral parlour, Sin é, dating from 1889 is among Cork's institutions. Their connection with Irish folk and the live music scene in the city has survived the sways of trends and fashion, remaining a firm fixture 7 nights a week. To visit on a busy music night is to experience a concentrated shot of culture, that comes as naturally to the musicians and loyal patrons as extending your arm, but will definitely make an impact as an outsider. It's important to also state that it's just as much a social meeting place, and outside of performances Sin é functions as a pub well, more than capable. Owned by the Rising Sons Brewery who have established the 'Cork Heritage Pubs' tour, you'll find some beers not normally seen on the taps at Irish pubs, with the usual classics too. The interior is a bunker decorated from head to toe in its decades of memories. Sitting down even on a quiet lunchtime is to become immersed in the pub and its role in the city, making it truly special. Sin é has two floors, and the first floor is quite different. Still characterful but lighter and almost like being in a different place. It had been used as a barbers.
