Fame and history mean this one has a bigger reputation and more sought after - something its pricing seems to have noted too. However, even in summer months that doesn't reach the level you generally find at Dublin's institutions. A bonafide classic. (Added February 2025)

name: The Corner House
description:
EBG Rating:: 7.6
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
A long bar with a pleasing wealth of options beyond the typical Irish classics including some European beers and a few Irish craft too from independent brewers. The fridge selection is decent enough, so while it isn't Abbot's or Bierhaus, we would say for a venue of its type, they've been paying attention. Whisky selection also pretty strong.
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Colourful mosaic frontage that is very attractive. An open plan venue, with seating and fireplace to the front opposite a long bar to the left that leads to a performance area to the rear. 
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Although many of the Irish pub raw materials are in place, something about the open plan nature of the place means it loses the intimacy of other pubs. This is a deliberate choice though and you're in what is very much a performance venue. Lively and you'll still find a cast of regulars at their posts to the left as you enter.
Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Live music, fireplace, snacks, crosswords (they photocopy crosswords for customers to idle away the time with)
Value For Money: ❤️❤️❤️
City centre rates
description: In a building dating from 1853, the most recent major changes in décor and ownership occurred around the mid-90s, and the pub since has taken on a 'performance venue' format, a hybrid of pub and place to see live music and other cultural events. As a result, despite many typical pub trappings (including photocopying crosswords for punters!) the Corner House feels a little less like a place to sit down for a quiet pint, and a lot more like where to drag a few friends to have a laugh and listen to some performers. Fun and gregarious, a place that doesn't take itself too seriously. Although perhaps not hitting the same heights as nearby, this adds a diversity and versatility to Cork's nightlife and remains still well worth recommending. (Added February 2025)

name: Dan Lowrey's Tavern
description:
EBG Rating:: 8.8
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️
2 Franciscan Well beers on tap plus a decent whisky selection are the standouts in an otherwise mainstream selection.
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️
A one room pub with a space to the rear with a fireplace. Dan Lowrey's pub is something of a work of art with its wood panel fittings, stained glass windows (rumoured to be from Kilkenny Cathedral) and ornate bar cabinet, but these finer elements are twinned with a lounge level comfort - bench seats and warmth.
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️
An instantly inviting warmth and sense of history, this pub is itself a character with its particular identity. Friendly service and communal lounge seating gives it an easy conviviality.
Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Toasties, snacks, TV, occasional events
Value For Money: ❤️❤️❤️
Typical central rates.
description: When we're explaining what makes a good pub sometimes it's tempting to sum up as: "it's just got it." Dan Lowrey's pub is something of a work of art with its wood panel fittings, stained glass windows (rumoured to be from Kilkenny Cathedral) and ornate bar cabinet, but these finer elements are twinned with a lounge level comfort, meaning that even for a pub on a busy street, you feel like you're cosy and cosseted in a backstreet boozer. A one room pub with a space to the rear with a fireplace, you can't really go wrong with where to sit, apart from perhaps a couple of favourite regular's perches at the bar. Service is friendly and we were impressed to be offered "the usual" even on a second visit. Dan Lowrey's offers some classics twinned with a few modern options from local Francisan Well brewery. Whiskies are also pretty good here, and they make a point of offering hot whiskies. If you want something to eat, the toaster is standing by. A TV for sport and soundtrack manage to not be too intrusive. As you sink back in your seat you can soak up the experience of being a pub you'd happily return to forever. (Added February 2025)

name: Dennehy's Bar
description:
EBG Rating:: 8.2
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️
A very traditional range of stouts and lagers - unfortunately. Limited whisky selection by local standards.
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
A beautiful frontage with some stained and tinted glass insets leads to a traditional unspoilt bar, the walls wood-strip in green and cream colour, decorated with local heritage. Simple and curated well, the bar is a little time capsule. Back room slightly more modern but a fireplace, chunky furniture and exposed walls still does the trick.
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️
A hugely characterful place that genuinely conveys its identity and heritage, for now in an authentic feeling, non-hokey, non-touristy way. Later in the evening you can experience a real mix of different sorts of people coming and out which makes the place feel even more of a fixture.
Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️
Snacks, merchandise, pizza can be delivered from Rising Sons Brewery a short walk away.
Value For Money: ❤️❤️❤️
Fair prices for the centre, though nothing too notable either way.
description: Although other publicans have tried to corral their own bars as exclusively 'Cork heritage', Dennehy's shows it goes further than a marketing campaign. Opened in 1957 and still family-run today by Mary Dennehy and her sons, you'll find one of the few original Cork pubs here. The central location has endowed it with many stories over the years, for example the colourful life of local legend Katty Barry, who is immortalised in a frame by the bar, along with other similar eccentrics. With a simple frontage leading to a small traditional bar, whose layout would not be seen today. The expansion to the rear sees Dennehy's switch to a tasteful blend of old and new - exposed brick, warm lighting and chunky tables. As a pub that has gathered a personality and a reputation, the sense of identity is palpable as you walk in. A real mixture of people come through the door due to its central location which can lead to some interesting encounters for all involved. (Added February 2025)

name: Mutton Lane Inn
description:
EBG Rating:: 7.9
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
A superior selection of drinks, with the usual Irish standards bolstered by 5 keg ales from Rising Sons brewery, a cocktail menu, decent gins and whiskies.
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Characterful alleyway entrance with large mural leading into a rickety old tavern with a tiled floor, which at first may remind you of somewhere like Whitelock's, Leeds. A snug to the left is prime spot (with bar access), while to the right you'll find a redecorated lounge with wooden floor, candlelit tables more resembling a cocktail bar. Moroccan lanterns at the bar is also unusual, but quite effective. 
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
The low lighting is a feature even at opening time early on, giving this pub an escapist feel. However, the passing trade and gossip of the city can break the spell. The best time to go really is later on as a buzz develops and all the moody lighting comes into its own. Dog friendly, background music generally at a sensible volume.
Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️
Outdoor seating, snacks. 
Value For Money: ❤️❤️
City centre rates.
description: Adjacent to the English market, Mutton Lane was the sheep run back in the day. Nowadays, the setting for an alleyway pub, one of those that feels nicely tucked away. In the centre of everything yet pocketed neatly. If you were walking briskly and not minding where you were, you'd easily walk past. To catch people's eyes, a huge mural has been commissioned opposite the pub, with tables spilling onto the street giving it that vibrant look. Inside, it's a tarted up old institution, at once familiar and pubby feeling, while also glamourised and refubished to an extent. All looks traditional at the bar as you enter, save for some more modern beer options from Rising Sons brewery (this is another Cork Heritage Pubs trail venue), but as you look around, the lounge to the right appears more like a candlelit cocktail bar, while the Moroccan lanterns the other side of the partition are distinctly not part of your average Irish pub ensemble. It is in this middle ground between chintzy contemporary décor and traditional fittings that Mutton Lane wishes to reside. The central location gives daytime trade a gossipy feel, but the low lighting everywhere has a sense of escapism all of its own. This works best later on in the day as day slides into evening into late night. You'll need to pay a visit here while in Cork. (Added February 2025)

name: The Hi-B Bar
description:
EBG Rating:: 8.7
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️
A classic familiar range of Irish stout and lagers, the whisky selection being perhaps a little more enticing. 
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️
Situated on the first floor of a grand old building on Plunkett Street, The Hi-B mosaic and grand old hallway is interest in itself, a relic of a different era, the 1920s, which shows in the rich red paint and the flair applied in its execution. The bar room itself is loungey, with low slung seating and a fireplace in the corner, other homely decorations and a fairly long sleek bar top you can sit around. 
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️
Highly social. One of the main points of Hi-B to note is the need to get stuck in to the chat in this pub. Once you pass the threshold don't expect to be pawing at the pages of a book quietly in a corner. People will ask after you, get a conversation going and expect a bit of engagement in return. If you're a shrinking violet this may not be for you. Also known for impromptu singalongs.
Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️
Fireplace, snacks
Value For Money: ❤️❤️
City centre prices which are not unfamiliar to many venues close by, although still unyielding.
description: Although we are in a new era, The Hi-B remains known even in recent memory for its idiosyncratic former owner Brian O'Donnell, who applies his strictly "no phones, no pint, no please" policy (which is still plastered on the walls today, but not quite as rigorously enforced), and had a reputation for refusing service if he didn't like the cut of your gib, or if a particular phrase caught his ire. The pub became infamous, though also beloved by its adherents, regularly making the list of best bars in Cork. Upon re-opening after Covid, the Hi-B has carried over some of the best aspects of that - its quirkyness and social focus - with a slightly more laid back hospitality and a few modern perks (card payment? stone the crows).

It's a very informal place - don't stand on ceremony if you're here. Get to the bar and tell the bartender what you want. 

Situated on the first floor of a grand old building, The Hi-B mosaic and grand old hallway is interest in itself, a relic of a different era, the 1920s, which shows in the rich red paint and the flair applied in its execution. The bar room itself is loungey, with low slung seating and a fireplace in the corner, other homely decorations and a fairly long sleek bar top you can sit around. 

One of the main points of Hi-B to note is the need to get stuck in to the chat in this pub. Once you pass the threshold don't expect to be pawing at the pages of a book quietly in a corner. People will ask after you, get a conversation going and expect a bit of engagement in return. If you're a shrinking violet this may not be for you.

A combination of its heritage flair, idiosyncratic setup and bloodymindness makes it one of Cork's absolute must visit pubs. 

(Added February 2025)

name: The Welcome Inn
description:
EBG Rating:: 8.5
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️
Familiar beer selection, the highlight being the back bar selection of whiskies.
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️
A wonderful little bar room. Smaller than anticipated from the huge Murphy's hoarding out from. Limited seating in the corners with a compact bar area. Standing room in the centre, with a few perches (often occupied by the regulars) either side of the bar. Decorated with the city's heritage. Fireplace in the middle of the wall, TV in the corner.
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️
The rhythms of Cork's social scene can be marked by Welcome Inn's early opening, making it a staple option for a morning drink. Some colourful characters can be found, and occasionally you may need your wits about you. However, in large part, the atmosphere is warm, welcoming (you'd hope so given the name), jovial and with a bonhomie you find in these rare places where most of the customers are standing rather than seated. Add to that the live music performances and you're onto a sure thing, trust us.
Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Live music, fireplace, snacks limited outdoor seating, TV
Value For Money: ❤️❤️❤️
Close to the going rate for the centre but some decent deals to be found.
description: One of the remaining "earlies", in the 1970s Cork boasted 33 public houses that opened up at 7am onwards, usually supplying drink to dockworkers. These days, the opening time here remains 7am. Morning drinking has taken on a lurid, almost taboo reputation in modern times, but the rhythms of a city have to include all who dwell within in it. The Welcome Inn are proud of their hours and are not shy of acknowledging that as a result, they host a few colourful characters. It would be a disservice to define the pub only around this aspect, but it's important to know of it before visiting. The Welcome Inn has a classic "drop in" feel. As soon as you walk through the doors you feel at the heart of everything. The fire is crackling, the telly is on, the regulars in front of you are quipping, and a host of customers are gathered, standing around the bar. As you look around, the sight of Cork's heritage is pinned to the walls of the bar. It's a vibrant sight and gladdens our hearts to see a true mixture of people from different ages and class enjoying the place. Live music performances are regularly hosted, a small corner seating area transformed into a stage. While this is the city centre, so don't expect miracles, there are some decent value drinks to be found here. Although the beer selection is familiar and firmly traditional, there are some decent whiskies to be spied., including some rarities and antiques, they say. Despite some exceptionally strong competition in the city, the Welcome Inn still qualifies as a true standout. Don't be shy on your visit, get involved and you'll find you get the most out of it. (Added February 2025)

name: The Castle Inn
description:
EBG Rating:: 8.7
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️
Tried and trusted standards, not bothered by much fancy on tap or in bottle.
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️
A superb old-school layout of a kind that isn't made any more, and probably wasn't 50 years ago either. Simple drop in boozer with typical wood panelled walls painted cream and crimson, a snug to the left of the entrance and a corridor with a simple bench to perch with your pint. The long room extends to a wider area and a rear lounge with open fireplace, which really feels like an overflow in comparison to the buzz at the bar.
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️
Truly feels like dialling into the Cork social scene, with all the gossip and goings on. Informal, but with a healthy respect for the family that runs the place.
Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Snacks, snuff, occasional live events, TV, fireplace
Value For Money: ❤️❤️❤️
Reasonable for the city centre.
description: Three generations of the same family have run The Castle since the 1930s, the pub itself operating since the 1870s. It won't surprise you to learn then that this is a kind of old-school establishment. It's important to not let all discussions of traditional pubs fall into the same bracket though, for this is not a traditional pub in the way Sin é is, or the way the Abbey is, or in the way the Hi-B is. Each of them have their own take on the notion. Different spaces and formats. The Castle Inn is super basic and simple, a drop in bar area to perch on a bench, sip your pint and shoot the breeze. They like to think of it as a country pub in the city. You can kind of see why. The owner's parents (and...employees?) Denis and Mary live above the bar, and are often seen working behind it. With open fires, a snug, sport on TV (But not ostentatiously), this is one pub perhaps above all else where you can really feel dialled in to the events of the city. They also appear to still sell snuff. That's the flavour of this place. An unmissable pub in Cork. (Added February 2025)

name: Arthur Mayne's Pharmacy
description:
EBG Rating:: 8.3
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️
Wine sampler, cocktails, port, and a few beers and gins thrown in too. It's unlikely you'll go missing for a good drink here.
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️
A well curated concept, low lit wine bar downstairs with old pharmacy cabinets and niches, aged wood and crackling plaster, leading out to a courtyard/street shared by different bars. 
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️
Undoubtedly an atmospheric space, indoors in winter and more so in warmer months as the areas bleed into one and there's a relaxed, almost Mediterranean feel as you wander around.
Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️
Food with late kitchen (til 1.30), wine sampler, snacks, outdoor seating
Value For Money: ❤️❤️
Typical city centre pricing.
description: A chemists converted into a bar, Arthur Mayne's is the kind of bar Cork needed, added variety and a modern touch, all the while tastefully and in a historic building. Late opening, with wine on the ground floor, cocktails upstairs and a rear exit onto Crane Lane, it very much feels like its own ecosystem, therefore something a bit special. Versatile with wide opening hours, it'll often be the on the tip of your tongue as you're asked "where next?" (Added February 2025)

name: The Oval
description:
EBG Rating:: 8.8
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Rising Sons beers are a genuine compliment to the typical Irish classics. Reasonable whisky selection. 
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️
A clearly elderly exterior, mossy whitewash, red & gold signage above the door, but a stylish Deco influenced hoarding at the back of the building. Inside, an original 1916 refit has been kept intact. Oval shaped bar with snug to the left, stools and chairs around the perimeter, and warren of niches into a firelit room at the back. Unique, highly distinctive and stylish.
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️
An incredibly characterful pub. The style of the interior is completely in keeping with the decorations, while candlelight sets a mood even during the afternoons. Busy weekend trade makes this feel like a significant place, but one where when you set foot through the door you leave the outside world behind.
Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️
Fireplace, snacks, limited outdoor seating
Value For Money: ❤️❤️
City centre prices, and on the slightly higher end.
description: A 200+ year old building, reconstructed in 1918 by Beamish & Crawford, The Oval is Cork's most lavishly designed pub. An oval ceiling as you look up from the entrance seems to inform the bar, seating and rooms that peel off around it. Both elegant and distinctive, with a sense of age to it. On entry, candlelight even during the day gives it a moody feel. Particularly at the back towards the fire you could easily allow hours to pass as you get comfortable in one of the niches. The place is very lively on Fridays and weekends though, events posters and an alternative music soundtrack pointing to this not just being a fusty old museum but a relevant venue, something underpinned by its range of Rising Sons Brewery beers. On the suspiciously incomplete Cork Heritage Pubs trail, all of which are owned by the same operation, but this is a business that allows each venue to speak for itself, much to their credit. It's an absolute must-see, but pick your moment carefully to be assured of a seat. (Added February 2025)

name: An Spailpín Fánach
description:
EBG Rating:: 8.1
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
With some surprise keg options from the likes of Kinnegar, this offers a notch above the typical Irish classics. A predictable but solid back bar.
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
A fairly large feeling pub of old wood. Spacious to the rear. Bar room and snug to the right and lounge, if you can call it that (it's still pretty rickety) to the left. Downstairs is a performance area.
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️
With a firelit snug, characterful rickety interior, regular performance nights, this is a venue that is showing its age in a characterful way, one that can become gregarious at its peak.
Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Live music, snacks, community events.
Value For Money: ❤️❤️❤️
Reasonable, close to the going rate for the centre.
description: "The Migrant Worker" was founded back in 1779, and although its rickety interior sure looks like it's seen plenty of action, the appearance belongs, to our eyes somewhere closer to the 60s or 70s. A two-room pub on the ground floor with performance area to the rear, making it one of Cork's slightly larger feeling pubs, a feeling emphasised by its simple wooden furnishings. Round the side of the bar is a beautiful firelit snug, while you'll find some curious in the 'lounge' to your left as well. The typical Irish beer range is assisted by a small helping of keg craft from the likes of Kinnegar, which is nice to see in a pub like this. Their reason for being is the live music and cultural events they put on downstairs, which sometimes spill upstairs, making it a pub that at its peak becomes lively, very cheerful and gregarious. (Added February 2025)

name: Callanan's Bar
description:
EBG Rating:: 8.7
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
A purposefully no-nonsense tap range with some surprise Belgian bottles and Irish craft appearing behind the bar. They don't serve Guinness, only Cork stout.
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️
A compact little boozer with an unreconstructed exterior and interior, typical of old Irish boozers. The signage will be familiar to those who lived through the 1960s, though the building itself was built in 1760.

You'll find a snug to the right of the entrance, and a narrow pub fitted in wood-panelling painted cream and red gloss. Curtains shield the view from the outside, giving it a nice clandestine feel inside.
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️
A late bar, its sole purpose, and a fine purpose it is too - is to turn up for a drink and a chat. No TV or loud music, but the atmosphere in the pub more than makes up for that, a pub with the knack of feeling like you're part of a special occasion even when it's just another night, which is one of the better compliments you can pay a pub.
Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️
Snug, snacks, occasional live music.
Value For Money: ❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️
Atypical pricing, with Beamish sold for at least a Euro less than many pubs in the nearby vicinity. There are a few other holdouts elsewhere in the city that maintain this abnormally low pricing, but this is one of the few that are genuinely great pubs too.
description: Callanan's opening hours are an obstacle course and have disappointed a fair few people who failed to do their research in advance. Therefore you have been warned.

A late bar, its sole purpose, and a fine purpose it is too - is to turn up for a drink and a chat. No TV or loud music, but the atmosphere in the pub more than makes up for that.

A compact little boozer with an unreconstructed exterior and interior, typical of old Irish boozers. The signage will be familiar to those who lived through the 1960s, though the building itself was built in 1760. 

You'll find a snug to the right of the entrance, and a narrow pub fitted in wood-panelling painted cream and red gloss. Curtains shield the view from the outside, giving it a nice clandestine feel inside.

The atmosphere has the odd knack of feeling like its a special occasion even when it's just another night, which is one of the better compliments you can pay a pub. Reputedly owned by the same family since 1935, there's a sense of continuity as you sit (or stand) among a crowd spanning the generations.

Known for its uncanny pricing too, with Beamish weighing in at a fraction of the cost of most pubs only 5 minutes walk away. They aren't shy of shouting about it either, and fair play to them.

A sensitive renovation project is ongoing to help Callanan's persevere into the future. 

Across Ireland you'll see many pubs with similar frontage to this which are nearly gone or long gone, but this place provides a blueprint for how to carry the best of the old into the modern day.

(Added February 2025)

name: The Abbey Tavern
description:
EBG Rating:: 7.8
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
A broad selection covering beer, whiskies and gin particularly well. Some local beers to look out for on the taps. The wine list is decent for a pub.
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
With bar room, lounge and back room, warmly lit with twinkly lights. Decorated with music posters (smart rather than scuzzy). Brick tile floor in the bar room, booth seating with studded leather upholstery. More of a classic set up than the nooks and crannies other write-ups suggest, but there are some characterful corners, for sure.
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Popular pub between the college and city centre with a mixture of youngsters and a family sensibility too. Not on the tourist circuit as much, making this one a place to mingle with locals. Perhaps more of a middle class end of pub than the likes of Welcome Inn or The Castle, not that there's anything wrong with that, and it can still get fairly lively with groups of youngsters turning up to knock bar jars of stout.
Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️
Fireplace, snacks, live music, pizza can be ordered in from another business. 
Value For Money: ❤️❤️
Typical central prices.
description: A little walk out of the very centre, the Abbey is adjacent to Saint Fin Barre's cathedral, in between city and college. This informs its audience, a mixture of students and post-grads with middle class families. A smart, but charming interior that's well curated with candles and fairylights, straddling interest in music and sport each to cater for the wide age range but none impinging on each other. The drinks are superior to average here with some beer from local breweries and whiskies, wines and gin that go beyond the stock selections that you'll fine in most other places. The atmosphere gets pretty bustling when busy, not quite doing justice to its moodier lighting which would suggest a more contemplative venue to enjoy a quieter drink. Nevertheless, it's a fine pub we can comfortably recommend trying. (Added February 2025)

name: Fionnbarra
description:
EBG Rating:: 7.5
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️
One of Cork's go to pubs for a strong selection of beers from independent brewers including Irish brewers. Though not on Bierhaus or Abbotts level, that is no criticism. A versatile range of other options, particularly whiskies, gins and wines. Most people will be satisfied here, and most of them pleasantly surprised.
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
A long bar to the left of the entrance. Although decorated funkily, the inside does feel almost like a corridor to your intended seating, a large covered outdoor area, astroturfed with some faux-Warhol type garish paint applied to statues. Large communal tables.
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
The versatility of the bar means it draws in a reasonable range, albeit slanting towards a younger audience.
Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Pizza, snacks, outdoor seating, board games
Value For Money: ❤️❤️
City centre prices.
description: A versatile Southside bar with a wide range of beers, gins, whiskies and wines, pleasing a broad crowd. The format here has morphed, like a few to its recently covered outdoor area with large communal tables and pop art influenced décor which oscillates between genuinely well done, fun and cruddy (although as always, it's in the eye of the beholder). With some local beers on offer, board games and a dog friendly policy, there's all manner of reasons to pop along here for an afternoon or evening. Could there be a few more deals and discounts? - yes - Could the inside area feel less like a throughway and more like a place to sit down? - also yes, but on balance it deserves its inclusion to our guide. (Added February 2025)

name: Coughlans Bar
description:
EBG Rating:: 7.8
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Gins are the major standout with a notable selection of over 150 bottles, while beers are a little more towards the familiar end. Not alone in claiming the best pint of stout in Cork. 
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
A small pub room with rear space by a fireplace. Traditionally decorated and furnished with memorabilia from the pubs former multi-use as stonemasons and medics. Covered outdoor area which can be used for events, and indoor stage and performance area with its own bar (apparently rarely used).
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️
Enjoyable patter even at quiet times. This is an operation that pulls in a good range of people besides the usual suspects, reaching its zenith around curtain call when events are on.
Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️
Live music, comedy acts, fireplace, outdoor seating
Value For Money: ❤️❤️❤️
Reasonable, on average for the city centre and nearby businesses.
description: Live music and frequent comedy acts keep a conveyor belt of punters coming through the door to Coughlan's stage area which becomes the 'Comedy Cavern' several nights a week. A democratic range from local acts and open mic to individuals you'll have heard about or seen in national productions. Of course, none of that means the slightest thing to our guide if the pub was not good. Instead, there's a pleasing immediacy to surroundings. Most people in the main bar room feel pretty close to the bar, just a holler away from getting attention of the staff. This gives it an informality that encourages craic and cross-chat. The pub room is decorated traditionally with the usual framed mirrors and heritage on the walls, and fireplace to the rear of the room. Some of the memorabilia harks back to the owners days as stone masons and medical practitioners. Coughlan's has also joined the trend of covered outdoor areas which can be seen out the back. Drinks-wise, gins are the major standout with a selection of over 150 bottles, while beers are a little more towards the familiar end. Not alone in claiming the best pint of stout in Cork. There's plenty of reason to drop by at any time of day or evening, but be warned the space inside fills up towards curtain call during events. (Added February 2025)

name: Krčma U Kellyho
description:
EBG Rating:: 7.8
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Bakalar and Cernovar beers on tap including honey beer. A fairly strong rum selection is also notable.
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Vaulted cellar with candlelit interior. Fairly 'theme restaurant' at the bar, but the main cellar is atmospheric with the number of candles and backlit alchemy equipment and murals. Basic chunky furniture. 
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
The historic premises, candlelight and décor add a present atmosphere even when quiet, which is a good sign.
Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Food, snacks, 
Value For Money: ❤️❤️❤️
Not the cheapest, but nothing too obnoxious either.
description: Located in the premises of Trebon castle, a candlelit basement pub restaurant which is surprisingly compact and pubby, seating only 60. A Medieval themed bar area continues into vaulted cellars. Their alchemy inspired interior is eye-catching, as is the array of candlelight which replaces most if not all electric lighting here. In the evening you'll find locals here, it isn't simply a tourist theme restaurant, which was a nice surprise. Trebon is a sleepy place and finding even a semblance of nightlife some evenings can be difficult. If U Certa is closed, this is your next best bet in the centre. The selection of drinks is relatively unusual, Bakalar and Cernovar represented, including a honey beer. (Added March 2025)

name: Krčma U Krokodýlího Ocasu
description:
EBG Rating:: 8.8
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
A surprising array of unusual misfit lagers, none of which are particularly cutting edge but certainly different to most. A stock back bar of familiar central European staples with some retro appearances.
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️
A beautiful, homely, worn-in little dive, warm lighting and sepia tones to its furnishings. Wood, lace, net, etc. 
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️
A delightfully young, vibrant and friendly hangout spot. Informal, without the scuzz element that many Czech dives have as a default, which may explain a healthy gender mixture here. 
Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Food, snacks, instruments, outdoor seating
Value For Money: ❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️
One of the cheapest places for drinks you'll find in the city. 
description: 'The Crocodile's Tail' is a classic example of not judging a book by its cover - or by online reviews. Gloomy lo-res photos of a characterful, but forlorn looking dive could hardly be less representative of this cult classic, a late bar that cut its teeth in the 1990s. Here we were imagining arriving to find the remaining 70-something men marking time in a largely empty pub, but instead found a vibrant, young audience both inside and stood out on the street. A bar that actually has more in common with the likes of the antiquey bars in Kazimierz district in Kraków, minus the tourists. Enter a homely, well-worn in small pub decorated with retro domesticity and a few hints at the pubs name to go with it. Tablecloths and lamp lights add an interesting touch to a usually minimalist format which Czechs don't often deviate from, adding a distinctive identity, the sort which you could easily become loyal to. There's an erratic feeling that suggests each visit here may go slightly differently, but service was really friendly, as were the surroundings. To add to its oddball, misfit feel, lesser spotted mid-range lagers on tap including some for a price which is really, really good. Would you order the fried cheese here? Possibly risky, but worth a try.

As with most bars of its kind, there are idiosyncrasies - it doesn't always smell great around the bar area, for example, but in the lounge it's super atmospheric.

Even allowing the surprise and delight to subside, when reflecting on our experience with a rational distance, we're still sure this is one of the best drinking holes in Czechia. (Added March 2025)

name: Zach's Pub
description:
EBG Rating:: 8.3
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
A versatile range of options, particularly the back bar, with superior Rums and whiskies to the typical Czech pub. Beer options are more familiar, but they do have an association with Pilsner Urquell which hopefully ensures good standards.
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️
A very characterful little one room bar with small stage in the corner and bar itself on the far side. Decorated with a dense array of ephemeral bar fittings which go beyond the typical Irish bar confines, spreading their wings further. 
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
As a live music venue there can be times of day which feel 'saggy', but the interior and pleasant courtyard are worth hanging out in whether quiet or busy. On busier evenings, particularly in Spring and Summer the bar comes into its own.
Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️
Live music & events, outdoor seating, snacks, community events
Value For Money: ❤️❤️❤️
Typical central Pilsen prices, nothing offensive.
description: In Pilsen, Zach's Pub occupies the space known as 'the institution'. Established in 1995, offering live concerts and opening late 7 nights a week means this is a venue most residents have been to at least once. Originating as an Irish pub, the theme is thankfully not taken over by that, but you will find the walls of their small inside saloon cluttered in fixed mirrors and posters. It would be best described as Irish-adjacent, and simply stems from the time when Czechia was seeking different reference points for bars. These days, a schedule of gigs keeps the bar busy, with spring and summer evenings its zenith as the atmosphere spills outside in its courtyard and from their stage area. In winter, a small stage in the corner, little more than a step has hosted many mini performances over the decades. As for drinks, the place offers a broad back bar reflecting its status as something beyond a typical central European pub, while on tap, the predictable Pilsner Urquell and Guinness are supported by some budget options - on our visit Poutnik, but previously Hubertus. Prices are middling for the city centre, but not offensive considering the general offering. This is somewhere to visit with a few friends when the evening is bubbling up nicely in order to see at its best. (Added March 2025)

name: Pink Panther Pub
description:
EBG Rating:: 7.6
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️
Basic wares all-round reflecting its status as a late bar.
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Basements with brick vaults set across a series of room. Bar room by the entrance with Pink Panthers hung up by the bar and TV in the corner, with some hideyholes and spacious backrooms. Backyard smoking area too.
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Typical alternative late bar feel that reflects its 90s energy. Unpretentious, somewhere to hang out. The informality and late hours often mean you can easily get talking to a stranger here. While service may appear a little surly superficially, it is willing.
Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Snacks, TV, games, outdoor seating
Value For Money: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Fair value for money.
description: Since 1997, Pink Panther has been the touchstone late bar in Pilsen. A basement dive bar split across a series of divided vaulted cellars, which, as you explore each layer adds a clandestine feel. Dub/reggae soundtracks the activity in the pub, while they accommodate football on TV at the bar and games in the other rooms. Drinks are basic but reliable, reflecting the status of late bar rather than pub. In most respects the operation has tried to keep everything the same, year after year. Given the raw materials this is entirely understandable. Perhaps a new beer or two would be a welcome addition.

As a casual late bar you'll find customers in various states of repair/disrepair and this is a venue where you can very easily get talking to someone new.

(Added March 2025)

name: U Jirky Plzeň Doudlevecká 9
description:
EBG Rating:: 7.6
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️
Pivovar Bizon beers on tap, usually 4-5 on rotation with some specials and further fridge options. A typical, familiar selection of back bar options, because specialist beer is the focus.
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️
A corner boozer with simple furnishings. Well maintained with sturdy wooden tables, traditional style but recent fit.  
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Warm, comfortable and more welcoming than a typical backstreet corner hospoda too. 
Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Food, snacks, takeaway, seasonal events, outdoor seating, TV
Value For Money: ❤️❤️❤️
Nearer to the going rate for the city centre, but in line with the quality of produce.
description: U Jirky offers superior beers in a corner bar neighbourhood setting. It's a small, warm, well-appointed space, traditional but typically minimalist and in good repair. Their beers are from Pivovar Bizon with occasional specials, a notch above the typical offerings around the city. It's a relaxing space, somewhere to unwind or have a chat with friends rather than go wild, and this can be seen in its audience, something of a man-creche at certain times in the afternoon or on match days with the TV on. 

Service is willing and not fazed by new faces (which is always appreciated by us in Czechia), while the beer is fresh and well-poured. 

It's also somewhere to eat, offering an also rather masculine array of food options with daily menus, seasonal specials and snacks.

For local life, good beers and a warm, comfortable environment, we can certainly recommend it. 

(Added March 2025)

name: Museum Czech Underground
description:
EBG Rating:: 8.6
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Normally an afterthought in such places, they offer between 2-4 taps, usually including the local Krumlov brand. The back bar is more perfunctory, but bases are covered.
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️
A shack laden with the events and ephemera of its history. Rickety, off-centre. As you enter there's a fire by the bar to the left, and ad hoc seating arrangements on the right, with a performance area to the rear.
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️
A lost atmosphere from bars which were in the past more frequent, but now are hidden gems. This isn't somewhere to take a date, or an instagram video of some template furniture. Instead, the atmosphere is clandestine, counter-cultural, a blend of unpretentious old geezers and youngsters, which peaks during musical performances. This is a slice of both folk and punk culture. Smoking (of various kinds) is permitted here.
Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Live music, events, snacks, fireplace, musical instruments, outdoor seating
Value For Money: ❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️
Entirely fair value for money. 
description: The search for this pub was one of the true wing and a prayer experiences, walking past an unlit lorry park and long closed roadside diner, the length of the building and round the corner in the dark, until suddenly a glow and a twinkle of lights. It does exist, and it's exactly where Google says it is. It is no surprise then, that this is a cult venue for those in the know, rather than passing trade. 

On entry though, the holy union of grizzled old geezers and youngsters didn't seem at all fussed by our presence, making us feel almost welcome, but certainly tolerated (which in Czechia can qualify as a compliment) .

This is a shed, a bunker,  drinking den of iniquity sheltered from the public glare. Wizened with character, the events and happenings plastered across its walls. Some easy to identify, others signifying, well..what exactly?

To the left of the entrance is the bar and a heater, which we're pleased to say was blasting out on a very cold evening. To the right, tables and a TV, with a passage to a music/performance area.

Yes, music and general cultural revue is a critical part of this venue, giving it a sense of contribution to the city and legitimacy that accompanies that, all the while feeling very transgressive. Certainly the smoke fumes, some of which are let's say greener than others, reinforces that, so be warned.

As bars are slowly reconfigured into a by-numbers exercise in blandness, venues like these show the virtues of doing it their own way. An unashamed love-or-hate place, but one that will be truly loved by its adherents, far beyond the love any Kozlovna or Lokál will ever manage.

On the subject of beer, normally an afterthought in such places, they offer between 2-4 taps, usually including the local Krumlov brand.

If you're an adventurous sort, a punk, a youngster or just fancy a complete change to the usual, it's well worth the short walk from the city centre. 

(Added March 2025)

name: Bluegrass Club
description:
EBG Rating:: 7.6
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️
Formerly local beers, but these days from what we can tell, only the familiar Pilsner/Kozel combo on tap and similarly familiar back bar options. Well cared for though.
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
The large open hearth dominates the room as you enter, providing a warming focal point to this homely inn, with Gasthof style vibes. The musical leaning is not just a name, with instruments pinned to the walls.
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
A very pleasant place to be whether busy or quiet, particularly in winter on account of the roaring fire and live music meetups.
Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Food, snacks, live music, fireplace, outdoor seating, hotel rooms, barbecue
Value For Money: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Decent value for money.
description: A setup similar to a German style Gasthof in some respects. Rooms with a pub restaurant. The pub itself opens for live music performances and community meetups. During the winter offers a roaring hearth which is an impressive spectacle. During the summer, the terrace and barbecue with riverside overlook are similarly appealing. Located just outside the centre of Cesky Krumlov, there is less of a tourist focus, which is to its credit, however it would benefit from more people knowing about it. Down to earth friendly service provided to enjoy hearty meals and well kept, if familiar beers. Mark it on your map, though be careful to pay attention to opening hours. (Added March 2025)

name: Zapa Bar Český Krumlov
description:
EBG Rating:: 7.6
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️
A broad, versatile selection from beers, mixers, cocktails and liqueurs with bases covered not only broadly but with reasonable quality too.
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Set in ancient rock vaults underneath the castle, the bar furnished with a lamplit saloon bar entrance room and glitzier, off-centre bar area. Small overall but with a sense of space to it.
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
The characterful environment is reason enough to visit, but the bar itself keeps a reasonable tempo and energy too. Service is quick and matter of fact, and the crowd varies from touristic in summer months to a healthy mixture the other 8 months of the year of visitors and locals. 
Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️
Snacks
Value For Money: ❤️❤️❤️
While expensive for some basics, the cocktails are reasonable considering the location and competition nearby. 
description: A 1990s cocktail bar based in ancient stone vaults set directly into the rock face. The natural environment proves an atmospheric place to hang out. Unlike Apotheke up the road, Zapa has a less exclusive feel, somewhere for anyone to come in and socialise. The cocktails are good, but the atmosphere is more casual, with more tempo to it as well. The pricing corresponds to this also. If you lived here you'd be visiting the place a lot. The bar area has a slightly glitzier feel, with the pubby entrance room feeling more versatile overall, both serving well. We can only recommend a visit.

Please note there is a sister pub with the same name in Pilsen. (Added March 2025)

name: Apotheka cafe bar
description:
EBG Rating:: 7.6
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️
With their own inventions and the ability to ask for known classics, bases are covered well. If you want a simple drink, well, it's Czechia so this is possible too.
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
A modern cocktail bar comprised of a small room with vaulted ceiling and wood fit back bar, backlit stylishly. High seats and benches around tall tables.
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
More formal than average, with table service and a no-phones policy which gives the place more of a refined feel. It's a comfortable and enjoyable place to be but perhaps lacking a little joie-de-vivre to elevate it further.
Amenities/Events: ❤️
Snacks
Value For Money: ❤️❤️
This is the high end option in town. Certainly by Western standards fairly priced but cocktails can be secured elsewhere in town for less. 
description: Apotheka is not the first, nor will it be the last cocktail bar to trade on being in a converted pharmacy. A compact little space with vaults, a smart cabinet for a back bar, and high seats around which are high benches and stools. Table service keeps things feeling fairly formal, as does its no phones policy, making you feel a little pinned in your seat when you may wish to explore and relax. However, the stylish lighting, very high quality standards and pleasant interactions with staff are factors which tip the venue into the credit column. If you are seeking for somewhere special to go in the centre, this is it. (Added March 2025)

name: Balbínova Poeticka Hospudka
description:
EBG Rating:: 8.8
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️
A familiar roster of Czech beers and liquor overall.
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️
Entrance from a sloped street into somewhat of a bunker. Pale pink walls and curved supports in a half basement. Simple, humble furnishings. Small overflow area near the entrance, then a larger pub room with bar to the right and stage to the left. 
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️
A clandestine feel, with an an alternative crowd. Not somewhere to take a date for dinner, but a rawer authenticity about it that would suit groups of friends or interested partners. 
Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Live events, music, poetry, comedy, culture, snacks
Value For Money: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Entirely fair value for money given the location.
description: In amongst the increasingly changed, wealthy Vinohrady district where businesses are inspired by global trends, it's reassuring to find a backstreet pub focusing on continuing Czech traditions, feeling in no way obliged to compromise in order to fit in. You'll find an operation similar to the far more famous "Shot Eye" (U Vystrelenyho oka) in Žižkov. As well as its low key, unpretentious setup, decorated by its history and feeling of continuity, they host cultural events spanning from poetry (unsurprising given the pub name) to music and more besides, changing on a regular basis. There was a time in the 1990s where bars like these would have been common around these districts, but as of the time of writing it feels more like one of a dying breed. There is no sense of this when visiting however, feeling at the heart of Prague's alternative scene, providing many times over more to the city than the umpteenth brunch bar. If they expanded their drinks offering this would propel the place to stardom, but as it is, you will barely find a better pub of its kind in the country. (Added March 2025)

name: Bar Chýše
description:
EBG Rating:: 8.3
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️
Several beers available on tap from high quality independent breweries. A decent, though more familiar back bar.
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Constructed in an old electricity substation, the unusual building stands out on the street. Homely decoration inside the pub, wood fittings and slightly twee furnishings. 
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Cosy, homely and friendly. Outside it looks like a locals bunker, but the service is willing. A few phrases in Czech won't hurt if you're looking to ingratiate yourself. 
Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Meals, snacks, fireplace, pet friendly
Value For Money: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Good value for money in line with the quality of products.
description: Why come out all this way from the city centre? Cimice is at the very city limits. Well, Chýše is arguably a Top 20 pub. Constructed in an old electricity substation, the unusual building stands out on the street. Inside, you'll find genteel homely charms. A roaring fire, willing service and surroundings to place you at ease. Being where it is, tourists and foreigners are, if not unheard of, then lesser spotted. Chýše also offers beers from good independent brewers like Matuska on tap, among others, and were relatively quick on the draw to do so. Humble, friendly and high quality, this is somewhere to go for respite from urban Prague and potentially make new connections. Change at Kobylisy or Ladvi metro stations for a bus to Cimice. (Added March 2025)

name: Beer bar Chmeloun
description:
EBG Rating:: 7.7
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️
Beer specialists. High quality beers on tap and in the fridge from independent Czech brewers, and more besides.
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️
A shack with an awning, this looks like it may have been a former snack-bar. Ad hoc furnishings in the taproom, mainly breweriana. Bar directly in front as you enter, seating to the right. The seating area is fairly warmly decorated with musical instruments and wooden furniture. 
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Local life, and an outsider feel too. This hardly a typical naval gazing craft beer bar, more a little dive bar with an excellent selection. Friendly too. New faces may be a surprise but they are certainly tolerated. Not somewhere for a quiet drink, more of an intimate experience among a cast of regulars. 
Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Snacks, outdoor seating, takeaway.
Value For Money: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Good value for money in line with the superior products on offer.
description: As with nearby Bar Chýše, the question is why travel out to Čimice when there are many good bars in the centre. The answers are manifold, but mostly it boils down to having a good time with good beers with locals, getting a break from the city centre and in the case of Chýše and Chmeloun, a break from tourists too. Perched almost at the very end of Prague's northern city limits, the bus terminus is yards away from this little shack. It looks like an old snack bar converted into a pub, with a particularly ad hoc feel when you walk inside. A bar, fridge and simple low-key seating at the back. Yes, this is a living room for regulars, dog-friendly too, so if you're looking for a quiet space to unwind, this isn't it. Instead be at ease with mingling with locals, perhaps answering a question or two (one of them being "how the hell did you end up there) and enjoying the fact there are some pretty fantastic beers on offer. Whether it's the fridge or tap selection, you can be assured of high quality beer from independent Czech brewers. When twinned with nearby Bar Chýše there is perfectly good reason to make a trip out here. (Added March 2025)

name: Bar MAY
description:
EBG Rating:: 7.5
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️
Pilsner + Radegast with limited fridge options. Basic back bar, a utilitarian selection.
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Blacked out windows and curtain at the entrance leading into a one room pub, more of a front room. Ramshackle, slightly hippy décor, world maps combining with colourful lampshades.
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️
One of Prague's more clandestine operations. Were it not for a few people drinking on the street you'd be excused for thinking this was a closed pub or not properly marked. However, the Pilsner Urquell sign and activity street side is enough to try the door despite the black curtain and blacked out windows. A step into the unknown. When in, you'll be drinking among a set of misfits and locals, a friendly vibe, the very antithesis of pretension. 
Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
TV, snacks, outdoor drinking, board games
Value For Money: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Entirely fair value for what's on offer. 
description: A bar with a truly low profile, but known to the local neighbourhood. If you pass at quieter times, you'd never notice a bar was there but for the Pilsner Urquell sign. With smokers and drinkers on the street, here is the indication something is happening. Pass the blacked out windows and enter through an unmarked door and further black curtain, a step into the unknown. You'll find a humble bar, purposefully low-key, decorated in a vaguely hippy/drop-out style. Imagine a student dorm from the early 00s, and you'll not be far away. Drinks are utilitarian, service is tolerant, and the atmosphere is one for those outsiders, misfits and unpretentious locals to turn up, have a chat, play a few games and forget about the sweeping homogenisation of Prague's pubs for an hour or two. (Added March 2025)

name: Café Nová Doba
description:
EBG Rating:: 7.5
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️
Konrad beer, other basic offerings that at least cover the bases well.
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Plainly decorated alternative bar whose main style appears to be 'worn out'. Deliberately unpretentious bordering on squat-like. 
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Atmospheric, almost transgressive feeling hangout spot for the alternative scene, youngsters, dropouts and anyone else who wants a drink and to socialise in a more informal setting without being judged.
Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Snacks, outdoor seating, table football
Value For Money: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Fair value in line with what is on offer.
description: First impressions are "oh cool, these places still exist around here". A late bar, dog friendly, for drop outs and kids and hang out in an unpretentious environment of knackered furniture and general decay. A mezzanine area, pushing the boundaries of legal, requires customers to stoop low underneath a large wooden beam. Nova Doba can be cliquey at the bar if some regulars are in, and you're best advised to stand your ground in that case, although service can be willing. Drinks are basic but cover bases. So low-key it is genuinely difficult to capture the atmosphere on camera. Don't forget about the garden in summer, a popular oasis in the middle of a built up area. (Added March 2025)

name: U Fleků
description:
EBG Rating:: 7.5
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Value For Money: ❤️❤️
description: We have ummed and aahed about including Fleku for a long time. A famous historic beer hall, unfortunately perhaps too famous for its own good. As a venue and an experience, worth maybe doing if you plan ahead and know the tricks. The venue is truly spectacular with 8 rooms decked out in dark wood, stained glass with frescoes on the wall, similar to a Bamberg style beer hall. They brew and their dark lager is undoubtedly one of the best in the country (or even best in the world). Since Covid they began doing a light lager, which was slightly disappointing given the unique quality of having only one dark beer. Visit on a Monday out of season (early March or something) earlier in the day and it can be quite a positive experience. However watch out for the raft of hidden extras they will add to your bill, and refuse the offer of Becherovka shots if you don't want an extra £5 to magically appear on your bill. Further marks down for the staff who patrol the place more like bouncers than servers, giving the feel of attending a beer hall in a police state, not quite allowing you to fully relax. The highs are so high it is worth trying, but you have been warned about the rest. (Added March 2025)

name: KMPCB Husova třída - Klub malých pivovarů České Budějovice
description:
EBG Rating:: 7.7
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️
Beers from smaller independent brewers on tap and in the fridge, with some Belgian and German specialist beers available too.
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️
Not the strongest suit. A long entrance hall into an open plan room with fish tank in the corner, bar to the right and simple tables. 
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
A friendly welcome even to an unfamiliar face is nice, and soon you'll feel part of the rhythm of the place. Warm in winter, it gives you good reason to return.
Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Snacks, outdoor seating, community events, takeaway, TV, fishtank
Value For Money: ❤️❤️❤️
Reasonable value in line with superior quality products
description: Following the sad closure of Klub Malych Pivovaru's sister pub Na Mlynske Stoce in the city centre, it's a case of getting a bus or walking out to their original venue. The concept is beers from smaller brewers, and the selection is truly excellent when accounting for tap and fridge. This can be enjoyed in a reasonably pubby premises that won't win any awards but is nevertheless warm, friendly and welcoming. A fish tank, TV and attentive service make it feel homely and make you, the customer feel like an important fixture, which is nice. It can lack atmosphere at quieter times but on other visits we have been pleased to discover it shines when the room is full. Can happily recommend it. (Added March 2025)

name: Le Corbeau
description:
EBG Rating:: 7.7
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Not simply the usual Stella/Leffe/Hoegaarden on tap, as there are a few others including Trappists. Bottle selection decent but not the sort of depth specialists will approve of.
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Classical brown cafe with wood panels, mirrors along the walls, booths and rows of wood seating. Brewery merchandise and signage and some Crow themed artwork. A typical city centre Belgian café but for the fact that in 2025 it's no longer typical.
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Calm, business-like during the afternoon, and raucous in the evenings at times, especially on weekends which can devolve into table dancing, something scarcely believable as you sit in the sedate environment of the afternoon.
Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️
Food, snacks
Value For Money: ❤️❤️❤️
Reasonably fairly priced for the location, all things considered.
description: A brown café of a style so typical for Belgium as to be thought unremarkable. These days, in central Brussels, it is one of a dying number. The Crow is handily situated in an area now more known for shopping than drinking, and during the day survives as an Estaminet type operation. Meals offered, but not essential. As you enjoy a beer among the classical surroundings of wood panels, mirrors and beer ephemera, the calmness of the afternoon leaves absolutely no hint of the raucous nightlife to be found here, with singalongs and table dancing not only permitted but encouraged. For this reason it is destined to be a venue people have starkly different experiences of. Was this the ripoff place that was full of louts that gave bad service and wouldn't let you split the bill? Very possibly. Was this the lovely old cafe that served you a delicious beer with a smile for a fair price? Also equally likely. It is best going in to these split personality venues with some knowledge of what may await. We hope this helps. (Added March 2025)

name: Le Cercueil - Bruxelles
description:
EBG Rating:: 7.6
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️
Beer and cocktails are the focus, some decent options though far from being an epicurean's dream.
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Camp gothic with UV lights and props, a small bar with limited space.
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Kitsch, fun, a novelty feeling to the atmosphere and about late night socialising. The later the better for somewhere like this.
Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️
Speed dating service?! Snacks
Value For Money: ❤️
Certainly on the more expensive side. 
description: Atlas Obscura writes:

"Le Cercueil was unleashed onto the world in 1974 following the release of the horror movie, “The Exorcist.” The decor, featuring grim reapers and dark skeletons, creates a morbid atmosphere in this unique tavern. The only thing creepier than placing your skull-shaped beer mug on a coffin is the nomenclature of the cocktails. Sit back and sip on your choice of corpse juice, devil’s sperm, and vampire blood. The bar offers a speed-dating service but beware, the ultraviolet neon lights give potential lovers an eerie corpse-like appearance."

Our experience? These days, very much a fixture of the micro-economy that operates in and around the Grand Place. The prices are not cheap, but expertly poised right on the limit of "OK yeah, go on then". The interior retains its camp gothika and is worn in almost to the point of worn out. Nevertheless, the sense of fixture and novelty value carry over a certain charm - it wouldn't be Belgium otherwise, would it? One to visit when you're in the mood. (Added May 2025)

name: Den Stillen Genieter
description:
EBG Rating:: 8.2
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️
Very high quality epicurean selection of specialist Belgian beers including on tap, and featuring local brews from independents. 
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Narrow bar with personalised/lived in appearance and genteel café bar/pub seating to the rear surrounded by brewing ephemera. Well renowned wobbly staircase to the upstairs.
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
A long standing bar with a cult audience and cast of regulars, a sense of the serene to be drinking with a classic music soundtrack in more of a hushed environment during the afternoon. In the evening conversation takes over a little more but this is not your typical party venue, more a man's idea of a relaxing, cosy pub.
Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️
Simple food, snacks, limited outdoor seating, takeaway
Value For Money: ❤️❤️❤️
Typical prices for the city centre, but fair and reasonable.
description: For over 40 years, Gerard Walschaerts has owned and run this classic Belgian café, renowned for forwarding the best of Belgian beers in the early days of the scenes revival in the 80s and 90s. These days you'll find a charming, characterful pub which begins with a narrow bar area and its row of stools, often occupied by the regulars, and genteel cafe seating to the rear. The soundtrack of classical music accompanies the 'gentlemen of leisure' concept well. This is not a place where the day to day is about throwing parties, but to contemplate the sublime in a reverential way. On that score, it may split opinion. What certainly won't do is the high quality array of beers both on tap and in bottles, including many specifically sourced from independent brewers in the local area. This really brings forth not only Belgian beers wonderful variety but depth and curiosity. Gerard has seen it all and upstairs you will see a presentation of his ageing appearance, a living legend in his 60s and he promises another decade at least. (Added March 2025)

name: Brauereigasthof/Hotel Bürgerbräu
description:
EBG Rating:: 7.8
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
A wide range of own brew options including seasonal specials, reaching a good standard. Typical back bar but with a decent wine list.
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️
Impressive setting by the market place, with the courtyard backed by the iconic 19th century brewery buildings and chimney. Inside, a multiroom brewery pub decorated in arch-Bavarian style with murals of traditional dances. Wood fit with candelabras.
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
There's always an added something to visiting a venue that's at the epicentre of a town's social scene as this so clearly is. There is a sense of importance but in a provincial, welcoming way. Slightly touristy, but outside of peak season a reasonable balance of visitors and locals. Characterful interior and yard.
Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️
Hotel, shop, food, snacks, outdoor seating.
Value For Money: ❤️❤️❤️
Higher than you'll find in Oberfranken but fairly typical for the area.
description: On the very tip of South Bavaria on the cusp of the alps, Bad Reichenhall is actually easier to reach from Salzburg in Austria than any German city. A spa town with the usual trappings, it also boasts an impressive and venerable town centre brewery. Their pub is at the epicentre of the town's social scene and of course, visitors and tourism.

They claim the brewery dates back to 1494, but any operations existing by 1834 were destroyed in a devastating fire. A new brewery was founded in the typical 19th century Industrial style. In 1901 the operation was purchased and the name changed to its current iteration.

These days, the large premises houses the brewing operations, a hotel and of course, the pub restaurant. This is still in private hands.

Moving on to that, the pub offers a number of characterful rooms decorated in arch-Bavarian style with murals of traditional dances and costumes, fitted with large candelabras and all-in-all, what you'd hope and expect to find in such a place. The front courtyard is overshadowed by the brewery chimney and buildings, and looks out onto the marketplace, making that too quite an iconic place to be. 

We found the service very engaging and willing.

If there is a downside to the layout, it's that the bar does not, as it really should, act as a focal point. 

You will also find the prices not exactly level with Franconia for food and drink, so be sure to pack a few extra euros.

Nevertheless, it deservedly occupies a status as iconic Sudbayern brewery pub. (Added May 2025)

name: KV KAPU
description:
EBG Rating:: 7.8
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️
A broad rather than specialist range of drink.
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Colourful, eye-catching exterior with porch and lean-to with a tool shed. Sometimes an oil drum used to make a fire for warmth. Indoors, a fairly spartan L-shaped bar to the left and event space to the right hand side.
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
An alternative slant with a younger audience. The courtyard feels like a collective of outsiders in both senses, while during gigs the bleeding of bar, outdoors and event space makes everything seem quite loose. At its best superb, sometimes a little bare and sparse. 
Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️
Live music, events, outdoor space, games, fire, snacks
Value For Money: ❤️❤️❤️
Reasonably priced, certainly competitive with most city centre offerings.
description: Dating back to the 1990s, KV KAPU is a cultural centre hosting gigs and events of various kinds, aimed at a younger and certainly, by Linz reserved standards, a more alternative audience. With a vibrant, colourful exterior, you can be in no doubt as you arrive what awaits you. As a bar, the venue is more than a little reminiscent of the likes of Metelkova in Ljubljana, KKC in Riga or Bohem Pizzicato in Szombathely. There is usually something happening in the courtyard out front as well as in the performance space. The bar area itself is a little on the ad hoc style, and can appear bare at quieter times as a result, but this is fairly typical for any events venue that also needs to cope with swells of people. There's no doubt this occupies an important, crucial role in the diversity of offerings in the city. (Added March 2025)

name: °PLATO Craft Bier Bar
description:
EBG Rating:: 7.5
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️
By Austrian/Linz standards a specialist selection. 8 taps, including Austrian classics from Hofstettner, but a strong range of bottles and cans covering a range of styles.
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️
Tasteful modern refit with dark greens, muted lighting and some back-lit beer ephemera. Chunky tables in a bar that is set up a few steps from the entrance. Beer garden to the rear.
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
A pleasant place to hang out, versatile, meaning pleasant while calm and a bit of a buzz when busy. 
Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Takeaway, snacks, outdoor seating. Food can be ordered and eaten in from the adjacent restaurant.
Value For Money: ❤️❤️❤️
Overall fair considering the central location and absence of competition.
description: Within a year of opening, Plato won the award for best beer bar in the region. Admittedly, without a vast array of competition. Austria and craft beer are still in the year 2025 becoming acquainted, but in the provincial cities you will usually find one or two specialist bars. Formerly the location for the cult rock bar Sputnik, a relocation provided opportunity to move into the premises. The interior is well executed with muted lighting and a tasteful dark green, modern but warm style, not flashy but functional and somewhere you'd return to. The beers are a pleasing range of classic Austrian brewing and genuine specialist beers that would be difficult and in some cases impossible to find elsewhere in Linz, other than in boutiques. Prices are OK too considering the absence of competition. With a rock/punk soundtrack that isn't overly loud, it signals its identity reasonably well. It should be the first port of call for any visitor to Linz who is interest in specialist beers, and around the top 5/6 bars in the city in our estimation outside of that consideration. (Added May 2025)

name: Pivnice U Vousatýho pulitru
description:
EBG Rating:: 7.8
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️
Pilsner Urquell in supreme condition, with a fairly spartan array of alternatives, though typical for Czechia.
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️
The owner is a blacksmith, thus there is more metalwork on show here than you'd expect for a small pub. A modern, metal-heavy bar occupies most of the room leaving little space for seating, but a side room to the right of the entrance provides some additional seating. Rows of tables on the terrace overlooking the river. Modern and clean style but with some wooden furnishings and in a characterful historic building with some unusual spacing.
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️
Very lively and atmospheric, accentuated by the welcoming and engaging service.
Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️
Snacks, outdoor seating
Value For Money: ❤️❤️❤️
Typical for the city centre
description: The work of a blacksmith and sculptor, owner Matouš Holý also sports a beard, referenced in the pubs title "The Bearded Pint". Taking over from a defunct operation in a prime location, the riverside setting proves an irresistible draw for people who want to enjoy a pristine pint of Pilsner Urquell with a pleasant view. That does take the focus of the pub. A large bar, styled with distinctive modern metalwork occupies so much space in the main room there is barely room for a stamgast table, and you'll be lucky to fit 8 people in there. But for a few leaning posts in the entrance, the second room to the right comprises the rest of the indoor seating. High demand and small space means you may be disappointed if you're hoping to turn up without a reservation, but the best days to try, ironically, are the busiest, because most will be outside rather than inside. A casual and disarmingly friendly approach from staff (we all remember what Czech service can be like) is a really distinguishing feature, making a first time visitor feel part of their scene. It is worth emphasising the beer here is served in super condition, which also helps. Formerly popular with visitors to the nearby theatre for a pre-post theatre drink, the swell of demand has meant that you could easily imagine copy and pasting the same pub along the riverside 4 times and filling all 4 easily. (Added May 2025)

name: U Věstonického Venouše
description:
EBG Rating:: 7.8
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Litovel/Opat/Holba, not personal favourites of ours but they are lesser spotted around Prague, so may be of some limited interest. A selection of well-priced wines from Czechia and Austria.
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Set in a basement in the corner of the park partly obscured by climbing Ivy. Descend steps to a small courtyard and through a door direct to the bar. The inside space appears standing only in the room to your right, while there's apparently jokingly named catacombs downstairs. 
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Knockabout, dog-eared but friendly. This is a little bunker where they may be surprised to see a new face but are not hostile to one either. Enjoyable to laze on the patio in the summer or for basement scheming and fun in the colder months.
Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Outdoor seating, music, snacks
Value For Money: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Fair value for money.
description: Around Prague (in 2025, the time of writing) there are still a few remnants of the 1990s hey day where small independent bars exploded, demand fuelled by workers coming from across the world - particularly the US to Prague.  U Věstonického Venouše is an even rarer example within that category, of an unchanged Vinárna. Christ, those things are virtually extinct in the city now! Budapest is perhaps the last city in Europe to have dozens of working class wine pubs. Yes, once of a day wine was considered an every day drink rather than a utility to push aspirational culture and social climbing. Working class wine pubs tend to be quite a bit like ordinary working class pubs, especially in the respect that most serve beer too. 

Set in a basement in the corner of the park, your chances of finding this place by chance are very low. You get the impression everyone from owner to regulars enjoys the anonymity and the slightly clandestine nature, a little refuge among a modernising district in Andel.

The small terrace is usually popular, regardless of the temperature if the sun is shining and its dry, people are out there. Inside the taps face the entrance - even to order you are among the throng. Standing room can be found to the right, but there is a further cellar jokingly called 'the catacombs' when it's busier. 

Yes, this is a pub with a long history, many stories and part of a wider social scene that involves musical connections - as seen by the photos, the decoration and the music itself. 

Although the entrance may feel like entering a stranger's lair, do not mistake the dog eared with the hostile. This is hardly hostile, this is a pub that will be friendly to you if you're friendly in return. 

Explore it on sunny afternoons in the courtyard or later evening in the basement to find it at its best. (Added May 2025)

name: Branická Formanka
description:
EBG Rating:: 7.7
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
A Braník pub, so don't expect strong flavours. Braník is a brand intended to be drunk in volume, therefore milder than most. To be fair to the pub, it is served close to as best as you're likely to get. The pour and condition are all often immaculate. The alternatives are spartan, but very typical for a little knajpa like this one.
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
A little drop-in kneipe that looks to have had a refurbishment in the 1990s, reportedly for the worse. Nevertheless, the compact, intimate space with tap straight ahead and bench seating still feels suitably out of time, particularly for the central location. Locals gather around the bar so don't by default hang around there - head for the benches to the right.
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
An old school drinking hole of a kind that is a genuine rarity in central Prague, a process which has taken the best past of 30 years to erode, but is now sadly genuinely true. If you want to experience a classic Czech pub with a proper taps and tapster, and unpretentious, typically masculine environment, you can hardly pick a better choice in the centre than this.
Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️
TV, food, snacks, limited outdoor space (leaning posts)
Value For Money: ❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️
Around the cheapest pint you can find in Prague old town.
description: A famous pub and one of the final old town 'pajzly', small boozers, this Branik pub still retains its 8am opening and 9pm closing. Perhaps this gives it its odd sense of similarity to a Spanish bar. Starting early is no shame to the regulars here who obey their own, rather than society's rhythms. The tapster Roman Pavlik belongs among the pantheon of famous old dudes working the beer taps around Prague. It isn't solely a seedy drinking den, as the pub welcomes respectful tourists and workers from the nearby Pasaz shops, cafés and theatres too. The entrance leads direct to the taps with a small bench to the left occupied by the regulars, with the benches to your right the safest bet. A 1990s refit has slightly, but not overly tackified the interior, indeed the surroundings themselves are taking on a certain age by this point. The Branik, for what it's worth, is delivered in supreme condition, proving you can sometimes make a silk purse out of a sow's ear. The prices? Well, you'll be looking at a handful maximum that can compete with it in the city centre. This particularly goes for their food offerings which are so cheap as to actually arouse suspicion rather than temptation, but some reviews are quite convincing. It is a particular kind of pub, and so not to everyone's tastes, but that is to miss the point entirely. (Added May 2025)

name: Na Stara Hospode
description:
EBG Rating:: 7.7
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️
A very traditional selection, Pilsner Urquell, Kozel and Gambrinus, but the beer was in good condition on our visit. The back bar is similarly predictable.
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️
A majestic building with baroque gables and classicist facade.  On arrival, you will notice the "Saal" rooms, Austrian era signage which refers to the various large beer halls.
