The bar, a large wooden construction is at the entrance, with a Schwemme style taproom that in all honesty doesn't appear to be somewhere you'd congregate. Head to one of the beer halls where you'll find impressive high vaulted ceilings and hunting trophies, candelabras all placing together an ensemble that feels familiar and in keeping with the history of the venue.
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
An every day feel due to its location outside the tourist trail, elevated by the grand surroundings.
Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Food, snacks, outdoor seating, TV
Value For Money: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Fair value for money, with some good lunch deals.
description: The name isn't only for show - there has been an inn here since Medieval times, lost only during the thirty years war. The current building is still impressively old, nonetheless, stood for over two hundred years, with records of its construction in 1711.

They claim to have put up Maria Therese and the Emperor Charles VI in the past.

In 1961 the pub was expropriated by the stated, only returned to private ownership after the velvet revolution.

It is the sort of venue you'd expect to be in the old town rather than by a motorway, opposite a suburban metro station and a shopping centre, but these things happen.

In the past this Inn would have represented a way point from Podebrady to Prague, these days it is consumed into Prague's urban sprawl. Being so close to the metro station there is really no excuse not to give it a try. While distant looking on the map, the door to door from Mustek to Hloubetin is 16 minutes only. The wonders of Prague's public transport. On arrival, you will notice the "Saal" rooms, Austrian era signage which refers to the various large beer halls. The bar, a large wooden construction is at the entrance, with a Schwemme style taproom that in all honesty doesn't appear to be somewhere you'd congregate. Head to one of the beer halls where you'll find impressive high vaulted ceilings and hunting trophies, candelabras all placing together an ensemble that feels familiar and in keeping with the history of the venue. The hunting theme extends to the menu's offerings which veers into game meat. 

Service is pretty sullen, sadly, but hardly unfamiliar to anyone who has visited these places, and on our visit was not directed solely at us, but to virtually all arrivals. 

As for the beer - a very traditional selection, Pilsner Urquell, Kozel and Gambrinus, but the beer was in good condition on our visit and fairly priced.

This will prove a curiosity for anyone seeking out unspoilt old Inns around Prague, as well as an opportunity to experience one with few, if any tourists at all.  

(Added May 2025)

name: Restaurace U Zímů
description:
EBG Rating:: 7.5
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️
A superb selection of lagers, from Svijany Slik and Pilsner Urquell to their own label beer, a semi-dark lager, and Fabian 12 from Pivovar Hostomice. 
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️
Stripped back venue with minimalist, genteel decor.
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Small town 'living room' for groups of friends to hold forth, most people walking through the door know each other by name, making a distinct difference to the atmosphere. 
Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Gifts, takeaway, own label beer, limited outdoor seating, food, snacks
Value For Money: ❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️
In some cases exceptional value for money. 
description: Established in 1991, this small town pub is a meeting place and living room for locals, and if you arrive as an outsider don't be surprised to find a few "who are you" type looks. That said, with an airy, well-maintained taproom and plenty of seating space, it's hardy like entering a spider's lair. The rhythm of life and local etiquette is interesting, markedly different from urban Prague, but in addition to that, you'll find a genuinely superb selection of European lager, with highlights being their own label Polotmave and Fabian 12 from Pivovar Hostomice, on sale for a frankly ludicrous price. They are a shop and offer takeouts of PET bottles, along with cooked food and snacks. Service was professional and welcoming too. (Added May 2025)

name: Klub Malých Pivovarů
description:
EBG Rating:: 8.3
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️
10 taps with 1 regular lager and a rotating offer of beers from smaller brewers, with a few big foreign names sometimes. European bottle selection, particularly from Belgian. Standard back bar focusing on liquor rather than cocktails.
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
A warm interior with exposed pine-wood beams and chunky tables, sympathetically lit. A fairly compact bar room with small overflow area around the corner.
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Lively and friendly with a young and sometimes surprisingly diverse (for Czechia) audience.
Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Occasional planned away days, board games, shop, food, snacks
Value For Money: ❤️❤️❤️
Reasonable value considering the range available. 
description: The conveyor belt of tourists from Plzen train station to Plzensky Prazdroj brewery - the home of Pilsner Urquell - too often overlook the presence of a beer specialists only yards away from the route. KMP specialise in beers from smaller breweries, usually with 10 tap options covering a good range of styles, with bottles/cans offering more besides. The venue itself is really pleasant, the front not really giving any indication of a barn-like space inside with exposed beams and warm lighting, using natural materials to create a homely environment. It's also popular with a wider audience particularly age-wise, making it a lively stop-off during the evenings. Service is fast and attentive too, there is really not much here to complain about! Elsewhere in Plzen, this multi-tap setup is not too common, with just a handful of alternatives. The location, environment and selection means it is one you will just keep coming back to. In fact, we're surprised it took us so long to visit in the first place. (Added May 2025)

name: Freudenpark
description:
EBG Rating:: 9
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️
Cocktail range, competent back bar and Franconian vollbier on draft including Huppendorfer. You will not want for options.
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️
Large signage and an elaborate garden out front with petanque court, stage, water features and barbecue is a flavour of what's to come. Inside, you'll find a vast space, high ceiling and wood fittings. Tastefully curated with a mixture of retro artwork and brand signs. Warm lighting.
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️
A fabulous place, whether busy or quiet to have a drink and socialise. There's an impressive sense of intimacy despite the large space and the variety of amenities.
Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Live music, BBQ, food, snacks, boules/petanque court, darts, pool
Value For Money: ❤️❤️❤️
Fair value for money.
description: Opening in 1984, Freudenpark has ascended to cult status in the subsequent decades. Set out in the Nordstadt, this venue is as close to the airport as it is to the city centre, and without many other options nearby, visiting here is a bit of a singular experience. However, it's easy to reach, a simple 10 minute bus ride. The suburban location means more space, something Freudenpark uses to great effect. Large signage and an elaborate garden out front with petanque court, stage, water features and barbecue is a flavour of what's to come. Inside, you'll find a vast space, high ceiling and wood fittings. Impressive, distinctive and eye-catching, rarely found in Germany. Tastefully curated with a mixture of retro artwork and brand signs, and as you survey the scene, you're still wondering what exactly is this. A late bar, a local pub, a cocktail lounge, a road house? The answer is, a little bit of all of that. One thing this is not, is a Gaststatte, or any kind of food-led Wirtshaus. This is where to go for an evening drink. The service at the bar has that sort of cocktail bar pretense, with the staff very much masters of the back bar, however, the approach and atmosphere is more casual still. Behind the bar they offer a few good beers as well as the wide selection of drinks. Huppendorfer Vollbier tastes as good on tap here as virtually anywhere. With darts and table football, this is an impressively versatile venue that due to its location pulls in a diverse audience, all without losing any identity or distinctive touches. It is, in essence, a superb creation. Forget how far out it looks on a map - hop on a bus and go to Nuremberg's finest bar. (Added May 2025)

name: Landbierparadies Nordost
description:
EBG Rating:: 7.7
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️
Always 1 Franconian beer poured from gravity from the wooden barrel. This alone would be worth the five stars, but a decent bottle selection of quirky Franconian beers and decent selection of schnapps adds further reason to visit.
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Compact two-room interior in arch-traditional  Gaststatte style. Plenty of dark wood and minimalist in decor, with a bar facing both rooms. 
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
The interior is rarely busy outside of colder months, with most action happening on the terrace. However, it is worth trying in all seasons.
Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Food, snacks, outdoor seating, takeaway
Value For Money: ❤️❤️❤️
Fair value for what's available.
description: Opening in 2016, you could be forgiven for thinking it had been around far longer when you wander in to find a dark wood fit tavern with a finish and wear that looks like it could have been around decades earlier. However, for 6 months of the year that interior barely features, as a large biergarten is set up in the space out front. Landbierparadies is a small chain focusing on beer from independent breweries in Franconia. They always offer 1 beer from the wooden barrel on tap, with a sizeable bottle offering of the various quirky and impossible to categorise Franconian beer styles. The combination of characterful, arch-traditional interior, buzzy garden and excellent drinks proves an irresistible draw. It's an easy one to each also, with a U-Bahn stop only a few minutes walk away. Convinced? You should be. (Added May 2025)

name: Brauereigaststätte Hebendanz
description:
EBG Rating:: 7.7
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Export on draft with some seasonal specials from their brewery. 
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
A fachwerk town house with entrance into a Schwemme area, which is the part of Hebendanz which hasn't been refurbished and retains a character. The Schwemme has an Ausschenk, hatch which opens for off-sales, which marks the history further.

Enter a small taproom, plainly furnished into what appears to be a 1970s style refit, lighter wood. A little twee in places. There are some hallmarks of its age and character to be found though - not least the crown glass pattern window behind the taps, a clear signifier of a battered old boozer in central Europe as you'll ever find.
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Pleasant patio terrace out front with the rhythms of the market town to view, while inside a fairly masculine cast of regulars, the stamgast, at the bar, something worth experiencing if you can handle the odd sideways glance.
Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️
Light meals, snacks, outdoor seating, off-sales
Value For Money: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Good value for money.
description: Hebendanz 'The Lifting Dance" is an evocative and quite genteel name for a brewery and pub that is fairly masculine. Boasting a genuinely impressive history, they claim the brewery has remained within the family since its founding in 1579. Yes, this little operation is several hundred years older than many countries. Such occurrences are frequent enough in Franconia that they don't receive the recognition they ought to. 

Famously set right by another brewery, Neder, only two doors down, this is in the heart of Forchheim, a town which until recently boasted 4 breweries, but is still doing extremely will with the 3 in operation.

Enter a town house into a Schwemme area, which is the part of Hebendanz which hasn't been refurbished and retains a character. The Schwemme has an Ausschenk, hatch which opens for off-sales, which marks the history further.

Enter a small taproom, plainly furnished into what appears to be a 70s style refit. There are some hallmarks of its age and character to be found though - not least the crown glass pattern window behind the taps, a clear signifier of a battered old boozer in central Europe as you'll ever find.

Hebendanz's export on tap is typical German fare, bready, malty and robust, but keep an eye out for seasonal specials too. Pricing is cheap and another signifier you're nestled deep in Franconia.

Forchheim's market town size as well as an operation which doesn't exactly scream to visitors to come in and sit in the Gaststube means that you'll mainly find regulars in the bar room itself. This means a few stares, but mind your p's and q's and you'll be served as well as anyone else.

As part of the Neder/Hebendanz duo, this has carved out its own little space in history and is an essential stop for anyone seeking to understand Franconian pub culture, etiquette and daily rhythms. 

(Added May 2025)

name: Lohmühl
description:
EBG Rating:: 7.5
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Franconian lager on draft including Huppendorfer Vollbier which is excellent. 
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Timberframed two-storey pub with twee downstairs but atmospheric upstairs which has more of a boudoir type feel with musical instruments and a more dressy look.
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Naturally characterful history building and atmospheric when busy, one of the town's highlights.
Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Live music, outdoor seating, food, snacks
Value For Money: ❤️❤️❤️
Normal prices for the region.
description: Evening pub with a rickety ground floor Gaststatte in a timber-framed building. Downstairs is a little twee, but check the upstairs with a little more bohemian flair. Atmospheric in the evenings, but it can be frustrating if you arrive without a reservation some days. This is a venue that should definitely reserve some space for walk-ins. We're pleased to say the offerings drinks wise are good with Franconian beer on draft in the shape of Huppendorfer's vollbier. A popular spot among a range of ages, it tries to occupy somewhere between an evening restaurant and casual hangout spot. We'd prefer if it leaned towards the latter but can definitely recommend giving it a try. (Added May 2025)

name: Gans Woanders
description:
EBG Rating:: 8.2
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Café bar offerings, broad rather than deep, but some typical choices.
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
A one off construction, with platforms built around tall mature trees allowing you to sit and spectate at mid-level. Sprawling with different areas to explore. Musical instruments on a stage opposite the main building, a little hut up on the platform, and patio furniture all in mid-brown wood.
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️
A very distinctive and characterful venue, coming into its own on warm evenings in spring and summer during performances.
Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️
Live music, events, food, snacks, instruments, books
Value For Money: ❤️❤️❤️
Typical Munich prices for the style and audience.
description: Made between 2019 and 2020 on the site of the former Hexenhausl, "The Witches House", Gans Woanders is a spin off from the Gans am Wasser riverside bar. Woanders means "somewhere else", in effect. You'll find a distinctive house and well-curated venue with mid-level huts and platforms built around tall trees, providing an overlook to a stage and garden. Everything appears bespoke, giving it a distinctive look. Café by day, but there's enough going on at night, particularly during summer for it to be worth serious consideration for an evening visit. A cultural roster of live music, poetry slams and even performance art/acrobatics, this is a versatile venue achieving it without becoming overly bland. Perhaps a little more decor in places would help establish its identity even further, but what is there works well. (Added May 2025)

name: Cafe Johannis
description:
EBG Rating:: 7.8
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Gutmann and Augustiner beer with occasional specials and a competent back bar of alternatives.
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️
Characterful old pub which evokes the decades past, with a ruritanial feel. Huge Alpine painting, rickety furniture, but somewhat of a classical old café feel too.
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
One of those bars where the clientele morphs during the day, from sleepy afternoons, food service to evening and on to late night, a melting pot.
Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Food, snacks, limited outdoor space, card games.
Value For Money: ❤️❤️❤️
Typical prices for the neighbourhood.
description: Johannisplatz's best late bar, the eponymous bar is known in Munich as a 'boazn', generally speaking casual little pubs for socialising. That said, Johannis isn't just a boozer, they offer food, particularly Flammkuchen. You'll find a twee, country leaning interior with an iconic image of the Matterhorn. Furniture has a classical, rickety look. Gutmann and Augustiner beer flows and you'll find anyone here from crust punks to bourgeois couples. The owner Olaf Schmidt has become a legend in his own lifetime since taking up the role in 1991, seen by his mockup as King Ludwig behind the bar. However, memories of the place linger back to 1925, and the years of time well spent in here are palpable. Clearly one of the best bars of its style in the city. (Added May 2025)

name: Café CaVa
description:
EBG Rating:: 7.7
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Broad rather than deep café bar selection, but covers plenty of bases.
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
The bar area is particularly characterful with its well chosen and positioned retro signage, but the long room it occupies is interesting too, particularly the antique furnishings and the windows/shutters out to the front. Terrace out front.
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Versatile and yet quite characterful space. 
Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️
Live events, TV, music, food, snacks, outdoor seating, books, board games
Value For Money: ❤️❤️❤️
Reasonable value for money overall.
description: A family-owned business from 1985, Café CaVa has developed a patina of charm in the decades that have followed. The bar area is particularly characterful with its well chosen and positioned retro signage, but the long room it occupies is interesting too, particularly the antique furnishings and the windows/shutters out to the front. It's a versatile space that occupies the role of café, bar, games room and even theatre (if you include watching football). The success of the place is making a space where you could easily go for an ice cream, or a meal, or to hang out with your mate with some beers without any of those feeling clashing and without the space feeling bland. Prices are relatively restrained aiming at a younger audience on a more modest budget. (Added May 2025)

name: Valentin Stüberl
description:
EBG Rating:: 7.5
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️
Value For Money: ❤️❤️
description:

name: bei Dagmar
description:
EBG Rating:: 7.5
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️
Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️
Value For Money: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
description:

name: Zoigl
description:
EBG Rating:: 8.9
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Delicious microbrewed Zoiglbier, an amber kellerbier. Typical Zoigl liqueurs available of mixed quality.
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Living room type pub with a small Gaststube and corner bar and a couple of additional rooms. Plain furnishings but some decoration of local artists. 
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️
One of the supreme social environments where you can meet and make friends with strangers. Sure, a little German may help this along, particularly with older clientele, but it's usually a case of filtering to the person who speak the most English. A fun experience which cuts to the very heart of why you go to the pub in the first place.
Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️
Takeaway, food, snacks
Value For Money: ❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️
Typically good value for the Zoigl food and drink, but more so given this is Allgau rather than the much cheaper economy in the Oberpfalz. 
description: Kaufbeuren's beer scene is dominated by the big brand ABK who have managed some cut-through in other European countries, however the quality is far from the highest you can find in Bavaria. It's always exciting to find a small, independent alternative, especially a passion project. Zoigl is perhaps one of the more unlikely. Zoigl refers to a culture which exists solely in the Oberpfalz region in the far North East of Bavaria where ancient brewing rights bestowed on houses entitle families to brew and sell beer. This is done rotationally and the pubs are open once a month, creating a fantastic atmosphere and and enthusiasm. Simple kellerbier is served alongside basic snacks and a limited menu of warm food. Gernot Wildung has taken inspiration and exported the format, beer and culture to the Allgau! You'll find a beautiful pub with living room type style and a small bar. There's a quaint but very homely atmosphere as the locals adopt and adapt to this new format. A beautiful amber kellerbier with a depth and bitter finish is one you can put back several of in the company of people from the local town. While the conversation isn't quite as mixed as true Zoigl, they have done their best to encourage it. With only a few operations like this on Earth, there is a lightning in a bottle sense of specialness to visiting that elevates it beyond the typical German Wirtshaus or Gaststatte experience. If you announce your arrival and perhaps stay for a few beers and food, Gernot is more than happy to show you his brewery over the road, where upstairs an additional pub room exists with a view of the market place. This was open before Covid but Gernot seems less willing these days to open it up. 

Clearly essential when visiting Kaufbeuren but if you have a Deutschland ticket this is worth a trip from Munich to visit.

(Added May 2025)

name: Galerie am Stephansberg
description:
EBG Rating:: 8
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Kellerbier from Brauerei Sauer served on gravity from the wooden barrel. Oh, and some other drinks too.
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
An Altstadt house down an attractive lane. Inside, traditionally furnished with wood panelling and candelabras, decorated with work from local artists.
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️
Somewhere between pub, café and late bar, gathering all under that umbrella. One for a quiet drink in a friendly, atmospheric venue. Calm, warm and welcoming.
Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️
Food, snacks, musical instruments, local art, limited outdoor seating.
Value For Money: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Price vs performance is good.
description: Bamberg's extraordinary array of breweries and beer halls somewhat obscures the fact it has a handsome selection of evening bars. The likes of Pizzini, Catwheezle's Castle & Rothenschild are every bit as much worth visiting. If you go too heavy early on in the day you'll miss your chance to enjoy these places. Don't think they are slouches when it comes to the quality of drinks either. Galerie am Stephansberg has as a regular beer a kellerbier served on gravity from the wooden barrel from Brauerei Sauer. Offering a younger crowd (in Bamberg this means under 50), and a kind of relaxed, bohemian informal take on a traditional pub. This is not a pub where you have to worry about being seated at a table or obliged to order food. It's more a place where you grab a board game or ask for a go on the piano. It's also a place you'll find locals. The famous beer halls tend to attract day trippers but with a lower profile, this bar is happy doing business with Bamberg's residents and anyone intrepid enough to find it - you can now add yourself to that list. (Added May 2025)

name: Zehendner Brauerei GmbH
description:
EBG Rating:: 8.9
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️
Among the highest quality Franconian brewers concentrating on a Lagerbier, Export and Weizenbier with Bockbier seasonal specials. At the pub the Lagerbier is served 'ungespundet' on gravity from the barrel. A selection of typical fruit schnapps available too.
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
A simple layout in the bar room, traditionally furnished in a compact social space, the design standout an overhanging lamp over the bar which is absolutely typical for the region.
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️
A brewpub with a social focus, here is where to have an evening with friends rather than a meal out, a distinction which is very significant in a region where the idea of pub and restaurant is a grey area at best. Forget a Wirtshaus, forget even a Gaststatte, this is a pub to hang out and have fun in.
Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Food, snacks, outdoor seating, cards, seasonal events, stork nest (webcam on website)
Value For Money: ❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️
Excellent value for money for both food and drink, deliberately offering simple food at fair prices, and beer at rates locals can afford.
description: A c.1808 brewery with a sky-high reputation among Franconians and Franconian beer adherents, this operation has remained within the same family since World War II. The Zehendner family don't outsource their work - on busy evenings in the pub you can bump into several family members, whether it's Grandma in the kitchen or master brewer Stefan himself greeting locals and visitors.

With a dedicated bus line from Bamberg passing by, getting here is relatively simple and doesn't take overly long either. Though that is the simple part.

Returning becomes more complicated as you sink into the wonderful surroundings and atmosphere of the pub, beer, food and environment gathering harmoniously and as it occurs to you that no, you don't want leave on the next -and only- bus home at around 6pm.

After this, it's a case of asking around to see if anyone would fancy sharing costs of a taxi. Not impossible given the visitors it receives from the city.

Their pub is a traditional Franconian taproom with the iconic long hanging lamp over the bar (think of the sort you get in old snooker clubs) displaying their brand; behind it, a barrel dispensing their Lagerbier on gravity, and warm, non-intrusive lighting that produces a glow - not unlike the one you will feel when you step out of the place. The layout of the pub interior is simple and unflashy, perhaps a little twee/quaint in the way rural Bavarian pubs can be, but nothing in your face.

As a venue, the taproom plays a role in the appeal of the venue in the way many great pubs achieve without quite being able to place your finger on it - a harmony of place and purpose. 

Regulars sit adjacent to the taps playing cards or dice and chatting at their Stammtisch. Other locals occupy their time-worn spots. But you will find larger tables so don't be shy if it is busy, it is customary in the region to share tables communally, so you only need to ask.

Homemade pretzels and locally sourced ingredients for their simple food elevate the gastronomic experience, but it is important to emphasis this is a pub where the food plays second fiddle to the social element and to be honest, the beer.

Ah yes, that beer. A wonderful lager awaits, simply named but beautifully created, but there's a local divide over whether the Lagerbier or their tap Export is better. You can easily tell who has chosen which by whether they have a stone mug or a glass in their hand. Both have their qualities, as does their regular Weizenbier, while seasonally specials like Maibock, Weizenbock are notable.

Although a relatively modest operation when you visit in person, this is a brewery with a decent distribution. As such, their bottles displaying the guilty drunk monk with halo above his head, which you may already be familiar with, can be found anywhere across Europe including some surprising places.

Stefan is an enjoyer of various beer styles and if the opportunity presents (and if he likes you), he may share something from his collection. 

We haven't touched upon the biergarten, also perfectly pleasant, or the stork nest on the roof, which despite some years of absences usually hosts stork families.

While you may think twice glancing at a map, be assured that this place can be visited relatively easily by public transport, and, with a bit of patience and perseverance you will likely find a way back to Bamberg with someone to share the cost of a taxi with.

In the future, the family's legacy looks to be on more secure footing, while it is interesting to speculate whether it will experience more custom or remain a kind of holy grail for those who have been to the core Franconian venues in the cities, and are seeking something perhaps quintessential.

(Added May 2025)

name: Brauerei Gasthof Drei Kronen
description:
EBG Rating:: 7.5
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
His robust, but unsubtle Zwicklbier will delight anyone who is seeking depth and bitterness to their Zwickl. It worked well for us. Seasonal specials are usually available. 
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
The 1970s are alive and well in this twee net-curtained Gaststube behind a rather bland grey frontage. An open plan set up with wooden tables for communal socialising and dining.
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Very much a primer for the typical Franconian brewpub experience. Rural market town trade, local life, elderly couples, hikers and bikers and a few larger tourist groups.
Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Food, snacks, limited outdoor seating
Value For Money: ❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️
Great value for money all-round.
description: A Marktplatz pub in a market town, offering its own beer under the label Aichinger, a surname attached to the couple who run the place. Reviews mention Erwin's wife being a particular character, while his robust Zwicklbier will delight anyone who is seeking depth and bitterness to their Zwickl. Seasonal specials are usually available. 

As you arrive, the grey frontage with metal balcony doesn't give much away, but the interior, something of a 1970s relic is intact, from the light wood, net curtains and old fashioned bar area with branded hanging lamp  which is so typical of the region.

There's a decent welcome and staff are happy to oblige, while the pub has a social scene rather than simply being a canteen, though that is predominantly due to it being a small town. 

Whether this will be your thing or not misses the point, you will rarely find a more typical example of a Brauereigaststatte in Franconia. Prices are also low reflecting the particularity of the Franconian economy versus elsewhere in the country.

If you are heading east into Franconian Switzerland area for hiking or for more breweries, Heiligenstadt forms an essential public transport stopoff, allowing you to access further breweries at Aufsess, Heckenhof, Hochstahl, Breitenlesau, Nankendorf and Waischenfeld all within a days hike. Heading here for lunch first to help soak up those beers will therefore always be a wide move. (Added May 2025)

name: Brauerei Heckel
description:
EBG Rating:: 8.9
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
The one and only beer. Christened "good Heckel vollbier", brewed once a month. Full bodied with an immediate hoppy presence which subsides to a beer that shows considerable depth and body, potentially dangerous stuff.
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
A plain, almost stark frontage halfway along a narrow lane near the fountain, with signage that looks like the many other closed breweries and operations from decades past. Only the clean lettering really indicates at a glance that this may still be an ongoing concern. Enter a small hallway with door advertising their peculiar opening hours, then the door into the promised land. This really is a tiny Gaststube with space for around 30 people comfortably, and maybe 40 at a push. Notice the crown glass on the doorway, such a typical feature of these lost in time central European pubs. Dark wood and a certain gloom until the light is switched on at a point of the owner's choosing. 
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️
One of the most concentrated, and at times intense exposures to local life you can find. This isn't only unusual for Germany but for the region too. A purely social focused brewery Gaststube which fills up quickly with locals. Your task is to find a seat and some method of communicating - if you have even basic German, brush up and try your best. The two brothers who have taken over the operation are polite, willing but naturally reserved characters. They show respect reciprocally so we would strongly advice to mind your p's and q's and you'll be absolutely fine. 
Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️
Offsales, cutlery/placemats for any food brought in, limited outdoor space to drink by the fountain.
Value For Money: ❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️
Put simply, a remarkable lager sold for possibly the lowest price in Germany.
description: Martin and Rainer Heckel took over their father's operation. "Old Man Heckel" and his one and only Vollbier had attained cult status in the region both for its quality and relative scarcity, but equally remarkable is their pub.

It is a Checklist of extremes and one offs.

Firstly, one of the smallest guestrooms in the country and opening hours that look like they were arranged by throwing some darts at times pinned to a dartboard. They don’t serve food of any kind here – extremely unusual for Franconia, although do allow you to bring food in to eat, even providing cutlery to do so. Then there’s the pricing – could this be the cheapest half litre beer in Germany? Zoigl in Oberpfalz used to be around the same price but has since risen, making this the strongest contender. Then there’s the beer. One beer, nothing else.

All of this has created a degree of mystique around the pub, certainly one we felt when originally hearing about it.

Walking towards Waischenfeld after a days hike across the region was a genuinely suspenseful moment.

Would it be as good as we hoped? Would there even be room? Would our terrible German help navigate the etiquette and conversation? Would it even be open? Brauerei Heckel’s remote location and combination of the above created a sense that this was our white whale.

We have now visited the pub.

Heckel fulfils nearly all expectations, being as quirky and intense an experience as anticipated, while also being richly enjoyable.

The pub isn’t one for shrinking violets, you are sat cheek by jowl to locals – nothing hostile but certainly intimidating for an outside. Unless you time your visit right, expect the pub to be packed out with only a few seats available.
The pub room is a 70s relic with crown glass patterned windows, dark wood and a sense of unlit gloom, almost as if it refuses to even doff its cap to the pretty riverside town outside it.

Card games are noisily played, laughter and banter flies across the room, and glass after glass of Heckel beer is consumed. At such a low price, why not? The beer provides an initial crisp hoppy bite, whacking you in the mouth, before that blends with a robust, full bodied sweetness. At 5.5% its dangerous stuff and before long you can get lost counting how far along you are.

The best moments are cultural exchanges, and so if you’re chatting to locals or visitors, a strange experience is one everyone can bond over, and this is truly a strange experience.

What makes it all the more interesting is that Martin and Rainer are reserved characters, rather than the life and soul of the party. They are respectful and give to the community and to outsiders. It’s important to acknowledge their work as part of visiting the place and to give them the kudos they deserve.

On almost every aspect this qualifies as a love or hate pub, but there’s so much to enjoy for those who really want to dig in to it. When we assessed it we considered whether we’d be happy coming here for the rest of our lives. It was easy: absolutely yes. (Added May 2025)

name: Brauerei und Gaststätte Mager
description:
EBG Rating:: 7.5
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️
A superb offering of their own Franconian beers with a couple that are among the best in the world in their iterations of the style. 
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Fachwerk haus on the high street opposite a church and museum, prominent fachwerk building which leads to a 1970s refit inside. Net curtains, mid-brown wood and house plants, with chunky communal tables. 
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
The family aspect can be experienced at opening time with the generations all chipping in for their own roles and kids scooting around the place. Then as lunch service starts, the place swells and blossoms into life.
Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Food, snacks, outdoor seating, hotel, books, merchandise, takeaway
Value For Money: ❤️❤️❤️
Higher than some Franconian pubs but within a margin that's reasonable.
description: A family brewery since 1774 (so by Franconian standards barely middle-aged) Mager and its fachwerkhaus pub occupies a prominent spot on the high street of a honeypot tourist town, with the mixed reviews you tend to get from businesses who absorb inundations of customers. 

We'd instead point to the excellent beers, with the Helles really a magnificent example of the style, with the Rotbier not far behind. These can be enjoyed in a Gaststube which is a frozen in time 1970s affair, mid-brown wood with net-curtains, house plants and large chunky tables.

The family nature of it is emphasised if you wander in around opening time, with generations all contributing to their particular roles while the kids race around on their toys. 

If you avoid peak times there's a nice pub to enjoy here.

(Added May 2025)

name: Brauerei-Gasthof Gradl
description:
EBG Rating:: 8.4
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️
Leupser Dunkel is renowned as a classc. Much drier, malty and herbal, it is one for the purists. Their pale lager isn't in the same league but still has a distinctive character that marks it out. The Dunkel is served on gravity from a wooden barrel.
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
A house with low-key  signage in Gothic lettering, typically unshowy and reserved. Beer garden is up the driveway with access to the pub through a side door. The bar room is a great, with the classic signifiers - hanging lamp by the bar, crown glass windows in the door and back bar, tiled oven, and simple communal seating in a small room. Second room is also notable. They claim it seats 70 in total, which would be a push, given it looked full to us with about 40 in it.
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
An experience of being a strange visitor in a small town, but as a curiosity rather than any hostility. Leups is a village without much else to mark it as a destination than the brewery. They are used to daytrippers, less so foreigners. Local life and rhythms can be witnessed here, the ritual of greeting every table with a rap of the knuckles, the card and dice games, small details like placing the krug on its side when you've finished and wish to pay. Conversation with those on your table is not mandatory but it is highly likely, so brush up on your German before visiting.
Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Food, snacks, shop, merchandise, outdoor seating
Value For Money: ❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️
Superb value for money on all fronts. You can eat and drink happily here at a fair price. 
description: Family owned since 1683, here is another beloved rural Brauereigaststätte in Franconian with a longevity that is startling. How they've managed to surf the waves of centuries past let alone the turbulence of a present day is an tale perhaps only the owners can tell. What we can tell you is that Leups, where they are based is an unassuming village of well kept houses and gardens, rather than some unholy Medieval backwater. It isn't the easiest place to access.

Other than a handful of buses from Pegnitz, Creussen and Bayreuth, it makes sense to have it as a target on a hike. Indeed, the Bierquellen is a marked trail if you wish to follow it.

We walked there from Pottenstein, a straightforward but enjoyable ramble through lanes and the heart of the Franconian countryside. Reaching the high point, a motorway, the terrain falls away towards Leups and its streams working their way to the valley bottom. 

Gradl's taproom is no doubt a regional classic, complete with some of the iconic features - a branded hanging lamp above the taps, crown glass (usually dating a pub fit to the 1970s) and a Gaststube that is compact and social. 

When guests arrive they take care to greet everyone and rap on the table - this is important etiquette and will help ingratiate yourself a little more. 

Although we can't speak for morning service, on Wednesdays when they open at 3pm, the pub was full by 3.45. 

It won't be easy if you don't speak German. With some shonky GCSE German we just about managed some basic polite conversation with locals, but if you have less than that, you may find it difficult. That said, there is usually someone in the room who speaks a little English.

Food is not expected here by any stretch, so if you wish to settle back for some beers you're more than welcome.

The beers? Well, Leupser Dunkel is renowned as a classc. Much drier, malty and herbal, it is one for the purists. Their pale lager isn't in the same league but still has a distinctive character that marks it out. The Dunkel is served on gravity from a wooden barrel, adding a further roundedness you won't experience drinking it from the bottle.

These are both available at an excellent price, as is their food. Not Heckel or Zoigl level, but pretty close. 

If you've made it this far, then you are deep, deep into Franconian pub and beer culture experiencing the rhythms and etiquette of locals, content to be seen by regulars as the curious interloper. This is not the time to be shy. Get stuck in and enjoy what is a rich experience. (Added May 2025)

name: Becher Bräu e.K.
description:
EBG Rating:: 7.7
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️
Excellent flagship beers with seasonal specials available. Creative 'non-standard' flavours.
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
An exterior which leaves no hint of the interior. You'll be met by a conservatory extension with brewkit out front, a little bit of an unwieldy mess of angles, while inside it becomes apparent the old Schwemme and Gaststube have been maintained. A 1970s time capsule awaits inside with mid-brown wood fittings and a social setup.
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
A social hangout, and a neighbourly one too. Dining is present but not expected (perhaps don't arrive in peak lunch hours if you just want a drink, but outside that it's fine).
Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Food, snacks, takeaway, merchandise, outdoor seating
Value For Money: ❤️❤️❤️
Reasonable prices but measure them against the city rather than the Franconian region which is a little cheaper.
description: The distance between Bayreuth train station and this traditional neighbourhood brewpub may seem excessive, though we can assure you it is well worth the visit. Morning opening hours 4 days a week also increase the chances of a successful visit. 

Boasting to be Bayreuth's oldest brewpub, the name connects the venue to Bayreuth's brewing history. This was a city where every citizen had the rights to brew at a communal brewery, and so their historical records are connected with this. Baking and the use of yeast naturally incentivised many bakers to become brewers. They report the explosion of bakers running inns was particularly common from the end of the First World War, though in Becher's case, their history traces back to the 1750s. 

Today, when you approach you'll find an unwieldy looking pub frontage with the brewkit shoved into view in a conservatory extension at the front, which gives absolutely no hint of the traditional time capsule 1970s pub room inside.

Their basic Krausen bier is lively, zesty but rich too, and a nice baseline flagship product. They do iterations of several styles, with seasonal rotations.

The atmosphere in the pub is very clearly not a city centre pub, but a locals one. Few visitors make the effort to take the pleasant walk along the Mistel stream to the outside of Bayreuth (unusually here, the Altstadt is a suburb rather than a city centre), but now you can be one of them.

(Added May 2025)

name: Manns Bräu
description:
EBG Rating:: 8.5
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️
The Hacker family brew for Becher Brau and Manns Brau in Bayreuth. Here you'll find a Helles and Dunkel as standard, with wheatbeer in summer, krausen and some seasonal specials. They are supposedly introducing a low % 'Schankbier' too.
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
An ungentrified relic, quite a delight to find amidst the thousands of refit Wirtshauser and Gaststatten around Germany. The typical quaint curtains and cushions aside, it's set up like a boozer with tables for socialising rather than dining. Tiled floor and tinted glass can be spied along with other preserved fixtures and fittings.
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️
Truly social rather than dining focused, groups of local regulars playing cards and exchanging conversation around the table. Even thought we're in a city, there are knocks of acknowledgement on each table as customers arrive. 
Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Food, snacks, games, merchandise, limited outdoor seating
Value For Money: ❤️❤️❤️
More alike Nuremberg prices than anywhere in rural Franconia or the Oberpfalz, but not a rip off.
description: Built in 1750 and remaining in the Mann family from 1823-1990. Originally innkeepers and bakers, leftover yeast was soon put to use in brewing. This began a storied history as a Bayreuth institution. These days, no longer in the family, or with independent brewed beer, a visit here may give cause to stop. However, the beers now brewed under a contract with only the label remaining have been kept reasonably faithful to their recipes, while the true reason to visit remains a pub which offers a genuine link to the past, a place which has absolutely not been sterilised into a tourist trap, or even a polite posh restaurant.

Instead, Manns is a regional classic, with an old-timer interior and many historic fittings to enjoy. Ownership and brewing may have passed on but the pub itself survives and thrives. Instead of walking through the door to find isolated families and diners, you'll find a Gaststube with regulars exchanging conversation, socialising and playing games over a beer or two. It's a magnificent sight and one you only wish was more widespread. Schafkopf, the famous card game is such a staple here even the website makes a point of mentioning it.

The staff at Manns has an international flavour, hardly surprising given it is a studenty town with a reasonable ethnic minority too. This gives a cosmopolitan flavour to what would otherwise be a quite parochial spot, and that's all to the better.

As it's Bayreuth, don't expect the same pricing as rural Franconia or the Zoigl area, with costs closer to the average German pub for food and drink.

If you're in the area it is a must visit. (Added May 2025)

name: Hinterhaus
description:
EBG Rating:: 7.8
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️❤️

EBG Rating:: 8.3

Value For Money: ❤️❤️
description: When The Highland closed in 2023 manager Simon Pierce predicted it would never again open as a bar.

Such is the paucity of vision, that this long neglected backstreet boozer had failed to attract new custom despite the construction of dozens of apartment blocks around it. The familiar drab cast of drinks, Sky Sports hoardings and a stench of death about the place that gathers when operations are desperately trying to cut costs was clearly not enticing. 

However, spin on to 2025, the owners of Empire Café in the city centre have given the place not just a spruce up but a faithful reworking to a traditional city tavern of the likes you could expect in London, or - given its name - Edinburgh.

A wedge-shaped building, now dwarfed by the high-rise around it is obscured from view, situated down a slope and round a corner. They have revived retro 1960s signage for their branding, which seems more than a little like trying to hitch a ride onto the likes of The Lauriston in Glasgow, the real deal.

The tiled floor inside remains, and a red gloss ceiling with framed heritage artwork and breweriana from its Tetley's days work brilliantly.

Beer has been given a significant upgrade with cask and keg and ales along with good quality lagers.

The atmosphere since opening has been buzzing and vibrant, deservedly too.

Perhaps the only misstep is the food where over the top pricing and pocket sized portions to boot doesn't quite fit with the easy informality of the pub they've created. A slight adjustment price wise, even at a slight downgrade of quality will bring it into line with the likes of Whitelocks in the city centre. 

Other than that, it's a welcome addition to Leeds pub roster and much needed. Additionally, it joins up a pub crawl from Kirkstall to Burley:

Kirkstall Bridge, Cardigan Arms, Daves Pies & Ales, Kirkstall Brewery Taproom and now the Highland Laddie.

Now you know where it is, what's stopping you?

(Added May 2025)

name: Pivnice U Kuby
description:
EBG Rating:: 7.6
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️
Pilsner Urquell, Kamenice 10 & 12 on tap, with a classic, slightly retro Czech back bar.
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️
A venue on a corner. High ceilings, dark brown wood, modern but with a traditional touch. A bright bar area, tall tropical plants by the windows and interest geometric patterned floor (mind the steps in the toilet). Some heritage artwork from the pub in its former life.
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Nicely social and local, popular with post-grads and thirty somethings giving it a lively, but mature atmosphere for social catchups.
Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️
Food, snacks, takeaway, limited outdoor seating
Value For Money: ❤️❤️❤️
Not unusual for central Brno
description: A venue tucked around the back of the cathedral that has seen many pub and restaurant operations in its former lives. The owners of Pivo & Syn have chosen this spot to continue Brno's almost obsessive project trying to reboot the Czech hospoda. U Blahovky has become such an iconic spot that there is no shortage of attempts to bottle that magic and create it elsewhere. U Kuby offers a lot of the same aspects - a social focus with a stripped down menu, a few hot dishes, food to enjoy with beer, and a streamlined selection of beers from Kamenice and Prazdroj. The corner space with its high windows lets a lot of light in, while decoration has a retro patina in its art work and choice of tall tropical plants add to that too. Service is pleasant and the drinks are poured immaculately, although sometimes a little short measured. 

Being around the back of the cathedral, what tourism Brno gets is unlikely to walk past this place naturally, meaning this is a spot for residents of Brno, both Czech and foreign. 

As of 2025 this place represents a touchstone for the direction Brno pubs have been heading in the last 7-8 years.

(Added May 2025)

name: Hausbrauerei Zum Schlussel
description:

name: KreuzherrenEcke
description:
City: Düsseldorf
description: Altestadt is a street full of boozers and one of them is this tiny corner pub. There are only 2 tables and a couple of bar stools for seating, yet somehow they manage to have live music here. Maybe the band take up position in the toilets.

It's fitted out in a simple, but tasteful manner with wooden fittings and a tile floor. The windows are unusual: the bottom third of each is etched with the name of a spirit, the middle third with the name of a country and the top with various coloured culinary symbols, such as corkscrews, beer taps, etc. I've no idea what the meaning of it is, but it's attractive enough. It reminds me of the sort of decoration you would see in Interhotel bars or HO restaurants built in the 1960's (if anyone can remember such things now).

name: Brauerei im Fuchschen
description:
City: Düsseldorf
description: Another alt brauhaus, this time with coherent traditional pub layout and good atmosphere

name: Gaststätte Zum Franz
description:
City: Düsseldorf

name: Schaukelstühlchen
description:
City: Düsseldorf
description: Cult central rock pub, down to earth and raucous

name: Kassette
description:
City: Düsseldorf

Vysehrad overlooking the lower district, great views. Wooden pub-like interior and hyped balkan grill for food.

name: Beer bar

All-round friendly community venue...it's too small, if anything. On a 2023 visit it bordered on worth of an inclusion, but will try again before deciding. (Added 2017)

name: The Greystones
description:
City: Sheffield
description: Another locally famous neighbourhood pub known for live gigs and quality beer.

name: Jubilee Cafe
description:
City: Victoria
description: Another Café Jubilee, a must visit if anything like the Valletta branch

name: Bohemia Boards & Brews
description:
City: Prague
description: Board games and beer, low key, modernist but cosy.

name: The Nutshell
description:
City: Bury St Edmunds
description: A tiny pub in Bury St Edmunds holds the Guinness World Record for the smallest pub in Britain, measuring just 15 feet by 7 feet. In 1984 they decided to see how many people they could fit in and somehow managed to squeeze in 102 people and a dog, like a clown car. When not conducting scientific experiments, only about 10-15 people can get in here at once. There are bank notes on the ceiling, a tiny dart board, and a tiny copy of The Times. There's also a mummified cat hanging from the ceiling, if that's your sort of thing.

name: The Cricketers Arms
description:
City: St Helens
description: Classic neighbourhood real ale pub https://www.theguardian.com/lifeandstyle/2018/feb/28/pub-boarded-up-for-closure-in-2013-is-now-best-in-uk-camra-says

description: Highly reputed neighbourhood pub with folk music and craft ale.

name: The Weavers

name: MEDUSA

name: Darkey Kelly's
description:

name: The Yorkshire Grey

name: The Barley Mow
description:
City: London

name: The Dolphin Tavern
description:
City: London

name: The Counting House
description:

name: Bricklayers Arms

name: The Bartons Arms

Right pub but wrong location, perhaps? Still quiet even on a Saturday night, drained of atmosphere, though the restaurant area was lively.

name: The Old Joint Stock
description:
City: Birmingham

name: The Wellington
description:
City: Birmingham
description: Extensive range of ales, carpet bar and lounge with niches and a stripped back décor. Can be busy on football matchdays. We will go back to make a more informed decision. Pub Cat! (Added August 2021)

name: The Royal Oak
description:
City: Chester

name: The Carlton Tavern
description:
City: Chester

name: Pub "O'Briens"
description:
City: Toledo

name: Bar Livingstone
description:
City: Toledo

name: Pub Atlántico

name: Calpe

name: Fraggle Rock

name: The New Barrack Tavern

name: The Closed Shop

name: West End Hotel
description:
City: Sheffield

name: Sportsman Lodge Moor
description:
City: Sheffield
description: Freehold lived in country pub, no-nonsense, no generic stuff, not a beige dining room, a pub for all.

name: The Miners Arms
description:
City: Hundall
description: A true freehold country pub, low slung wooden beams, homely lived in feel, pool table.

name: The Strines Inn
description:
City: Bradfield Dale

name: The Coachhouse & Olde Bar
description:

name: The Unicorn
description:

name: The Turnpike
description:
City: Manchester

name: Fox Inn
description:

Carefully restored by Tetley’s in 1985, preserving the old corridor layout with serving hatch, the pleasingly functional front bar and the delightful ‘tramcar room’. Have visited twice and it was reasonably nice. Large beer garden under large old trees.

name: Craven Arms Pub & Cruck Barn

name: The Crows Nest
description:

name: The Nobody Inn
description:

name: Warren House Inn
description:

name: The Great Western
description:
City: Wolverhampton
description: Wonderful cosy community pub with train memorabilia and a welcoming sense of place.

name: Hole in T' Wall
description:

name: Minerva Inn
description:

name: Dipton Mill Inn
description:

name: The Olde Wine Shades
description:
City: London

name: Ye Olde Salutation Inn

That said, it isn't awful and if you like ancient buildings and unpretentious boozing you'll enjoy this. We are keeping this as a tentative suggestion.

name: The White Lion Inn

name: The Coronation Tap

name: The Cornubia

name: The Palm Tree

name: Milecastle Inn

name: Clachaig Inn

name: Nouvelle Vague Tirana

name: V.O.F. Café Chaos

name: Proeflokaal De Drie Fleschjes

name: Café De Gouden Florijn

name: Café Eijlders

name: Café Gruter

name: Schützenbruder

description:

name: Zum Gemalten Haus
description:

name: Anglo Irish

name: Mogk's Bierstubb

name: Gute Stute

name: Castle Inn
