description: Canalside pub with a threatened future. Outside of that it looks ideal for a spring and summer visit with beautiful surroundings and ancient feeling interior.

name: Fosters Arms
description:
City: Bridgnorth
description: While short on good beers, this cosy old freehouse has a lot of other simple appeals from the unspoilt bar area to the pool table room. Without being flashy, it's a pub as it should be.

name: The Black Boy Inn
description:
City: Bridgnorth
description: A reasonably intact bar area in historic surroundings. Some good ales on tap too. Worth a look.

name: Oak Inn
description:
City: Oswestry
description: A compact real ale pub that is on the Bass beer trail. Simple inside but cosy in the huddle.

name: Black Lion
description:
City: Oswestry
description: Lovely-looking honest boozer with comfy upholstered bench seats and lots of real ales on tap. Well reviewed.

name: The Prince Of Wales
description:
City: Shrewsbury
description: A rather old fashioned working men's club vibe to this pub, but not necessarily a bad thing. Very well reviewed and good ales.

name: The Pot & Glass
description:
City: Yarm

description: Outstanding looking bar area with blackened wood, horse brasses and carved wooden bar front. Prides itself on being an honest, proper pub. Looks very nice.

name: The Black Bull Inn
description:
City: Ugthorpe
description: Very well reviewed country pub with lots of the usual trappings: exposed stonework, beams, thick carpet, hearty food (vg options) and real ale. Looks good.

name: Bouchon Comptoir Brunet
description:
City: Lyon
description: Super old-timer pub with framed photographs, worn in tables and cast of regulars.

name: CAFÉ COMPTOIR ABEL - Le plus vieux bouchon lyonnais
description:
City: Lyon
description: Super old-timer pub with framed photographs, worn in tables and cast of regulars.

name: La Clave de San Pedro
description:
City: Cadiz
description: Well rated bodega/bar for night-time socialising. Wooden beamed ceiling, some nice tiles and a bar, but this is no quaint middle aged place, it's lively.

name: DuckBar
description:
City: Brno
description: Whether this is worth a walk we aren't sure yet, but an enticing riverside setting with nice beer garden, mainly locals and quirky highly individual interior that's lived in and homely.

name: Kaffibarinn
description:
City: Reykjavik
description: Enduring bar café hybrid, that's good for a local beer. Well reviewed, solid all-rounder, we would say.

name: Kleine Glocke
description:
City: Cologne
description: A smaller scale beer hall (think Sunner im Walfisch) that looks pubby enough for beer and food. Cosy scale and as featured on Parts Unknown by Anthony Bourdain.

name: The Wentworth
description:
City: Sheffield
description: A preserved old Ward's pub with some classic Northern pub characteristics, real fireplaces, upholstered seats, etc. Seems to be a couple of interesting atrium areas too.

name: Poole Arms
description:
City: Poole
description: Beautiful green faienced tiles line the frontage of the pub. Of course, it's what's inside that really counts, and it looks like they have still kept a reasonably coherent mid-brown pub with fairly low ceilings and drinking atmosphere, not only dining. Worth a look, at least.

name: Hostinec U Tesaře
description:
City: Brno
description: Multitap pub with regional beers and craft on rotation. Fairly minimalist inside but with a few personal touches. It is mainly about the garden terrace here which has a bar itself. We enjoyed it on our visit in April 2024 but ultimately it didn't quite tip the balance for an inclusion. Nevertheless, one to consider if you're in the area. (Added 2022)

name: Gasthaus zum Sieg
description:
City: Vienna
description: This looks to be an absolute classic. Central European knajpa/hospoda with simple wood fittings, old timer decor and pub grub. Highly rated.

name: The Three Goats Heads
description:
City: Oxford
description: Warning: Sam Smiths owned.
Palatial and well preserved interior in this classic city tavern.

name: The Bear Inn, Oxford
description:
City: Oxford
description: A wood paneled genteel alehouse. Something about wood manages to be both minimalist and characterful at the same time, and this seems to find the right balance.

name: The Royal Oak Inn
description:
City: Wantage
description: Looks like a true boozer done well. Real ale for a good price, cosy lived-in surroundings, community feel and some amenities and games to go with it. We want to go!

name: Grosmont Crossing Club
description:
City: Grosmont
description: Interesting little bar that seems to make use of an old club premises. Very old school, information thin on the ground, however comes highly recommended.

name: Skehans
description:
City: London
description: Quirky free house with interior that has a hint of Eastenders' Queen Vic. Nice and lived-in with a mixed community, live music, nik naks and a decent bit more personalised than a lot of more central London offerings.

name: The Old Crown
description:
City: Hesket Newmarket

description: Outstanding looking village pub in stone cottage with a frozen in time feel around the bar area. Carpeted, with pool room, fire going, very unpretentious-looking.

name: Seven Stars, Falmouth
description:
City: Falmouth
description: Excellent looking pub with distinctive bar area and predictable coastal town heritage. Looks individual but clearly enjoys mainstream trade. Well reviewed.

name: The Cover Bridge Inn
description:
City: East Witton

description: Classic welcoming North Dales country pub with fireplace, carpets, low ceiling, radiating warmth and comfort, without the airs and graces you get with some dining rooms.

name: The Bull Inn
description:
City: West Tanfield

description: Beautiful beer garden with willow trees stone bridge and riverside views along with the local church and tower. Inside a solid not-yet-totally gentrified Yorkshire pub with real ales.

name: Stamford & Warrington
description:
City: Coalville
description: Information thin on the ground but reportedly one of the best 'basic' pubs in the country and a throwback to the 1960s. Marston Pedigree is the lynchpin beer on offer. This is either your idea of heaven or a bit unappealing. We shall see.

name: The Crown Tavern
description:
City: Bristol
description: Love it or hate it, one of those pubs, this one looks like it has barely changed since the 60s, but time has dealt so much damage that in such a way that it becomes almost perversely interesting again. We would give it a try.

name: Waggon & Horses
description:
City: Halesowen
description: Highly-reputed real ale pub in the suburbs with very attractive bar area, plenty of choice, and cosy carpeted surroundings. A place to hole up for the evening no doubt. We look forward to visiting.

name: The Crooked Tap
description:
City: Acomb
description: Looks to be a well done modern taproom, with, of course, good beer options, but also a decent enough setup to not feel stark and try-hard.

name: Blind Jack's Pub
description:
City: Knaresborough
description: Looks to be a successful craft beer pub, worthy of a try

name: Ye Olde Smugglers Inne
description:
City: Alfriston
description: Timberframed pub with genteel, rustic surroundings, and ancient looking bar area which seems to be the best part of the pub, given some rather bland painting choices elsewhere.

name: The Boat Inn
description:
City: Ashleworth
description: Extremely cosy old country pub with intimate feel around a narrow bar room, carpets and chunky furniture. Famous for good ciders. Well reviewed.

name: The Fountain Inn
description:
City: Ashurst
description: Idyllic country setting, the bar area keeps its olde world charm, assisted by the Inglenook fireplace, exposed brickwork and beams. Grade II listed building, with literary and pop culture connections. Old barn area features a skittle alley.

name: The Mug House Inn & Restaurant
description:
City: Bewdley
description: Historic inn, that has been changed substantially inside, however a reasonably tasteful bar area with tiled floor and rustic niches keep a bit of character going. With a nice beer garden and riverside view there is a lot of appeal remaining to accompany the old stories.

name: The Great Western
description:
City: Bewdley
description: Attractive, if minimalist ale house with a quality range of drinks and timeless simple storied layout that just avoids being too bland in its appearance. Very well reviewed.

name: The Three Tuns Inn
description:
City: Bishop's Castle
description: The taproom for Britain's oldest licensed brewery. In the mid-70s this was one of 4 home brew pubs left in the country. Cavernous venue divided into sections, wood floors, oak beams, bench seating and fireplaces dominate, with good views of the brewery building, perched as it is on the top of the town.

name: Lord Crewe Arms Hotel
description:
City: Blanchland
description: Very much a modern dining room for the most part rather than a pub, however medieval cellars in the Crypt Bar are worth exploring with a great selection of ales. A popular stop off for stargazers in the region noted for its lack of light pollution and clear skies.

name: Doffcocker Inn
description:
City: Doffcocker
description: As a quirk, this is a calendar pub with 365 panes of glass, 52 doors, 28 rooms, 12 rooms in the cellar and 7 bedrooms. No-one seems to know why. As far as pubgoing goes, this is a cosy suburban pub with attractive wooden bar area and upholstered seating, popular for boardgames, darts, occasional live music and Holt beers.

name: Cricketers Arms
description:
City: Boscombe
description: Suburban neighbourhood pub with Edwardian fittings and layout. Carpeted, pleasant niches and corners to relax and socialise. Comfortably and homely, well loved, and with a good reputation for well-kept beers.

name: Fisherman's Tavern
description:
City: Broughty Ferry
description: For a Scottish pub this doesn't look too bad at all. Low ceilings, panelled walls and original ornate fireplace. Decorated with nods to the nearby lifeboat station. Converted from three fisherman's cottages. Looks like that was a good decision.

name: The Tree Inn
description:
City: Stratton
description: Local ales in a historic building. Gnarled beams, carefully curated furniture and slate floor. A little bit on the foodie side but enough character to visit for a sit, a pint and a chat.

name: Kings Arms
description:
City: Stratton
description: A typical classic village pub for locals and regulars. Pool table, comfortable seating, fireplace, dartboard, simple non-fussy grub. Homely and lived-in.

name: The Preston Gate Inn
description:
City: Poughill
description: A simple classic Cornish pub. Lived-in, homely and well loved, with live music, simple pub grub, and a long bar area.

name: Cliff Inn
description:
City: Crich
description: Superb looking unspoilt village inn where the emphasis is on a comfy spot to rest up, no airs and graces. Looks distinctive and authentic.

name: The Red Lion
description:
City: The Red Lion
description: Part of Crich Tramway Village, this pub was moved brick by brick by the museum's volunteers and rebuilt on the site. Historic art nouveau facade with faence glaze and brick. This is the focal point of the Edwardian period village. Open only during museum hours, but well worth a look.

name: The Speedwell Bar
description:
City: Dundee
description: Preserved Edwardian L-shaped pub with 100+ whiskies and up to date selection of beers. Looks to be a real classic with bell-pushes, etched glass and Jacobean effect ceiling. On CAMRA's national inventory of historic interiors. Friendly conversations and socialising abound, sometimes live folk music too.

name: The Hidden Treasure Micropub
description:
City: Dymchurch
description: One of Kent's many recent micropubs, offering cosy intimate surroundings and modern drinks choices.

name: Tiger Inn
description:
City: East Dean
description: A frankly beautiful building dominating the village green, and also occupying part of it when the weather is good. Inside is a not yet ruined low ceilinged pub with chunky furniture and comfy corners, perhaps slightly bland. History with connection to smugglers.

name: Royal Hill
description:
City: Edgerley
description: Highly rated rustic country inn with typically low ceiling, tiled bar, stone floor, snooker and darts, outside seating and camping available.

name: Tolbooth Tavern
description:
City: Edinburgh
description: Didn't quite do enough on our visit, but there is reason to consider it. The striking building and its history alone justify popping by at least. Inside, comfortable and inviting, quite intimate interior with upholstered bench seating and carved wood bar., although not a standout for Edinburgh. (Added February 2024)

name: The White Hart Inn
description:
City: Edinburgh
description: Clearly a little touristy, it remains to be seen if the character of the place remains intact when the tourists descend and the cantine food emerges, but nevertheless, attractive wood beams and stylish decor look inviting and worth a look. Reportedly Edinburgh's oldest pub

name: The New Inn
description:
City: Flash
description: The highest village pub - apparently. 1518ft above sea level. 250 year heritage and reputation for cockfighting, counterfeiting and so on. While nothing of such ill-repute happens these days, it does appear to be an old fashioned boozer, a place the locals enjoy. The sign hanging above the bar: "Diane welcomes you to the madhouse'

name: The Camp House Inn
description:
City: Grimley
description: Beautifully unspoilt lived-in country pub with simple pleasures. Looks an absolute classic. Mind the peacock and geese around the grounds.

name: Stag Inn
description:
City: Hastings
description: Grade II listed timber-frame pub with a pleasant rustic cosy interior in keeping with the heritage of the building. It's also a little weird with mummified cats, witch decorations and local rituals, giving it all a distinctive feel. Very well reviewed.

name: The White Horse
description:
City: Hedgerley
description: Fantastic looking country pub with rave reviews. Beer poured directly from cask and recent orchard supplying local cidermakers. Fire blazes in winter. Two small intimate bars. Lovely garden. Everything a pub should be.

name: The Red Lion
description:
City: Hooe
description: An archetypal old Southern British pub overlooking the village green with picnic tables, while inside the trusty combo of beams, fireplace, stone floor and the patina of history. Some careful modernisation means it isn't totally jaw dropping but is worth a look if you're in the area.

name: Twa Dogs Inn
description:
City: Keswick
description: Very pleasant looking boozer with darts room festooned with scarves, wood pannelled bar and nice all-round appearance that is unpretentious and in keeping with the surroundings.

name: Running Horse
description:
City: Leatherhead
description: A 14th century timber-framed pub with sloping floors and ceilings and crooked fixtures, but remarkably even this place has been given a lick of that godawful grey/blue paint in one room. Nevertheless, some character appears to have remained to link the current venue to its past.

name: Sun Inn
description:
City: Leintwardine
description: Outstanding looking pub on CAMRA's national inventory of interiors. Adapted from a row of cottages c.1860, the old owner Flossie kept the place unchanged during a 74 year tenture. The heart of the pub remains in use despite a bright slate floored extention being added in 2011. The old parlour remains open unchanged.

name: The Hand at Llanarmon Ltd
description:
City: Llanarmon
description: Quaint stone walled pub with a recognisable country inn appearance. Low beamed snug bar, popular late nights for local farmers.

name: The Skirrid Mountain Inn
description:
City: Llanvihangel Crucorney
description: Wales' oldest pub, but more importantly, a success in terms of retaining the meaning of being that, with suitably timeless layout, low slug ceilings, stone walls, oak beams, flagstone floor and traditional decor.

name: Ye Old Mitre Inne
description:
City: Chipping Barnet
description: Narrow corridors, aging beams, atmospheric surroundings from a pub steeped in history, but with the current offerings tasteful and redolent of that. Timber framed, grade II listed and decent selection of traditional ales. Looks good.

name: The Carpenters Arms
description:
City: London
description: Successfully preserved corner pub with panelled walls, simple fireplace and bench seats. Narrow corridor leads to a rear room for more clandestine drinking.

name: The Blacksmith Arms
description:
City: Cudham
description: Lovely village pub converted from a farmhouse. Exposed beams and some 60s era signage at the bar give the main bar room character. Cosy and carpeted, available for drinkers as well as diners.

name: Prospect of Whitby
description:
City: London
description: Still a little dubious about whether this place has retained enough of interest, but we recommend it for the time being. Unfortunately in the clutches of Greene King.

name: Six Bells
description:
City: Wick
description: A 300 year old flint inn with gorgeous exposed beams, inglenook and cosy wooden surroundings. Looks fairly unspoilt so go now before they manage to ruin it.

name: Staggs (The Volunteer Arms)
description:
City: Musselburgh
description: Fantastic looking pub with light brown wood strip panel walls, vintage brewery mirrors and snug. Looks great from almost any angle.

name: Lollard's Pit Pub
description:
City: Norwich
description: A reasonably characterful town inn with exposed beams, carpets and intimate feel. Perhaps more of an all-rounder but we shall see.

name: The Hand & Heart
description:
City: Peterborough
description: Mixed reviews about the place but it has a one off bar area on CAMRA's national inventory, modernist in style, and seems to have a cast of locals and good selection of ales.

name: The White Horse
description:
City: Prior's Dean
description: Spectacular looking pub. As Bob Barton says 'a patina of antiquity', with half timbering, tree trunk counters, old fireplaces, bare stone, old plastic. AKA 'The Pub With No Name'

name: Rye Waterworks Micropub
description:
City: Rye
description: A unique location for a micropub. The place has been a pump house, a soup kitchen and public toilets, before becoming an antique shop. The latest incarnation shows its versatility. Of course, being a micropub, there are great ales in abundance. Interestingly, the antique shop still partly runs and customers can even make offers for the furniture if they like them.

name: The Haunch Of Venison
description:
City: Salisbury
description: The gastropub furnishings have taken over, slightly spoiling the otherwise medieval atmosphere. Different rooms called the House of Lords and the House of Commons and a truly attractive bar area still make this a distinctive venue worth seeking out.

name: Bridge Inn
description:
City: Santon Bridge
description: A typical northern country pub with thick carpet, exposed beams and, typical for these days anyway, relatively open plan in the main room. Looks to still retain character not just from outward appearances.

name: The Woolpack Inn
description:
City: Slad
description: An absolutely magnificent looking unspoilt rustic country pub with roaring hearth, wooden floors, ageing bench seats, piano and divided into different rooms. Tempting line up of ales and cider. Can't wait to go.

name: Dancing Man Brewery
description:
City: Southampton
description: Successful use of space, this old wool house has been converted into a brewery with visible equipment, warmly lit stone walls, and showpiece staircase. Plenty of memorabilia to fill the large space. Modern but tastefully done and useful for locals.

name: Duke of Wellington
description:
City: Southampton
description: Half-timbered house with beautifully preserved wooden bar. Both smart and historic, this is a clearly well executed and maintained pub.

name: The Red Lion
description:
City: Southampton
description: Pub in a medieval style great hall, called 'one of the treasures of our surviving medieval inns', there is a Tudor stone fireplace, exposed rafters, court room, flags and heraldry, etc. Also good ciders.

name: The North Star Inn
description:
City: Steventon
description: A heritage inn of England, customers are served from a ground floor cellar rather than a bar, alternatively a stable door and a hatch in the lounge will do. Outside seated are served from the kitchen window. Panelled walls, tile floor, wood framed snug with worn bench seats. Outhouse toilets. Traditional games. The ruritanial pub of your dreams, it seems.

name: The Stiperstones Inn
description:
City: Stiperstones
description: Ignore the dining rooms and head for the beautiful lounge. Rustic and cosy with fre beams, upholstered bench seating, horse brasses in typical country fashion. Rave reviews for the current owners and on CAMRA's regional inventory.

name: Nicky-Tams Bar & Bothy
description:
City: Stirling
description: Live music and cosy market tavern feel inside this bunker like venue, escape from the outside world, or 'grim reality' as it indicates towards your exit.

name: The Duke Of Wellington
description:
City: Wareham
description: Looks to be a classic example of an unspoilt authentic English market tavern. Unpretentious and not corporate or cookie cutter. Comfy, lived in and cosy.

name: The Schooner
description:
City: Gateshead
description: Lovely 'proper boozer' proving that being down to earth and good quality aren't mutually exclusive as Wetherspoons, Greene King and Sam Smiths would have you believe. The environment of a true local with a lived-in premises, live music, quiz, events, and versatile venue. Well reviewed, good ales on cask.

name: The Little R'Ale House
description:
City: Wellingborough
description: A station bar and micropub with a welcoming cosy looking bar area.

name: The Letter B
description:
City: Whittlesey
description: Not quite full information on the interior layout but this free house community local has great reviews for the quality of ales and warmth of welcome. Seems to be the best place in town.

name: The Rugglestone Inn
description:
City: Widecombe-in-the-Moor
description: Isolated beautiful pub with beer served directly from cask. Timeless beauty to the farm cottage type exterior to the genteel rustic exterior, which while new, is sympthetic and in keeping with the wider environment. Looks authentic and we'd love to go.

name: Tom Cobley Tavern
description:
City: Spreyton
description: Village pub cherished by locals, seemingly with good reason. A welcoming interior has not been swept away with recent fashions, but has kept itself homeless and unpretentious. Very well reviewed.

name: The Rose Tavern
description:
City: Wisbech
description: Traditional one room pub stripped back to its simple core. Drink, conversation and old time pub games.

name: The Draughtsman Alehouse
description:
City: Doncaster
description: Micro-pub at the train station serving an excellent range of ales. Limited seating but decent atmosphere supplemented by attractive tiled walls from what must have been a waiting room. Keeps limited hours.

name: John Fallon's "The Capstan Bar"
description:
City: Dublin
description: Attractive ale house. Fairly open plan by Irish bar standards but some nice wooden fittings, glow of light and conviviality. Popular with locals, slightly younger crowd perhaps. Worth a look.

name: Fallon's Bar
description:
City: Clonaslee
description: Lovely homely Irish pub. Could perhaps tone down the flags but there's a lot of authenticity on display

name: Fagans
description:
City: Moynalvey
description: A stop-off in the heart of the countryside. Authentic, raw, homely and lived.in. Well reviewed.

name: The Hanging Gate
description:
City: Chapel-en-le-Frith
description: An uncomplicated roadside inn with cosy interior, black wood furniture, carpet, fireplace and simple food and drinks. Looks ungentrified and authentic, therefore likely to be good.

name: The Barrel Drop
description:
City: Nottingham
description: Well rated central alehouse, looks to have a bit more about it than just the beers

name: The Lincolnshire Poacher
description:
City: Nottingham
description: Castle Rock Brewery tied pub with simple alehouse surroundings, fairly well rated

name: Ye Olde Cheshire Cheese Inn
description:
City: Castleton
description: Looks an excellent option with low beams and the sort of rustic country pub people seek out in this part of England.

name: Drink
description:
City: Hebden Bridge

description: A decent bottleshop/bar with tap and bottle selections and a few improvements to the decor. Close to warranting an addition to our guide but will give it a few more goes.

name: New Delight Inn
description:
City: Blackshaw Head

description: Looks like a terrific unspoiled country inn, without a thought towards bland dining room embellishments, all about the lived in cosy homely feel. Would like to visit very soon.

name: Shoot the Crows
description:
City: Sligo
description: Named after a pest control traditional, this is a pokey compact but hugely atmospheric pub known for quirky fittings and authentic Irish traditional music.

name: Walsh's
description:
City: Dublin
description: Looks a solid option. Relatively airy in the bar room but with a snug, stained glass, live music and a relatively timeless appearance you have a pub that's well loved.

name: Tigh Chóilí
description:
City: Galway
description: Excellent looking pub with clutter pinned to the bar fixtures and wall space filled with framed artwork and photos, along with god knows what else. Famous for its live music and also known to have a decent whisky selection.

name: McDermott's Pub
description:
City: Toomullin
description: Decent looking country pub with several rooms off a cluttered bar space. Barn-like in places but fairly cosy and non-corporate (aside the usual drinks options). Known for its particularly fervent and energetic live music performances.

name: The Board Inn
description:
City: Lealholm
description: Beloved village pub known for its live music performances, cask ales, riverside setting and pub grub. Interior looks undramatic but hints of a personal touch. This will demand a visit.

name: The Heron Bar and Restaurant
description:
City: London
description: The pub recovered most of the interior of the old Windsor Castle and despite the unprepossessing exterior there seems to be a serious reason to go here.

name: Ma Che Siete Venuti A Fà
description:
City: Rome
description: Beer mecca with some football leanings. Stickers on the entrance etc, but inside it is not a dangerous place by any means but a cosy hangout spot.

name: Wishful Drinking
description:
City: Rickmansworth
description: Very well reviewed bottleshop and bar. Interior looks reasonably good though still of its style, there is enough to pique the curiosity. We shall see.

name: The Old Ship Inn
description:
City: Bridlington
description: Pleasingly unchanged appearance with classic upholstered seating, carpets and cabinets, with the main concession to modernity being an improved drinks selection. That seems the right way around. Live music.

name: The Swan
description:
City: Little Totham
description: Fantastic looking village pub, in large thatched cottage with exposed beams. Plenty of personalised non-corporate signage, great reviews.

name: The Cat's Back
description:
City: London
description: Some of the original features are slowly sliding away as the modernising years take over, but there is still plenty to enjoy here by the look of it

name: Anchor Tap
description:
City: London
description: Well preserved Edwardian style corner pub with traditional features - plenty of colours in between black white yellow and brown, essentially. Looks cosy and well review. 
Warning: this is a Sam Smiths pub

name: The Kings Arms
description:
City: London
description: A bit of a mixture. The main room looks relatively uneventful, but an atrium area with distressed furniture and nik naks looks pretty good, and some original features remain in what appears to be a snug room.

name: The Royal Oak
description:
City: London
description: Unsure about this one. A Victorian corner pub with a very nice sweeping bar area in the centre. Need to visit to assess if it has become too bland. Harvey's beers.

name: The Cow
description:
City: London
description: Intriguing luncheon bar with seafood options, however more importantly there is a saloon where one can drink among some preserved Victorian environs.

name: The Swan at Milton
description:
City: Milton
description: Traditional pub with upholstered seating, red and green colours. Real ales and a personal touch. Not modernised but well kept. Decent looking beer garden too.

name: The Railway Arms
description:
City: Alton
description: Looks a true classic. More than one nod to the railway, but the general theme is rustic with real ales. Well review.

name: The Golden Pheasant
description:
City: Lower Farringdon
description: A homely and quite personalised pub here eschewing some of the more template formats, but still achieving a degree of warmth and welcome. Well reviewed.

name: The Harrow, Steep
description:
City: Steep
description: 17th century inn with garden, rustic yet plush interior, corners for drinking and not just an open dining room. Very attractive bar area. Well reviewed, and looks good.

name: Llandoger Trow
description:
City: Bristol
description: Preserved Tudor building which apparently might have a pub in? Nothing on Google but there are plenty of up-to-date references elsewhere.

name: Horská chata Na Perlíčku - Prdek, hospůdka, minipivovar a ubytování
description:
City: Paseky nad Jizerou
description: Very attractive looking brew pub with cabin/stone aesthetic. Cosy and a bit personalised too.

name: Cross Keys
description:
City: Eastgate
description: An ungentrified country inn with exposed beams lined with jugs, cushioned bench seating and carpets, fire going, pub grub. Unpretentious and homely. Very well reviewed.

name: Hare & Hounds
description:
City: Westgate
description: Looks a bonafide classic country inn. Ungentrified with exposed beams and tangible history. Impressive bar area with brass detail. Simple homely and unpretentious. Real fire. Pub grub. Exceptional reviews.

name: The Old Green Tree
description:
City: Bath
description: Attractive compact alehouse with wood panels and simple stripped back format. Nice plotting parlour side rooms. Some European beers in addition to ales. Looks very good.

name: The White Hart
description:
City: Truro
description: Half step down into this low ceilinged ale house. Post-covid, there looks to be potential here with some attractive preserved fixtures at the rear, chunky furniture and decent enough range of cask ales. Plenty of local life too.

name: De Hems Dutch Cafe Bar
description:
City: London
description: Dutch style brown cafe with certain features that bring to mind an Amsterdam pub. Overall it didn't impress us enough to make a final inscription but we will tentatively recommend going.

name: Bohemia House
description:
City: London
description: Interesting venue. Bohem brewery beers in a building with a long standing connection for Czechs and Slovaks in london. Grand townhouse with 'restaurant' which is actually very much like a Czech pub. Grand but extremely informal with table football, pool, TV, simple menu with Czech offerings and a decent supply of ex-pats. We will need to try a few more times before giving a final verdict.

name: Lowlander Grand Cafe
description:
City: London
description: A Belgian/Dutch style cafe with high ceiling, pillars and mezzanine level. Great range of drinks albeit at eye-poppingly expensive prices. The space becomes quite noisy and cacophonous when busy but can otherwise be pleasant. Needs a few more visits to make a final decision.

name: The Albert Inn Bridgetown Brewery
description:
City: Totnes
description: Lovely-looking trad ale house serving as the base for a local brewery. Distinctive slat-clad exterior and rustic furniture inside. Unfortunately closed when we tried to visit, but looks good.

name: Totnes Brewing Company
description:
City: Totnes
description: Lovely looking ale house that serves as the base for a local brewery. Simple brown and golds dominate. The building is prominent at the top of the long drag up the hill which again seems to amplify its status as a destination. Well reviewed. Closed when we tried to visit, however.

name: Red Lion
description:
City: Colwyn Bay

description: Attractive traditional neighbourhood pub with wood panels, bench seating, arrange of real ales and local life. Well reviewed + looks good.

name: The White Lion Inn
description:
City: Llanelian
description: Ungentrified country pub with an olde-world feel. Carpets, dark beams and furnishings, real fire, pub grub. Looks good, exceptionally well reviewed.

name: Thomas Connolly Bar
description:
City: Sligo
description: Fantastic looking preserved boozer that is a heritage building. Simple wooden ale house that has gained the worn patina of years and memories. Attractive bar area and partioned areas of seating off it. Ultra-minimalist furnishings.

name: The Pelican Inn (Wye Valley)
description:
City: Gloucester
description: Smashing-looking neighbourhood boozer with attractive bar area and great range of ales. Well reviewed.

name: Café René
description:
City: Gloucester
description: A beautifully put together venue with exposed beams and brasses, barrels and a bit of personalised quality. Looks great.

name: The Red Lion Inn
description:
City: Belchamp Otten

description: Highly personalised free house country inn with a homely feel, and space for drinking and socialising as well as food. Exceptionally well reviewed.

name: The Roseland Inn
description:
City: Philleigh-in-Roseland
description: Isolated country pub with a genteel garden and interior. Some attractive preserved features that haven't yet been gentrified. Fairly foody but looks like there are some spots for a drink and to socialise.

name: The Tinners Arms
description:
City: Zennor
description: Attractive country inn with genteel garden out front and more traditional interior that has been relatively well preserved, some space for drinking and socialising and not just dining. Well reviewed.

name: Pandora Inn
description:
City: Mylor
description: Attractive riverside inn that is served fresh catches by local fishermen. The downstairs is a well preserved dark wood affair. While foodie and fairy bland on the outside and in the upstairs, it does look good downstairs and appears to have ample space for drinking and socialising.

name: Rashleigh Inn
description:
City: Polkerris
description: Priceless beachside location (right onto the beach) but with a reasonably well preserved interior and operation that is trying to preserve local interest as well as tourists. It still looks to have something about it.

name: Ship Inn, Mousehole
description:
City: Mousehole
description: The central bar and rooms off it have been well preserved with blackened beams and bench seating, which serves as an enticing place for a drink.

name: The Golden Smog
description:
City: Stockton-on-Tees
description: Magnificent looking little alehouse, micropub with outstanding reviews. Simple seating and a personalised interior that is distinctive.

name: Den Gode Naboen AS
description:
City: Trondheim
description: Riverside pub with outdoor seating, but also cosy log-cabin type interior with low beams and plenty of wood. Ales aplenty, and great reviews.

name: Antikvariatet
description:
City: Trondheim
description: Attractive cafe bar with older stylings as you might guess from the name, a homely bookish feel with some instruments suggesting live music. Very well reviewed.

name: Grünerløkka Brygghus
description:
City: Oslo
description: Brewpub with a British-style appearance. Not in a tacky way thankfully, but instead with some thought put into layout and upholstery.

name: Hospůdka na Rychtě
description:
City: Valašské Meziříčí
description: Throwback hospoda - very local, so prepare yourself - with Rychtar beers and a typical authentic Czech atmosphere. It was close to making our guide on our one visit, and worth noting if you're in town. (Added October 2024)

name: Hospůdka v Židech
description:
City: Lomnice
description: Beautiful setting with outdoor seating and some home brew, perhaps need a bit more information about the interior, but looks promising.

name: Ye Olde Reine Deer Inn
description:
City: Banbury
description: Tacky sounding name but the pub appears to be a bit of a classic. Old 2-sided wooden bar with grand fireplace. Low ceilings, exposed beams, wooden bench seating. A lovely looking old fashioned market town inn.

name: The Walnut Tree
description:
City: Broad's Green
description: Excellent looking village pub with a stately timelessness that seems to have been a deliberate decision. All for the better.

name: East Cliff Tavern
description:
City: Folkestone
description: Very fabulous looking mid-terrace pub with unspoilt, genteel homely decor. Some cask ales available. Looks a bonafide classic.

name: Why Not ? Cafe-bar
description:
City: Worsley
description: Small cafe bar with beer options and a music leaning that looks reasonably individual and distinctive. Very well reviewed.

name: Hollybush Inn
description:
City: Breedon on the Hill
description: Other than some bland and inappropriately grey paint at the bar area, the pub looks great with a half timber exterior, low ceiling and beams inside. Very popular locally.

name: The Wonston Arms
description:
City: Sutton Scotney
description: Well loved free house and village pub with large outdoor area and nicely down to earth homely interior, attractive without being dramatic or flashy, with local life and good range of ales.

name: Bier Huis Grand Café
description:
City: St Ives
description: Attractive and relatively charming attempt to recreate a belgian bar, with the usual signage and ephemera, smart fitted bar and lamp lighting, mezzanine level.

name: The Dove, Hammersmith
description:
City: London
description: Historic Thameside pub with a famously small snug bar room, riverside seating and nice wooden beamed interior that retains a degree of historic character.

name: The Greyhound
description:
City: Saxton
description: Magnificent looking unspoilt country in with low ceilings, rustic nik naks, and glorious timewarp 1950s simplicity. WARNING: Sam Smiths pub

name: Burton Bridge Inn
description:
City: Burton upon Trent
description: An in all ways 'classic' pub with large fireplace, wooden fittings, beams, jugs, brasses, Simple and homely. Looks great.

name: The Little Plough
description:
City: Doncaster
description: Screams 'proper pub', although in Doncaster all bets are off. Carpeted interior with dartboard and classic lounge bar. Faienced frontage.

name: The Manor Castle
description:
City: Sheffield
description: Excellent unspoilt pub on CAMRA's national inventory next to ruins of a 16th century lodge. Not your typical out of town large inn, this is a corner boozer, down to earth, well reviewed.

name: Chantry Inn
description:
City: Handsworth
description: Info a little thin on the ground, but meant to be a strong choice for ales, down to earth neighbourhood pub, albeit one that is on CAMRA's national inventory.

name: The Gardener’s Arms
description:
City: Bilton
description: Superb looking unspoilt country inn with real fire, and timewarp atmosphere. WARNING: Sam Smiths pub.

name: The Crown Inn, Glossop
description:
City: Glossop
description: Unreconstructed backstreet boozer with simple furnishings and throwback atmosphere, real fire, homely. WARNING: Sam Smiths pub.

name: The Samuel Oldknow
description:
City: Marple
description: Attractive micro-pub/ale house with an intimate appearance and great selection of beers.

name: The Eyre Arms Old Eyre Arms
description:
City: Hassop
description: Beautiful traditional village pub. Has been closed under Covid but worth watching to see if it re-opens. On CAMRA's national inventory of interiors.

name: The Shepherds Arms
description:
City: Whaley Bridge

description: Probably not going to be to everyone's tastes but this remains a drinks focused village boozer with attractive wood and leather fittings, on CAMRA's national inventory of interiors.

name: Hare & Hounds
description:
City: Manchester
description: Preserved century old interior and a still popular vibrant pub with a mixed city crowd. Fabulous tiling, leather and wood fittings along with distinctive side rooms. On a first visit it had a fair bit going for it, a distinctly working class character and possibly a bit cliquey unfortunate, however we are prepared to give it another try.

name: Coach & Horses
description:
City: Whitefield

description: Historic old boozer with modern and spacious beer garden. The interior has been preserved and is on CAMRA's national inventory. Despite a relatively low rating on Google, this appears to be due to a couple of low level incidents years ago. Most if not all recent reviews are very good.

name: The Turks Head
description:
City: Retford
description: Mock-tudor exterior and well preserved old-world interior on CAMRA's national inventory. Real ales. Looks to have carpeted floors, fire, bench seating, wood panels, a very good example of a specific style, essentially.

name: The Alexandra
description:
City: Stockport
description: Maybe not the first pub to go to in Stockport but nevertheless on CAMRA's interior inventory as a pub of national importance. A grand wooden bar area and mosaic floor gives the place a late Victorian/early Edwardian appearance, with some cosy siderooms. We aren't 100% sure about it but there's only one way to find out for sure. Robinsons beers.

name: Duke of York Inn, Elton
description:
City: Elton
description: 2021 Update: Possibly closed for whatever reason. Magnificent unchanged country pub that is normally only open in the evenings.

name: The Queen's Arms
description:
City: Patricroft
description: Extremely genteel, calm, plush and cosy neighbourhood pub with Queen Vic memorabilia and some retro signage and fittings too. On CAMRA's national inventory. Very well reviewed, a definite throwback.

name: The Sweet Green Tavern
description:
City: Bolton
description: Despite miserly (and possibly impoverished) locals bickering about the prices (note to readers: prices at Wetherspoons are abnormally low so get used to normal prices elsewhere) there does appear to be considerable charm about this place which attracts a mixed crowd with it's more old man preserved interior, dog friendliness and more modern outdoor area. Landlady seems to work very hard keeping it afloat.

name: Ye Olde Gate Inn
description:
City: Brassington
description: Classic country inn. While it has gone foody, the rustic furniture, old fireplace and cooker lend it plenty of charm. On CAMRA's national inventory of interiors.

name: Harrington Arms Gawsworth
description:
City: Gawsworth
description: Pleasingly ungentrified rustic country pub with tiled floor and chunky wooden furnishings. Pleasant exterior in rural setting. Very recently attached to a working farm. Timeless taproom. Robinsons beers.

name: The Ale House
description:
City: Horwich
description: Well executed looking Ale House specialising in Bank Top Brewery beers. A simple effective format with plenty of keg/bottle options as well. Good reviews.

name: The Beehive Inn
description:
City: Maplebeck
description: A potential 10/10 here. Looks absolutely wonderful. Smaller than normal country inn with intimate feel, classic exposed beams and personal touches. Very well reviewed.

name: The Swan & Railway
description:
City: Wigan 
description: Grade II listed historic pub with recent sympathetic refurbishment. Ale focused with late Victorian stylings. Leather upholstered bench seats, cut glass, varnished wood, etc.

name: The Victoria Arms Worton
description:
City: Worton
description: Currently unclear as to its future, but this looks like one of the final dying breed of unchanged country inns in Yorkshire. Naturally, it looks homely, rustic and magnificent in that way only places that have clearly been lived in and love for a long time can have.

name: Ring O' Bells Inn
description:
City: Lower Stretton
description: Attractive ungentrified village pub with low ceiling, exposed beams, leather upholstered seating, carpets and real fire.

name: The Exeter Arms
description:
City: Derby
description: While someone tarted up, this pub retains a degree of its historic character and what new decoration there is has been reasonably sympathetic. While foodie it is clear there are several side rooms and a drinks-focused bar area all of which look very good. Well reviewed.

name: Malt Shovel
description:
City: Spondon
description: Unspoilt village pub with some rustic touches and a homely layout. Very well reviewed for the food, ales and genteel atmosphere. On CAMRA's national inventory of interiors.

name: The Wheatsheaf
description:
City: Sutton Leach
description: Known as 'The Wheaty', the walls are filled with rugby/football memorabilia, plates and trinkets creating quite a distinctive impression. The interior is homely with upholstered bench seating and carpets. Well reviewed both for ales and food.

name: The Anchor Inn
description:
City: Kegworth
description: Riverside pub that has retained its character and kept its drinking/old school pub features despite introducing meals.

name: Limeburners Arms
description:
City: Nether Kellet
description: A really smashing looking country pub with simple homely decor, not trying to impress some foodies or out of towners. Authentic. Occasional live music, dartboard, fire.

name: The White Swan
description:
City: Melbourne
description: Characterful village pub with attracting red seating and low slung beams. The odd negative Reviews seem to concern the Landlord. On CAMRA's national inventory of interiors.

name: Travellers Rest, Alpraham
description:
City: Alpraham
description: A survivor, in the same family for decades, friendly and welcoming, traditional offerings in period surroundings listed on CAMRA's national inventory. Bowling green garden. Unspoilt and one of a near extinct species of country pub. Usually open evenings only.

name: Chequers Inn
description:
City: Ticknall
description: Must go down among many of the great unspoilt pubs in England. Carpets, fireplace, exposed beams, cosy looking. Real ales (including Bass). Local life. Very well reviewed.

name: Kings Arms
description:
City: Haskayne
description: Gloriously unspoilt small town boozer with carpets, brasses, exposed beams, fireplace and attracting bar area. Looks homely and cosy. Very well reviewed. Occasional live music.

name: The Guest House
description:
City: Southport
description: Attractive and well executed backstreet pub with mock tudor frontage, tiled walls and stained glass. Some nice side rooms and leather seating. Well reviewed.

name: The White Lion, Rempstone
description:
City: Rempstone
description: Community pub brought back to life. On CAMRA's national inventory of interiors with a sympathetically decorated interior. Modern and pleasant looking patio. Clearly run with lots of passion and excellent reviews. Looks interesting, though photos are thin on the ground.

name: Dew Drop Inn
description:
City: Hathern
description: Revived pub with heritage features on CAMRA's national inventory of interiors. Looks to be a drinks-focused alehouse with a timeless stripped back appearance.

name: The Prince Arthur
description:
City: Liverpool
description: Looks like a very cosy drinking den with cosy tiled bar on CAMRA's inventory of interiors, though also very likely to be uber-local. Some mixed reviews on that front.

name: Wheatsheaf
description:
City: Louth
description: Typically small and quaint Lincolnshire pub that has retained some character. Please note during Covid there have been closures.

name: The Three Horse Shoes
description:
City: Whitwick
description: Unclear information whether it is open but a couple of recent reviews suggest it is back. Unspoilt local in a coalmining village.

name: The Red Lion
description:
City: Rudgeley
description: Very popular 3 room pub focused on ales and drinking generally rather than dining. On CAMRA's national inventory and reviews confirm a cosy homely interior.

name: Masons Arms, Strawberry Bank
description:
City: Strawberry Bank

description: While the exterior has been well and truly ruined by THE GREY PAINT and the pub mainly relies on food and the beautiful views on the terrace, inside you'll find a not yet ruined bar area with a thick carpet, fireplace, chunky tables, blackened beams and real ales.

name: The Swan
description:
City: Newport
description: Old fashioned small town pub with preserved rustic charm. Upholstered seating, fireplace, communal layout. Naturally frequented by elderly domino players.

name: Turf Tavern
description:
City: Bloxwich
description: Preserved and intact boozer 'like stepping back in time' that has remained in the same family for generations. Looks a one-off. Unlikely to be everyone's cup of tea but we are interested.

name: The Dog & Gun
description:
City: Earl Shilton

description: Mock Tudor pub from the 30s which has retained many fittings and its original layout. These days well loved despite its old-timer appearance. Could be worth a look.

name: Spring Cottage
description:
City: Bloxwich
description: Pictures thin on the ground but seems to be a very traditional old pub/ale house and one that's in CAMRA's national inventory of interiors.

name: The Manor Arms
description:
City: Rushall
description: Canalside pub that looks like a must-visit. Blackened beams, red upholstered seating and period bar area that seems to be without a counter. Quirky. On CAMRA's inventory of national interiors.

name: The Queens Head
description:
City: Barwell
description: Cracking looking market town inn with original siderooms off a central bar. Tiled floor, heritage hung artwork, upholstered seating. Communal feel.

name: The Pretty Bricks
description:
City: Walsall
description: Named after its glazed brick frontage, original features remain in this survivor of a pub that seems to have the community at its heart.

name: The Vine Inn
description:
City: Wednesfield
description: Exceptionally well reviewed pub featuring an interior of quote "National importance" according to CAMRA. Certainly an old fashioned well preserved ale house with a good selection. Looks good.

name: Colomendy Arms
description:
City: Cadole
description: A simple small 2-roomed ale house focused on drinking and chatting. Everything is quite stripped back with some stone features and a preserved bar area. Looks social with local life. Exceptionally well reviewed.

name: White Lion Inn
description:
City: Glan-yr-afon
description: A throwback, barely changed and well lived in old cottage with real fire, comfy seating and all the ungentrified comforts and welcome. Reviews speak of local life, and perhaps not appreciating this as much as they ought to be. Open evenings during the week.

name: Fox Inn
description:
City: Ysceifiog
description: Beautiful country inn with much of the rural charm intact, not turned into a dining room.

name: The White Horse Inn
description:
City: Cilcain
description: Very pleasant looking village pub that hasn't turned itself into a bland grey or beige dining room just yet. Plenty of charm, a historic cottage that's on CAMRA's national inventory of interiors. Well reviewed.

name: The Stile Inn
description:
City: Wolverhampton
description: Some charm in this backstreet boozer with the odd preserved fitting and a nicely done up beer garden. Polish dishes on offer and a mixed community crowd. Well reviewed.

name: The Rose & Crown
description:
City: Graianrhyd
description: Beautiful and cosy with open fire, traditional unspoiled pub. With a friendly, welcoming landlord. Very well reviewed. Looks excellent, a dying breed. Open late afternoons and evenings during the week.

name: The Old Dungeon Ghyll
description:
City: Great Langdale

description: Incredible clifftop backdrop to this hotel, but for drinkers, head to the Huker's bar converted from an old cow shed and on CAMRA's national inventory of interiors. Think exposed beams and uncomplicated furniture for hikers to get refreshed.

name: Waggon & Horses
description:
City: Oldbury
description: Looks the archetypal 'proper pub' with preserved wooden fittings and bench seating.

name: The Woodman Inn
description:
City: Shrewsbury
description: Well-reviewed and reputed ale house with some preserved fittings, but clearly a hub for the community and strong social ties here too. Update - Visited February 2025. A brewer's Tudor style 1960s refit is characterful with segregated bar, lounge and fireplace, friendly service and wide range of ales. Need to go back another time when busier in order to determine a full inclusion. (Added February 2025)

name: Bell Harborne
description:
City: Harborne
description: Overlooking a church green and old tower, the exterior is one of the most typical English scenes you could wish to see. Inside much seems to remain with blackened timber beams, albeit slightly opened out. Looks a decent option though.

name: The Jolly Sailor
description:
City: Whitburn

description: The grey exterior misleads as to the preserved CAMRA inventory-inscribed interior inside that remains homely and cosy by the looks of things. A well loved 'olde worlde' pub.

name: The White Swan
description:
City: Greenside
description: Information thin on the ground other than it being in CAMRA's national inventory of interiors for preserved features and being a 'cracking traditional old pub'.

name: Red Lion Hotel
description:
City: Llansannan
description: The parlour bar looks a must visit with a cured settle around a range fireplace. Service via a hatch. The scene looks positively medieval - in a good way.

name: Case Is Altered
description:
City: Hatton
description: Possible 10/10. Outstanding example of a country inn with low beamed bar, fireplace and preserved features and arrangement noted on CAMRA's national inventory of interiors. Looks great and is terrifically well reviewed.

name: The Crown Inn
description:
City: Llanfihangel
description: Grade II listed country inn. These pubs are vanishing quick so visit while you can. Concentrates on beer and conversation, albeit the setting outside is distractingly idyllic.

name: The Somerville Arms
description:
City: Leamington Spa

description: Lovely looking understated pub with warm colours and a social setting. Some live music. CAMRA noted.

name: Cain Valley Hotel
description:
City: Llanfyllin
description: An unchanged hotel bar that has lasted since the 60s with full height wood pannelling reputedly from a ship.

name: Bowling Green Inn
description:
City: Stoke Prior

description: Adjoined railway cottages near a canal form the buildings housing this traditional, rather genteel pub that seems to specialise in the social and communal aspect - all the better. On CAMRA's national inventory of interiors.

name: Albion Hastings
description:
City: Hastings

description: An old fashioned bar that has had the full works done to it. Sympathetic renovation but it remains to be seen if some of the charm has washed away in the process.

name: Cinque Ports Arms
description:
City: Hastings
description: Still plenty of charm remaining in this mock tudor pub, with attractive cosy hues, wooden panels and leather seating. Some classic ales from the region too.

name: The Star Inn
description:
City: Old Heathfield

description: Beautiful and distinctive old country inn with standout inglenook fireplace and some personal touches that are quirky without being tacky.

name: The Red Lion
description:
City: Snargate
description: Visit before it's gone. One of the vanishing truly traditional unspoilt village pubs left in the UK. On CAMRA's national inventory as a pub of national importance. For how much longer though? (Added July 2021)

name: Blackboys Inn
description:
City: Blackboys
description: Terrific unspoilt inn with candlelit tables, upholstered red leather bench seats in niches, and an intimate feel with plenty of wood, red and warm candle light. On CAMRA's national inventory of interiors. (Added July 2021)

name: The Plough & Harrow
description:
City: Litlington
description: While the place has gone foody, they have spared the famous snug, kept a characterful bar area and overall inside does not look too ruined at all. A potential option. (Added July 2021)

name: Prince of Wales
description:
City: Newhaven
description: Spectacularly preserved faineced frontage, and thankfully the interior of the pub lives up to it on this occasion. A well preserved long bar with stools and bench seating opposite the long room. Well reviewed, drinks focused boozer.

name: The Lewes Arms
description:
City: Lewes
description: While clearly foodie, the small 3 room layout with snug seating appeals and there is some visible character remaining that has a Georgian ale house feel to it.

name: The Hatch Inn
description:
City: Coleman's Hatch

description: Certainly foodie but an undeniably beautiful setting with slate fronted cottage, climbing ivy, moving into a black beamed pub with chunky tables. Perhaps a couple of more pubby areas in and around the bar. Perhaps one for after a hike.

name: The Coach and Horses
description:
City: Danehill
description: Thankfully the bar area and immediate rooms remain intact and unspoilt with a simple rustic country charm. Of course, the place heavily relies on food.

name: Old House
description:
City: Ightham
description: Be warned, there is no pub signage, but this is well worth seeking out for a timewarp of a country pub with an almost classic combination of decor, layout and focus. Visit before it goes for good (Added July 2021)

name: Bear Inn
description:
City: Faversham
description: One of the historic survivors. Grade II listed. A relatively unspoilt town boozer with retro frontage leading into a small pub. 3 drinking spaces and plenty of pieces of decor and old fittings to enjoy, even if they have started slightly positioning this towards the moneyed set.

name: Ship Inn Southwick
description:
City: Southwick
description: Not a pub that will appeal to all, but with its intact 1960s interior, a sort of ship-like cabin with wooden panels and lamps keeps every super intimate. Worth a look for those who like that sort of thing. (Added July 2021)

name: Half Moon Inn
description:
City: Cheriton Fitzpaine

description: A rare treasure, unspoilt village pub exuding character from times passed. Wonky fittings, exposed beams, homely additions, the works. Go before it vanishes. Added (July 2021)

name: Bridge Inn
description:
City: Topsham
description: When we say homely and unspoilt British pub, this is an archetype. Run by the same family for over a century, this grade II listed pub looks a classic and hasn't been given wholly over to food. Excellent reviews. (Added July 2021)

name: The Blue Flame Inn
description:
City: Nailsea
description: Terrific country inn that has focused on homespun charm rather than dining room mediocrity. Skittles, books, boardgames and calm local life in a fabulous looking spot. (Added July 2021)

name: The New Inn
description:
City: Llandewi-Brefi
description: An unspoilt timelessness to the place. A true village boozer and community hub. Good reviews tell of a warm welcome and local life. Appearance shows a 40s style corner bar, stone walls and simple furniture.

name: Bluebell Inn
description:
City: Llangurig
description: A throwback pub that evokes post-war pubgoing with simple seating, a communal layout, low ceilings and bags of local life. Notable fixtures such as wood pannelling and settles listed on CAMRA's national inventory. (Added July 2021)

name: The Mount Inn
description:
City: Llanidloes
description: Ungentrified village pub with low ceilings, blackened beams, pool table, carpets, cushioned bench seating, some original settles, fireplace, Bass signage out front, almost as though time stopped. (Added July 2021)

name: Y Llew Coch - The Red Lion
description:
City: Dinas Mawddwy

description: Fantastic views to be had out front, while inside you'll find an unspoilt, if unspectacular warm welcoming country inn that's terrifically well reviewed. Popular with hikers and bikers. (Added July 2021)

name: Tafarn Y Plu
description:
City: Llanystumdwy
description: Terrific looking pub that has married well preserved homely character with good quality up to date drinks selection. (Added July 2021)

name: New Cross Inn
description:
City: Court Henry

description: Very very unprepossessing and almost derelict looking pebbledashed exterior makes way for an absolutely classic frozen in time isolated pub that's close to 1 in 10,000. (Added July 2021)

name: Etxeberria
description:
City: San Sebastien
description: An eclectic bar with handwritten notes, old bottles and personal touches. Chaotic and thus charming. 22 taps of beers covering Basque, Spanish, Belgian and German, not to mention cider, vermouth and cocktails

name: Bar Desy
description:
City: San Sebastien
description: Twinning tapas with craft beer, not a bad idea. But wait, this isn't a brand new squeaky clean soulless venue. Enjoy a classic wooden counter and some trad fittings with a bit of history and charm. Very well-reviewed (Added July 2021)

name: Corner House
description:
City: Barnstaple
description: An appropriate name for this corner boozer. Preserved wood fittings in this drinking den, good reviews for its friendly atmosphere. On CAMRA's national inventory of interiors. (Added July 2021)

name: Ye Olde Globe Inn
description:
City: Berrynarbor
description: Unspoilt homely country inn with rustic seating, personal touches. A free house, naturally. Visit before it disappears forever. (Added July 2021)

name: The Thatched Inn
description:
City: Chambercombe
description: This pub name can be taken literally! Beautiful inside, tastefully and carefully restored and maintained while still allowing the historic character to shine through. Interesting layout, wood fittings, carpets, warm glow, intimate space. (Added July 2021)

name: The Castle Inn
description:
City: Lydford
description: A very good example of an unspoilt country inn with the bar and dining areas nicely personalised with rugs and hung artwork, off-centre beams and low ceilings. Rustic, personal, looks very good and well reviewed (Added July 2021)

name: Eliot Arms Square and Compass
description:
City: Tregadillet
description: If only these pubs didn't need food service to make a living! Despite that, the blackened interior with brasses fixed to the bar area is impressive, and wall space is filled up with framed artwork, clocks and niknaks. Very evocative looking venue. (Added July 2021)

name: Napoleon Inn
description:
City: Boscastle
description: A historic feel to the place with blackened beams and preserved bar area with some interesting siderooms. Looks reasonably atmospheric and rustic, genteel in places. Very well reviewed. (Added July 2021)

name: Black Horse Inn
description:
City: Cranham
description: Rustic 1600s village pub with log fires, real ale, cider and a genteel mid-brown look to the small rooms. The poor reviews of 2017ish seem to have died away and better reviews lately. Worth a look, we think (Added July 2021)

name: The Lamb Inn
description:
City: Devizes
description: The typical 'olde worlde' reviews stem from preserved interior listed on CAMRA's national inventory. No food, a drinks-focused town pub with a degree of character to it and die-hard local fans. Looks interesting. (Added July 2021)

name: The Plough in Prestbury
description:
City: Prestbury
description: Some truly classic country inn features in this 1700s thatched cottage with large stone fireplace, blackened beams and pewter tankards hung above the bar, simple genteel furnishings. Well reviewed, worth trying. (Added July 2021)

name: The Locomotive
description:
City: Wellingborough
description: Simple backstreet boozer with benches opposite a fine bar with interesting fittings and classic tankards hung above. Plenty of ales and local life to be found. Near the train tracks, hence the name. Very well reviewed. (Added July 2021)

name: The Old Cherry Tree
description:
City: Great Houghton
description: Looks to be a strong example of a well preserved and as yet unspoilt village pub with personal homely touches, fireplace, rustic furniture, blackened beams and on CAMRA's national inventory of interiors. Well reviewed. (Added July 2021)

name: Savile Arms
description:
City: Eakring
description: Rare example of a drinks focused village pub still operating, though that has much to do with the Sam Smiths ownership. Inside is a familiar super stripped back historic pub. WARNING: Sam Smith's pub, so love-or-hate it. Quite well reviewed for a pub under this ownership. (Added July 2021)

name: The Coach & Horses Inn
description:
City: Tilney St Lawrence
description: Reasonable-looking unspoilt pub out on its own. Decent reviews.  (Added July 2021)

name: The Star Inn
description:
City: Harbottle
description: Stone Inn that has diversified to stay alive, acting as a newsagents and post-office as well as a pub. Slight doubts whether it has had its historic core ruined by GREY PAINT but inconclusive, and the fantastic reviews tip the balance. (Added July 2021)

name: The Grey Bull Inn
description:
City: Wark
description: Not to be confused with the differently shaded Bull directly next door, this is a drinking den and not a foodie pub, that has wood panels and a well-preserved core of some character. Well reviewed for local life and atmosphere, though not going to be everybody's cup of tea. (Added July 2021)

name: The Star Inn
description:
City: Netherton
description: WARNING: Very restricted opening hours. You will need to enquire locally regarding when to visit.

A classic near-extinct throwback pub in a timewarp. Building also serves as a post-office and shop like so many dying rural communities. (Added July 2021)

name: Railway Tavern
description:
City: Jedburgh
description: A potential love or hate pub, this has kept its 60s era fittings and ensemble well. Basic local's boozer focused on drinks. Very popular with locals, only come if you have the nerves and are up for an experience. (Added July 2021)

name: Ancrum Cross Keys
description:
City: Ancrum
description: Despite some pretentions to foodiness, the central appeal comes from its classic intact tavern fittings with fireplace, wrought iron-legged tables, mirror panels and local life. well reviewed. (Added July 2021)

name: Victoria Hotel
description:
City: Great Harwood
description: Looks a neat little boozer with Victorian/Edwardian tiles and wood fixtures, simple upholstered bench seating, live music, some personal touches, a bit of character. (Added July 2021)

name: The Heaton Tap
description:
City: Newcastle
description: Small but attractive little craft beer bar with wooden tables and a row of fridges, along with some tap options. (Added July 2021)

name: Waggon and Horses
description:
City: South Reston
description: Well maintained 'brewer's tudor' style pub with wood panels, exposed beams and carpets, with some stained glass. Old features such as a 'smoke room' . In CAMRA's national inventory of interiors. Looks a decent roadside inn. (Added July 2021)

name: Coach & Horses Hotel
description:
City: Greasby
description: A village boozer attractive in its simplicity. Popular with musicians. Well preserved interior with settles and exposed beams. Very positively reviewed. On CAMRA's national inventory of interiors. (Added July 2021)

name: The Fox & Hounds
description:
City: Barnston
description: Homely, genteel and slightly twee decor. A series of characterful rooms including a smoke room. On CAMRA's inventory of interiors. Looks pretty good though some of it has been taken up with food, inevitably. Good reviews. (Added July 2021)

name: The Wheatsheaf Inn
description:
City: Raby
description: Converted cattleshed/barn with timber beams and thatched roof. While there is a large and not particularly characterful atrium area for dining, they appear to have preserved the bar area and snug rooms nicely. On CAMRA's national inventory of interiors. Well reviewed. (Added July 2021)

name: The Fox & Hounds
description:
City: Dalehouse
description: An almost caricature village pub set in a dell by the riverside, with the rustic and genteel surroundings you'd expect. Instant comfort and cosiness, some local life. Looks to be a little gem. Visit before these disappear for good. (Added July 2021)

name: The Lamplighter
description:
City: St Helier
description: Charming old city pub with attractive red frontage with greenery, and hops fixed above the bar inside, tankards fixed to the beams. Not messed around with, clearly to the delight of locals who give this good reviews. On CAMRA's national inventory of interiors. (Added July 2021)

name: Ye Olde Cider Bar
description:
City: Newton Abbot
description: Rustic charm, real cider 'from the wood', traditional historic fittings. Sheer simplicity in its construction. Occasional live music and simple snacks + sandwiches offered. Very well loved and one of the few true original cider houses left. On CAMRA's national inventory of interiors. (Added July 2021)

name: Teign Cellars
description:
City: Newton Abbot
description: Very nice looking ale house with some homely touches and strong selection of beers. Pool table, basic meals, occasional live music. Well reviewed. (Added July 2021)

name: British Lion
description:
City: Devizes
description: A well kept town pub that's a good example of keeping with the times while preserving its history. Low beams, some personal touches to the decor, and decent looking spots to sit in. On CAMRA's national inventory of interiors. Well reviewed. (Added July 2021)

name: The Weavers Bar
description:
City: Strathaven
description: By Scottish standards a reasonably well preserved town pub with attractive bar area, low beams etc. Clearly a community hub and most likely atmospheric for it. Very well reviewed. (Added July 2021)

name: The Berry
description:
City: Walmer
description: Unmistakably brightly painted exterior. Real ale heaven inside. Hops pinned above the bar, fireplace, overall genteel alehouse that receives rave reviews. On CAMRA's national inventory of interiors. (Added July 2021)

name: The Final Whistle
description:
City: Southwell
description: A terrific 'station pub' , albeit the trains have long gone and the route turned into a nature trail. The building is magnificent with some of the original station features intact. Inside it is spacious yet still somehow intimate with exposed brickwork, wood fittings, tiled corridors and some side rooms. On CAMRA's national inventory of interiors and wins local awards for real ale offerings. Well reviewed. (Added July 2021)

name: Hostinec Hlučál
description:
City: Pusta Rybna
description: The epitome of a throwback country pub that has decided to stick in the 1970s. In Czechia that means oddly twee decor, sparse surroundings, great beer and a folk community of people. Could be good. Well reviewed, at least. (Added July 2021)

name: The Black Lion
description:
City: High Roding
description: A timberframe pub that has tried to both modernise with signage and food options while remaining a personalised boozer. Never the most easy mix, but it looks to have been executed well. The reviews seem to agree. On CAMRA's national inventory of interiors. We shall see... (Added July 2021)

name: The Cross Keys
description:
City: Harpenden
description: Unspoilt pub with a bit of a local town atmosphere. Fireplace, aged bench seats, stripped back and rustic by modern standards. On CAMRA's national inventory of interiors. We shall see. (Added July 2021)

name: The Farriers Arms
description:
City: St Albans
description: Lovely genteel alehouse with attractive midbrown wood. The panels both on the floor, bench and sealings give a slightly cabin like feel, with the lamp lights. The more negative reviews appear to be from quite some time ago. On CAMRA's national inventory of interiors. (Added July 2021)

name: The Miners Standard
description:
City: Winster
description: 17th century stone pub. Large fireplace, exposed beams and gnarled edges. Dartboard, pool table, low ceiling. On CAMRA's national inventory of interiors. Decent reviews. Worth a look. (Added July 2021)

name: The Redoubt
description:
City: Wakefield
description: Very old fashioned pub which will probably be a love or hate it affair. Several individual rooms (4 snugs) so a fair chance of escaping from any idiots. Mixed reviews so will need to suck it and see. On CAMRA's national inventory of interiors. (Added July 2021)

name: The White Horse Inn
description:
City: Friendly
description: Attractive and unspoilt homely interior with distinctive layout. On CAMRA's national inventory. Must be worth a look. (Added July 2021)

name: Duke of Wellington
description:
City: Heywood
description: While the main bar area is not unattractive, the main event is the baronial lounge room opposite with carved wood interior, fitted curved bench seats, fireplace, lamp lights and stained glass that looks magnificent. On CAMRA's national inventory of interiors. (Added July 2021)

name: Rodinny Pivovar 713
description:
City: Hradec Kralove
description: A dinky but cosy little taproom for this local family brewery. Looks decent. (July 2021)

name: The Brushmakers Arms
description:
City: Oulton
description: Promising stripped back ale house that's been freehold owned for 35+ years by the same landlord. Distinctive lived-in decor, and all about drinks not meals. Relatively homely decor and furniture, all about local life and conversation. Sounds promising.

name: Sir Robert Peel
description:
City: Tamworth
description: Well reputed alehouse with intimate surroundings and stripped back wood panel format. Characterful bar area.

name: Bodega Montferry
description:
City: Barcelona
description: Well reviewed traditional bar, still relatively close to the city centre and not yet extinguished. Some character behind the bar, with barrels, ceiling fans and the classic aluminium counter.

name: Cusack's
description:
City: Dublin
description: A decent looking all rounder with wood panelled ceiling, some stained glass, walls covered with artwork and crests.

name: The Doric
description:
City: Edinburgh
description: Wood panelled bar with bistro upstairs, pub downstairs, Looks to still have character. Real ale and whiskies available.

name: The Dog House
description:
City: Edinburgh
description: A quirky and funky cluttered setting with offbeat decor and highly personalised.

name: The Who'd Ha' Thought It
description:
City: Rochester
description: Excellent looking corner neighbourhood pub with original signage outside and preserved interior on CAMRA's national inventory. Reviews tell of a friendly old-school pub with good range of ales.

name: The All Nations Inn
description:
City: Madeley
description: Long-standing home-brewer pub with rustic feel inside and out. Farmhouse type interior with old tiled floor, beams and simple seating. Fireplace warming genteel welcoming and social surroundings. Excellent reviews and it looks lovely.

name: Royds arms
description:
City: Spotland
description: Traditional riverside boozer on CAMRA's national inventory of interiors. Information thin on the ground but seems promising.

name: Flower Of The Valley
description:
City: Buckley
description: Stripped back traditional pub that is on CAMRA's national inventory of interiors but information is thin on the ground. Believed to be a Sam Smith's pub so that comes with a clear WARNING that it will not be everyone's cup of tea.

name: Half Moon Inn Belchamp
description:
City: Belchamp St Paul
description: A classic English pub of yore, an idyllic, beautiful thatched cottage leads into an ancient rustic inn with timber frames and beams, cosy corners, carpet, fireplace. The sort of venue that has been turned into bland dining rooms across England, but still here appears to serve drinkers too.

name: The Rifle Volunteers
description:
City: Maidstone
description: Excellently well reviewed town tavern with cask ales on rotation, dart board, music nights and a great sense of community about it. Looks very nice.

name: La Cebada
description:
City: Zaragoza
description: Lovely looking pub with rustic wooden seating, homely and personalised with Belgian beer.

name: The Griffin Inn
description:
City: Shustoke
description: Excellent looking country inn with large outdoor area and rural views. Inside, blackened beams and traditional pub ephemera hold sway. Stone bar and fireplace. Tiled floor. Cushioned bench seats. Looks good and very well reviewed.

name: Crown Inn
description:
City: Oakengates
description: Splendid-looking community pub with enhanced outdoor area, space for live music and comedy nights. Rotating range of real ales and decent European bottles in the fridge. Decor simple and homely inside. Very well reviewed.

name: King Edward VII
description:
City: Guide
description: A 'locals' pub that is friendly and community led. Standout features are the Edwardian pub layout with separate rooms, tiles. Dartboard and fireplace, all a bit of a throwback, seemingly in a good way.

name: The Glen View Inn
description:
City: Cornholme
description: Seems to be an unpretentious classic Lancashire village pub with cosy homely interior, pub grub, friendly welcome. Outstanding reviews.

name: Crooked Billet Worsthorne
description:
City: Worsthorne
description: Looks to be a dynamic community pub with attractive hatched windows and stone frontage, homely interior with beams and nice bar area. Lots of events. Very well reviewed.

name: The Cannon
description:
City: Brompton
description: Excellent looking neighbourhood pub that seems very homely with attractive beer garden and intimate interior. Frontage has green faienced brick and Truman brewery signage. Looks to be at the heart of the community and drinks focused.

name: Carpenters Arms
description:
City: Eastling
description: Excellent looking village pub with low beams and greenery. Some food focus inevitably, but some community interaction and live events too. Genteel brick exterior with attractive signage.

name: The Three Chimneys
description:
City: Biddenden
description: 15th century pub with sympathetic wooden refurb inside, lamp lights and real fire. Harvey's beers, Inevitably much is taken up with dining, sadly, but explore the pub to find lovely off-centre door frames and nice crackled bits of history. Worth a look. (Added August 2021)

name: The King's Head
description:
City: Leicester
description: Attractive black beamed narrow pub with comfortable seating and local life. Perhaps a little bit lacking in distinctive character to stand out but an enjoyable and reliable option. Some nice snack food available for pennies such as samosas and bhajis. Black Country ales.

name: The Two-Tailed Lion
description:
City: Leicester
description: An attractive little pub with hanging baskets outfront and characterful branding, however on our visit it felt a bit plain and lacking character in the absence of customers. With some more attention paid to the decor we may find ourselves won over. Check out the upstairs room as well.

name: The Rose & Crown Inn (Eli’s)
